titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Jun. 11, Cold Water [to] R.H. McEwen, Nashville, Tennessee / W.B. Robinson

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 11, 1838 from W.B. Robinson to Colonel R. H. McEwen in Nashville, Tennessee. It is a brief letter relating to cotton cultivation and market conditions.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1808 Jan. 1, Pittsburgh, [Pennsylvania] [to] King, et al. / John Sumerall

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by John Sumerall to King, Canon, & King on January 1, 1808. In the letter, Sumerall informs the merchants of the conversation that took place between himself and a Mr. Hunt in Lexington, Kentucky pertaining to the service of cotton baling that Hunt was going to perform for the men. Sumerall states that he gave his oath to Hunt that the men are good for the money that is required to pay for the cotton baling.

titleInfo.title: Notice [of the arrival] of appraising agents for settling claims [of the Cherokees]

mods.abstract: This document is an undated notice of the arrival of agents appointed to settle the claims of the Cherokee Indians under the New Echota Treaty (1835). The notice indicates that Cherokee claims will be received and filed according to the terms of the treaty. It is unclear precisely who wrote this notice or to whom it is directed.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Dec. 13, Washington [to] Mrs. Hugh Lawson White / Hugh Lawson White

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written in 1835 by Hugh Lawson White to his wife. White writes about social events and political goings on in Washington.

titleInfo.title: Thrilling narrative: How the judgement of Heaven fell on the Indians who wounded Rev'd Joseph Brown in 1794, / Rev[erend] Joseph Brown

mods.abstract: This document, entitled "Thrilling Narrative. How The Judgement of Heaven fell on the Indians who wounded Rev'd Joseph Brown in 1794," was written to Colonel A. W. Putman on March 30, 1858 by Reverend Joseph Brown. In this narrative Brown details the events surrounding his return trip from Knoxville to Nashville. It appears that he was informed by a Cherokee trader that there was a large body of Indians waiting to do harm on the direct route, so he was advised to return through Kentucky. Accepting this advice, Brown and travel partners, William Hayes, a Negro woman, Ross, Friley, and others set out only to be ambushed along the way by Indians. During the attack Brown was wounded in the shoulder although they escaped. He stayed with a Dutch man for two nights and then with a brother-in-law, who was a doctor, of Ross's for six weeks, until he healed well enough to travel home. Later, Brown was informed by another trader that the same party of Indians had rode into East Tennessee to take prisoners of women and children and if Brown and others wanted to free the prisoners he would show them where they were. Brown set out with a group of white men to seek revenge on the Indians. When they located them they noticed that the Indians were wearing white men's clothing and, satisfied that these were the guilty Indians, they decided to lay in wait to ambush them in the morning fearing that the prisoners would be killed if they acted too quickly. The Indians were all killed the next day and the white men found a little girl who had hid for three days. Brown submitted this account with the intent that it would be published or returned. It was, in fact, published in the "Banner of Peace" August 5, 1858.

titleInfo.title: [Order for Payment] 1812 Dec. 31, Knoxville, [Tennessee] [to] Thomas Claibourn, L. P. Montgomery / E. W. Hudnall

mods.abstract: This document is an order for payment dated December 31, 1812. The order requires Thomas Claibourn and L. P. Montgomery to pay Robert King $310.58 when he receives these funds from Joshua Ballance and John Summerville (a.k.a John S. Williamson). The order is signed by E. W. Hudnall.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Nov. 4, Clover Dale, [TN] [to] Mr Samuel Bell, Cornplanter, Venango County, PA / William B. Bell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 4, 1838, from William B. Bell in Dickson County, TN to his brother Samuel Bell in Cornplanter, PA. In the letter, William primarily discusses business matters related to iron works and farming. He explains that the dry weather has left the iron furnaces in Dickson County non-operational. He also comments on the increasing price of corn, which is expected to be between 75 cents and a dollar per bushel in the spring. William also expounds on other farming matters.

titleInfo.title: 1844 Dec. 26 Carthage [TN] [to] A[dam] Fergusson / G. G. Brookshier

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Adam Fergusson from G. G. Brookshier, dated December 26, 1844. Brookshier writes that he missed seeing Fergusson at his home. He is leaving soon for Alabama and wants to be paid for some work he has done.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1830 Nov. 14 [to] Col[onel] Joseph Brown, Maury County, Tennessee / James Brown

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to Col. Joseph Brown in Maury County, TN from his son James Brown, dated November 14, 1830. In the letter, James discusses his previous plans to go into business with his brother Joseph and another man by the name of Estes as well as the house and plot of land that he has recently purchased.

titleInfo.title: [Marriage bond] 1792 Nov. 2, Washington County, between William Perogh and Elizabeth Denton

mods.abstract: This document is a marriage bond written on November 2, 1792 in regards to marriage of William Perogh and Elizabeth Denton. The bond stipulated an amount of 600 pounds to be void on the condition that there was no lawful objection to the marriage. The bond was signed by John Sevier, and witnessed by Isaac Denton and George Nolen.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1831 Sep. 19, Nashville, Tennessee [to] W[illia]m Carroll / T.A. Durmest

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Governor William Carroll dated September 19, 1831. It is from T.A. Durmest, an engineer. He is reporting on the natural obstructions in the Tennessee River. He also makes recommendations for overcoming them in order to improve travel on the river. He gives a list of the estimated costs of improvements.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Dec. 24, Mouth of Sweet Water [to] Charles Welcker, Laurel Banks, Roane Co[unty, Tennessee] / A[lbert] S. L[enoir]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 24, 1839, from Albert S. Lenoir to his brother-in-law Charles F. Welcker in Roane County, Tennessee. Lenoir writes to inform Welcker that his sister, Lenoir's wife, Catherine had just given birth to a baby boy. Both mother and child were in fine health. He also briefly mentions that he hopes the Georgia railroad will extend to Chattanooga.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 Nov. 6, Nashville, Tennessee [to] J. Bridgeman, S. Ranken, and F. Fergues / James Jones

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated November 6, 1841 from Tennessee governor James Jones to Bridgeman, Ranken, and Fergues. The subject of the letter is Colonel Scott Terry, who was recently elected Superintendent of Public Instruction.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Dec. 12, Hanover College [Indiana] [to] Parents [Mr. and Mrs. Ethel Henry Porter] / Edward [Porter]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Edward Porter to his parents on December 12, 1849. In the letter, Edward discusses the events taking place with his sister, Mary, at her school. He writes to their parents how unhappy she is there, and that she has not written home because she does not like her teacher, Mr. Anderson, to read her letters before she sends them. Edward tells them that the teacher will not send her letters if she writes something disagreeable to him, and has threatened her with expulsion if she does not act better and do as he wishes. Edward concludes the letter by describing what he has been doing at Hanover College and about the social events at the school and in Hanover.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1808 Apr. 10, Greenville, So[uth] Carolina [to] Return J. Meigs, Highwassee / Col[onel] Elias Earle

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 10, 1806 from Colonel Elias Earle to Return J. Meigs, agent for Indian affairs. Earle informs Meigs that an unnamed treaty recently signed with the Cherokees has not been ratified and speculates that the failure is attributable to an inaccurate map of the United States. Earle mentions a memorial sent by [James] Vann and [Charles] Hicks. He also discusses the storage of corn at Highwassee as opposed to Chickama[u]ga Creek, both inside the Cherokee Nation. Earle was a congressman from Greenville, South Carolina.

titleInfo.title: 1834 Aug 6, East Tennessee [to] Sam[ue]l G. Smith, Nashville, Tennessee / William Carroll

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor William Carroll, to Secretary of State Samuel G. Smith, dated August 6, 1834. Carroll writes that R.K.Chism will deliver the constitutions to counties in East Tennessee for the amount of one hundred and sixty dollars.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Oct. 26, Tallahassee, [Florida to] Andrew J[ackson] Donelson, Washington City, D.C. / Gen[era]l D[aniel] S. Donelson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 26, 1835, to Andrew Jackson Donelson in Washington, D.C. from his brother Daniel S. Donelson in Tallahassee, Florida. Daniel writes urgently to report that he was accosted about a political scandal involving Andrew and two men by the names of Bell and Barrow. Daniel fears that his brother's image is being tarnished in order to reflect negatively on the President, their uncle Andrew Jackson.

titleInfo.title: [Drawing of Fort Loudoun, British military post from 1756-1760, lower Little Tennessee River] / [by Doug Henry]

mods.abstract: This is a drawing of Fort Loudoun, a British colonial military post on the lower Little Tennessee River that was occupied from 1756-1760. It was built in Overhill Cherokee territory in what is presently Monroe County and named for John Campbell, the Earl of Loudoun, who was commander-in-chief of British forces in the colonies. William G. De Brahm designed the fort, but abandoned the project because of disagreements he had with Capt. Demerre who commanded the militia troops and British regulars stationed at the post. Survival of this frontier outpost was dependent upon good relations with the Cherokees who supplied food for trade goods. During the French and Indian War, tensions began to mount between the Cherokees and the colonists. In March 1760 the Cherokees laid siege to the fort, cutting off supplies and forcing its surrender. Excavations of Fort Loudoun were conducted by the University of Tennessee from 1975-1977 in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator and Field Director, Carl Kutruff.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of a pit feature excavation at Fort Southwest Point in Kingston, Tennessee, taken circa 1980s] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This photograph is of a pit feature being excavated at Fort Southwest Point, located near the city of Kingston, in Roane County, Tennessee. Fort Southwest Point was established in 1792 as a blockhouse post for the territorial militia troops that were protecting white settlers from Indian acts of hostility. By 1797, the militia was replaced by Federal troops whose goals were to maintain peace with the Indians and protect their rights on the frontier. During the years between 1801-1807, the fort was established as the headquarters for the Cherokee Agency. In 1974, archaeological crews from the University of Tennessee unearthed portions of six fort building foundations, the remains of a massive stone wall, and many fort-period artifacts. A 1984 excavation of the site by the Department of Conservation and the City of Kingston located the sites of a total of thirteen buildings. These buildings include an officer's barracks, four blockhouses, and several buildings that are believed to have been barracks. A complementary excavation in 1986 revealed the location of two more buildings, bringing the total to fifteen buildings. The excavation also produced a more detailed examination of the palisade and stone wall enclosures, and uncovered several historic and prehistoric features. Additional excavations were conducted at Fort Southwest Point in the 1990s yielded new information as to the fort's original layout and functions, as well as the life ways of the people who occupied the fort. Fort Southwest Point was given to the city of Kingston by the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) and is now used as a historical and recreational area.

titleInfo.title: 1838 Oct. 14, St. Louis, Missouri [to] Newton Cannon, Nashville, Tennessee / Edmund Pendleton Gaines

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Newton Cannon, Governor of Tennessee, from General Edmund Pendleton Gaines, dated October 14, 1838. Gaines writes extensively about his proposal to build a series of canals, turnpike roads, and railroads from the interior to the frontier. He sites evidence from the War of 1812 (which he refers to as the War of 1814) and European wars as to why these avenues are necessary. He offers several complaints against the existence of political parties and their detrimental effects to the United States. He writes about the importance of steam powered engines. Gaines is very concerned with protecting the borders from European and Native American nations combining their forces against the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Aug. 20, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Edmond Gaines / Newton Cannon

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated August 20, 1838 from governor Newton Cannon of Tennessee to General Edmond Gaines. The purpose of the letter is to inform the General that there is a plentiful number of mounted volunteer soldiers ready and willing to be called upon for service.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1834 Aug. 2, Columbus, McMinn C[oun[ty], E[ast] Tenn[esseee] [to] Charles F. Welcker, Talladega Court house, Ala[bama] / Fred[erick] A. Welcker

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated August 2, 1834, written to Charles F. Welcker by his brother Frederick A. Welcker in McMinn County, TN. In the letter, Frederick writes of his departure from home in April and his journeys since across East Tennessee in search of employment.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1808 Feb. 26 Bond for court appearance of Stephen Porter

mods.abstract: This document is dated February 26, 1808, it is a legal bond for the appearance of Stephen Porter at the Washington County Superior court house in Jonesborough , Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1804 June 25, War Department [to] Colonel Return J. Meigs, South West Point, Tennessee / Henry Dearborn

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Henry Dearborn, Secretary of War, to Return J. Meigs, Agent to the War Department. Dearborn instructs Meigs to provide a horse and safe passage to Missouri for a Captain Randal.
This is a letter dated June 15, 1838 from Henry King to his uncle H.D. Jameson. In the letter King writes to his mother, and expresses his well-being as part of his battalion.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1812 Apr. 26 [to] Thomas McNeal, Duck River / David Hutcheson

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated April 26, 1812, from David Hutcheson to Thomas McNeal in Duck River. Hutcheson writes of business matters and debts that are due to him.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Oct. 31 [to] Mrs. William R. Caswell / William R. Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 31, 1846 from Captain William R. Caswell to his wife in Jefferson County, Tennessee. Captain Caswell served in the Mexican-American War and was part of the Tennessee "Volunteers." Caswell wrote numerous letters to his wife while on duty in, and around Mexico.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1848 Jul. 17, Independence, Texas [to] Louiza G. Flemming, Mount Pleasant, Murry County, Tennessee / N.A. Gee

mods.abstract: This is a letter from N.A. Gee to his sister Louiza, dated July 17, 1848. He writes about several deaths in his family and his remarriage. Most of the letter regards the division of their family estate, including that of two female slaves.

This is a letter from Alex Alexander to General James Winchester, dated November 6, 1806. Alexander owes money to Winchester. He explains that he is working for General Andrew Jackson, but still does not have the money. Alexander asks if Winchester would be willing to take property instead.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1838 Mar. 27, Jane & Willie Blair vs. The Pathkiller & Gardenhire

mods.abstract: This is a legal document, dated March 27, 1838, against The Pathkiller, a Cherokee Indian who lost his land during the removal of the Cherokees west of the Mississippi River. The Pathkiller wants to re-claim his land which was sold to Jane and Willie Blair.

titleInfo.title: [Legal petition] [to] Tennessee State Legislature / Citizens of Bedford County, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a legal petition signed by the citizens of Bedford County, Tennessee. The petition asks for a clause to be entered into the state Constitution that will emancipate all of the slaves held in Tennessee by the year 1866. Both slaveholding and non-slaveholding citizens signed the petition.

titleInfo.title: Memorial to the Honorable Convention of the State of Tennessee
[Letter] 1828 Jun. 1 [to] Sam Houston, Nashville, Tennessee / L.T. Greenfield

mods.abstract: This document is a brief letter dated June 1, 1828, from L.T. Greenfield to the governor of Tennessee, Sam Houston. The subject of the letter is a slave, owned by Greenfield, who had recently been convicted of breaking into a store near Williamsburg, Virginia, and sentenced to be hung. Greenfield believes that much of the testimony against his slave in the trial was coerced, and asks Houston if he may send his slave out of state.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1796 Nov. 8, Tellico Blockhouse [Tennessee, to John] Sevier / Silas Dinsmoor

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Governor John Sevier from Silas Dinsmoor dated November 8, 1796. Dinsmoor is the agent to the Cherokee Nation. Dinsmoor is writing regarding a recent act of Congress pertaining to relations with the Cherokees. Dinsmoor includes a list of whites he knows who have settled on the Cherokee's land.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Mar. 10, Hartsville, Ten[nessee] [to] Adam Fergusson, Carthage, Ten[nessee] / Ja[me]s S. Dyer

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 10, 1845, from James S. Dyer to Adam Fergusson in Carthage, TN. Dyer writes about political matters, particularly upcoming congressional elections and the strategy of the democratic party. He offers some advice as to how campaigning should be done in Smith County, where Fergusson resides.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Apr. 29, Greenville, Tennessee [to] Sam Houston, Nashville, Tennessee / T.A. Howard

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 29, 1829 from T.A. Howard in Greenville, Tennessee to his dear friend, Sam Houston in Nashville. It is a letter of condolence over the news of Houston's resignation of the Governor's office. He resigned as a result of a failed and scandalous marriage, that fell apart soon after the wedding. In the letter, Howard offers his friend words of optimism and hope for his future.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Jan. 20, Choctaw Agency [to] James Winchester / John McKee

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated January 20, 1815 from John McKee to General James Winchester. McKee reports on the business of recruitment service, specifically, that during the winter season most Choctaw gun-owners are currently engaged in hunting food for their families, and therefore, that his quarter should not be relied upon until their return. He also mentions the recent victory of General Andrew Jackson at the Battle of New Orleans against the British, and as a result, the Choctaw Indians will probably not be needed there.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Feb.16, Westwood, [TN] [to] Joseph Woods, Columbia, Tennessee / Julia [Woods?]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Joseph Woods in Columbia, TN from his sister Julia, dated Feb. 16, 1845. She reports the sinking of a steamboat named Pathfinder, a neighbor girl nearly burning to death, and other happenings in her town of Westwood. She also mentions some friends who will be accompanying the President to inauguration.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of Fort Loudoun, British colonial military post from 1756-1760, lower Little Tennessee River] / [by Jefferson Chapman]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of Fort Loudoun, a British colonial military post on the lower Little Tennessee River that was occupied from 1756-1760. It was built in Overhill Cherokee territory in what is presently Monroe County and named for John Campbell, the Earl of Loudoun, who was commander-in-chief of British forces in the colonies. William G. De Brahm designed the fort, but abandoned the project because of disagreements he had with Capt. Demerre who commanded the militia troops and British regulars stationed at the post. Survival of this frontier outpost was dependent upon good relations with the Cherokees who supplied food for trade goods. During the French and Indian War, tensions began to mount between the Cherokees and the colonists. In March 1760 the Cherokees laid siege to the fort, cutting off supplies and forcing its surrender. Excavations of Fort Loudoun were conducted by the University of Tennessee from 1975-1977 in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator and Field Director, Carl Kutruff.

titleInfo.title: 1796 Apr. 25, Tellico Blockhouse [Tennessee, to] David Henley, Knoxville [Tennessee] / John McKee

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John McKee to David Henley, dated April 25, 1796. McKee, who is in charge of Indian relations, is concerned that the government will stop giving out whiskey and other amenities to the Chiefs that come to visit. He believes that they will suspect other policies towards them will change also, and become unfriendly.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Nov. 13, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Col[onel] R[obert] J Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Mary Jane Chester to her father, Robert J. Chester, on November 13, 1842. In the letter Mary Jane tells Robert of events going on in Columbia, Tennessee, where she is attending school at the Female Institute, and inquires about events happening at home in Jackson. She tells him how upset she is that he did not visit her when he promised, and she also speaks of their cousin's new baby, visiting with Governor Polk, and the death of her mother. Mary Jane concludes the letter by asking him to bring her a black muslin when he comes to visit her.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Jul. 22 [to] Benjamin McCulloch / William R. Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 22, 1846 from Captain William Caswell to his father, Benjamin McCulloch of Murfreesboro Tennessee. Caswell wrote from aboard the Steamship Champion on his wait to fight as one of the Tennessee volunteers in the Mexican-American War.

titleInfo.title: [Petition] [to] William Hall on behalf of John Tompkins

mods.abstract: This is a petition to Tennessee Governor William Hall for the release of John Tompkins from prison. Tompkins was imprisoned for dealing Faro, an illegal card game, at his home.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Dec. 8, Warrenton, Virginia [to] D. Burford, Dixons Springs, Tennessee / J. Saunders

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 8, 1832 from J. Saunders in Warrenton, Virginia to D. Burford in Dixons Springs, Tennessee. The subject of the letter is slave trade and transportation to the Mississippi area. In the letter, Saunders mentions that pestilence has had a major impact on the south and will be a factor in choosing a trade route.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Jul. 9, Knoxville [to] Major John Childs / R. B. Purdom

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by R. B. Purdom in 1819, to Major John Childs regarding documents needing signed for one Robert Davis to receive his pay.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Feb. 10, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] The Warriors and Chiefs of the Cherokee Nation / John Sevier, Governor of the state of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 10, 1797, addressed to the warriors and chiefs of the Cherokee Nation by Governor John Sevier of Tennessee (1796-1801). Sevier sent his apologies for the recent violence that had been committed against several of the Cherokees. He also criticized the chiefs for not making any complaints about these actions, for it impeded the process of apprehending the perpetrators. Sevier stated that although the murders of two Cherokees were committed in Kentucky, the murderers were from Tennessee. Sevier, however, changed his tone when he began to speak of crimes committed against White people by Cherokees. He warned them that if such actions did not cease, it would bring about a war, which would have disastrous consequences for the Cherokee Nation.

titleInfo.title: [Computer generated map of an excavation unit at the Chattooga site, created in 1993] / [by Eric Howard and Brett Riggs] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is a computer generated map of an excavated unit at the Chattooga site. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. Through the use of surface collection, test pit excavations, and remote sensing equipment, vast amounts of artifacts and the location of additional buildings and features were found with minimal disturbance to the site. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.

titleInfo.title: [Legislative Bill] 1826 Nov. 22, to ascertain at what age a man becomes a bachelor / Tennessee General Assembly

mods.abstract: This document is a Bill proposed by the Tennessee General Assembly on November 22, 1826 to determine what age a man should be considered a bachelor. The proposed age was thirty years old and at that time if the "bachelor" was unmarried he would have to pay a twenty-five percent tax on his total worth. This tax was to be divided annually between all unmarried woman over twenty-five. The Bill passed the House of Representatives but was set aside by the Senate for thirty years.
This document dated March 1, 1847, is an indenture between Thomas K. Porter et. al. for a woman named Charlott to serve as an apprentice for seven years.

titleInfo.title: 1845 Jun. 23, Gallatin, Tennessee [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / Abram Bradley

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Abram Bradley to A. Fergusson, dated June 23, 1845. He is reminding Fergusson that he promised to send some business to the War Department for Mrs. Dorris. Bradley writes that it is important for Fergusson to take care of it as soon as possible, as Mrs. Dorris is very old and sick.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Nov. 16, Bellemont [to] Mr. H [owell] A. Taylor / A.W. Littlejohn

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by A.W. Littlejohn to Howell A. Taylor, dated November 16, 1846. In the letter, Littlejohn asks for Taylor's certificate testifying to allegations made by a man named J.J. Alison. Alison had made bad remarks about Littlejohn's character.

titleInfo.title: Taylor Family of Fayette Co. TN Letters MS 384 (corr. 1836-1847)
[Letter] 1839 Dec. 24, Chattanooga [to] Mr. C[harles] F. Welcker, Kingston, Tennessee / R. A. Ramsey

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 24, 1839, from R. A. Ramsey in Chattanooga, Tennessee to Charles F. Welcker in Kingston, Tennessee. Ramsey is responding to an enquiry from Welcker and states that he intends to retain his current blacksmith at a price of 350 dollars.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] ca. 1804 [to] Gen [era] l Andrew Jackson / G. W. Campbell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to General Andrew Jackson from G. W. Campbell dated circa 1804. In the letter, Campbell lists the names of the people that are the managers of the impeachment of governor Claiborne.

This is a letter dated April 30, 1850, from George House to his wife Mary in Nashville. He hopes that she has had a safe trip to Clarksville. He asks her if she has her life preserver blown up in case she has to jump overboard. He mentions the local news, including one death. He also writes that he will be involved in a Temperance ceremony during the May Day festivities.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1813 Jan. 28, Fortville [to] Col[onel] Metcalf / Charles Hicks

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Charles Hicks, a Cherokee Indian, to a Colonel Metcalf. Charles Hicks complains that some of Colonel Metcalf's men killed a Cherokee man and whipped other Cherokee men. Hicks writes that the action violates the existing treaty between the Cherokee Nation and the United States. The letter appears to have been forwarded to Return J. Meigs, agent to the Cherokee Nation.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Oct. 16, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Col[onel] Robert J. Chester, Jackson, Tennessee/ M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated October 16, 1842, from Mary Jane Chester to her father Colonel Robert J. Chester in Jackson, TN. In the letter, Mary Jane writes about her social and academic affairs at the Female Institute in Columbia, TN.

titleInfo.title: 1837 Oct. 5, Washington [City, D. C.] [to] Adam Fergusson / W. B. Campbell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from W. B. Campbell to Adam Fergusson, dated October 5, 1837. Campbell writes about Mr. Fair, a man who was wrongly dropped from the pension rolls. He wants to have Congress pass a law in favor of the man. He also writes of the state of Mrs. Kezia McCarroll's claim, and of trying to get information on other people that Fergusson has written to him about. Campbell also bemoans a resolution proposed in the House to not fund a National Bank.

titleInfo.title: 1843 Jan. 25, Murfreesboro [TN] [to] Mr Blishe Williams, Nashville, Tenn[essee] / J. P. Williams

mods.abstract: This is a letter to George House in care of Blishe Williams, dated January 25, 1843. It is from J. P. Williams. Williams is requesting that House allow him to take some medicine that Williams had received in the past from Dr. Burk. Dr. Burk has left House as his agent. William writes that he will pay whatever House asks, if the pills cure him.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Nov. 30, Georgia [to] Newton Cannon, Tennessee / George M. Gilmer

mods.abstract: This is a letter from George Gilmer, Governor of Georgia to Governor Newton Cannon, dated November 30, 1837. The letter is about coordinating representatives between the respective state legislatures. The plan is to approve a law allowing the Western and Atlantic Rail Road to run across their joint border from Georgia to the Tennessee River.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 21 Feb. Knoxville [to] David Henl[e]y / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by John Sevier requesting forty dollars in payment for a house he built at Southwest Point. The letter was written to David Henley in 1797.

titleInfo.title: 1834 Oct. 7 [to] Andrew J. Donelson, Washington City / James S. Mayfield

mods.abstract: This is a letter from James S. Mayfield to Andrew J Donelson, dated October 7, 1834. Mayfield writes about Major Harney, who is awaiting trial in jail because he could not get bail. Mayfield writes that Harney's Washington responsibilities are being handled.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1839 Nov. 14, Knox County, Tennessee [to] State of Tennessee / Joseph C. Strong [et. al]

mods.abstract: This is a letter by Joseph C. Strong, President of the Hampden Sidney Academy and is co-signed by the Academy's Secretary, David A. Deaderick. This letter dated November 14, 1839 states that the Academy's Board of Trustees is relinquishing all claims it has against the State.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835, Jul. 22, Frederick[s]burg, [VA] [to] Dr. J. Beckwith, Florence, Ala[bama] / Andrew B. B[eckwith]

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Andrew B. Beckwith in Fredericksburg, VA to his brother Dr. J. Beckwith in Florence, AL, dated July 22, 1835. Andrew is updating his brother on the new of his friends and family, especially of the family's embarrassment caused by the behavior of their brother Butler.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1812 Jun. 30, Knoxville, [TN] [to] Major Gen[era]l John Cocke, Rutledge, Grainger County, [TN] / Willie Blount

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 30, 1812, from Tennessee Governor Willie Blount to John Cocke, in which Blount makes the momentous announcement that the US has declared war on Britain. Blount instructs Cocke to have his Division prepared for battle.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Feb. 10, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Silas Dinsmore / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Governor John Sevier (1796-1801) to Cherokee agent Silas Dinsmore, dated February 10, 1797. In his letter, Sevier sent apologies for several Cherokees who had been killed, wounded, or who were missing. While Sevier promised to do his best to seek out the perpetrators of such crimes, he also warned Dinsmore that the Cherokees should be restrained from retaliating. He stated that a war would bring about the destruction of the Cherokee Nation.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Jul. 21 [to] Mrs. William Caswell / William Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 21, 1846 from Captain William R. Caswell to his wife in Jefferson County, Tennessee. Captain Caswell writes that he is awaiting passage by steamship to New Orleans where he will then go to Mexico to serve in the Mexican-American War.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1823 Oct. 9

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. These are the the first two pages of the docket, spanning from October 9 to October 14, 1823. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Jun. 26, Nashville [Tennessee, to] W[illia]m Polk, Raleigh, North Carolina / Ephraim H[ubbar]d Foster

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Ephraim Foster to General William Polk, dated June 26, 1832. Foster writes that he is unable to give Polk much information yet about a financial affair. Foster will be able to write more to Polk when Mr. Woods returns, who is taking care of the business for them.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1820 Aug. 16 Knoxville, [to] J [ohn] C. Calhoun / Gideon Morgan

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to John C. Calhoun, former Secretary of War , from Gideon Morgan, dated August 16, 1820. In the letter, Morgan states that the land he purchased from the Cherokee agency was divided and sold to others while he was away in Knoxville conducting business. He states that the Cherokee Nation is indebted to him for $815.00, the money he paid for the land.
This is a claim directed towards Col. R.J. Meigs regarding a stolen horse.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1818 Jun. 11, Lexington, [KY] [to] Mrs. Sarah B. Woods, Nashville, [TN] / C C

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 11, 1818 to Mrs. Sarah B. Woods from her sister who only signed the letter CC. The letter from CC consists of numerous complaints about her health and finances.

This leather-bound book of Cherokee improvement valuations entitled Valuations under the Treaty of 1828 Emigrations 1833 and 1834 is 412 pages in length. It contains approximately 587 property valuations for 248 individuals who are listed in an alphabetical index at the end of the book. The evaluations were conducted from the fall of 1833 until the spring of 1834 in accordance with the Treaty of Washington, 1828, concluded between the United States and members of the Cherokee Nation. Under this treaty, the Cherokees were promised seven million acres of land in the Arkansas Territory and the U.S. government was to appoint suitable agents to evaluate all improvements that the Cherokees would relinquish. On September 1, 1831 Benjamin F. Currey was appointed superintendent of removal for the Cherokees, and he appointed agents to appraise the property of those Cherokees enrolled for removal. Most of the approximately 587 valuations consist of an enumeration and brief description of the property, an estimate of its worth, and a total owed to the former occupant of the estate.
This document is an affidavit given by James Robertson on April 16, 1784 regarding one Major John Reid's journey to treat with the Chickasaw Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1831 Dec. 28, Washington [to] John Ross, Cherokee Nation / John Martin [and] John Ridge

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John Martin and John Ridge, Cherokee leaders in Washington, to John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, dated December 28, 1831. Martin and Ridge report to Ross on the progress of the Cherokee delegation in Washington and their decision to delay the delivery of the Cherokee Memorial to Congress. They indicate that they have news of atrocities against the Cherokees in Georgia. They further inform Ross that Elias Boudinot and John Ridge have met with Henry Clay who has pledged his support. They lament the hypocrisy with which they are met in dealing with the U.S. government. In addition, Martin and Ridge make reference to a delegation of Creek leaders also in Washington and comment on William Wirt's involvement in the Supreme Court case Worcester v. Georgia.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Jan. 30, Sugar Hill [to] Peter Hardeman, Camp Jackson, New Orleans / Thomas. Hardeman

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated January 30, 1815 from Thomas Hardeman to his son Peter Hardeman near New Orleans. In the letter, Thomas expresses grief and regret that two of his sons had been captured as prisoners of war by the British in New Orleans; he is optimistic that they will return home safely.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1823 Oct. 15

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Wednesday October 15 and Thursday October 15, 1823 sessions of court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1803 Apr. 13, Knoxville, [Tennessee], [to] the citizens of Anderson County, [Tennessee] / Archibald Roane, Governor of the State of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated April 13, 1803, written by Archibald Roane, Governor of the State of Tennessee, to the citizens of Anderson County, Tennessee. Roane intended to address this letter to the citizens who were presently residing on lands that had been guaranteed to Indians, and he warned them that prosecution would be brought against them if they failed to remove themselves. Roane stated that the Indians were demanding their rightful land, and the federal government would comply with those demands, be it by legal prosecution, removal by troops, or both.

titleInfo.title: 1850 Mar. 14, Washington [City, D. C.] [to Adam Fergusson] / Andrew Ewing

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Andrew Ewing dated March 14, 1850. It is probably to Adam Fergusson. Ewing writes about pension claims and a decision by Mr. Edwards and Mr. Legare about them. He also mentions that the slavery question has not yet been resolved.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Dec. 10, Nashville [Tennessee, to] C. C. Trabue, Nashville / James K. Polk

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor James K. Polk to Charles Clay Trabue, mayor of Nashville. It is dated December 10, 1839. Polk is writing to say that there is no legal basis for the resolution that Trabue has recently passed.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Jan. 7, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Members of Congress / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated the 7th of January, 1797 from governor John Sevier of Tennessee to members of Congress. In the Letter, Sevier informs the statesmen of supposed plundering of several wagons by Cherokee Indians while in route to the Cumberland plateau.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Jun. 30, Washington [to] Gen[era]l Jackson / M[artin] Van Buren

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from Martin Van Buren to General Jackson on June 30, 1837. In the letter, Van Buren thanks Jackson for sending a copy of his reply to a Judge who has made accusations against Jackson. Van Buren also mentions the lack of support they are getting from the people in their district.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1822 Apr. 5, Nashville, Tennessee [to] James Winchester, Cairo, Tennessee / William L. Alexander

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated April 5, 1822 from William L. Alexander in Nashville, Tennessee to James Winchester in Cairo, Tennessee. The letter has many missing sections, the right side of the document is torn away. The subject matter of the letter concerns the shipment and purchase of supplies such as coffee and sugar.

titleInfo.title: 1844 Jun. 8, Carthage [Tennessee, to unknown recipient] / [Adam Fergusson]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to an unknown recipient dated June 8, 1844. The author is most likely Adam Fergusson. Fergusson is writing to announce the nomination of James K. Polk for president. He describes the convention party in Carthage. According to Fergusson the citizens celebrated with great enthusiasm. Fergusson also writes about people's reactions to the nomination.

titleInfo.title: 1808 Mar. Mar. 3, Georgetown [Virginia, to] Gabriel Duvall / David Henley

mods.abstract: This is a letter from David Henley to U.S. Comptroller of the Treasury, Gabriel Duvall, dated March 3, 1808. Henley has apparently been accused of owing money from his time spent as an agent for the War Department in Tennessee (formerly the Territory Southwest of the Ohio River.) This letter is explaining in detail his time there. Henley mentions many of the people he worked with. He explains how hard he worked and how little his pay was, comparing his job and salary to other's. He defends his actions, pleads for justice, and promises to pay some of the money back.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1816 Jan. 19, Cabarrus County, North Carolina [to] Thomas Campbell / Cha[rle]s Harris

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Charles Harris to Thomas Campbell on January 19, 1816. In the letter, Harris claims that a George Calhoun wishes to have a dispute over land that Charles' brother Samuel Harris sold him in Williamson County, Tennessee. Samuel Harris sold Calhoun 350 acres of land that was a parcel of land that was made up of 1000 acres. Calhoun disputes the amount of land that was actually sold to him, and has not paid any of the expenses or taxes that have accrued to the land.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1834 Apr. 9 [Certificates concerning the enrollment of Charles Jones and Edward Welch]

mods.abstract: This document, dated April 9, 1834, is statements regarding the alleged false enrollment of Charles Jones And Edward Welch into the Cherokee Nation by the United States agent to the Cherokee. The men claim to have been coerced into signing the enrollment papers.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Jun. 4, Rutherford County, Tennessee [to] James King, Tuscaloosa, Alabama / Burl Gannaway

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 4, 1839 from Burl Gannaway to James Moore King. The contents of the letter focus on daily life events and serves to update King on many matters of business.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 March 9, Clover Dale, [TN] [to] Ann Jane Bell, Cornplanter, PA / M[argaret] V. Bell :

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Margaret Bell to her sister Jane Bell dated March 9, 1840. Margaret writes about her grief over the death of their father, followed unexpectedly by the death of their mother. She includes notices of other people who have either died or are sick. She also mentions how favorable the weather has been for the crops and peaches. Their brother is giving a speech on temperance that Margaret wishes Jane could attend. She writes that it will be almost impossible for her to visit Jane , and that it is her wish for Jane and their brother Sam to come to Clover Dale for a visit.

titleInfo.title: 1839 Apr. 4, Carthage, Tennessee [to] Felix Grundy, Washington [D.C.] / A[dam] Fergusson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Adam Fergusson to the Honorable Felix Grundy, dated April 4, 1839. Fergusson has several questions regarding pension law that he wants Grundy to answer. He also discusses the local political climate.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Feb. 19, Highwassee Garrison, [TN] [to] Colonel James Brown / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated February 19, 1815, from Cherokee Agent Return J. Meigs to James Brown, a son of Colonel Joseph Brown. Meigs is advising Brown that recovering his father's slaves from Cherokee chief Coteoyetohee is threatening a peace between the US and the Cherokee and is in violation of a treaty. Meigs reminds Brown that treaties are the highest law and that all are accountable to the law.

titleInfo.title: A MAP of The TENNASSEE GOVERNMENT formerly Part of NORTH CAROLINA taken Chiefly from Surveys by Gen,[era]l D. Smith. & others / Engraved by J. T. Scott

mods.abstract: This document is a rare map of Tennessee surveyed and engraved circa 1795. The map shows public roads, Indian boundaries, forts, Indian towns, and width of rivers in yards.

titleInfo.title: 1841 Oct. 7, St. Louis, Missouri [to] [James Chamberlain] Jones, Nashville, Tennessee/ Edmund P. Gaines

mods.abstract: This is a letter from General Edmund Pendleton Gaines to James Chamberlain Jones, Governor of Tennessee. It is dated October 7, 1841. Gaines writes in reference to a recent Act of Congress authorizing a "House Squadron". He is concerned that the port towns of the United States are not defendable against ships running under steam power. Gaines is also concerned that a war with a European power is possible. He believes that the Native Americans he is defending the Western Frontier from might unite with a European aggressor. Gaines offers recommendations for building and staffing forts, and mentions the need for rail roads west of the Mississippi River. Gaines lists some ideas for how to deal with the Native American and European threats. He also lists his objections to current U.S. military policy, especially in regards to forts and New Orleans' defence against war ships under steam power.

titleInfo.title: [Military] Orders No. 25, 1838 May 17, Eastern Division, Cherokee Agency, Ten[nessee] / [signed by] Winfield Scott, W. J. Wirth

mods.abstract: The following document is a Military Order issued on May 17, 1838, by General Winfield Scott, federal officer in charge of Cherokee removal. Scott issued, on the authority of President Andrew Jackson, the order for federal troops to enforce the removal of all the Cherokee remaining east of the Mississippi River, according to the terms of the Treaty of New Echota, signed by a Cherokee minority in 1835. Scott divided the Cherokee Nation into three military districts in order to facilitate a speedy evacuation. The orders of President Jackson and General Scott began what was to be called the Trail of Tears, in which 15,000-20,000 Cherokee were exiled to Indian Territory in present-day Oklahoma. An estimated one-fifth died during the whole of the journey, which lasted until the spring of 1839.

titleInfo.title: [Legal writ] 1794 Oct. 23 Nashville, [to] The Sheriff of Davidson County [Tennessee] / Andrew Ewing

mods.abstract: This is a legal document to the Sheriff of Davidson County, Tennessee from Andrew Ewing, Clerk of the Davidson County Court, written on October 23, 1794. The document requires the Sheriff to bring eighteen shillings which were paid to him from outside parties. This money is now requested by the court as recovery payment to another individual.

titleInfo.title: Territory of the United States South of the River Ohio
[Letter] 1818 May 4, Cherokee Agency [to] Colo[nel] Geo[rge] Gillespie / Jos[eph] McMinn

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 4, 1818, from Tennessee Governor Joseph McMinn to Colonel George Gillespie. Governor McMinn writes this letter in regards to the compensation Gillespie will receive for his work as commissioner for valuing Cherokee improvements. The letter also includes a table of goods received to be distributed amongst the Cherokee.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1802 Jul. 27, United States to Lewis Tarwater / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for five dollars, paid to Lewis Tarwater for provisions and forage. Return J. Meigs, agent for the War Department made the payment on behalf of the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1803 Aug. 22 [to] Henry Breazale, Roane County [Tennessee] / Archibald Roane

mods.abstract: This is a copy of a letter to Henry Breazale from Governor Archibald Roane, dated August 22, 1803. Roane is requesting information on the possible whereabouts and movements of a man named Trainum. Trainum is a suspected horse thief and murderer.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 Mar. 28, Columbia, [Tennessee] [to] Elizabeth Chester, et al., Jackson, Tennessee / M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Mary Jane Chester to her mother, Elizabeth Chester, and other members of her family on March 28, 1841. In the series of short letters, Mary Jane discusses events going on in the family and with people she has come in contact with in Columbia, and she urges her family to keep in touch with her while she is away at school.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Feb. 26, Dresden [to] William Fitzgerald / E.A. Fitzgerald

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated February 26, 1832 from E.A. Fitzgerald to her husband William Fitzgerald. She writes to her husband of several political and social matters of the period including the establishment of a temperance society. She also mentions prominent political figures such as Henry Clay, Daniel Webster, and Martin Van Buren.

titleInfo.title: 1850 Sep. 9, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Adam Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / J. J. Burnett

mods.abstract: This is a letter from J. J. Burnett to Adam Fergusson, dated September 9, 1850. Burnett writes that the Supreme Court is convening in Knoxville. He also mentions how excited the people in Knoxville are about the railroad and that they also seem like nice people.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1831 Jan. 7, Covington, Tennessee [to] William Carroll, Nashville, Tennessee / J. Tipton

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated January 7, 1831 from J. Tipton to Tennessee governor William Carroll. In the letter, he informs the governor that the Tipton troops are in need of arms, but otherwise ready for duty. He also mentions the vacant position of Principal Surveyor for the 11th District in Tipton County, and recommends an appointment to that position.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1814 Jan. 31, Fort Strother, [TN] [to] Maj[o]r General John Cocke, Knoxville, East Tennessee / Major Gen[era]l Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated January 31, 1814, from Andrew Jackson at Fort Strother to John Cocke in Knoxville. Jackson sends this military order during the War of 1812, telling Cocke not to march his army until he has weapons for them. He gives his opinion about the dismissal of a general named Ratliff and the seizure of his property.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1800 July 27, Tennessee [to] James White / Charles McClung

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Charles McClung to James White, dated July 27, 1800. McClung empowers White to call before him and to question Abraham Job regarding another court case.

titleInfo.title: [Testimony] 1838 April 18, Cherokee Agency East / William Reid

mods.abstract: This document is a sworn statement given by William Reid regarding six head of cattle killed by white men in November of 1823. Reid requests 72.00 dollars in compensation from the United States Government.

titleInfo.title: [Funeral invitation] 1845 Jun. 9, Nashville [Tennessee], Invitation to the funeral of Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is an invitation to the funeral of Andrew Jackson presented on June 9, 1845. Jackson died the evening before, June 8, and the funeral service will take place on the following day, June 10.

titleInfo.title: 1843 March 20, Rock Cave, K[entuck]y [to] Emaline Hamilton, Nashville, Tenn[essee]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Emaline Hamilton from her sister Mary. It is dated March 20, 1843. Mary starts by apologizing to Emaline for not writing as often as she should. Mary writes about going to parties and to church since she has been in Rock Cave. She mentions how some people were scared of the Great Comet of 1843. Some believed it heralded the Second Coming. She sends her love to many family members.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Feb. 17, Knoxville, Tennessee, to] Benjamin Hawkins, Superintendent of Indian Affairs / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Benjamin Hawkins, Superintendent of Indian Affairs, from Tennessee Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) on February 17, 1797. In this letter, Sevier accounted the story of two slaves belonging to Captain James Richardson who had run away and ended up in the Cherokee Nation. The slaves were then taken by a member of the Creek Nation, who announced he would not relinquish possession of the slaves until some of his horses stolen by Cherokees, were returned. Sevier also told Hawkins that it is suspected that Creeks and/or Cherokees had recently been exerting aggression against settlers in the Cumberland, having killed one man and stealing several horses. Sevier requested that Hawkins attempt to have the slaves and horses returned as soon as possible.

titleInfo.title: 1850 Feb. 22 [between] John R. Wilson, Davidson County, Tennessee [and] the Trustees of Washington Institute

mods.abstract: This is a legal document dated February 22, 1850, exchanging a land deed in Davidson County, TN, between John R. Wilson and the trustees of the Washington Institute. Wilson has conveyed for one dollar a piece of land to the Washington Institute for the establishment of a school. In return, the trustees agreed that Wilson and his heirs will be able to attend classes for free and will also retain a lien on the land. The witnesses are W. L. Wilson and Thomas B. Wilson.

titleInfo.title: 1846 Sep. 10, Comargo, Mexico [to] William Fitzgerald, Paris, Tennessee / J.R. Hawkins

mods.abstract: This is a letter to the Honorable William Fitzgerald from J.R. Hawkins, dated September 10, 1846. Hawkins writes about General Taylor moving his troops to take over Monterey. Hawkins believes that there will be more fighting than expected and that the troops from Tennessee will be too sick to fight properly. He describes the Rivers Rio Grand and San Juan. Hawkins mentions an embarrassing incident where some of the men from his company deserted leading to an exaggerated an untrue story in a local paper. Hawkins requests that Fitzgerald get the newspaper to print a retraction.

titleInfo.title: 1811 Sep. 19, [to] James Winchester, Sumner County, Tennessee / John R. Eaton

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Major John R. Eaton to General James Winchester, dated September 19, 1811. Eaton writes about the effect on trade with Spain and Portugal in relation to England. He also expresses concern about the possibility of war with England. Eaton reports that a British naval ship is off the coast.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 Jan. 30 [to] Joseph Brown, Maury County Tenn[essee] / Joseph Porter Brown

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated January 30, 1841 to Joseph Brown from his son Joseph Porter Brown regarding a trip he plans to take to visit his father.

titleInfo.title: [Letter], 1802 June 30, Chickamoga [i.e. Chickamauga], [to] Maj[or] William Lovely [Tennessee?] / Daniel Ross

mods.abstract: Daniel Ross, Indian Agent, writes to Major William Lovely and informs him that some horses were stolen out of his possession. He thinks that the horses ought to be paid for by the government in agreement with the Tellico Treaty. Daniel Ross believes there is sufficient evidence to name Estridge as the thief, and he would like action to be taken against him and his family, June 30, 1802.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Nov. 18, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Aaron Brown, Nashville, Tennessee / Isaac Lewis

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated November 18, 1846 from Isaac Lewis in Knoxville, Tennessee to Governor Aaron V. Brown in Nashville. In the letter, Lewis discusses the completion of the Hiwassee Rail Road, and the hopes and prospects that East Tennesseans hold for it.

titleInfo.title: Letter, 1838 June 12, Washington to C.A. Harris / Jno. [i.e., John] Ross

mods.abstract: This is a copy of a letter from John Ross to C.A. Harris, commissioner of Indian Affairs, dated June 12, 1838. Ross applies to Harris for payment for Hair Conrad, Jesse Bushyhead, Thomas Woodward, and Major Pole Cat, who acted as mediators to the Seminoles in Florida.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1842 Apr. 12, Tahlequah District, The United States to Edward Welch

mods.abstract: This document is a claim against the United States by Edward Welch, a member of the Eastern Cherokee Nation. Welch was dispossessed of his land and personal property and asked for 1,291.00 dollars in compensation.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1812 Dec. 23, Raleigh, North Carolina [to] John Sevier, City of Washington / J. Winston

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated December 23, 1812 from Colonel Jas.Winston to John Sevier. He informs Sevier of the status of his memorial, and its introduction into the legislation of the state of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Sep. 28, Murfreesboro, Tennessee [to] Joseph McMinn / James Park

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated September 28, 1819 from James Park to the governor of Tennessee, Joseph McMinn. The subject of the letter is the wretched condition of the Turnpike road between Knoxville and Sparta, and the growing difficulty that United States mail wagon carriers have in its passage. In the letter, Park writes of mail routes throughout Tennessee. He also asks the governor to consider whether or not a toll should be authorized on the Turnpike.

titleInfo.title: 1837 Nov. 20, Carthage, Tennessee [to unknown recipient] / Adam Fergusson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Adam Fergusson dated November 20, 1837. The recipient is unknown, but is from Scotland. Fergusson is writing because he wishes information from his parents hometown in Scotland. He gives the names of his relations there, and where they are from. Fergusson requests that the recipient find someone willing to correspond with him.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 10 April [18]48 Shelbyville, [TN] [to] Mrs. A[nn] J[ane] Bell, Charlotte, Tenn[essee] / Theodore A. Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Theodore Bell to his mother Jane Bell dated April 10, 1848. He writes that he would be willing to take up a profession, but that he is unable. He lets Jane know that despite the rumors, he is not married. He informs her that he is still poor, with no hope yet of improving his situation. He reports of cholera in Nashville and Murfreesboro. He also writes about a fire that almost destroyed the business district.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Apr. 20, East Tenn[essee] College, Knoxville [to] Mr. Charles F. Welcker, Talladega, Ala[bama] / Fred[erick] A. Welcker

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 20, 1837, from Frederick A. Welcker at East Tennessee College (currently the University of Tennessee) to his brother Charles F. Welcker in Talladega, Alabama. Frederick talks about the school, his examination, and the rival social societies. He also discusses upcoming congressional elections and the candidates. Finally, he expresses shock at the news that their sister Catharine had recently gotten married.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1823 Aug. [to] The bank of Tennessee / [signed by] James K. Polk et. al.

mods.abstract: This document is a promissory note signed by James K. Polk, William Parr, and George Johnston in August 1823. The document shows that these men have promised to repay $100 to the bank of Tennessee eighty eight days after this note was signed.

This document is a letter from David Campbell dated September 25, 1796. The recipient of the letter is unknown. In the letter, Campbell expresses his interest in becoming the District Judge of the newly formed state of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 March 3, Dresden, Tenn[essee] [to] John Overton, Nashville, Tenn[essee] / John Charlton

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated March 3, 1828 to John Overton from John Charlton concerning land that Charlton had purchased for Overton in Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1800 Jul. 7, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] David Henl[e]y / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a brief letter dated July 7, 1800 from governor John Sevier of Tennessee to David Henley, agent for the department of war. The purpose of the letter is a death allegedly caused by Indians in march of 1799. The governor requests any information Henley may have on the matter.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Nov. 15, Columbia, Tenn[essee] [to] Col[onel] Joseph Brown, Maury County, Tenn[essee] / W.H.D. Wendel

mods.abstract: This is a letter from W.H.D. Wendel to hi grandfather Col. Joseph Brown dated November 15, 1849. He writes about visiting his grandmother, and local politics.

titleInfo.title: 1800 Jul. 17, Greenville [to] Joseph Hamilton, Russellville, K[entuck]y / Joshua L.Wilson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Joshua L. Wilson to Joseph Hamilton, dated July 17, 1800. Wilson laments his money troubles. He just lost some court cases that caused him to lose some of his land. Wilson asks Hamilton if he would be willing to trade land for horses. Wilson writes about the upcoming election. He is concerned for the reputation of Hamilton's area if an undesirable candidate, whom Wilson calls the King of Beasts, is elected. Apparently this man came to office by nefarious means, and it is proving difficult to remove him.
This document is a claim dated September 5, 1838 made by Nawatta (also called Grits) to the United States to recover the value of six horses that were stolen by a white man in 1830.

titleInfo.title: Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors [Archibald Roane--1801-1803] / J. S. Jones

mods.abstract: The Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors, dated 1904, contains 31 plates, each featuring a Tennessee Governor's photo on the front and biographical information on the back. This plate features Archibald Roane, Tennessee's second state governor.

titleInfo.title: [Drawing depicting Cherokee townhouse and summer pavilion posthole patterns at mid-18th century Tomotley, created in 1976] / [by Marion Drescher]

mods.abstract: This is a drawing of posthole patterns dating back to the mid-18th century of a winter townhouse (top) and summer pavilion (below) from the Overhill Cherokee town of Tomotley. All political and social events were held in these townhouses. The winter townhouse was a large conical structure, which contained amphitheater seating around a central hearth. The rectangular summer town or council house was an open pavilion suitable for warm weather. Excavations of Tomotley were conducted by the University of Tennessee in 1976 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, Gerald F. Schroedl.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 May 12, Clover Dale, [TN] [to] Mrs. Ann Jane Bell, Cornplanter, Venango Co., PA / Margaret V. Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Margaret V. Bell to her sister Ann Jane Bell dated May 12, 1839. Margaret writes that their father is feeling much better and can walk around some. She writes of the farm and crops and flower gardening. Mr. Collier brought the family a large assortment of gifts. She writes that Jane's friend Allen has been elected second colonel.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Sep. 1, Winchester, Tennessee [to] William Hall / Micah Tane

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated September 1, 1829 from Micah Tane, writing from Winchester, Tennessee, to the acting governor of the state, William Hall. In the letter he tells the governor of the brutal murder of his son Thomas P. Tane by Rufuss K. Anderson. He asks the governor to use his position and influence to assist in the apprehension of Anderson, believed to be in Alabama.

titleInfo.title: 1835 Oct. 21, Nashville, T[ennessee] [to] A. J. Donelson, Washington City / S. H. Laughlin

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated Oct. 21, 1835, from S. H. Laughlin to Major Andrew J. Donelson. Laughlin is writing about the political situation, especially as it pertains to President Jackson. He mentions some promising Democrats. Laughlin promises to keep Donelson updated on the news that he will not find in the newspapers. He mentions a dinner being given in honor of Colonel Polk in Mooresville. Laughlin writes that he and some others are supporting Polk for Speaker of the House, over a man named Bell.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 June 6, Fosterville [to the] Quartermaster / Charles Hicks

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Charles Hicks to the Quartermaster at Camp Ross requesting one hundred and forty bushels of corn for the people of Durt town to be paid out of their annuities.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Jun. 4, Knoxville [to] Reverend F. W. Porter, Philadelphia, Pa. / Joseph L. King

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 4, 1846 from Joseph L. King of Knoxville to the Reverend F.W. Porter regarding the sale of books to supply Christian schools in the East Tennessee area.

titleInfo.title: [Commission] 1839 July 19 [for] Thomas B. Reppatoe / [signed by] Newton Cannon

mods.abstract: This document is a commission dated July 19, 1839 for Thomas B. Reppatoe to serve as justice of the peace in Jefferson County, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1795 Jul. 2, Knoxville, Territory of US south of Ohio River [to] David Henley / William Blount

mods.abstract: This is a receipt given to David Henley of the War Department from Governor William Blount. It is for money given to William Rickard to be used for troop salaries. The receipt is dated July 2, 1795.

subject.topic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Apr. 10 Bean Station, Grainger Co[unty, Tennessee] [to] Board of Managers of the A, B, Society, Nassau, New York / Thomas Springfield

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 10, 1846 and written by the Reverend Thomas Springfield to the board managers of the A.B. Society in Nassau, New York. Springfield details his evangelistic travels all over East Tennessee, Western North Carolina, and Western Virginia.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Dec. 29, Greenville College, E[ast] Ten[nessee] [to] Thomas Abernathy, Elkton Giles County, West Tennessee

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated December 29, 1835 from M.S. Temple to Thomas E. Abernathy. Temple writes that his mother has gotten married unexpectedly. He writes about how much the local people want the railroads to come through East TN. He also tells Abernathy not to sell the land that he is managing for the Temple family in Giles County yet.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] Dec. 18, ca. 1820, Greeneville [to] Peggy A. Ramsey, Swan Pond, Knox County [Tennessee] / H. Ramsey

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Peggy A. Ramsey from her husband, dated December 18 of an unknown year (probably around 1820). Ramsey writes about his travels. He mentions many names of people he has seen and stayed with.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1843 Jan. 14, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Col[onel] R[obert] J. Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated January 14, 1843, from Mary Jane Chester to her father Colonel Robert J. Chester of Jackson, TN. Mary writes from the Female Institute in Columbia, TN and discusses her busy school schedule and upcoming examination.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1828 Nov. 6

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is an excerpt from Thursday November 6, 1828, on which dated a case involving debt was heard before the court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Minutes of Rail Road meeting] 1836 June 28 / A. C. Eaton

mods.abstract: This document is the minutes from a railroad meeting dated June 28, 1836. Four delegates were chosen to attend a convention to be held in Knoxville, Tennessee on July 4th 1837. Delegates from all over the United States would then discuss the construction of a railroad from Cincinnati, Ohio to Charleston, South Carolina.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1820 Jan. 8, Frankfort, Kent[uck]y [to] Andrew Crockett, Franklin, Tennessee / R. J. Todd

mods.abstract: This is a letter from R. J. Todd to Andrew Crockett dated January 8, 1820. Todd is updating Crockett on a land deal and the laws pertaining to it.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Jun. 30, Dresden, Tennessee [to] Aaron Brown, Nashville, Tennessee / William Blakemore

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 30, 1846 from William Blakemore, the coroner of Weakley County, Tennessee, to Governor Aaron V. Brown in Nashville. In the letter, Blakemore describes a brutal murder committed by William Dunn, who has since fled the county, and he requests the governors assistance in his apprehension.

titleInfo.title: 1806 Aug 17, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] James Winchester, Sumner County [Tennessee] / Sampson Williams et. al.

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Sampson Williams and John Wynne to General James Winchester, dated August 17, 1806. Williams and Wynne inform Winchester of some Bills that propose to divide Tennessee into administrative districts. They describe the details such as locations and reactions to the idea. They mention that some people want to call a constitutional convention. Winchester is asked if he plans on running for Congress. If so, they assure him of support.

titleInfo.title: [Petition] 1836 Jul. 26, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Newton Cannon / Citizens of Columbia

mods.abstract: This document is a petition signed by forty-five citizens of Columbia, Tennessee to the governor of the state, Newton Cannon. They are asking the governor to bring the issue of the construction of a turnpike road from Columbia to the Tennessee river, before the state legislature.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] ca. 1815, Bachelors Hall The Lades Choice Bachelors Hall [to] Uncle / James Moore King

mods.abstract: This is a letter from James Moore King to his uncle announcing his return home to Tennessee following a seven month campaign against the British in New Orleans. It outlines a vivid description of battle and narrow escape.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1827 May 17, Franklin, Tennessee, [to] John Overton, Nashville, Tenn[essee] / T. H. Cahal

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to John Overton from T. H. Cahal concerning a stray horse found near Rutherford's Creek in Tennessee. Cahal believes the horse is one that Overholt is missing.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1802 Jun. 18, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Henry Dearborn / Archibald Roane

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor Archibald Roane to Henry Dearborn, dated June 18, 1802. Dearborn is the Secretary of War. Roane is writing regarding the Natchez Trace, an important road from Nashville to Natchez, Mississippi. Roane requests that Dearborn send new orders to a Colonel Butler that will allow Butler to open the road in Williamson County.
This document is a claim made in 1815 against the United States by Taw,le,eskee, a Cherokee Indian to recover the value of his mare and a colt believed to be taken by the militia.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Mar. 9, Alexandria, Louisiana [to] James King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Thomas Moore

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated March 9, 1835 from Thomas Moore to his cousin James King. He urges his cousin to resettle in the south, specifically Louisiana, as soon as possible, as land is quickly being bought and land prices are rising.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1820 Jul. 23, The United States to Lewis Ross

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for payment to Lewis Ross from the United States, dated July 23, 1820. Ross was paid three dollars and 12 and one half cents for forage during the time he looked after the Cherokee Light House.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Jul. 30, Macon, Noxubee Cty., Miss[issippi] [to] E.H. Porter, Raleigh, Tennessee / LeRoy B. Gaston

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 30, 1836 to E. H. Porter of Tennessee from LeRoy Gaston regarding various business ventures in Mississippi and Georgia.

titleInfo.title: [Bond] 1807 Mar. 13, Camden County, Georgia [to] State / Eli Whitney

mods.abstract: This document is a bond dated March 13, 1807 in the amount of ten-thousand dollars. Its purpose is for entitling the state of Tennessee to purchase the Patent Right of Eli Whitney's and Phineas Miller's Saw Gin. The bond also outlines the conditions of the obligation.

This document is a letter written by A.J. Donelson on June 1, 1835. The letter discusses several students attending West Point and their scholastic abilities. Donelson also gives his political views on several candidates and practices that are important to the politics of the time.

titleInfo.title: [Testimony] 1843 Nov. 4 [of] William H. Thomas regarding the improvements of Rebecca Starritt

mods.abstract: This document is a sworn statement given by William H. Thomas. Thomas claims he was employed by Rebecca Starritt in 1838 to help her receive compensation for improvements to her land. Thomas also states that he failed to obtain compensation for Rebecca Starritt. See also pa0252, pa0253, and pa0254.

titleInfo.title: 1805 May 25, Knox County [Tennessee, to] James Winchester, Cragfont [Tennessee] / Archibald Roane

mods.abstract: This is a letter from former Governor Archibald Roane to General James Winchester, dated May 25, 1805. Roane is considering running for Chief Magistrate. He believes that many people are against his winning. He requests that Winchester find out what the people of his area think about Roane's candidacy.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of small pit filled with charred corn cobs, 18th century Cherokee Village of Tanassee, taken in 1972] / [by J. Worth Greene]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a small pit filled with charred corn cobs used to smudge ceramic vessels or to process deer hides at the Overhill Cherokee Village of Tanasee (Tanasi). Tanasee is sometimes referred to as Chota-Tanasi as the two towns were very close together. Chota and Tanassee were two of over 60 Cherokee settlements in the Southeastern states during the 18th century. Excavations of Overhill Cherokee villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project. Excavations continued until 1983, and laboratory studies and report preparation continued until 1987. The excavations were conducted in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River Valley, in eastern Tennessee, by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal Investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, J. Worth Greene.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] ca. 1824 Oct. 20

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt, dated Monday October 20, around the year 1824, announces the adjournment of the court until the next day due to the absence of a judge. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: Letter, 1866 Jan. 19, Washington City, D.C. to Mr. Rice, Philadelphia, P[ennsylvani]a / John Ross
