mods.abstract: Copy of a letter dated January 19, 1866 from John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, to a publisher in Philadelphia named Mr. Rice. Ross apologizes for the delay in sending a manuscript written by Reverend Headley for submission in a publication called Indian Biography. A note on the back of the document indicates that this letter is a copy, but Ross's signature appears to be in his own hand.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Jun. 6, Murfreesboro, Tennessee [to] George M. Troup, Millidgeville, Georgia / W[illia]m Carroll

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor William Carroll to George M. Troup, dated June 6, 1825. Troup is governor of Georgia. The Tennessee legislature has proposed that a canal be built to connect the Hiwassee River to the Coosa River, and also for one to bypass the muscle shoals. Carroll writes Troup for information about undertaking such a project and to secure Georgia's cooperation.
This document is a brief letter of request dated January 13, 1844 from W. Houston to the governor of Tennessee, James C. Jones. In the letter, Houston asks for the addition of clerk to his branch.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Jul. 15, Nashville, Tennessee [to] D.G. Broom, Natchez, Mississippi / F.H. Knapp

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from the year 1842. It is from F.H. Knapp to D.G. Broom, a dental surgeon in Natchez, Mississippi. The purpose of Knapp's letter is to update his friend on his numerous travels and adventures. In the letter, Knapp tells Broom that he has had a very agreeable trip, and has spent time with some of the greatest men of the age, including Andrew Jackson.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Oct. 28

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt, dated Saturday October 28, around the year 1824, takes account of a case being brought against John Walkings by Joseph Rogers. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Aug. 12, Tyrus Springs, [Tn to] James A. Woods, Nashville, [Tn] / Robert Woods

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated Aug. 12, 1840 from Robert Woods to his son James. Robert is giving James advice, mostly about how to pursue a career, and about school. He also mentions the importance of good health, and his opinion that his own health is in a permanent decline. Robert also writes how much he is concerned for the welfare of all his children, James included.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Sept. 18, Clover Dale, TN [to] Miss Ann Jane Bell, Philadelphia / C[aroline] D. Bell

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated September 18, 1837, from Caroline D. Bell in Clover Dale, TN, to her sister Ann Jane Bell in Philadelphia. In the letter, Caroline describes a church camp meeting she had recently attended , in which 60 people had "professed religion." Caroline further explains the nascent religious revivalism that had swept over the area and discusses more church revival meetings that were being planned.

titleInfo.title: [Affidavit of James Johnston] 1837 Nov. 12, Roane County, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is an affidavit given by James Johnston regarding land that belonged to The Pathkiller, a Cherokee Indian. The Pathkiller was dispossessed of his land during the Cherokee removal and fought for years to gain it back.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1813 Jun. 23, Beauport [to] George Prevost / James Winchester

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 23, 1813 from James Winchester to General George Prevost concerning United States militia men being held near Quebec by the British as prisoners of war. The prisoners were captured during the war of 1812. Winchester is concerned for their health and living conditions; he asks General Prevost to intercede on the prisoners behalf.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1826 Oct. 25

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from October 25, 1826, and reports of the Court's decision in the case of the heirs of Betsy Springston versus David and Delilah McNair. The McNairs were ordered to pay the plaintiffs for the price of two slaves. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Aug. 18, Mouth of Poplar Creek [to] Geo[rge] L. Welcker, W[est] Point, New York / Cha[rle]s F. Welcker

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated August 18, 1833, written by Charles F. Welcker in East Tennessee to his brother George L. Welcker in West Point, New York. Charles writes to inform his brother of the latest news from home, including the results of recent elections and an update on the well-being of friends and family.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Apr. 24, Camp near Jalaka [to] Mrs. W[illia]m R. Caswell, Jefferson County, Tennessee / W[illia]m R. Caswell

mods.abstract: The following document, dated April 24, 1847, is a letter written by William R. Caswell to his wife during the Mexican-American war. Caswell was one of many Tennessee volunteers to fight in the war. He writes to assure his wife that he is safe and well after the battle of Vera Cruz, and he expresses hope of returning home soon.

titleInfo.title: Constitution of the Cherokee Nation, 1827 Jul. 24, New Town Echota

mods.abstract: The following document is the constitution drafted on July 24, 1827 that sparked the beginning of the modern Cherokee Nation. The document was a product of a Constitutional Convention of 1827, headed by John Ross, who was elected the first Chief of the Cherokee Nation when the constitution was put into effect the following year. In the constitution, which was largely patterned after the United States', the Cherokees referred to themselves as a sovereign entity and outlined three branches of government. Although the Constitution of the Cherokee Nation was largely developed in order to prevent the forced removal of the Cherokee, it was only ten years after its adoption that the Cherokee were ultimately displaced.

titleInfo.title: [Letter to the] Speaker and Gentlemen of the House of Representatives / W[illia]m Blount

mods.abstract: This is a letter to the House of Representatives of either Tennessee or the U.S. of unknown date. William Blount writes that he agrees with the House's decision concerning the militia.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Jun. 19, E[ast] Ten[nessee] College [to] Henry Welcker, Kingston, Tenn[essee] / F[rederick] A. Welcker

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated June 19, 1836, to Henry Welcker of Roane County, TN, from his son Frederick at East Tennessee College (currently the University of Tennessee). Frederick writes about the cost of some land belonging to his late brother William, as well as other financial matters.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1838 Sept. United States to George Still of Cherokee Nation East

mods.abstract: This document dated September 1838 is a spoliation claim for George Still of the Cherokee Nation East. Still is requesting that the United States government reimburse him for horses, steer, and cows that he claims were stolen from him by white men.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 May 19, Washington [to] Felix Grundy / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 19, 1833, from President Andrew Jackson to Felix Grundy. Jackson writes in response to Grundy's May 6th letter, in which Grundy asked Jackson to vouch for his conduct at a recent session of Congress.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Nov. 10, Benjamin Timpson vs. Chuankee

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Wednesday November 10, 1824 session of court in which a case was heard between a man and his wife. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1804 Feb. 9, [to] warriors chiefs of the Cherokee Nation / [John Sevier]: a machine-readable transcription of an image

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Tennessee Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809), dated February 9, 1804, and addressed to the warriors and chiefs of the Cherokee Nation. In the letter, Sevier reported that the recent murders of Cherokee men in Buncombe County, North Carolina, were not committed by a resident of Tennessee. Sevier had received a description of the man suspected and had been informed that he had likely fled to Tennessee, in which case Sevier assured the Cherokee leaders that he would do his best to have the man apprehended. The Governor also briefly discussed business of a road being opened through the Cherokee Nation and suggested that arrangements for such should be made soon.

titleInfo.title: [Resolution] In the House of Delegates, 1800 Jan. 10

mods.abstract: This document is a resolution passed by the House of Delegates on January 10, 1800. The document summarizes preceding congressional acts regarding the cessation of the Southwest Territory from North Carolina in 1790, the establishment of "Walker's line" as the boundary of North Carolina in 1791, and the creation of the state of Tennessee in 1796. It was then resolved that three commissioners be appointed to meet with Tennessee commissioners regarding issues concerning the boundary line between the two states.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1793 June 17, Withe County, [Tennessee to] General Smith / William Blount, Governor of the State of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from William Blount, Governor of the state of Tennessee from 1790 to 1795, to General Smith, dated June 17, 1793. In his letter, Blount stated that he had been informed that the President and Secretary of War were awaiting his arrival in order to discuss business regarding the Indians in the South. Blount and others were apparently unhappy with the Indians, and Blount suggested that a full-scale war was the only way to coerce them into acting in accordance with the US's wishes. Blount also discussed providing arms for the frontier settlers.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1796 May 6, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Colonel White et.al. / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor John Sevier dated May 6, 1796. The letter is to Colonels White, Kelly, and Weir. Sevier writes that he is going to be in Washington D.C. for about a month. He asks that the Colonels keep a close watch on the frontier and on the Cherokees.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1827 Oct. 18-19

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt contains the both the October 18 and 19, 1827 court summaries. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1843 May, Columbia, Tenn[essee] [to] Col[onel] R[obert] J. Chester, Jackson, Tenn[essee] / M[ary Jane] Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Mary Jane Chester to her father Colonel Robert J. Chester, postmarked on either May 19 or 29, 1843. Mary writes to her father from her school in Columbia, TN, and she explains that her examination is soon approaching and that she is excited about the prospects of returning home afterwards. She also describes an encounter she had with an old friend of her father's by the name of Mr. Trotter. Enclosed is a letter addressed to her sister, in which she discusses the death of a man by the name of W. Patton and expresses her anticipation at her sister's expected arrival in Columbia.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Jul. 7, Mouth of Sweet Water [to] Mr. Cha[rle]s F. Welcker, Roane County, Ten[nessee] / A[lbert] S. Lenoir

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 7, 1839, from Albert S. Lenoir to his brother-in-law Charles F. Welcker in Roane County, Tennessee. Lenoir writes to inform Welcker that Ellick, a slave he had hired from Welcker was found to have left his clothes behind in a hollow log as he had seemingly departed from Lenoir's property. Lenoir states that he wishes to flog Ellick, but asks Welcker his opinion on the matter.

titleInfo.title: [Tavern Bond] 1827 Jan. 23, Maury County, Tennessee [for] Taswell S. Alderson

mods.abstract: This document is a tavern bond, dated January 23, 1827 for Taswell S. Alderson of Maury County, Tennessee. The bond allows Alderson to provide lodging, food, drink, and stable privileges to travelers.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1796 Mar. 30 Knoxville [Tennessee], [to] Governor [John] Sevier / W [illia] m Blount

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) from former Governor William Blount (1790-1795) dated March 30, 1796. This letter proposes cutting a road through the mountains through Warm Springs. The enclosed papers that originally accompanied this letter are missing from the document.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Dec. 21, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Wm. Trousdale / David Graham

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 21, 1850 from David Graham to Tennessee governor, William Trousdale in Nashville. The purpose of the letter is to inform the governor of the selection of a slab of marble from Hawkins county, Tennessee for inclusion in the Washington monument in Washington, D.C.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1827 Aug. 17 [Tennessee, land survey for James S. Johnson] / J. Nelson

mods.abstract: This is a land survey dated August 17, 1827, written by J. Nelson. The document states the boundaries of a tract of land belonging to James S. Johnson along the Nolichucky River.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Mar. 17, South Harpeth, Tennessee [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / Ezra Holstead

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Ezra Holstead to Adam Fergusson, dated March 17, 1840. He writes responses to his last letter about her property. Holstead also requests that Fergusson visit him when he comes through the area on his way to Charlotte.

titleInfo.title: 1822 Jan. 9 [to] James Winchester, Cairo, Tennessee / William Martin

mods.abstract: This is a letter to General James Winchester from Colonel William Martin, dated January 9, 1822. Martin writes mostly about the current political situation. He mentions France, the economy, and Congress. Martin is disappointed with the lack of progress Tennessee is making. He hopes that reforms will be attempted, but worries that the effort would be futile.

titleInfo.title: [Military Order] 1827 May 19, [to] Gen[era]l John Coffee / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a military order from Andrew Jackson allowing General John Coffee to deliver to Edmund Winston a bond due by Colonel Anthony Winston for the sum one thousand, sixty six dollars and two third cents.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] Jul. 10, 1796, Suffolk, VA [to] William Blount, Knoxville, Ten[n]essee / H. Allmand

mods.abstract: This is a letter from H. Allmand to William Blount, dated July 10, 1796. Allmand is in the mercantile business. He is writing to request information that will help him decide whether or not he will move with his family and his business to Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Apr. 22, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Washington County Sheriff / James Jones

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 22, 1845 from the governor of Tennessee, James Jones to the sheriff of Washington County, located in Northeast Tennessee. The purpose of the letter is to urge the sheriff to fulfill his duty, and obligation by carrying out the warrant issued for the arrest of William Bales, Nathaniel Brown, John Block, and Arless Collins, charged with highway robbery in North Carolina. In the letter, the governor says he is aware of a strong "feeling and excitement" created in Washington county by the case, however, it is not up to him, or the sheriff to pass judgement.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] [ca. 1840] Feb. 12 [to] James K. Polk / C. A. Harris

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to James Knox Polk by C. A. Harris on February 12 ca.1840. The letter requests that Polk give Harris the name of someone to attend a Medical Board. The name is needed so that the invitation can be sent to the individual in time for the Medical Board.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1838 Sept. 29, The United States to John Vann

mods.abstract: This document is a spoliation claim of John Vann concerning property taken from him by white man citizens of the United States. The property taken from him include both livestock and household items totaling $2237.87 in value.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Sep. 28, Warrenton, Virginia [to] D. Burford, Nashville, Tennessee / J. Saunders

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from J. Saunders in Warrenton, Virginia to D. Burford in Nashville, Tennessee. In the letter, Saunders mentions the conflict known as the "Bank War" between those associated with the second bank of the United States and president Andrew Jackson. Saunders also mentions their slave trade business.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt for Cherokee Annuity] 1812 July 13, Highwassee Garrison

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt dated July 13, 1812, acknowledging that the Cherokee Chiefs received an annuity payment from Return J. Meigs for nine thousand dollars. The document is signed by several Chiefs of the Cherokee Nation.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Nov. 1

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This document is the excerpt of the Monday November 1, 1824 session of court, during which several cases were heard. One of the cases involves Lewis Ross, who brought suit against two other men for harboring one of his slaves. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 Sept. 29, Columbia, Tennessee [to] John Overton / T. H.Cahal :

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to John Overton from T. H. Cahal regarding a tract of land registered to a Mr. Bradshaw.

titleInfo.title: Invoice of merchandize [sic] forwarded to that part of the Cherokee Nation removed to the River Arkansa[s], 1813 [?] Mar. 13, Arkansa[s] River / [signed by] Talontiskee ... [et al.]

mods.abstract: Receipt for goods totalling 629.50, bought and delivered by the United States to the Cherokees who removed to the Arkansas River area. Most of the goods were received on March 13, (1813 ?), and the receipt was signed by Talontiskee, Kannetoo, Kalawakskee, Wahachee, Oolanahhee and Horace Wallis.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Mar. 22 [to] Daniel Montgomery, Sumner County, Hendersonville, Tennessee / John T. Minter

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated March 22, 1847 from John T. Minter to Daniel Montgomery in Hendersonville, Tennessee. The purpose of the letter is to inform Montgomery of the death of Hugh McBride, and the circumstances that led to his demise. Minter also gives Montgomery some good news concerning the marriage of his daughter. Additionally, he includes a list of profitable items sold along with their prices. And finally, he offers news of his good financial prospects for the upcoming year.

titleInfo.title: [Testimony] 1843 Nov 1 [of] W[illia]m Henson regarding the Improvements of Rebecca Starritt

mods.abstract: This document is the sworn statement of William Henson, dated November 1, 1843. Mr. Henson swears that he knew an Indian named Grub who sold land in Union County Georgia to Rebecca Starritt, formerly Rebecca Henson. See also pa0252, pa0253, and pa0255.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1824 Oct. 2, [to] Alexander McCoy and Nathaniel Hicks / Charles R. Hicks

mods.abstract: This document, dated October 2, 1824, contains instructions given to Alexander McCoy and Nathaniel Hicks by Charles R. Hicks for dealing with Cherokee who claim compensation for improvements they made on their lands.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Oct. 5 [to] Mr. Alex[ander] D. Coffee, Florence, Ala[bama] / Andrew J[ackson] Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from Andrew Jackson Coffee to his brother Alexander D. Coffee, dated October 5, 1850. In the letter, Andrew discusses an amount of money owed him by Robert and William Warren and about some "Bounty Land" coming to the family for his father's service in the Creek War of 1812 and with Britain in 1814 and 1815.

titleInfo.title: Andrew Jackson Coffee Family Papers 1833-1903 MS 27
[Letter] 1847 April 14 [to] Capt[ain] William R. Caswell / E. C. Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from E. C. Caswell of Russelville, Tennessee to her husband William Richard Caswell, dated April 14, 1847. Mr. Caswell was part of the "volunteers" of Tennessee who fought in the Mexican-American War. Her letter expresses concern for him because she had just received news about the battle in Vera Cruz and had not heard from him in several weeks.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 May 4, Springfield, Te[nnessee] [to] Miss Lucy L. C. Bailey, Clarksville, Tenn[essee] / Ann Maria [Bryon]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Ann Maria Bryon to her cousin, Lucy Bailey, on May 4, 1838. In the letter, Ann shows excitement about taking care of her Cousin Kitty's house and overseeing all household activities while Kitty is sick. She is also excited about a trip that she plans to take across Tennessee and Virginia.
This document is a complaint, dated June 15, 1810, made by John Den of Rhea County, Tennessee against Richard Fen for trespassing.

titleInfo.title: 1843 Jun. 20, Pension Office [to] A[dam] Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / G[eorge] W[illia]m Crump

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated June 20, 1843, from George William Crump to Adam Fergusson, attorney and pension agent for Tennessee. Crump writes on the matter of the pension claim of Elizabeth Kelly and her husband William Kelly, who was a member of the revolutionary militiamen.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Aug. 25 [to] John Coffee Jr. / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated August 25, 1832 to John Coffee Jr. from Andrew Jackson requesting that Coffee pick up his watch from a repair shop and return it to him.

titleInfo.title: [Bill of Sale] 1814 May 30, Benjamin Powell to William B. Lenoir

mods.abstract: This document is a bill of sale by Benjamin Powell for three slaves in the amount of four-hundred dollars to William Lenoir. Lenoir was a Revolutionary War general and famous North Carolina politician of Fort Defiance, in Caldwell County. He later moved to Roane county, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Dec. 26, Louisvill[e] [KY] [to] Geo[rge] W[ashington] House, Nashville, Tenn[essee] / John A Burk

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John A. Burk to George W. House, dated December 26, 1842. He discusses patient care.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1798 Sept. 16, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] The Hon[ora]ble James Robertson, Lachlen [i.e. Lachlan] McIntosh, and James White / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document was written by Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) to James Robertson, Lachlan McIntosh and James White, dated September 16, 1798. This letter was written to inform the three men that the Cherokee are preparing to enter into a treaty with the United States commissioners. Sevier instructed the men to attend the treaty meeting and represent the interests of the state of Tennessee, particularly in regards to the settlers who have been removed from their plantations because they resided within Indian land boundaries.

titleInfo.title: 1837 Sep. 1, Henry County, Tennessee [to] T. C. Monroe / Joseph Ridgway

mods.abstract: This is a bill of sale dated September 1, 1837. It is between T. C. Monroe and Joseph Ridgway. Monroe will gain some slaves and land for covering a debt of Ridgway's. Along with the agreement are statements from the County Clerk and the Registrar for Henry County, dated September 9, 1837.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1826 Nov. 15, Valley Towns, [North Carolina to] James Barbour, Sec[retar]y of War / Evan Jones

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Evan Jones, a Baptist missionary at the Valley Towns (North Carolina) of the Cherokee Nation, to James Barbour, Secretary of War (1825-1828), dated November 15, 1826. Jones communicates information to Barbour relative to the progress of various industries in the Cherokee Nation, most notably the establishment of several mills. The improvements have been made under the direction of the Board of managers of the Baptist General Convention and also include a well attended school. Jones also remarks on the general "progress" of the Cherokees with respect to Christianity and the "civilized arts."

titleInfo.title: [Map] ca. 1815, Division of Washington County, Tennessee into election districts

mods.abstract: This document is a hand-drawn map circa 1815. It divides Washington County, Tennessee into seventeen election districts.

titleInfo.title: 1841 Mar. 24, Carthage, Tennessee [to unknown recipient] / [Adam Fergusson]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to an unknown recipient dated March 24, 1841. The author is probably Adam Fergusson. The letter is to an agent involved with treaties with Native nations. Fergusson is trying to find information on Mary Jameson, an American who, as a child was taken captive by a Seneca tribe in New York state. He wants to find out if she has any living descendants in order to ascertain whether her two brothers in Tennessee are her legal heirs. This is in relation to land given by the Seneca Nation in a treaty with the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Feb. 9, Hazlewood [to] Isaac B Williams, Paris, Tennessee / M. Finiman

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated February 9, 1839 from M. Finiman to her brother Isaac B Williams in Paris, Tennessee. It is a personal letter, detailing information on family members, and their current affairs.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Nov. 7 [to] Elizabeth Chester, Jackson Tennessee / Mary Jane Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 7, 1840 to Elizabeth Chester from her daughter Mary Jane Chester. Mary Jane describes her daily life at the Female Institute in Columbia, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 May 6, Nashville [to] Gen[era]l [Andrew] Jackson, President of U[nited] States / Felix Grundy

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 6, 1833, written by Felix Grundy to then-President Andrew Jackson. In the letter, Grundy asks Jackson a series of questions in order to clear up controversies over Grundy's conduct at the last session of Congress and his feelings toward the issues of nullification and secession.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1830 Jan. 13, Randolph T[X] [to] Rev. Joseph Brown, Near Columbia, Ten[nessee] / Joseph Porter Brown

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated Jan. 13, 1830 from Joseph Porter Brown to his father Joseph Brown. Joseph P. is explaining why he feels it necessary to leave Randolph. He is taking a trip down the Mississippi to find a situation in which he can make some money. He feels that he is ready to embark on a business career now that he is almost 22 years old. He also says that he is poor, and cannot make a living in Randolph.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of unexcavated structural ruins at Fort Southwest Point in Kingston, Tennessee, taken circa 1980s] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This photograph is of unexcavated structural ruins at Fort Southwest Point, located near the city of Kingston, in Roane County, Tennessee. The ruins show that the structures were composed of stacked mortared and unmortared limestone blocks and, occasionally, river rocks. Fort Southwest Point was established in 1792 as a blockhouse post for the territorial militia troops that were protecting white settlers from Indian acts of hostility. By 1797, the militia was replaced by Federal troops whose goals were to maintain peace with the Indians and protect their rights on the frontier. During the years between 1801-1807, the fort was established as the headquarters for the Cherokee Agency. In 1974, archaeological crews from the University of Tennessee unearthed portions of six fort building foundations, the remains of a massive stone wall, and many fort-period artifacts. A 1984 excavation of the site by the Department of Conservation and the City of Kingston located the sites of a total of thirteen buildings. These buildings include an officer's barracks, four blockhouses, and several buildings that are believed to have been barracks. A complementary excavation in 1986 revealed the location of two more buildings, bringing the total to fifteen buildings. The excavation also produced a more detailed examination of the palisade and stone wall enclosures, and uncovered several historic and prehistoric features. Additional excavations were conducted at Fort Southwest Point in the 1990s yielded new information as to the fort's original layout and functions, as well as the life ways of the people who occupied the fort. Fort Southwest Point was given to the city of Kingston by the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) and is now used as a historical and recreational areal.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Jun. 7, Washington [to] Capt[ain] John Donelson / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated June 7, 1829 from President Andrew Jackson to his brother-in-law Captain John Donelson. Jackson writes that he misses his recently deceased wife and wishes that he could retire to their home "The Hermitage" in Nashville, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1795 April, United States of America [to] Sheriff of Knox County, Territory South of the Ohio River / Cha[rle]s McClung

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated April 1795 from Charles McClung to the sheriff of Knox County. The letter states that John Scott is liable to James Gealey for a sum of money. The letter also states that the sheriff is responsible for collecting the money.

subject.topic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

titleInfo.title: [Excerpt of a letter] 1833 Jan. 27, West Point, N[ew] Y[ork] [to] Father / [George Welcker]

mods.abstract: The following document is an excerpt of a letter written by George Welcker at the West Point military academy to his father in Tennessee. In the letter, George updates his father on issues related to his schooling, including his position in recent class rankings and fellow Tennesseans at West Point.

titleInfo.title: 1814 Dec. 30, Chocktaw [Nation, to] James Winchester, Mobile [Alabama] / John McKee

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Colonel John McKee to Brigadier General James Winchester, dated December 30, 1814. McKee is the U.S. agent to the Choctaw Nation. McKee is reporting an order he received from General Jackson. McKee is to round up as many Choctaws as he can to help in the war against England.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Mar. 25 [to] Maj[or] A[ndrew] J[ackson] Donelson, Washington City / William Donelson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 25, 1835, by William Donelson to Andrew Jackson Donelson, nephew and personal secretary to President Andrew Jackson. William informs Andrew that his land purchase has been completed. He also asks about the possibility of selling two of his slaves. Enclosed with the letter is a diagram of the plot of land newly purchased.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Feb. 14, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Hon[ora]ble Mr. W[illia]m Blount, [Washington D.C.] / J[ohn] Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Tennessee Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) to former governor William Blount (1790-1796) in the US Congress, dated February 14, 1797. Sevier reported to Blount that the Cherokees had killed two people and wounded one, in retaliation for the murders of two Cherokees committed by Ned Mitchell and John Levingston. Sevier also discussed reports of the possibility of a war with the French and direct taxation, which may further excite the situation with the Native American tribes.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1834 May 16, Balt[im]o[re] [to] Major A[ndrew] J[ackson] Donaldson [i.e., Donelson], Washington / Jno [i.e., John] Patrick

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 16, 1834, from John Patrick of Baltimore to Andrew Jackson Donelson, confidential secretary to President Andrew Jackson. Patrick writes on behalf of two hat makers who wish to make the President a hat as a show of support for the recent decision to destroy the Bank of the United States. Patrick seeks to find out the size and description of a hat that would please the President.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Aug. 7 [to] Mrs. William R. Caswell / William Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated August 7, 1846 from Captain William Caswell to his wife in Jefferson County, Tennessee. Caswell served during the Mexican-American War and was part of the Tennessee volunteers. In this letter Caswell describes his trip down the Mississippi river and the islands along the coast of Mexico.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1834 May 19, Wilson C[oun]ty, Tenn[essee] [to] Mrs. Martha J. Reams / A. H. Reams

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by A. H. Reams to Martha J. Reams on May 19, 1834. In the letter, A. H. Reams describes to Martha how productive his business in Wilson County, Tennessee is, and instructs her to collect money from people who are indebted to him.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1827 Dec. 10, Frankfort [to] Andrew J. Donelson / Henry Banks

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 10, 1827 to Andrew Jackson Donelson from Henry Banks. The letter includes a printed Memorial by Banks and discusses the presidential election.

titleInfo.title: [Resolution] 1804 Apr 4, Resolutions of the National Council of Cherokee Chiefs at Eustinalee

mods.abstract: This document outlines various resolutions passed by the National Council of the Cherokee Chiefs between the dates of April 4-10, 1804. Resolutions include that the six Stands for Housed of Entertainment on the Cumberland Road be leased for five years to Thomas N. Clark, Sampson Williams, and Hugh Beatty, and that the rest shall be two hundred dollars for each stand. Also resolved, that the Moravian ministers residing near Mr. James Vann may continue in the Nation until December 25, 1804 and at that time will be reviewed to remain if they proceed in the education of said Nation's children. Further, the Nation agrees to lease a salt peter cave near the boundary line of Tellico and that said cave be leased for five years.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt for printing newspapers, signed by Return J. Meigs]

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt made to Captain James Carry, interpreter for Indian affairs, for six dollars due a printer for making newspapers. The receipt is signed by Return J. Meigs, Agent to the Cherokee Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1834 Oct. 25

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from Saturday October 25, 1834. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: 1821 July 14, Knoxville [TN] [to] James Park / C. H. White

mods.abstract: This is a letter from C. H. White to James Park, dated July 14, 1821. White writes that he and Park's daughter Nancy want to get married. This letter's purpose is to notify the Parks, and to give them a chance to let their wishes be known.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Oct. 24, Department of War [to William Carroll] Tennessee / James Barbour

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Governor William Carroll from James Barbour, dated October 25, 1825. Barbour is the Secretary of War. Barbour writes to ask Carroll to have the Civil Engineer of Tennessee meet Captain Poussia and Lieutenant Trimble, who will be surveying for the national road from Washington D.C. to New Orleans.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Feb. 7, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Captains Sparks & Wade / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a brief letter from governor John Sevier of Tennessee to Captains Sparks and Wade. The purpose of the letter is to instruct them to assist and console and offer favorable indulgences to the unfortunate plight of the Indians targeted for removal from their land to West of the Mississippi river.

titleInfo.title: [Invoice] 1844 Dec. 27, [for school book purchase of] Mr. W[illia]m B. Bell

mods.abstract: This is an invoice for books and other school supplies for William Bell. Payment was received for these supplies on December 27, 1844.

titleInfo.title: [Aerial photograph of Fort Loudoun during archaeological excavations, taken in 1976] / [by Karl Kutruff]

mods.abstract: This is an aerial photograph of Fort Loudoun during archaeological excavations by the University of Tennessee in 1976. Fort Loudoun was a British colonial military post on the lower Little Tennessee River that was occupied from 1756-1760. It was built in Overhill Cherokee territory in what is presently Monroe County and named for John Campbell, the Earl of Loudoun, who was commander-in-chief of British forces in the colonies. William G. De Brahm designed the fort, but abandoned the project because of disagreements he had with Capt. Demerre who commanded the militia troops and British regulars stationed at the post. Survival of this frontier outpost was dependent upon good relations with the Cherokees who supplied food for trade goods. During the French and Indian War, tensions began to mount between the Cherokees and the colonists. In March 1760 the Cherokees laid siege to the fort, cutting off supplies and forcing its surrender. Excavations of Fort Loudoun were conducted by the University of Tennessee from 1975-1977 in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator and Field Director, Carl Kutruff.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Oct. 19, Trenton, Tennessee [to] Isaac B Williams / James M Moore

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated October 19, 1849 from James M. Moore to Isaac B. Williams. In the letter, Moore consoles Williams over his defeat in an election while verbally chastising the political system that facilitated his demise. Moore denounces the corrupt, and secretive methods of the power brokers who control elections, and favors giving power to the people through democracy.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1805 Jul. 29, Blount County [to] John Sevier, Nashville, Tennessee / Colonel Jas Scott

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 29, 1805 from Colonel Scott to governor John Sevier of Nashville, Tennessee. The purpose of the letter is to ask assistance in a matter relating to an alleged complaint of stolen and damaged property sustained by a resident of Blount county by several Cherokee Indians.

titleInfo.title: 1844 May 15, Loudon County, Virginia [to] Andrew J. Donelson, Tennessee / John A. Carter

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John A. Carter to Andrew J. Donelson, dated May 15, 1844. Carter thanks Donelson for helping Betty and her child to Virginia. Carter asks Donelson if he is willing to buy a slave named Polly. In an addition to the letter that Donelson writes two years later, he states that he did buy Polly.

titleInfo.title: [School Record] 1842 March 11, [of] F[rancis Fogg] Foster [to] Jane M Foster

mods.abstract: This is the attendance record of Francis Fogg Foster from the English Classical and Mathematical Seminary. It is dated March 11, 1842, and is addressed to Jane M. Foster.

titleInfo.title: Civilization of the Cherokees : [Excerpt] from an address of Honorable Edward Everett, representative in Congress from Massachusetts, delivered in the House of Representatives, 1830 May 19

mods.abstract: This document is a typed excerpt from a speech delivered by Edward Everett, a Senator from Massachusetts, on the floor of the U.S. House of Representatives on May 19, 1830. The speech was printed in the Congressional Debates, Vol. VI, pt. 2, and pertains to the proposed removal of the Southeastern Indians to a territory west of the Mississippi River. The typed excerpt presented here is from a portion of Everett's speech in which he describes the current conditions of the Cherokee people by enumerating statistics relative to population and property. This excerpt contains several minor variations from Everett's original wording.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1814 May 6 [to] Col. Return J. Meigs / Charles Hicks

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated May 6, 1814 from Cherokee leader Charles Hicks to Colonel Return J. Meigs concerning a number of topics including the requesting of supplies and corn for food.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Apr. 20, Nashville, Tenn[essee] [to] Maj[or] W. J. Whitthorne, Shelbyville, Tenn[essee] / S[amuel] H. Laughlin

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated April 20, 1844, from Samuel Laughlin to Major W. J. Whitthorne in Shelbyville, Tennessee. In the letter, Laughlin discusses both national and state politics. He updates Whitthorne on election results from around the country, and he warns that a fierce battle must be fought to prevail against the Whigs in upcoming elections. Laughlin, an ardent supporter of James K. Polk, was also one of the "Immortal Thirteen" who, fearing the election of a Whig, refused to meet with the Tennessee House to elect a representative to the U.S. Senate, leaving Tennessee unrepresented in the Senate for 1841-1843.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Feb. 9, Woodbery [Woodbury], [Tennessee] [to] Miss Martha Burger / Susan Burger

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Susan Burger to her cousin, Martha Burger, on February 9, 1844. In the letter, Susan tells Martha what subjects she is studying in school and recommends that she attend school also.

titleInfo.title: 1844 Jan. 17, Nashville, Tennessee / Thos. Pritcher [et al]

mods.abstract: This is a letter from the Central State Corresponding Committee dated January 17, 1844. It is to an unknown recipient. The committee represents the Democratic Convention of Tennessee. They express outrage over the fact that Martin Van Buren did not win the presidential election of 1840, and that he is a favorite for the current nomination. The committee writes that they want James K. Polk to run for Vice-President. A copy of the address stating this decision is included.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1806 Dec. 15, Newbury [Massachussets, to] Charles Coffin, Greeneville, Tennessee / L[eonard] Woods

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 15, 1806, from Leonard Woods to the Reverend Charles Coffin. Woods writes in great detail on various religious teachings.

titleInfo.title: [Invitation to Whig convention] 1840 Jul. 4, Nashville, Tennessee [to] I.L. Tellinghurt, Washington City / L.D. Morgan, et al

mods.abstract: This document is an invitation to I.L. Tellinghurt, from a group known as the "union of the Whigs for the sake of the Union," to a convention to be held in Nashville, Tennessee, on August 17, 1840, for the promotion of retrenchment and reform in the southern, and western states of the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1813 Jun. 11, Washington [to] Colonel G.W. Sevier, Knoxville, Tennessee / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 11, 1813 from John Sevier to Colonel George Washington Sevier. He recounts news of a naval battle between the British frigate Shannon and the United States frigate Cheasapeake, and fears the Cheasapeake may have been taken. The USS Cheasapeake was captured by the HMS Shannon on June 1, 1813, just off Boston Harbor.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Apr., Dixons Spring, [Tennessee] [to] Miss Sarah Donoho / Ja[me]s L. Alexander

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by James L. Alexander to Miss Sarah Donoho in April 1845. In the letter, Alexander expresses his love and respect for Miss Donoho and hopes that she feels the same way about him.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Dec. 16, Knoxville [to] Mr. V A McBee, East Tennessee College / David Campbell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 16, 1836, written by David Campbell to Mr. V. A. McBee, corresponding secretary of East Tennessee College (currently the University of Tennessee). Campbell writes to accept his nomination as honorary member of the Chi Delta Literary Society.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1802 Nov. 12, Nashville [to] Colo[nel] R J Meggs [i.e., Meigs] / James Robertson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 12, 1802, written by James Robertson to Cherokee agent Return J. Meigs. Robertson describes a claim in which a Cherokee named Culsetche had his horse stolen from a White person. Both Robertson and James Jones attest to the credibility of the claim.

titleInfo.title: Survey report containing Path Killer's plat and certificate, 1820 Aug. 15, Tennessee / [signed by] David Taylor ... [et al.]

mods.abstract: Survey report of the Cherokee leader Path Killer's plat and certificate of 640 acres dated August 15, 1820. The surveyors and commissioners mark the property boundary according to the Treaty of the Cherokee Agency, 1817 and the Treaty of Washington, 1819. Path Killer had filed a claim at the Cherokee Agency on April 14, 1819.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1816 Mar. 10, Williamson County, Tennessee [to] Joseph McMinn, Nashville, Tennessee / Thomas Ridley

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 10, 1816 from Thomas Ridley, the Sheriff of Williamson County, Tennessee to the governor of the state, Joseph McMinn. The subject of the letter is Aaron Gladden, a convicted horse thief who escaped from jail after it burned. Gladden is described by the Sheriff as a man of exceedingly bad character, and asks the governor whether or not a reward for his arrest is warranted.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1822 Mar. 25, Hermitage [to] Captain Richard K. Call, Pensacola, West Florida / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 25, 1822 from Andrew Jackson to Captain Richard K. Call. Jackson writes of his resignation from the army and rumors of his possible impeachment.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1792 Nov. 14, Natchez [to] [Governor] Manuel Gayoso de Lemos / Daniel Clark

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated November 14, 1792, from the representatives of Daniel Clark and Ebenezer Rees to Manuel Gayoso de Lemos, the Spanish governor of the district of Natchez and later governor of Louisiana. The two American traders wrote to inform Lemos of a debt that is owed to them by Thomas Wilkins.

This document is a letter, whose author is unidentified, addressed to Mary C. Porter on May 2, 1846. The author is most likely someone from Mary's immediate family, as the letter discusses social and family events such as Mary's brother Edward's illness, Mary joining a church, his school, and a new boat called the 'Gray Eagle'.

titleInfo.title: [Legal license] 1841 Mar. 27 [to] Jacob Chriesman / Lemuel Bell McConnico

mods.abstract: This document is a legal license issued to Jacob Chriesman by county court clerk Lemuel Bell McConnico on March 27, 1841. The legal license shows that Chriesman is allowed to keep a Stallion in the county and has paid the property taxes for the stallion.

titleInfo.title: [Drawing of mid-18th century Cherokee segmented domestic structure] / [by Thomas Whyte]

mods.abstract: This is a drawing of a Cherokee segmented domestic structure from the mid-18th century based on archaeological excavations by the University of Tennessee at Overhill Cherokee sites on the lower Little Tennessee River Valley. Excavations of Overhill Cherokee villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project. Excavations continued until 1983, and laboratory studies and report preparation continued until 1987. The excavations were conducted in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River Valley, in eastern Tennessee, by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA).

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: 1815 Feb. 26, St. Stephens [Alabama, to] James Winchester, Mobile [Alabama] / Geo[rge] S[trother] Gaines

mods.abstract: This is a letter from George Strother Gaines to Brigadier General James Winchester, dated February 26, 1815. Gaines is in charge of the Choctaw agency. Gaines expresses concern that the British are lying about their desire to end the war. He also writes that his health is not good.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1847 Feb. 20 [to] John Swan / [signed by] Hewhitt & Gant

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt dated February 20, 1847 written by Hewhitt & Gant in the amount of fifty-two dollars and seventy eight cents as the result of a judgement in the case of Luke Lea v. John Swan.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1824 Jan. 15, Nashville, Tennessee [to] J. G. M. Ramsey, Mecklenburg / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This is a letter, dated January 15, 1824 from Andrew Jackson to J. M. G. Ramsey thanking him for a print commemorative of the Declaration of Independence from a convention held in Mecklenburg in 1775.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Aug.2, Cairo, Tennessee [to] John C. Calhoun / James Winchester

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated August 2, 1819 from James Winchester to the secretary of war, John C. Calhoun. Winchester describes the marking of the Southern boundary of the state of Tennessee, as agreed in a treaty with the Chickasaw Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1821 May 1 [to] Sheriff of Rhea County, Tennessee / [witnessed by] Daniel Rawlings

mods.abstract: This document is a legal summons witnessed by Daniel Rawlings to the Sheriff of Rhea County, Tennessee on May 1, 1821. The summons orders the sheriff to appear at the court house on May 8, 1821 in Rhea County to testify in a case between the state of Tennessee and a man named Laban Stuart.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1808 Mar. 5, Oosunaleh [to] Return J. Meigs, Indian agent, War Department / Cherokee Chiefs

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to Return J. Meigs, agent to the Cherokee Indians, from the Cherokee Chiefs. The Chiefs complain that the government is allowing too many "white people" to move onto Cherokee land.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of fragment of Cherokee vessel with check stamp design, Chota, taken in 1969] / [by George Fielder]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a fragment of a Cherokee clay pot with a check stamp design. It was recovered in Chota by the University of Tennessee in 1969. Chota was recognized by Europeans as well as other Indians for its powerful social and economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. Excavations were conducted in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The university worked under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, J. Worth Greene.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Nov. 2

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is the excerpt from the Tuesday November 2, 1824 session of court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 Feb. 3, Paris [to] Governor Sam Houston, Nashville, Tennessee / G. W. Terrill

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to Governor Sam Houston of Tennessee from G. W. Terrill dated February 3, 1828. Terrill discusses various newspaper articles and the upcoming Gubernatorial election.

titleInfo.title: [Deposition] 1795 Jun. 2, Knox County Court / [witnessed by] G. Roulstone

mods.abstract: This document is a deposition in a case where John Allen Smith Carrington assaulted George Martins after a verbal dispute.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 May 23, Athens, Tennessee [to] William Hall, Nashville, Tennessee / J.C. Mitchell

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated May 23, 1829 from J.C. Mitchell to Tennessee governor William Hall. In the letter, Mitchell writes of the circumstances surrounding the previous governor, Sam Houston after his humiliating marriage scandal, and flight from Nashville dressed in disguise. Mitchell assumed the governorship in the month prior to the writing of this letter, he served through October.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Sep. 13, Choctaw Nation, Pigeon Roost [to] Reverend W. Elias Cornelius, Andover, Mass[achusetts] / David Folsom

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated September 13, 1819, from David Folsom of the Choctaw Nation to Reverend Elias Cornelius in Andover, MA. Folsom writes in reference to an inquiries made by the United States government about a possible exchange of money for land within the Choctaw Nation. Folsom also describes plans to build a new missionary school in Yello Busha. At the close of the document, the obituary of David Folsom is attached. Folsom fought with the US army against the Creeks during the Creek War and he served as a chief of the Choctaw Nation from 1826 to 1830. He was one of the Choctaw leaders responsible for the treaty which removed the Choctaw Nation to Oklahoma.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1808 March 6, Federal Bottoms, [to] Return J. Meigs, Highwassee / William P. Anderson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to Return J. Meigs, agent of the War department from William P. Anderson. Anderson asks that Meigs help a Mr. Barclay with a business enterprise in Cherokee territory.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of a carved steatite (soapstone) pipe excavated at the former site of the mid-18th century Cherokee town of Chota, taken in 1969] / [by George Fielder]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a mid-18th century Cherokee carved steatite (soapstone) pipe that was excavated at the site of Chota in 1969. Chota was recognized by Native Americans and European settlers as a powerful social and economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. Excavations of Chota and other Overhill villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, J. Worth Greene.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Feb. 17, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Captains Sparks Wade / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Governor John Sevier to Captains Sparks and Wade, dated February 17, 1797. Sevier wrote this letter in regards to a conference the captains were preparing to hold with the settlers living within Indian lands. Sevier pleaded with Sparks and Wade to show compassion and tenderness towards those people, for they would soon be forced to relocate.

titleInfo.title: 1850 Jul. 19, Nashville [Tennessee] [to] Jo[h]n / R. H. McEwen

mods.abstract: This is a letter from R. H. McEwen to his son John, dated July 19, 1850. McEwen reports that the cholera epidemic is abating. He tells John that he should be taking good care of himself for his child, friends and family.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Nov. 25, Hartsville, [Tennessee] [to] Doctor Ja[me]s L. Alexander / D. W. Mentto

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by D. W. Mentto to Doctor James L. Alexander on November 25, 1838. In the letter, Mentto expresses his relief that Transylvania College, in Lexington, Kentucky, will be able to sustain itself with the help of several donors. He mentions several deaths, births, and marriages of people that are acquaintances of Alexander's. He concludes the letter by naming several of the candidates running for the lower house seats in the government.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1818 Feb. 15, Dixon Springs, Tennessee [to] Winchester and Cage, Cairo, Tennessee / William Martin

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated February 15, 1818 from William Martin in Dixon Springs, Tennessee to Winchester & Cage in Cairo, Tennessee. The letter covers several subjects including, importantly, remarks concerning a decision to send a branch of the United States bank to Nashville.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1802 Apr. 28, [to] Colo[nel] Henry McKinney, Jackson County, [Tennessee] / Archibald Roane

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Archibald Roane, Governor of Tennessee (1801-1803), to Colonel Henry McKinney, in Jackson County (Tennessee), dated April 28, 1802. Roane informs McKinney that he has information regarding the recent depredations committed by inhabitants of Jackson County and is fearful of reprisal by the Indians in the area. He indicates his intention to placate the Indians, but urges McKinney to seek criminal charges against the perpetrators, despite any deals they may have made to avoid justice. He refers to an enclosure from Mr. B. Blackburn that is no longer attached. Another letter from Roane relative to this issue also appears in the Southeastern Native American Documents Database as ch018.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1801 May 4, Tennessee, Affidavit of Samuel Barton / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This is the affidavit of Samuel Barton dated May 4, 1801. It is witnessed and signed by Andrew Jackson who also writes a petition for writs of Certiorari and Supersedeas on behalf of Barton. Barton accuses Andrew McCasland of wrongfully claiming some of his land while Barton was being held in a Mero prison, for which Barton also blames Moses Akels. Barton also accuses William Allen of impersonating a deputy sheriff.

titleInfo.title: Letter from the Secretary of War transmitting a list of persons entitled to reservations under the treaty with the Cherokees of the 27th February, 1819, [et c.], 1828, Washington

mods.abstract: Congressional publication containing a letter dated January 23, 1828 from James Barbour, Secretary of War, to the Speaker of the House concerning Cherokee reservations provided for in the Treaty of Washington, 1819. Barbour transmits the communication from Thomas L. McKenney, a clerk in the Office of Indian Affairs, along with a list of reservees, indicating whether they are entitled to fee simple or life only reservations. One hundred and seven are life only reservations and 39 are fee simple. The 23 reservations that exist within the bounds of Georgia have been purchased for that state through a provision of Congress.

titleInfo.title: 1844 Nov. 21 [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / R. M. Boyen

mods.abstract: This is a letter from R. M. Boyen to A. Fergusson, dated November 21, 1844. Boyen wants to help convert Whigs to the Democratic party. He suggests they hand out newspapers personally to Whigs, that they can read quietly at home.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1820 Nov. 23, Catawba [to] Joseph McMinn / William Terry

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 23, 1820 from William Terry to the governor of Tennessee, Joseph McMinn. The subject of the letter is a survey of the Coral River conducted by Terry regarding its navigation.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Nov. 19, Watertown [to] Ethel H. Porter, Raleigh, Tennessee / H. Scoville

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 19, 1837 to Ethel H. Porter of Raleigh, Tennessee, from H. Scoville. Scoville catches Porter up on family matters and tells him of the death of many relatives due to whooping cough and typhus fever.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Nov. 21, Hermitage [to] Andrew Jackson Donelson, West Point, New York / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from Andrew Jackson to his nephew Andrew Jackson Donelson on November 21, 1819. In the letter, Jackson inquires about Donelson's studies and his health. He asks Donelson to write more often and to express his views and opinions with Jackson on different subjects.

This is a letter dated July 16, 1850, from Mary House to her husband George House. She writes that the cholera is starting to subside in town, and who has died from it. She reports of a cousin who is badly sick, whom she wants to accompany herself, George and their daughter on a trip. She tells George that she never wants him to travel again, and to that end, she wants him to stay gone on this trip until he is completely finished, no matter how long it takes. Their daughter Sallie adds a few lines.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Feb. 20 [to] Col[onel] George Wilson, Nashville, Tennessee / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 20, 1825 from Andrew Jackson to Colonel George Wilson regarding the recent Presidential election. Jackson charges that President John Quincy Adams and Henry Clay made a corrupt bargain that resulted in Clay being offered the position of Secretary of State.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt for taxes] 1799, John Hillsman, Grainger County, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt dated in the year 1799 for the return of sixty-eight thousand, two-hundred acres of land in Grainger county for the payment of taxes thereon. It is signed by John Hillsman.

titleInfo.title: [Letter], 1819 Sept. 3, Department of War to Rev[erend] Samuel Worcester, Sec[retar]y of the Amer[ican] Board of Commissioners for For[eig]n Missions / J[ohn] C. Calhoun

mods.abstract: Copy of a letter wherein John C. Calhoun, Secretary of War, writes to Reverend Samuel Worcester, Corresponding Secretary of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions and missionary to the Cherokees, about an enclosed letter pertaining to the views of President Monroe, September 3, 1819. The enclosed letter appears in the Southeastern Native American Documents Database as ch042

titleInfo.title: [Petition] 1839 Oct. 21, Benton, Tennessee [to] Legislature, Nashville, Tennessee / Samuel Ewing

mods.abstract: This document, dated October 21, 1839, is a petition, written by the residents of Benton, Tennessee in Polk County. The petition requests that the Tennessee General Assembly change the law regarding the sale of "ardent spirits." The law at that time limited retail sales to one quart and the parties involved requested the amount to be changed to one gallon.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1808 Jul. 7, Talassee [Alabama, to] Benjamin Hawkins / Hopohuilthlu Miceo

mods.abstract: This is a copy of a letter to Colonel Benjamin Hawkins from the Creek Chief Hopohuilthlu Miceo, dated July 7, 1808. Hawkins is the U.S.'s Agent for Indian Affairs south of the Ohio River. Miceo is writing in regards to an attack by some Creeks on their American neighbors. Miceo wants Hawkins to assure President Jefferson that the Creeks will find out and punish the guilty parties.

This is a letter from Mary House to her husband George House, dated June 24, 1850. She tells him of a disturbing dream she had recently, where many of her loved one's were sick, dead or missing. She writes of the family and friends that she has been visiting and corresponding with. She mentions that cholera has come to Nashville. Their daughter Sallie adds a few lines about her kittens.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1809 Aug. 6, Knoxville [to] Return J. Meigs, Highwassee / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written in 1809 by John Sevier to Return J. Meigs regarding a postponed meeting with various Indian Chiefs.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1836 Dec. 15, [to] Cass County, Georgia / Spencer Jarnagin

mods.abstract: This note, dated December 15, 1836, concerns payment of legal fees for services rendered in the courts of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Jul. 9, Tallahassee [to Andrew Jackson Donelson, Washington D.C.] / Dan[ie]l S. Donelson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 9, 1835, from Daniel S. Donelson in Tallahassee, FL to his brother Andrew Jackson Donelson, who was at the time serving as personal secretary to their uncle President Andrew Jackson. Daniel writes primarily about his struggles farming in Florida and about the incessant sickness and death in the region.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Oct. 31

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Monday October 31, 1825 session of court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.
This is a letter written on Christmas eve, 1850 from Thomas Moore to James Moore King. Moore tells King of his crop yield and sales prices.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Deposition of Andrew Morrison] 1822 Sep. 28, Nashville, Tennessee, [to] the Clerk of Brackenridge Circuit Court, Hardinsburgh, Kentucky

mods.abstract: This document is a deposition given in Nashville, Tennessee for a trial that was held in Hardinsburgh, Kentucky. Andrew Morrison gave the deposition on behalf of the defendants. His deposition was dated September 28, 1822, and the subject was the condition of the Ohio River, the month of October 1817.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Feb. 24, Washington [D.C., to] County Court Clerk of Jefferson County, Tenn[essee] / W[illia]m B. Carter

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated February 24, 1837 from William B. Carter to the clerk of the county court of Jefferson County. Carter writes that he is sending the clerk a copy of proceedings of the House of Representatives.

titleInfo.title: 1815 Jan. 3, New Orleans [Louisiana, to] Ja[me]s Winchester, Mobile [Alabama] / W[illia]m Carroll

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Major General William Carroll to Brigadier General James Winchester, dated January 3, 1815. Carroll writes to inform Winchester that he has his baggage, but will be unable to send it to Winchester for awhile. Carroll updates Winchester on the progress of General Andrew Jackson's battles. He also mentions some British commanders that they are up against.

titleInfo.title: Dec. 22, 1779, Fort Patrick Henry, Holston River / John Donelson

mods.abstract: This is the Journal kept by John Donelson on his trip from Fort Patrick Henry to French Salt Springs which he also refers to as the Big Salt Lick. He travels down the Holston, French Broad, Clinch, Tennessee, and Cumberland Rivers. The trip starts on December 22, 1779 and is completed on April 24, 1780. Donelson's boat is joined early in the voyage by several others going along the same route. Donelson writes about an accident they have on the French Broad river in February. One of the other vessels sinks. A slave dies on the Clinch river in March from severe frost bite. Later that month the travellers have trouble with the Chickamaugas, who have villages down the south side of the Tennessee River. Captain Blackemore's boat, which had been quarantined from the others due to small pox, is attacked by these natives, and many people are killed or captured. Donelson writes about the flotilla trying to navigate the Whirl, a particularly dangerous place on the Tennessee River near Chattanooga. There, they are attacked again by the Chickamaugas. One family named Jennings is left behind when their boat becomes trapped in the Whirl, but they are able to eventually catch up to the others. Donelson writes about trouble they have going through the Muscle Shoals in mid-March. On the Cumberland River they begin to have food shortages and are forced to hunt buffalo to survive. When they arrive in Big Salt Lick, they meet Captain Robertson and company. The group decides to stay temporarily in some log cabins they find.

titleInfo.title: Letter, 1839 July 13, Illinois Camp Ground to Brev[e]t Brig[adie]r Gen[era]l M[atthew] Arbuckle / George Lowrey ... [et al.]

mods.abstract: Copy of a letter dated July 13, 1839 from members of the Cherokee Convention to General Matthew Arbuckle regarding Arbuckle's suspicions about the nature of the convention. Arbuckle is assured by the members of the convention that they were called to assemble by the Cherokee people and that there is no cause for concern among any group of Cherokees or others. The undersigned include George Lowrey, George Guess (Sequoyah), John Ross and many others.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Jan. 30, City of Washington [to] Rachel Jackson, near Nashville, Tennessee / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Andrew Jackson to his wife Rachel on January 30, 1819. In the letter, Jackson discusses the political atmosphere surrounding him in Washington and that he has both allies and opponents in the government.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt for payment to] Long Beard, 1809 Dec. 18, Highwassee [i.e., Hiwassee, Tennessee] Garrison

mods.abstract: This is a receipt for payment of one hundred dollars to a Cherokee man named Long Beard, by the United States agent to the Cherokees, Return J. Meigs. The sum was paid as compensation for the murder of Long Beard's son Blackbird by a white man in Cherokee territory in exchange for Long Beard's promise that he and his family would not seek retribution. The marks of several Cherokee chiefs, including The Ridge, also appear on the document, dated December 18, 1809.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Oct. 25

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Monday October 25, 1824 session of court, during which two cases involving debt pleas were heard. It also lists the names of the judges and jurors for this session. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Dec. 30 War Department [to] Richard Smith Esq[uire] / J. C. Spencer

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 30, 1842 from the War department regarding dividends due to various Indian tribes under the United States Treasury Loan of 1841.

titleInfo.title: [Pay warrant for the protection of the frontier] 1794 / [signed by] William Blount

mods.abstract: This document is a pay warrant, dated December 3, 1794 and signed by Governor William Blount. William Rickard, pay master, received three hundred and thirty nine dollars to pay troops under Captain Thomas Murray for protecting the frontier from October 22, 1793 to November 22, 1793.

subject.geographic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

titleInfo.title: Pay warrant for the protection of the frontier
[Letter] 1835 Nov. 23 [to] Charles F. Welcker, Talladega, Ala[bama] / Richard Grantham

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 23, 1835 to Charles F. Welcker from Richard Grantham regarding various business deals Grantham is working on for Welcker.

titleInfo.title: [License] 1821 Feb. 7 [to] Knox county ministers of the gospel and Justices of the peace / Charles McClung

mods.abstract: This is an official document of licensure granting any regular minister of the gospel or justice of the peae in Knox county, Tennessee the authority to marry Betty Davis and William McMillan. This power is granted by Charles McClung, Clerk of the Court of Pleas and Quarter Sessions of Knox county.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1815 Nov. 30, Return J. Meigs and John Ross to the United States

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for tobacco for the Cherokee Indians paid to the United States by Return J. Meigs, agent to the Cherokee and John Ross, a Cherokee Chief

titleInfo.title: 1839 Jan. 22, New Orleans, Louisiana [to] Sam[ue]l J. Peters / Edmund P. Gaines

mods.abstract: This is a letter from General Edmund Pendleton Gaines to Samuel J. Peters, President of the Chamber of Commerce, dated January 22, 1839. Gaines is writing in response to a recent report by the Chamber on improving navigation of the Mississippi River. Gaines describes in great detail the mannerisms of the Mississippi River and how it differs from other rivers, especially concerning formation of alluvial lands. Gaines writes how important the river is in relation to national defence, commerce, and agriculture. Gaines also includes his opinions on improving national defence in relation to the use of railroads, and waterways. Accompanying Gaines' letter is a note dated April 6, 1839 from C. W. Dreschler, who is forwarding the letter to Tennessee Governor Newton Cannon per Gaines' request. Gaines hopes that the Governor will consider the views expressed in his letter.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Jan. 2, Memphis [to] Henry Kirtland, Poland, Trumbull Co[unty], Ohio / J B Kirtland

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated January 2, 1849, written by J. B. Kirtland in Memphis to his cousin Henry Kirtland in Ohio. J. B. writes in response to Henry's enquiries regarding land in Tennessee and Mississippi.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1825 Oct. 25

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. The excerpt is from the Tuesday October 25, 1825 session of court, in which several cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

This is a letter to Mr. Woods (probably James Woods) dated May 2, 1840 from an unknown author at Marion College in Missouri. The author talks of his declining health and the debts he owes to Woods and others, mostly due to failed business endeavors. He writes that he wants to visit Nashville. Included is a partial recipe for ointment.

Copy of a letter dated October 20, 1823 from the Cherokee Council to (U.S. Commissioners Duncan G. Campbell and James Meriwether ?) in response to the commissioners' request for negotiation of further land cessions. The Council explains that the Cherokee government will not make anymore cessions of land and offers several arguments for this position.

titleInfo.title: 1838 Mar. 30, Nashville [Tennessee, to] Joel R. Poinsett / N[ewton] Cannon

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor Newton Cannon to the Secretary of War, Joel R. Poinsett. It is dated March 20, 1838. Cannon is assuring Poinsett that he will not allow the local citizens to protest the removal of the Cherokee.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1849 Mar. 15, Davidson County, Tennessee, [to] Washington Institute Trustees / John R. Wilson

mods.abstract: This is a legal document dated March 15, 1849, in which John R. Wilson is donating some land to be used for a school and church, named the Washington Institute. He adds the condition that he be allowed water access for his livestock and that he be given free tuition for one student each session. He also adds another stipulation--that he be able to appoint his successor to the board of trustees.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Oct. 7 [to] Mary Jane Chester, Columbia Tennessee / Robert Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 7, 1840 from Robert Chester to his daughter Mary Jane, who attended a female academy in Columbia Tennessee. Chester discusses family affairs and tells her that Andrew Jackson was at their house for dinner when her last letter arrived.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1803 Oct. 9, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] John Sevier / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 9, 1803 from Andrew Jackson challenging John Sevier to a duel, either in Knoxville, Tennessee or at the Indian boundary. Jackson demands reparation for the insults that Sevier inflicted on Jackson's wife Rachel.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 Dec. 8, Bolivar? [to] Col[onel] Joseph Brown, Cave Spring, Maury County, Tenn[essee] / J[ospeh] Porter Brown

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated December 8, 1841 to Colonel Joseph Brown from his son Joseph Porter Brown. His son relates a few details of a trip he and his family are on.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Nov. 20 Memphis, [to] Rhea & McCrabb / Charles S. Barth

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to two merchants named Rhea & McCrabb from a businessman named Charles Barth on November 20, 1825. In the letter, Barth discusses his business travels throughout Tennessee en route to New Orleans. He also gives Rhea & McCrabb permission to take care of his affairs at home in Athens, Tennessee while he is away.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Sep. 2, Batchelors [Bachelors] Hall Tenn[essee] [to] Mr. James L. Alexander / N. B. Hamilton

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by N. B. Hamilton to his cousin, James L. Alexander, on September 2, 1838. In the letter, Hamilton tells Alexander about a dinner he went to in Murfreesboro, Tennessee, where James K. Polk was giving a speech. He says that there were many Whigs at the dinner. His overall impression of Polk was lessened when he heard the speech and saw his actions with the Whigs at the dinner. Hamilton states that there are country lawyers that give better speeches than Polk.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Aug. 7, Frankfort, [Kentucky] [to] E. H. Foster / J. J. Crittenden

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by J. J. Crittenden to E. H. Foster on August 7, 1845. In the letter, Crittenden wishes good luck to Foster who is running for Governor of Tennessee.
