He also mentions the meeting he had with Governor Jones of Kentucky. Crittenden concludes by predicting that the number of Whig Representatives in Congress will increase over time.

titleInfo.title: 1846 Feb. 20, Carthage, Tennessee [to] Mr. [and] Mrs. Mc Nabb, Canada / Adam Fergusson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Adam Fergusson to Mr. and Mrs. Mc Nabb, dated February 20, 1846. Fergusson is writing because he has not heard from the Mc Nabbs in a while. Fergusson gives a glowing report of current economic conditions, owing them to James K. Polk's administration. He writes about seeing their son, Dugald C. and his uncle on their trip. Fergusson reports helping them financially on their promise of reimbursement. He writes that he has still not received any news or money from them. Fergusson asks Mc Nabb to repay him, and to reply to the letter immediately.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1812 Oct. 19 State of Tennessee versus Thomas Miller

mods.abstract: This is a legal document dated October 19, 1812 regarding a monetary forgery case in Washington county, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1798 Dec., Knoxville [Tennessee, to] David Henley / Sampson Williams

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Sampson Williams to Colonel David Henley, dated December 1798. Williams is writing to inform Henley that some Cherokees have been accused of stealing horses, and some other natives have been accused of killing a cow. Williams writes that the Cherokees may be arrested and taken to Nashville.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Mar. 22, [to] William Donelson / Andrew Jackson, Washington, D.C.

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 22, 1829 from Andrew Jackson to William Donelson. The subject of the letter is Jackson's son Andrew Jackson Hutchings, who came under Jackson's supervision after the death of his father John Hutchings. The tone of the letter is one of regret at Hutchings' poor performance as a student, and the resignation that he will not be a classical scholar, but may be more aptly suited to life as a farmer.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1805 Aug. 12, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Colonel Jonathan Meigs, Department of War / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated August 12, 1805 from John Sevier of Tennessee to Colonel Jonathan Meigs at the Department of War. Sevier's brief letter to Meigs informs of an enclosed letter by Colonel Scott describing a massacre involving Cherokee Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1837 Feb. between Spencer Jarnagin and the Cherokee Nation East / Spencer Jarnagin

mods.abstract: This is a legal document between the Cherokee Nation East and Spencer Jarnagin who served as attorney for them from 1820 to 1837. The document shows that the Cherokee Nation paid Mr. Jarnagin two hundred and fifty dollars per year for a total of four thousand dollars. The document then has a written statement from Mr. Jarnagin disputing the correctness of the amount paid to him.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Aug. 31, [to] David Henley, Agent of War / William Richards :

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated August 31, 1797 from Captain William Richards to David Henley, Agent of War. Richards requests money to purchase a wagon to carry supplies for himself and his men.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1830 Apr. 20, Washington City [to] James Park, Knoxville, East Tennessee / Luke Lea

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated April 20, 1830 from Luke Lea to James Park. Lee primarily addresses personal correspondence with Park; however, much of the letter addresses congressional business

titleInfo.title: 1830 Oct. 24, Louisville [KY] [to] John Overton, Nashville, Tennessee / Fort[unatus] Cosby Sr.

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated October 24, 1830, from Fortunatus Cosby Sr. to his friend John Overton. Cosby is asking Overton to help his son William gain entrance to West Point. He is also requesting that Overton help his grandson Robert get into the navy.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Sep. 15 [to] E. H. Porter, Shelby County, Tennessee / Ja[me]s Stafford

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to E. H. Porter of Memphis Tennessee from James Stafford regarding possible business ventures in the state of Illinois.

This is a letter to John Cocke dated December 23, 1828. The writer is in favor of the US developing a permanent navy. The writer's opinion is that the people in a republican country (as far as keeping their personal freedoms) are safer because of their navy than they would be from an army. He is also concerned about protecting valuable ports from blockade.

titleInfo.title: [Address] 1818 Mar. 14, Executive Department, Knoxville, Tennessee [to the] Public / Joseph McMinn

mods.abstract: This document is a public address dated March 14, 1818 from the governor of Tennessee, Joseph McMinn. The subject of the address is a treaty with the Cherokee Indians regarding boundary lines within the state.

titleInfo.title: [Map of Overhill Cherokee sites, 18th century], / the University of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a map of the Overhill Cherokee sites that were occupied during the 18th century. The map is based on Henry Timberlake's 1762 map of the area as well as archaeological investigations made in 1967 through 1982, by The University of Tennessee as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). These well- known Overhill settlements of Mialoquo, Tuskeegee, Toqua, Chota, Citico, Tallassee, and Chilhowee are now all under water. The Cherokees who were located in north Georgia, northwest South Carolina, and Western North Carolina had to travel over the mountains from South Carolina to reach their brethren who lived in the lower Tennessee and Hiawasee River Valleys and thus they were referred to as the Overhill Cherokees.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1826 Oct. 28

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the 1826 term of court, specifically the Saturday October 28 session. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Nov. 4, Nashville [Tennessee, to] R.G. Douglass / Ja[me]s K. Polk

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor James K. Polk to R. G. Douglass, dated November 4, 1839. Polk is writing to complain about the content of a certificate that Douglass recently sent. The information in the certificate pertains to the Gallatin Cumberland Turnpike Company.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1826 Apr. 14 Jackson [Tennessee], [to] Rhea & McCrabb / Charles Barth

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from Charles Barth to fellow merchants Rhea & McCrabb on April 14, 1826. In the letter, Barth discusses business practices and prospects are to be found for merchants in Jackson, Tennessee. Barth states that business prospects are good in Jackson, but that goods and rent are expensive, due mostly to the influx of wealthy citizens into the area.

titleInfo.title: 1849 Jun. 27, Gallatin, Tennessee [to] [Adam] Fergusson / Jas. T. Crary

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Jas T. Crary to Adam Fergusson, dated June 27, 1849. Crary writes about politics in Tennessee. He mentions General Trousdale. He writes that cholera has hit Gallatin very hard. He writes that he wanted to visit Carthage but could not leave his school. He wants Fergusson to write him with a summary of the speeches that he missed.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1797 Jun. 30, Knox County [Tennessee, statement of] John Johnston / James White

mods.abstract: This is a sworn statement dated June 30, 1797. It is given by John Johnston to James White, and written out by White who is the Justice of the Peace for Knox County. Johnston swears that he was shot at by some Natives while hunting.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Feb. 5, Hermitage [to] Rev[erend] H. M. Cryer / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Andrew Jackson to the Reverend H. M. Cryer on February 5, 1840. In the letter, Jackson proposes to sell a tract of land on his property to help his son get out of debt. He asks for Cryer's help in finding someone who would want to buy the land. Jackson wants to sell the land for fifteen thousand dollars, with five thousand dollars as a down payment. This total price equals out to be approximately thirty dollars per acre of land.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Oct. 26

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Tuesday October 26, 1824 session of court, during which a plea of default was heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1825 Oct. 24

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Monday October 24, 1825 session of court, during which a series of both civil and criminal cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Apr. 14, Nashville [to] Sarah B. Hamilton, Russellville, K[entuck]y / Mortimer Hamilton

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated April 14, 1833 to Sarah B. Hamilton from her son Mortimer Hamilton. Hamilton informs his mother of a murder in Nashville, a friends desire to purchase a young girl, and writes in length about his desire to become a Christian.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Nov. 11, Shepherdsville, [to] E[dward] E. Porter / C. Clay Balfrey

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by C. Clay Balfrey to Edward E. Porter on November 11, 1850. In the letter, Balfrey mentions the fact that many people have been getting married and that marriage seems to be the popular thing to do at the time. He also mentions that Edward's former landlord, a man named Nick Simmons, was shot in the back in a fight and has recovered. He concludes by saying that he wishes for Edward and himself to renew their friendship after some previous disagreements.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1826 Oct. 26

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This particular excerpt is from October 26, 1926, and takes count of two cases. In both cases, the plaintiffs were awarded money. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.
This document is an order dated May 5, 1818 from Andrew Jackson for John Hill to procure supplies for the Tennessee Volunteers Militia.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1834 Feb. 24, Alexandria, L[ouisian]a [to] James King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Tho[mas] O. Moore

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated February 24, 1834 from Thomas Moore to his cousin James King. Moore mentions that three of his slaves had run away and describes their pursuit and capture. He also writes of his prospects of his cotton and corn crops in light of the "bank question" possibly being settled by Congress.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Jun. 6, Philade[lphia], [PA] [to] James A. Woods, Nashville, Tenn[essee] / Jane Theora [Woods]

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Jane Woods to her brother James Woods dated June 6, 1840. Jane writes about a picnic she recently attended. She declares that Philadelphia is incorrectly named "The City of Brotherly Love". She anticipates her family's visit and asks James to give her love to many people in Nashville.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Sep. 13, Clinton [to] Mr. Charles F. Welcker, Kingston, Tennessee / J. C. Mitchell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated September 13, 1837, from Judge James C. Mitchell to his son-in-law Charles F. Welcker in Kingston, Tennessee. Mitchell talks about the good health that he and the family are enjoying, and he gives Welcker and his daughter Caroline the good news that he has recently remarried. He also discusses the various schools throughout Tennessee to which he may send his children and grandchildren. The remainder of the letter involves family matters and Mitchell's personal business.

titleInfo.title: Cherokee Council's decision of the conflicting claims of Mrs. E. Pack [and] Jno. [i.e., John] H. Jeffrey, 1820 Apr. 22, Council House near Hicks' Mill / [signed by] John Ross

mods.abstract: Copy of a legal decision of the Cherokee Council dated April 22, 1820 concerning a property dispute between Mrs. E. Pack, who purchased property from Charles Hicks, and John H. Jeffrey, who claims right due to his marriage to a Cherokee woman. The council decides in favor of Pack. Elijah Hicks created this copy.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Mar. 5, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] John Watts and other chiefs of the Cherokee Nation / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated March 5, 1797, written by Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) and addressed to John Watts and other chiefs of the Cherokee Nation. The letter was written in response to a letter by the Cherokee chiefs regarding earlier communications sent by Sevier. In this letter, Sevier negated the claims of Watts and others that the Cherokees have not caused damage to the persons or properties of white settlers. Sevier cited instances in which white settlers were killed in retaliation for the murders of Chief Red Bird and his attendant. Sevier also criticized the Cherokee Nation for not making an official complaint regarding those murders. Furthermore, he denied Watts' claim that his preceding communications were threatening in nature, as he stated that he was merely hoping to convince the Cherokees of the dangers of going to war. Sevier contended that he wished to establish and promote a peace between the United States and the Cherokee Nation.

titleInfo.title: Receipts for the cure of most diseases incident to the human family / by the celebrated Indian doctor, John Mackentosh, of the Cherokee Nation

mods.abstract: This is a published work of receipts, or recipes, for treatment of a variety of injuries and diseases, including whooping cough, snake bite, sprained ankles, cholic, and fever. The work was written by John Mackentosh, a Doctor of the Cherokee Nation, and appears to have been published in New York, 1827.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Mar. 27 [to] Mrs. William R. Caswell, Russelville, Tennessee / William Richard Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by William Richard Caswell to his wife from Vera Cruz, Mexico during the Mexican-American War. Caswell explains that the take over of Vera Cruz was victorious for the Americans and that his wife should hear from intelligence soon.

titleInfo.title: 1819 Apr. 13, Nashville, Tennessee [to] James Winchester, Cragfont, Tennessee / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from General Andrew Jackson to General James Winchester, date April 13, 1819. Jackson is writing to discuss his ideas on running a line between Tennessee and the Chickasaw Nation. Jackson wantsWinchester to assist in getting the Chickasaw chiefs to the meeting location.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Mar. 5, Cherokee Agency [to] Mr. John Miller / H. Montgomery

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 5, 1833, written by H. Montgomery from the Cherokee Agency to John Miller. Montgomery informs miller that two men, Joseph Lynch and James Foreman, have taken a group of slaves belonging to someone else. Montgomery asks that the slaves be returned immediately.

titleInfo.title: [1849] December 20, Washington [City, D.C.] [to Adam Fergusson] / Andrew Ewing

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Andrew Ewing to Adam Fergusson, dated December 20, presumably in 1849. Ewing writes that the government is in great disorganization over the slavery question. He considers the Northern Democrats and Whigs to be anarchists. He also fears that the chaos in America might lead to an end of the liberty that America stands for.

titleInfo.title: [Address] 1837 Mar. 22, Headquarters, New Echota, G[eorgi]a / Br[i]g[adier] Gen[era]l John E. Wool

mods.abstract: This document is an address from Brigadier General John E. Wool, at army headquarters in New Echota, to the Cherokees, dated March 22, 1837. Wool informs the Cherokees that they have until May 25, 1838 to remove to a territory west of the Mississippi according to the provisions of the New Echota Treaty (signed in 1835) or else be forced to remove by U.S. soldiers. Wool threatens them with despicable treatment and tells them their fate will be even worse than the Creeks if they do not cooperate and remove voluntarily.

titleInfo.title: 1848 Nov. 23, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Daniel D. Claibourne, Lafayette, Tennessee / Adam Fergusson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Adam Fergusson to his nephew Daniel D. Claibourne, dated November 23, 1848. Fergusson mentions the recent presidential election in which his candidate Cass lost, despite winning the popular vote. Fergusson informs Claibourne that his name is not allowed to be a on a bank note that Claibourne is trying to obtain. Fergusson writes that Claibourne needs a different person to sign.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 May 20, Pleasant Plains [to] Miss Ann J[ane] Bell, Charlotte, Dickson County, Tennessee / Ann T Barry

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated May 20, 1828, to Ann Jane Bell in Dickson County, TN from her friend Ann T. Barry in Pleasant Ridge, TN. In the letter, Barry discusses her recent travels across the state, paying special attention to the landscape of the various counties and the variation in taste and color of their streams. She also expresses great awe at traversing the Tennessee River, and she discusses other news of family and friends, including the high rate of sickness and death in the region.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Jul. 14, Nashville Academy, [Tennessee] [to] Lucy [L. C. Bailey] / Ann M[aria] Bryon

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Ann Maria Bryon to Lucy L. C. Bailey on July 14, 1836. In the letter, Ann tells Lucy about her school, the Nashville Academy, and that it will have 30 new students, making 100 students total attending school there. She also informs Lucy that she will send her some flowers the next opportunity she has.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1799 June 24, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Cap[tain] Edm[un]d Butler / [John Sevier] : a machine-readable transcription of an image

mods.abstract: This is a letter written by Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) to introduce Reverend Lyman Potter to Captain Edmund Butler. Sevier explains that Mr. Potter has business in the Cherokee Nation to discuss with Captain Butler.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Feb. 2, [to] Maj[o]r Andrew Crockett, Williamson County, [TN] / Rob[er]t Scales

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Robert Scales to Andrew Crockett dated February 2, 1819. Scales informs Crockett that his hogshead of tobacco, which was a special casket used to store and transport tobacco, is ready to be attended to.

This is a letter dated December 1817. The author is unknown, but the recipient is probably James Winchester. The author is describing the hardships inflicted during the War of 1812, from both British and Native American combatants. Some of the people suffering are unknown, but one may be Winchester himself and a family by the name of Navarne.

This document is a letter dated March 22, 1813 to Colonel Sevier, written by his father, former Governor of Tennessee, John Sevier. Sevier discusses various topics in the letter, including the War of 1812, a lawsuit against Polk, and the condition of his son's mare.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 June 1, Columbia Female Institute [to] Mrs Elizabeth Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / Mary Jane Chester

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated June 1, 1841, from Mary Jane Chester to her mother Elizabeth Chester. Mary Jane writes about her upcoming examination and her hopes that many members of her family will come to Columbia to attend the examination.

titleInfo.title: [Estate Sale] 1806 Feb. 27, of goods and chattels belonging to James Law, deceased

mods.abstract: This document is an inventory of an estate sale dated February 27, 1806. The belongings of James Law, deceased, were sold at a public vendue.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of posthole patterns of Cherokee winter and summer domestic houses at the former site of the mid-18th century Cherokee town of Citico, taken in 1978] / [by Robert D. Newman]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of posthole patterns of mid-18th century summer and winter domestic dwellings from the Overhill Cherokee town of Citico. As was common in most Overhill villages winter houses were built in a circular dome structure which contained a central hearth for fire. Adjacent to the winter home was an open rectangular summer pavilion used in warm weather. Excavations were conducted by the University of Tennessee in 1978 in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Jefferson Chapman. Field Director, Robert D. Newman

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Bill of Sale for Slaves] 1850 Aug. 1, Shelby County, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a bill of sale, dated August 1, 1850. William Stokes sold a family of slaves to the firm of Cook & Hanley for twelve hundred dollars.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Aug. 3, Memphis, Tennessee [to] Miss Sarah J. Armstrong, Jerusalem, Virginia / Daniel Douglass

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated August 3, 1850 from Daniel Douglass to Sarah Armstrong. Douglass writes of his travels from Lancaster, Pennsylvania to various other cities along the Mississippi River.

This document is a circular dated September 18, 1838 from the governor of Tennessee, Newton Cannon. It concerns conflicting provisions of an act passed by the state legislature on January 19, 1838 regarding the establishment of a State Bank, a fund for internal improvements, and the establishment of a system of education.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1813 July 23, Creek Path [to] Colonel Return J. Meigs, Highwassee / Kanchestaneskee et al.

mods.abstract: This document appears to be a letter to Return J. Meigs dated July 23, 1813 composed by several Cherokee chiefs at the request of Pathkiller, the principal chief, to inform Meigs of the growing Creek civil war. The letter tells that the town of Tooquachee (Toocabatchee) in the Creek Nation, where four different tribes of Indians once held friendly conferences, has been taken from Creek chief Big Warrior and destroyed. While Big Warrior is considered a "friendly" Creek, the letter states that the majority of Creek Nation has gone against him to join the rebel party. The Cherokees indicate that they have information that one of the prophets partly responsible for the uprising has escaped to the Choctaw Nation. Included is a warning from Big Warrior to the Cherokees to arm themselves against the rebellious Creeks along their borders.

titleInfo.title: 1844 May 1, Washington [City, D. C.] [to] A. Fergusson / W. B. Campbell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from W. B. Campbell to A. Fergusson, dated May 1, 1844. Campbell reports on the progress of the pension claim by the heirs of Lieut. Col. Henry Dixon. He mentions the Texas question of statehood, and believes that there are too many Congressmen against it for it to happen.

titleInfo.title: Letter in Cherokee [with] translation, 1838 Jan. 5, to John Ross, Washington / George Lowrey

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written in the Cherokee syllabary from George Lowrey, Assistant Principal Chief, to John Ross, Principal Chief, dated January 5, 1838. Lowrey reports to Ross, who is in Washington, D.C. with a Cherokee delegation, on the status of the Cherokee Nation. He informs Ross that the Cherokees have been given an ultimatum for removal and are threatened with violence if they do not cooperate and prepare to leave. Lowrey has attempted to stall the progress of their removal and desperately desires communication from Ross. A type written translation appears with this document.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Sept. 29, Columbia [to] Elizabeth Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / Mary Jane Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Mary Jane Chester to her mother, Elizabeth Chester, on September 29, 1840. In the letter, Mary Jane discusses her recent illness, her desire to return home, and her schooling at the Institute. She says that the Institute is very strict against girls and that there are 112 scholars enrolled in school there.

titleInfo.title: [Speech] 1832 Jul. 4 Eulogy of Gen [eral] Jackson / Henry Carter

mods.abstract: This document is a eulogy written by Henry Carter for Andrew Jackson on July 4, 1832 while Jackson served as President of the United States. The eulogy was written to demonstrate the animosity Carter held towards Jackson. The eulogy concludes with a derogatory poem about Andrew Jackson's life, from his birth to his death.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Nov. 4, Nashville [Tennessee, to] Ja[me]s S. U. Hawkins / Ja[me]s K. Polk

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Captain James S. U. Hawkins from Governor James K. Polk, dated November 4, 1839. Polk is writing to inform Hawkins of the implications of a legislative act on his militia company.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1817 May 13, Nashville [to] Geo[rge] Graham / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 13, 1817 to George Graham, Acting Secretary of War, from General Andrew Jackson. Jackson gives instructions on opening a military road from the northern boundary of Mississippi territory to Lake Ponchetrain.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Jun. 13, Nashville, Tennessee [to] W[illia]m Fitzgerald, Dresden, Tennessee / Jno [i.e., John] Fitzgerald

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 13, 1829 from John Fitzgerald to his brother William Fitzgerald. It is a personal letter congratulating William on his prospects of making money and the good health of his family.

titleInfo.title: 1835 Nov. 21, Charlotte, Dixon C[oun]ty [to] Lot Hazard, Carthage, Tennessee / A[dam] Fergusson

mods.abstract: This is a letter to his father-in-law Lot Hazard from Adam Fergusson, dated November 21, 1835. Fergusson is reporting on a trip that he and his family are on. He writes that all are fine, but that it has been slow going due to heavy rains.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] agreement [between] Cherokee [officials and] Jos[eph] McMinn, 1823 May 23, / [signed by] Jno. [i.e., John] Ross ... [et al.]

mods.abstract: Copy of a legal agreement dated May 23, 1823 between John Ross, Richard Taylor, Alexander McCoy, and Nathan Hicks, Cherokee officials acting on behalf of the Nation's treasurer, Charles R. Hicks, and Joseph McMinn, Cherokee Agent (and former Governor of Tennessee), concerning the 1823 Cherokee annuity payment.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 May 1, Nashville, [to] Andrew Jackson / William B. Lewis

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from William B. Lewis to President Andrew Jackson. Lewis writes on various topics, including cholera, the troubles with the United States Bank, and politics.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1814 Feb. 4, Fort Armstrong, [Alabama], [to] Colo[nel] R[eturn] J[onathan] Meigs / Gideon Morgan

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Cherokee Colonel Gideon Morgan to Colonel Return J. Meigs on February 4, 1814. The letter is Morgan's account of a battle during the Creek War of 1813-1814, in which General Andrew Jackson's American forces allied with the Cherokee against Creek warriors. While it first appeared that the Creeks had the upper-hand in the battle, Jackson's troops were able to maintain their ground and gain victory in the end. Morgan was able to estimate the losses on both sides, and he stated that afterwards the Cherokee were permitted to return to their homes. Morgan, who was writing from Fort Armstrong, also reported that more troops and Cherokees were expected to arrive at the fort, and he noted that at that time provisions were scarce.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Feb. 23, College Hill, Hanover, [Indiana] [to] Miss Mary C. Porter / Ben [Sawtelle]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Ben Sawtelle to his niece, Mary C. Porter, on February 23, 1849. Ben attends South Hanover College in Indiana and tells Mary of the school and social events happening there. Ben also discusses events happening to acquaintances of theirs, as well as mentioning his support for the sewing and abolitionist societies with which Mary is involved.

titleInfo.title: 1841 April 24, Columbia [to] Adam Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / J. H. Dew

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Adam Fergusson from J. H. Dew, dated April 24, 1841. Dew gives the location of Mr. Fitspatrick, but that he does not know where Mrs. Davis lives. Dew also writes about the upcoming Congressional election. He names many candidates for the Whigs and the Democratic Republicans.

titleInfo.title: [Drawing depicting a Cherokee townhouse at Chota] / [by Thomas Whyte]

mods.abstract: This is a drawing of an Overhill Cherokee winter townhouse at Chota. Winter townhouses which were cone-shaped appeared to look like small mountains from a distance. Some were large enough to hold 500 people. The seats were arranged like an amphitheater with the seats rising one above another, leaving an area in the center for a fire. The drawing is based on historical descriptions as well as archaeological excavations conducted by The University of Tennessee from 1969-1974. The excavations were conducted in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Directors, J. Worth Greene, Duane H. King, and Gerald F. Schroedl. The drawing is by Thomas Whyte.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1816 July 6, Cherokee Agency, [to] Major Gen[era]l Andrew Jackson / Return J[onathan] Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Cherokee agent Return J. Meigs to General Andrew Jackson written on July 6, 1816. Meigs is telling Jackson about a convention he attended with the Cherokees in order to establish the boundary line of their land. He says that the lands given up by the Cherokee will benefit both the Cherokee and the United States because of land-holding and monetary issues.

This is a letter dated February 27, 1846. It is from a woman named Ada to L. E., who is probably a man. Ada writes about a terrible event in her town where a woman named Rosalie died from a broken heart after being betrayed by a womanizer. Ada is very upset because she feels that it is a common occurrence, and admonishes L. E. never to do anything of the sort. She also mysteriously writes that she may have to stop corresponding with him.

titleInfo.title: [Military] 1813 Sep. 25, Camp Good Exchange [Regimental orders from] General [Andrew] Jackson / J[oh] n Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is dated September 25, 1813, and is written by John Coffee. He is relaying Regimental orders from General Andrew Jackson for several companies to march to Huntsville, Tennessee under the command of Lt. Colonel Allcorn and Major Lauderdale.

titleInfo.title: Abstract of disbursements made by Return J. Meigs, 1812 Nov. 14 - 1812 Dec. 1, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This is a summary of the disbursements made by Return J. Meigs, U.S. Agent to the Cherokee Nation, at the Cherokee Agency in Tennessee from November 14, 1812 through December 1, 1812. The expenses include salary payments to various interpreters, payment for claims against the Cherokees, legal fees, transportation costs, and payment for spinning and weaving articles.

titleInfo.title: 1844 Jul 31, Nashville [TN] [to] Mary House, Louisville, Alabama / George House

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated July 31, 1844 to Mary House from her husband, George House. He writes quite a bit about how much he misses her. He even stares out his window at night in the direction she lives. He gives the news of his friends, and their family. He also describes in detail a recent Whig rally and looks forward to their convention. He gives the news of their family, and the people that want her to write to them. He also advises her to take boneset tea if she gets another cough.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1842 Apr. 30 Moses Swafford to the State of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document dated between March and April 30th 1842 has two parts. The first part is a land grant by the State of Tennessee to Moses Swafford of 80 acres of land in the Ocoee District of Polk County. The second part is the sale of that land by Moses Swafford to the State of Tennessee for the sum of Ten dollars.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Feb. 4, Jackson, [MS] [to] Col[onel] Joseph Brown, Maury County, Tennessee / James Brown

mods.abstract: This is a letter from James Brown to his father Joseph Brown dated February 4, 1850. James advises Joseph to stop helping his brother Randolph, and to tell him to get a job, possibly as someone's apprentice. He informs Joseph that he will be loaning money to Mr. Love. James also updates him on local politics and correspondences he has had with other people.

titleInfo.title: [Article on the Cherokees], 1844, [from the] Universal gazetteer / R. Brookes and John Marshall

mods.abstract: This document is a typed excerpt from an article in the Universal Gazetteer, a geographic dictionary originally published in 1835, and reprinted in 1844. The typed excerpt contains parts of the full article and describes the state of the Cherokee people in the mid-nineteenth century. Cherokee leaders Charles Hicks and John Ross are mentioned. The excerpt presented here contains several minor typographical variations from the original article.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Dec. 29, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Col[onel] Robert J. Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Mary Jane Chester to her father, Robert J. Chester, on December 29, 1842. In the letter, Mary Jane discusses her examination in January and her hopes that some of her family will be there for it. She also mentions to her father that the rumors regarding her engagement to an unnamed man are unfounded. She concludes the letter by expressing love to her family and asking her father to burn the letter once he had read it, which he obviously did not do.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1808 Mar. 25 [for] corn for the Cherokee Nation

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for one hundred and thirty bushels of corn for the Cherokee Nation. Samuel Riley delivered the corn on behalf of Return J. Meigs, agent to the Cherokees.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Jan. 21, Washington City [to] Lewis Cass, Secretary of War / Lewis Ross

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated January 21, 1836 from Lewis Ross to Lewis Cass, secretary of War. Ross has been asked to move from the Agency Reservation that he has lived on since 1820. Ross explains that he was moved to his current residence by Agent Return J. Meigs and believed it to be his permanent home. Ross further writes that he has invested thousands of dollars in improvements to his home and begs for the opportunity to stay.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1828 Oct. 31

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is an excerpt from Friday October 31, 1828, on which date two civil cases were heard before the court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1818 Jan. 28, Plainfield [North Carolina] [to] Ja[me]s M.[oore] King, Murfreesborough, Rutherford County, Tennessee / Ann Eliza King

mods.abstract: Letter dated January 28, 1818 from Ann Eliza King to her Cousin James Moore King. The brief letter expresses her disappointment in not receiving a reply from her last letter, and her happiness to see him in the future.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Legal Indictment] 1789 Feb. [to] the Superior Court of Law / State of North Carolina

mods.abstract: This document is a legal indictment from the state of North Carolina to the Superior Court of Law, dated February Term 1789. This document is a ruling by the state jury that a man named Moses Rennolds stole possessions from John Rogers.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Dec. [to] William M. Lowry / Andrew Johnson

mods.abstract: This document is a portion of a letter written by Andrew Johnson circa 1849, to William M. Lowry. In the letter, Johnson discusses politics and his hatred for someone only referred to as Williams.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1803 June 9, Knoxville, [Tennessee], [to] Henry Dearborne, [i.e. Dearborn], Secretary at War / Archibald Roane, Governor of the State of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written on June 9, 1803, by Tennessee Governor Archibald Roane (1801-1803) to Secretary at War Henry Dearborn. In the letter, Roane informed Dearborn of a road in Tennessee which was believed to be inhabited by bandits who had been attacking travellers. It was unknown if the bandits were Indians, white men, or both. Roane offered some suggestions concerning the insurance safety of the travellers, including offering a reward to induce the Indians to help catch the culprits. Roane expressed concern that if it were discovered that the bandits were from an Indian tribe, relations between the Indians and whites in the region would deteriorate.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Dec. 24, Mossey Creek, Jefferson C[oun]ty, Tennessee [to] Newton Cannon, Nashville, Tennessee / George Branner

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Governor Newton Cannon from George Branner, dated December 24, 1836. Branner suggests that Cannon appoint Judge Jacob Peck to be an engineer on the Charleston-Cinncinnati-Louisville Rail Road.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Feb 15, Pebblehill Academy, Jefferson, Ten[nessee] [to] Mrs. Jane M. Foster, Nashville, Tennessee / Robert C. Foster, Jr.

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Robert C. Foster, Jr. to his mother Jane M. Foster, dated February 15, 1833. The younger Foster writes that he misses his mother and hopes that she will get better as she appears to be suffering from cholera.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1796 May 4, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Cherokee [Nation] / J[ohn] McKee

mods.abstract: This is a letter to the Cherokee Nation from Indian agent Colonel John McKee, dated May 4, 1796. McKee is writing to advise the Cherokees to maintain peaceful relations with the U.S., and not let a few destroy it. McKee also assures them that the guns the Cherokee say have been stolen from them will be returned.

titleInfo.title: 1844 Nov. 19, Russellville, KY [to] Mary [House] / Presley Ewing

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated November 19, 1844 from Kentucky politician Presley Underwood Ewing to Mary House of Davidson County, TN. Ewing updates House on family and local news, including the recent visit by her mother and rumors that he seeks a widow with children to marry. Ewing also discusses his own mother's illness and his father's teaching job.

titleInfo.title: 1846 Feb. 6 [to] George W. House, Nashville, Tennessee / Mary House

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Mary House to her husband George House, dated February 6, 1846. She had been traveling down the Cumberland River but disembarked in Vicksburg, KY. There she and the other members of her party had some trouble continuing on their trip. From there she travels to a town named Clinton to visit her brother, and meets his new wife for the first time and their new baby.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1813 Dec. 19 [to] William B. Lewis Esq[uire] Nashville, Tennessee / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is an early transcription of a letter dated December 19th 1813 to William B. Lewis from Andrew Jackson. In the letter, Jackson complains about losing the Tennessee Volunteers to sickness and desertion. He requests that Lewis convince the Governor of Tennessee to issue an order to keep the Tennessee Militia involved in the Creek War. The original letter, and later transcription can be seen by viewing document sl006.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1812 Mar. 28, Maury County, Tennessee [to] Elias Earle / James Holland

mods.abstract: This is a copy of a letter from Major James Holland to Elias Earle dated March 28, 1812. Holland discusses the establishment of an iron works factory in the Cherokee Nation and briefly outlines the grounds on which the land for the factory was to be obtained by Earle.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1825 Oct. 29

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Saturday October 29, 1825 session of court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of mid-18th century trade beads, kaolin pipe fragments, small metal buttons, and fragments of European ceramics, Chota, taken in 1969] / [by George Fielder]

mods.abstract: This photograph is of glass trade beads, kaolin pipe fragments, and small metal button fragments found in excavations of the mid-18th century Cherokee village of Chota. The Overhill Cherokees traded actively with the lower Cherokees of Georgia and South Carolina. Chota was recognized by Europeans as well as other Indians for its powerful economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. Excavations of Chota and other Overhill villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, J. Worth Greene.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837, June 27, Clover Dale, TN [to] Miss Ann Jane Bell, Philadelphia, [PA] / Sarah Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Sarah Bell to her sister Ann Jane Bell dated June 27, 1837. She complains that her family would not let her write to Jane because they were worried Jane would not want to pay the postage. She writes that the family has been concerned for her and that their mother wants to know what kind of medicine she is taking. Sarah updates Jane on the news from the neighborhood, sicknesses, marriages, etc. The sisters are trying to decide between a barbecue or a speech on temperance as their July 4th activities. Margaret has greatly enjoyed the book The Three Eras of a Woman's Life. They did not like Mrs. Cary's book because she thinks that all women should be punished for what Eve may have done, and the sisters do not agree. Sarah wants to be sure that Jane will send her a copy of her piece on Presentiment and her anecdote.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Oct. 26, Murfreesboro, Tennessee [to William Carroll] Tennessee / William L. Williford

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Governor William Carroll from William L. Williford and George W. McGehee, dated October 26, 1825. This is a report on the latitude of Walker's Line which formed the southern border of Kentucky.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] Jul. 23, Hartsville, [Tennessee] [to] Doctor J[ames] L. Alexander / W. C. Hamilton

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by W. C. Hamilton to Doctor J. L. Alexander on July 23, 1839. In the letter, Hamilton informs Alexander that he will not be visiting him because Colonel Polk will not be there, and also that he wishes for him to attend a meeting of candidates in Hartsville, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Land Grant] 1840 Mar. 26 [to] James S. Porter / John Eaton

mods.abstract: This document is a land grant given to James S. Porter from John Eaton dated March 26, 1840. The grant specifies what sections of land Porter will get from the lands ceded to the United States from the Chickasaw Nation and John Eaton, their commissioner, in the Treaty signed at Pontotoc Creek.

titleInfo.title: [Letter], 1857 Nov. 11, Washington City [to the] Secretary of the Treasury / W[illia]m H. Thomas

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from William H. Thomas, legal representative of the North Carolina Cherokees, dated November 11, 1857 to the acting Secretary of the Treasury regarding a number of treaties, acts, and resolutions specific to the payment of annuities to the eastern Cherokees. Thomas quotes from several of these legal documents in arguing for the appropriate payments due the North Carolina Cherokees and pointing out obvious discrepancies in the federal policies. This document was originally bound (as wtp080) with the following documents in the Southeastern Native American Documents Database: wtp081, wtp082, wtp083, wtp084.

titleInfo.title: 1847 Oct., Knoxville [TN] [to] Mary House, Nashville, Tennessee / Mary Broyles

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Mary Broyles to Mary House, dated October 1847. Broyles has been travelling, and has stopped in Knoxville for the day. She writes about the people she has been meeting. She mentions the health of her family members. Because the weather is good, she will not be going through Nashville, which is not agreeable to her. Broyles is afraid she may never get the chance to see her Nashville friends again.

This document is a spoliation claim made by Edward and Sarah Graves requesting that the United States government pay them the sum of forty-eight dollars for 12 hogs that were killed by troops under the command of General White during the Creek War.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Dec. 23, Memphis [TN] [to] John A. Claybrooke, Williamson County, Tenn[essee] / John Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John Overton to John A Claybrooke. It is dated December 23, 1842. Overton gives the details of a land purchase deal between himself and Joseph J. Andrews. He wants to use the money to build a ferry boat. He writes about an upcoming business trip to Pittsburgh. He is going with Major Winchester in relation to the ferry boat project.

titleInfo.title: 1841 Feb. 22, Washington [City, D. C.] [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Ten[nessee] / W. B. Campbell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from W. B. Campbell to A. Fergusson, dated February 22, 1841. Campbell reports that a pension claim has been denied. It was filed by the heirs of a Revolutionary War soldier, Col. H. Dixon.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Apr. 15, Roane County [to] Mr. Cha[rle]s F. Welcker, Kingston, Tennessee / James M. Welcker

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 15, 1839, from James Monroe Welcker to his brother Charles Frederick Welcker in Kingston, Tennessee. James writes from the home of a Captain Lackey, whom he says has two mules that Charles may like to employ for ploughing.

titleInfo.title: [Drawing of the posthole pattern of a mid-18th century Cherokee townhouse at Mialoquo, created in 1977] / [by Marion Drescher]

mods.abstract: This is a drawing of a posthole pattern of an 18th century Cherokee winter townhouse at Mialoquo. Overhill townhouses were situated in a common village plaza. There was generally a winter townhouse, which was a large circular dome in which a fire could be built in the center and an adjacent rectangular open pavilion for summer use. Both were used for public social and political activity. Excavations of Mialoquo were conducted by the University of Tennessee in 1977 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Jefferson Chapman. Field Director, Gerald F. Schroedl.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Abstract] 1822 Oct. 7 Abstract of the minutes of the Abingdon Presbytery / Hebron Church

mods.abstract: This document is an abstract of the minutes of the Abingdon Presbytery taken on October 7, 1822. The abstract states that Reverend Andrew S. Morrison will leave the Presbytery of Union and is well accepted at the Presbytery of Abingdon.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Jun. 21, Carthage [Tennessee] [to] A[dam] Fergusson, Underhill / Dryald C. Whab

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated June 21, 1844, from Dryald C. Whab to Adam Fergusson. Whab writes to warn Fergusson that some are accusing him of being the author of an anonymous newspaper article attacking the Whigs, and that some young men are seeking retribution for the insult.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Jan. 17, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Sec[retar]y of the Department of War / John Sevier, Governor of the state of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Governor John Sevier of Tennessee (1796-1801) to Secretary of War James McHenry, dated January 17, 1797. Sevier reported that the companies of Captains Wade and Sparks had arrived, but were incomplete. He requested three companies of infantry and a troop of cavalry be sent as well in order to protect the frontier settlers and scare the Indians. Sevier also informed McHenry that several families had their horses stolen and wagons plundered along the Cumberland road, and he had written to Cherokee chiefs and their agent to prevent such acts. Sevier ended his letter by claiming that he would endeavor to prevent encroachments upon the hunting grounds of the Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 July 9, Red Clay, C[herokee] Nation, [to] Col[onel] W[illia]m Y. Hansell and S[amuel] Rockwell, Milledgeville, Georgia / Jno. [i.e., John] Ross

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, to Colonel William Y. Hansell and Colonel Samuel Rockwell, lawyers for the Cherokee Nation, dated July 9, 1835. Ross complains to the two attorneys regarding the controversy of the payment of the Cherokee annuity. A vote is to be held under the direction of Major Benjamin F. Currey to determine to which Cherokee faction, the Ridge party or the Ross party, the annuity is to be paid. Ross complains about slanderous depictions of him in local newspapers and also mentions the arrival of Reverend John F. Schermerhorn to submit treaty proposals to the Cherokees.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1821 May 24, Wheeling, Virginia [to] Miss Anne Jane Bell, near Nashville, Tenn[ess]ee / John Bell

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated May 24, 1821, from Dr. John Bell to his sister Anne Jane Bell in Tennessee. John writes the letter to inform his family that he will soon be embarking on a journey to Nashville to visit them. He also discusses the other places and people he has visited and plans to visit.

titleInfo.title: 1795 Nov. 24, Nashville [Territory South of the Ohio River, to] David Henley, Knoxville [Territory South of the Ohio River] / J.W. Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John Overton to David Henley, dated November 24, 1795. Overton is writing from Andrew Jackson's home. He is writing to inform Henley that he has accepted Mr. Searcy as contractor for an unmentioned project.

subject.topic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Sep. 20, Terre Haute, Indiana [to] Mr. Charles F. Welcker, Talladega, Alabama / Geo[rge] L. Welcker

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated September 20, 1837, from George L. Welcker in Terre Haute, Indiana, to his brother Charles F. Welcker in Talladega, Alabama. The Welckers were a prominent family in Roane County, Tennessee. In this letter, George writes mostly about family matters. He also discusses Mississippi, describing it as an unhealthy and destitute country. George further updates his brother on events in his own life in Indiana.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Aug. 20 [to] Gen[era]l John Coffee / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated August 20, 1819 to General John Coffee from Andrew Jackson regarding the birth of General Coffee's son who was named after Andrew Jackson.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1802 Jul. 31, United States to Ransom Davis / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for payment of three dollars and fifty cents to Ransom Davis for tobacco. Return J. Meigs, agent for the War Department in Tennessee made the payment on behalf of the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1820 Oct. 15, Nashville, Tennessee [to] James Winchester, Cairo, Tennessee / John Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated October 15, 1820 from John Overton in Nashville, Tennessee to James Winchester in Cairo, Tennessee. The content of the letter concerns travel arrangements, supplies needed, and departure details for Overton and Winchester.

titleInfo.title: [Notice of Sale] 1850 Sep. 5 / James D. Foresee

mods.abstract: This document is a notice of the sale of a horse and a yoke of oxen, offered by James D. Foresee, sheriff of Humphreys County, and dated September 5, 1850. The items were apparently the property of Jacob M. Wheat but were taken into possession by the Circuit Court of Humphreys County.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Jul 26 [Knoxville] Tennessee [to Willie] Blount [Nashville] Tennessee / H.L.White

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Governor Willie Blount from H.L. White, dated July 26, 1815. White is the president of the state bank in Knoxville. The letter refers to the banking policy of suspending payments in specie, as a result of the financial strain of the War of 1812. White writes that his bank has decided to follow the suspension, as to not would cause the bank to call in too many loans, thereby putting too much financial strain on the local community. The letter contains a brief summary of the political, martial, and financial situation in the U.S. and Europe as explanation for the change in policy.

titleInfo.title: 1837 Sep. 7, Tampa Bay, Florida [to] Newton Cannon, Nashville, Tennessee / [Thomas] Jessup

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Major General Thomas Jessup to Governor Newton Cannon, dates September 7, 1837. Jessup is requesting troops for the war against the Seminoles.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Oct. 27, Claiborne C[oun]ty, Ten[n]essee [to an unknown] Crockett / [Andrew Crockett?]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated October 27, 1819, presumed to be from Andrew Crockett in Claiborne County, TN, to one of his brothers. In the letter, Andrew talks of ironworks and discourages his brother from getting involved in the business. The page is torn off at the bottom, making it unclear to whom the letter is written.

titleInfo.title: [Military Commission] 1840 Oct. 12 [of] James M. Bowden [signed by] James K. Polk

mods.abstract: This document is a military commission dated October 12, 1840 for James M. Bowden to enter the Tennessee Militia. The commission is signed by James K. Polk, Governor of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1826 Oct. 30

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Monday October 30, 1826 session of court, during which a civil case over the rights of a horse was heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: 1838 Apr. 11, Washington City [to] N[ewton] Cannon, Tennessee / Winfield Scott

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Winfield Scott, the Federal officer in charge of Cherokee Removal. It is to Governor Newton Cannon, dated April 11, 1838. Scott is asking Cannon to send him troops for his army. He details the positions he needs filled.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Apr. 24, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] the Hon[ora]ble the Sec[retar]y of the Department of War [James McHenry] / J[ohn] S[evier]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to James McHenry, Secretary of War, from Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) on April 24, 1797. The letter is mainly in reference to the arrival of two men by the names of Hawkins and Pickens in Tennessee in order to determine the Indian boundary line. Sevier explained that the drawing of the line had caused much uneasiness among Tennessee settlers who feared that their residences might fall within Indian boundaries. Sevier suggested that the drawing of the line be postponed in the case of conflict with the European powers, for he also warned the the Creeks, Cherokees, Choctaws, and Chickasaws were all in friendly alliances with the Spanish government. Sevier feared that drawing the line would only spark tensions between these tribes and the American citizens.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1812 Nov. 16 Knoxville, [to] Winchester & Cage / Hugh L. White

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to Winchester & Cage from Hugh L. White, with a return message from Cage, dated November 16, 1812. In the letter, White asks Winchester & Cage to either return the lottery tickets that he sent them to sell, or the money they acquired from the sale of the tickets. Cage replies to the letter by returning the 50 tickets that were sent to them.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1838 Aug. 30, The United States to Harry Vann of Hightower

mods.abstract: This document, dated August 30, 1838, is a claim by Harry Vann of Hightower towards the United States regarding acreage and those goods needed to build on a home and surrounding land.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1816 Aug. 15, Oak Grove [to] James King, Rutherford County, [TN] / Ezekiel Moore

mods.abstract: A letter written on August 15, 1816 from Ezekiel Moore in Oak Grove to his nephew James Moore King in Rutherford County, Tennessee. Moore writes of illness in his neighborhood and inquires about a horse.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Mar. 29, Washington, [to] the editors of the "National Intelligencer" / John Ross

mods.abstract: This is an unsigned letter, ostensibly from John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, to the editors of the "National Intelligencer", a nationwide periodical published from 1800-1863. Ross expresses his dismay at the paper's representation of him, particularly the charge that he is purposefully misleading the Cherokee people with regard to removal. He details the motivations for his behavior and explains his course of action. The letter is dated March 29, 1838, and contains a note attributing it to Ross.

This is a stock certificate dated October 30, 1835, stating that Robert C. Foster, I, has 5 shares of stock in the Nashville, Murfreesborough, and Shelbyville Turnpike Company. He has attached a note dated February 18, 1842, stating that he is transferring these stocks to Robert C. Foster, IV .

titleInfo.title: [Plans for the establishment of a school] 1839 Sep. 20 [Tennessee] / Daniel Montgomery

mods.abstract: This is a legal document dated September 20, 1839. Daniel Montgomery is providing land for a school house. The document also contains the monetary amounts and work that several men have donated to get the school started.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Jun. 3 [to] Harmon G. Lea Esq [uire] / Hardin P. Shannon

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Hardin P. Shannon to Harmon G. Lea on June 3, 1845. The letter discusses Hardin Shannon's affiliation with the Whig political party and events that have transpired because of this affiliation. Shannon states that elections are going to be held soon and that he will run in the election as a Whig delegate.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1798 Sep. 17, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] John Adams / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated September 17, 1798 from governor John Sevier of Tennessee to the president of the United States, John Adams. The purpose of the letter is to inform Adams of sundry resolutions passed by companies of cavalry and infantry tendering their services if they are needed.

titleInfo.title: 1850, Feb.25, Russellville, [KY] [to] Mary House, Nashville, Tenn[essee] / J. P. Ewing

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated February 25, 1850, from J. P. Ewing to Mary House in Nashville. Ewing mostly writes of the local news and personal announcements. He mentions the controversy over the newly proposed Kentucky constitution, in relation to the Democrats, Whigs, and the slavery debate.

This is a letter to an unknown person dated March 22, 1831. It is probably from Adam Fergusson. Fergusson is upset by what he sees as corrupt Demagogues. He writes about a corrupt law passed, and about supposed fraud during election time. He mentions a Colonel Parrish in relation to defalcation and the State Bank.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] August 17, Cornplanter, [PA] [to] Mr. William B. Bell, near Charlotte, Tenne[ssee] / J[ane] Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Jane Bell to her brother William dated August 17, probably 1840. Jane offers the good news that, contrary to previous worries, she is still alive and well. She also writes that millwrights have been in town and that they will be leaving soon. She regrets that she has not seen all their work as apparently it is as entertaining as a stage show. She writes that she is expecting visits from many family members and that it would be nice if someone from TN came also. She wants William to write her weekly.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of mid-18th century European manufactured iron hoe, Chota] / [by David Stansberry]

mods.abstract: This photograph is of a European manufactured iron hoe head traded to the Cherokees in the mid-18th century. It was recovered by the University of Tennessee during an excavation of the Overhill Cherokee village of Chota. Chota was recognized by Europeans as well as other Indians for its powerful economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. The Cherokees kept small vegetable plots near their homes as well as maintained large communal agricultural fields of beans, corn, and squash. Excavations of Chota and other Overhill villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, J. Worth Greene.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Jun. 4, [to] Mr. Adam Fergusson, Nashville, Ten[nessee] / Samuel D. Hughes

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from Samuel D. Hughes to Adam Fergusson, dated June 4, 1850. Hughes asks Fergusson to send him two pistols that he can use to defend himself against a man by the name of Ross, who had earlier threatened Hughes' life.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Sept. 17 [to] Mary Jane Chester, Columbia, Ten[nessee] / Elizabeth Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Elizabeth Chester to her daughter, Mary Jane Chester, on September 17, 1840. In the letter, Elizabeth wishes good health to her daughter, and expresses her and her family's desire to see Mary Jane soon. Elizabith writes of missing her daughter, the sickness of a dear relative, and information concerning the relocation of some of Mary Jane's friends.

titleInfo.title: Letter, 1831 May 16, Milledgeville, [Georgia], to Rev[erend] Samuel A. Worcester / George R. Gilmer

mods.abstract: A copy of a letter in which George R. Gilmer, Governor of Georgia, writes to Reverend Samuel A. Worcester informing him that all white persons who refuse to take the oath to support the constitution and laws of the state are requested to vacate Cherokee lands and that the United States does not recognize missionaries acting under the direction of the American Board of Foreign Missions as government agents, May 16, 1831.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1804 Nov. 2, Knoxville [to] Return J. Meigs, Southwest Point / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Governor John Sevier to Return J. Meigs. Sevier requests a permit to provide Adam Peck with provisions to begin construction of a road through Indian lands between Tennessee and Georgia.

This is a letter written ca. 1831, presumably from James Moore King; the recipient is only identified by William. The letter consists of adulation, and highly descriptive language of audience reactions to colts and stallions at an exhibition in Murfreesboro.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: 1848 Nov. 21, Carthage, Tennessee [to] R. Yeatman & Co., New Orleans [Louisiana] / A[dam] Fergusson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Adam Fergusson to R. Yeatman & Co., dated November 21, 1848. Fergusson is getting into the business of tobacco. He is consigning his crop to Yeatman. Fergusson also wishes Yeatman to give him periodic advice, as he is new to this business.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Jun. 24, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Newton Cannon, Nashville, Tennessee / J.H. Thompson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter of request from J.H. Thompson to Tennessee governor, Newton Cannon. The letter is dated June 24, 1838; its purpose is to request a supply of muskets for a newly organized company of soldiers styled the "Columbia Blues."

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1817 Sep. 30, Plainfield, North Carolina [to] James M. King, Rutherford County, Tennessee / Ann Eliza King

mods.abstract: A letter dated September 30th 1817 from Ann Eliza King, writing from Plainfield, North Carolina to her cousin James Moore King in Rutherford County, Tennessee. She urges him to find a wife, and offers hope on finding an appropriate bride.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

mods.abstract: This is a letter written on March 7, 1850 to James King, from Thomas Moore. Moore discusses his farm and the desire for more slaves for himself and other family members.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: A Bill : Appropriating a certain sum of money to defray the expense of holding a treaty with the Indians claiming lands in the State to Tennessee, 1798 Jan. 26

mods.abstract: This document is a bill enacted by the Senate and the House of Representatives of the United States of America on January 26, 1798. In the bill, Congress allocates no more than 25,880.00 to be used to pay all costs of any treaty or treaties held with the Indians that claim land in the state of Tennessee. The bill also states that the 25,880.00 will be paid out of money in the Treasury of the United States that is not appropriated elsewhere.

subject.topic: United States. Congress. House. Committee on Appropriations

mods.abstract: This is a copy of a speech given by Governor William Hall to the Senate and House of Representatives, dated September 21, 1829. Hall talks about the need for a strong and wise judiciary. He also mentions the penitentiary system. Hall talks about the need for a standardized currency to a sound economy. He explains a dispute with Kentucky over an area of their shared border.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1824 Nov. 4, Madson County, Ten[nessee] [to] Rev[erend] Finis Ewing, Cooper County, Missouri / W[illia]m Barnett

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated November 4, 1824 to the Reverend Finis Ewing from William Barnett. The letter discusses the Presbyterian religion and the need to spread their beliefs to other towns.

titleInfo.title: [Aerial view of the Chattooga site oriented to the north, taken in 1993] / [by Skyshots Inc.] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is an aerial view of the Chattooga site oriented to the north. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. Through the use of surface collection, test pit excavations, and remote sensing equipment, vast amounts of artifacts and the location of additional buildings and features were found with minimal disturbance to the site. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: 1844 Aug. 1, Columbia [Tennessee, to] J[oh]n Heiss, Nashville, Tennessee / James K. Polk

mods.abstract: This is a letter from James K. Polk to John Heiss, dated August 1, 1844. Polk asks Heiss to devote a larger section of the Union newspaper (of which Heiss is editor) to political matters in anticipation of the upcoming elections.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1803 Jun 27, Frankfort, Kentucky [to] Archibald Roane, Nashville, Tennessee / James Garrard

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated June 27, 1803 from James Garrard, governor of Kentucky to the governor of Tennessee, Archibald Roane. The purpose of the letter is the request the apprehension and delivery of Robert Wiley, who has been charged with a felony in that state.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Aug. 29, New Town, Cherokee Nation [to] Jno. [i.e., John] Ross / William Carroll

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from William Carroll, Governor of Tennessee (1821-1827, 1829-1835), to John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, dated August 29, 1829. Carroll informs Ross that the President is very interested in the removal of the Cherokees to a territory west of the Mississippi River, specifically in light of recent decisions by certain states to extend their jurisdiction over the Cherokee Nation. Carroll requests a meeting with the principal chiefs and impresses on them the importance of settling these matters peacefully.

titleInfo.title: [Letter], 1823 Oct. 24, New Town, Cherokee Nation / Path Killer ... [et al.]

mods.abstract: (Copy ?) of a letter dated October 24, 1823 from the Cherokee Council to (U.S. Commissioners Duncan G. Campbell and James Meriwether ?) concerning future cessions of land. The Cherokee government refuses to sell anymore land to the United States and offers several arguments for their position.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1831 July 9, Nashville [to] John Gill Jr., Philadelphia Pa. / Joseph P. Brown

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 9, 1831 to John Gill Jr. from Joseph P. Brown regarding various business deals including stocks and real estate.

titleInfo.title: 1808 Oct. 13, Belleview [to] James Winchester, Cragfont [Tennessee] / William Martin

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Colonel William Martin to General James Winchester, dated October 13, 1808. Martin writes to express sorrow at having missed seeing Winchester the month before. He mentions the long length of their friendship. Martin describes a recent election. He writes at length on an attempt to survey an area for logging. Martin gives his opinions on the candidates for the upcoming Presidential election. He especially admires James Madison.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1810 Jan. 3 Knoxville, [to] Winchester & Cage / Hugh L. White

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to Winchester & Cage from Hugh L. White, along with several other men, dated January 3, 1810. In the letter, White states that he, along with the other men, have been appointed trustees over a lottery to be held for the benefit of East Tennessee College. White asks Winchester & Cage, two merchants, to aid the cause by selling tickets for the lottery at five dollars per ticket.

titleInfo.title: [Commission] 1830 Mar. 29, [to] James M. Dowry / William Carroll

mods.abstract: This document is a formal commission order dated March 29, 1830, issued by Tennessee governor William Carroll to James M. Dowry as Colonel Commandant.

subject.topic: United States. Dept. of Defense. Military commission order

titleInfo.title: [Engraving of the likeness of] Lewis Cass, [Secretary of War from 1831-1836] / engraved by P.[?] B. Welch

mods.abstract: An engraving of the likeness of Lewis Cass, Secretary of War from 1831-1836, by P.(?) B. Welch. Cass was appointed Secretary of War by President Andrew Jackson and served in that position just prior to the removal of the Cherokees.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Dec. 23, Williamson County, Tn. [to] John Claybrooke / John S. Claybrooke

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated December 23, 1833 to John Claybrooke of Virginia from his son John S. Claybrooke in Tennessee. John S. writes about various business deals that he and his brother Thomas are involved in and announces his engagement to Mary A. Perkins.
This document is a letter dated December 18, 1835 to Henry Welcker from his sister Catharine Welcker. Catharine writes of various events that occurred in her boarding school in Kingston Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 May 15, Columbia, [Tennessee] [to] Elizabeth Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / Mary Jane Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Mary Jane Chester to her mother, Elizabeth Chester, on May 15, 1841. In the letter, Mary Jane speaks of events happening at the Female Institute, that she looks forward leaving there in 6 weeks, a funeral conducted by General Harrison, and the girls from different political parties and their actions.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Jun. 16, Nashville, [to] Dr. James Gorver / William H. Russell

mods.abstract: summary

titleInfo.title: [Deed] 1803 Jan. 22, Davidson County, Woolsey Warrington to Lucy White

mods.abstract: This document is a Deed for 50 acres of land in Davidson County, Tennessee dated January 22, 1803. The land was sold to Lucy White, now known as Granny White, by one Woolsey Warrington.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Mar. Fork Creek, Tennessee [to] Board of Directors of the Tennessee Consolidated Lead Mining Co. / James V. Lymons

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 1850 from James Lymons to the Board of Directors of the Tennessee Consolidated Lead Mining Company. Lymons reports on various job sites and the condition of those sites in the East Tennessee area.

titleInfo.title: 1825 Mar. 19, Madison County, Ten[nessee] [to] Finis Ewing, Boonville, Cooper County, Missouri / W[illia]m Barnett

mods.abstract: This is a letter from William Barnett to Finis Ewing, dated March 19, 1925. Barnett complains that Ewing has not written him in a while. He writes that he will continue sending Ewing letters, though. Barnett writes extensively about his Presbytery. Barnett asks Ewing's advice on whether his Synod should change to a General Assembly because of its size. Barnett writes that he lives near Ewing's nephew, Joseph Lynn. He has many good things to say about Lynn and his family. He mentions having pains in his stomach that he believes are signs of a fatal illness. Barnett worries a great deal about his ability to stay a good, Christian man. He also worries about what will happen to him if he becomes unable to preach, as it is his only skill.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1788 May 7 [to] General Joseph Martin / James Robertson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written in 1788 by James Robertson to Captain Joseph Martin regarding possible peace with the Creek Nation. Robertson wants the message of peace advertised along with the news that a road will be open and ready for people who wish to settle in Pleasant Grove.

titleInfo.title: 1845 Sep. 18, Carthage, Tennessee [to unknown recipient] / A[dam] Fergusson
