mods.abstract: This is a letter from Adam Fergusson dated September 18, 1845. The recipient is unknown. Fergusson is writing to obtain proof of a marriage.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Dec. 16 [to] Mr. N. A. McBee / David Campbell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 16, 1836 to Mr. N. A. McBee at East Tennessee College from David Campbell. Campbell thanks McBee for being invited to join the Chi Delta Society as an honorary member.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Feb. 1, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Governor McNutt, Jackson, Mississippi / Newton Cannon

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 1, 1838 from governor Alexander G. McNutt of Mississippi, to the governor of Tennessee, Newton Cannon. The purpose of the letter is the marking of the boundary line between the states of Tennessee and Mississippi.

titleInfo.title: [Certification of noncitizenship to the Cherokee Nation, 1834]

mods.abstract: This document was a statement given by Nathaniel Peak on April 2, 1834, regarding James Hanson, a white man who had enrolled as a Cherokee to be removed to Arkansas. Peak and other Cherokee certified that Hanson nor his family were citizens of the Cherokee Nation.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Jul. 14, Nashville [Tennessee] [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Tenn[essee] / Robertson, Felix [et.al.]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Adam Fergusson dated July 14, 1847. The letter is signed by Felix Robertson, A. O. P. Nicholson, E. L. Eastman, and G. C. Lorbett. The letter is describing the political situation in Tennessee. The authors are concerned about the apathy in the Democratic party. They are worried that the Whigs will be able to take advantage of it during the next election. Fergusson is instructed to work hard at drumming up support.

titleInfo.title: [Letters] 1845 Nov. 30, Haywood County, Tennessee [to] Aaron Brown, Nashville, Tennessee / William Shapard

mods.abstract: This is a brief letter dated November 30, 1845 from William Shapard to Tennessee Governor Aaron Venable Brown in Nashville. In the letter he informs Governor Brown of the detention of John Smith in the county jail at Brownsville, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: 1823 Mar. 11, Bellview [to] Francis McGavock, Murfre[es]boro, Tennessee / W[illiam] Martin

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Colonel William Martin to Francis McGavock, dated March 11, 1823. Martin writes about a mutual acquaintance named Brier. He also mentions his children and that he hopes they can becomes successful. Martin writes about the importance of patronage to a person's success.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1827 Nov. 22, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania [to] Sam Houston, Nashville, Tennessee / Sam Brown

mods.abstract: This document is a brief letter dated November 22, 1827 from Sam Brown in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to governor Sam Houston in Nashville, Tennessee. In the letter, Brown discusses a proposal for establishing a public library in Tennessee, and every state in the union.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of the post hole pattern of an excavated townhouse at Chattooga, taken in 1993] / [by Gerald F Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of the post hole pattern of an excavated townhouse at Chattooga. Townhouses were usually found in villages with a population of more than 350 people and was the most prominent building in the villages. Townhouses were where most of the social, ceremonial, and political activities took place in the village. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. Through the use of surface collection, test pit excavations, and remote sensing equipment, vast amounts of artifacts and the location of additional buildings and features were found with minimal disturbance to the site. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Mar. 17, Columbia, Tennessee [to] John Overton, Nashville, Tennessee / T. H. Cahal

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated March 17, 1829 to John Overton from T. H. Cahal regarding the purchase of mules.

titleInfo.title: [Invoice] 1810 Jan. 1, The United States to Return J. Meigs / [signed by] Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is an invoice of money due Return J. Meigs by the United States covering the months October 1st through December 31st 1809. Meigs worked as agent to the War Department and agent for the Cherokee Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Bill of Sale] 1813 Apr. 29, Campbell County, Tennessee [to] Lemuel P. Montgomery / Hugh Montgomery

mods.abstract: This document is a bill of sale dated April 29, 1813. The bill shows the sale of a negro boy, Ezekiel, to Lemuel P. Montgomery from Hugh Montgomery. The bill shows that Ezekiel is sold for $420.00.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 June 5, Columbia [to] Mary House / George House

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 5, 1850 from George House to his wife Mary regarding his travels to several cities in Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Oct. 29, Alexandria, Virginia [to] David Burford, Nashville, Tennessee / J[ourdan] M. Saunders

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 29, 1829 to David Burford from his business partner Jourdan Saunders. Saunders was on a slave trading trip and wrote about one slave who cut off all the fingers on his right hand and another who ran away. He informed Burford that the trip would not render a profit unless he recovered the runaway slave.

titleInfo.title: 1850 Jan. 24, Washington [City, D.C.] [to Adam Fergusson] / Andrew Ewing

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Andrew Ewing dated January 24, 1850. It is probably to Adam Fergusson. Ewing writes that there is no hope for the pension claim by the heirs of John Martin. He writes about the problem of California becoming a free state. He mentions a special message given by President Taylor on the subject in regards to the Wilmot proviso. Ewing thinks that the President it being unduly influenced by General Taylor. He asks Fergusson to write to him with the opinion of him and his friends on the matter.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] ca. 1790's Dec. 21 [to] Gen[era] l William Hall / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Brigadier General William Hall from Andrew Jackson on December 21 in the early 1790's. In the letter, Andrew and Governor William Blount question the term of service under which the Tennessee Volunteers are obligated to serve. Jackson asks Hall to give the Volunteers orders of service because their term of service has not yet expired. Jackson states that neither he nor the Governor can order the Volunteers, that they can only take orders from General Hall.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt for annuities paid to the Cherokee, 1812]

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt dated 1812 for annuities paid to the Cherokee Indians. Many Cherokee were paid individual sums that totaled 7,550.90 and the rest were paid a lump sum of 1,449.10.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Jan. 13, Knoxville, [Tennessee to] Silas Dinsmore / John Sevier, Governor of the state of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Governor John Sevier of Tennessee (1796-1801) to Cherokee Agent Silas Dinsmore, dated January 13, 1797. Sevier wrote the letter to inform Dinsmore that a man by the name of Abraham Martin reported that, while on his way to Cumberland, he lost a horse. Martin had reason to believe the horse was stolen by some Cherokees, and Sevier urged Dinsmore to inquire about the matter within the Cherokee nation and return the horse if possible.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1827 Oct. 17

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is from the October 17, 1827 session of court, during which a trover case was heard. The costs of suit are detailed herein. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: 1846 Jun. 6, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Maj[or] Gen[era]l Brazelton / Aaron V. Brown

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor Aaron V. Brown to Major General Brazelton, dated June 6, 1946. Brown writes to discuss troop movements. He also writes about providing provisions for the soldiers. He wants the responsibility of provisions to fall to the captains of each company.

titleInfo.title: [Letter], 1831 June 10, New Echota, Cher[okee] Na[tion] to George R. Gilmer, Governor of Georgia / S[amuel] A. Worcester

mods.abstract: Letter dated June 10, 1831 from Samuel A. Worcester, Christian missionary living in the Cherokee Nation, to Georgia Governor George R. Gilmer in response to a letter Worcester received from Gilmer. Worcester received Gilmer's letter through Colonel Sanford and is informed by Sanford that he is liable to arrest if he has not removed within ten days. Worcester defends himself against accusations made by the governor, contending that his goal is to stimulate the spiritual growth of the Cherokee people and not to revolt politically against the state. He explains why he cannot in good conscience take the oath of Georgia and describes his progress in translating Christian texts into Cherokee. Worcester is determined to remain with the Cherokee until he is forced to move. Elias Boudinot, editor of the Cherokee Phoenix newspaper is mentioned.

titleInfo.title: [Hand drawn map detailing Battle of Horseshoe Bend] 1814 May 15th, Rhea County, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a hand drawn map of the battle that occurred at Horseshoe Bend on March 27th, 1814. Led by General Andrew Jackson, the United States regular army, the Tennessee militia, Cherokee and Lower Creek Indians fought against the Upper Creek Indians at Horseshoe Bend, in present day Alabama. Over eight hundred Upper Creeks were killed and over two hundred women and children were captured. This was the final battle of the Creek War of 1813-1814. The Creek Indians lost almost 20 million acres of land in Alabama and Georgia in a treaty with the United States. Andrew Jackson returned to Tennessee a hero and was later elected as President of the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Sep. 18, Macon, Tennessee [to] Mary House, Nashville, Tennessee / C. A. Newborn

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated Sep. 18, 1850, from C. A. Newborn to Mary House. Newborn has heard of the death of Mary's husband George W. House, and wants to know the details of his life, illness, and death. Newborn also wants a lock of George's hair. Newborn also writes about a nearby boarding school for girls, run by Mrs. Miller and her husband, Rev. Miller.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1818 Apr. 16, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] John Overton, Nashville, Tennessee / Jos[eph] McMinn

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated April 16, 1818 from Governor Joseph McMinn in Knoxville, Tennessee to Judge John Overton in Nashville, Tennessee. In the letter, McMinn states that he is preparing to set out for the Cherokee agency on request of the president to supervise the removal of the Cherokee Indians to West of the Mississippi river.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Jun. 7, Madison County, Ten[nessee] [to] Rev[erend] Finis Ewing, Missouri / W[illia]m Barnett

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to the Reverend Finis Ewing dated June 7th 1825, from William Barnett. Barnett thanks the reverend for being his mentor and guide. He also writes of various religious issues with the Presbyterian Church.

titleInfo.title: 1849 Feb. 4, Clinton [MS] [to] Joseph D. Hamilton, Nashville, Tennessee / Mary [Hamilton]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Joseph D. Hamilton from his sister Mary, dated Feb. 4, 1849. She informs him that her Dr. Hamilton has bought a plantation but that they have not yet built a house on it. She has been boarding in a tavern. She writes that many people have gone out to California for the gold rush. She wants to go for the weather, not the gold. She hopes that Joseph does not want to go as it is very dangerous.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Aug. 30, Rurel Rest [to] James King, Rutherford County, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Henry King

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated August 30, 1838 from Henry King to his father James King. In the letter Henry tells his father of his endeavors at the market, as well as the prices per pound that he obtained for his hams.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Sep. 6, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Col[onel] R[obert] J. Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / Mary Jane Chester

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated September 6, 1842, written by Mary Jane Chester to her father Colonel Robert J. Chester. Mary writes the letter after returning to the Female Institute in Columbia, TN, for the commencement of the new school year.

titleInfo.title: 1822 Oct. 10, Edwardsville [to] James Winchester, Cairo, Tennessee / P. Winchester

mods.abstract: This is a letter to General James Winchester dated October 10, 1822. The author is a nephew of Winchester's. The author wishes to receive a job recommendation from General Andrew Jackson. He hopes that James Winchester can help him obtain this recommendation.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of a representative selection of Qualla body sherds from the Chattooga site, taken in 1993] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a representative selection of Qualla body sherds from the Chattooga site. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of mid-18th century iron trade ax recovered at Chota] / [by David Stansberry]

mods.abstract: This photograph is of a European manufactured iron ax head traded to the Cherokees in the mid-18th century. It was recovered by the University of Tennessee during an excavation of the Overhill Cherokee village of Chota. Chota was recognized by Europeans as well as other Indians for its powerful economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. Excavations of Chota were conducted from 1969-1974 in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The university worked under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Directors, J. Worth Greene, Duane H. King, and Gerald F. Schroedl.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Legal Indictment] 1789 Feb. [to] Washington District Superior Court / State of N [orth] Carolina

mods.abstract: This document is a legal indictment by the state of North Carolina against Ezekial Abell, dated February Term 1789. The indictment states that the grand jury of the state indicted Abell for stealing 600 feet of planks from a man named Jacob Nidevor.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Feb. 28, Hermitage, [to] Major W[illia]m B Lewis / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Andrew Jackson to Major William B. Lewis, dated February 28, 1845. In the letter, Jackson expresses his opinions on the politics of the state of Tennessee, as well as his opinions on the major political figures of the time. Jackson focuses on the administrations and actions of Polk and Buchanan.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1836 Mar. 1 [to] Isaac W. Rodgers / Lawson D. Franklin

mods.abstract: This is a loan receipt dated March 1, 1836 for $2100 between Isaac W. Rodgers and Lawson D. Franklin

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1802 Apr. 30, [to] Colo[nel Return J.] Meigs, Southwest Point, [Tennessee] / Archibald Roane

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Archibald Roane, Governor of Tennessee (1801-1803), to Colonel Return J. Meigs, U.S. agent to the Cherokees at Southwest Point in Tennessee, dated April 30, 1802. Roane reports that two white men killed a Creek Indian in Jackson County (Tennessee) and the nearby inhabitants fear reprisal from the Indians. He also advises Meigs to warn the Indians in his area not to hunt near Jackson County, as the local inhabitants are alarmed. Roane assures Meigs he will conduct an inquiry into the murder and seek punishment for the perpetrators. Another letter from Roane on this topic also appears in the Southeastern Native American Documents Database as ch017.

titleInfo.title: Land Certificate, No. 1182, 1833 Jun. 3 [to] Samuel Gragg / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: The following document is a certificate issued to Samuel Gragg of Lawrence County, Alabama, by the office of Andrew Jackson, United States President, June 3, 1833. This certificate sanctions Gragg's purchase of land in Alabama, to be sold in Huntsville.

titleInfo.title: 1850 Jan. 14, Hendersonville Ten[nessee] [to] A[ndrew] J[ackson] Donelson, Fort Larimie, Oregon Route / Dan[ei]l S. Donelson

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Lieutenant Andrew Jackson Donelson, son of Andrew Jackson Donelson. It is from his uncle Daniel S. Donelson, dated January 14, 1850. Daniel writes that Andrew's father has arrived home safely from a trip. Daniel informs Andrew that the family heard rumors that he had been killed by Indians, and were relieved to find it not true. Daniel hopes that Andrew will be allowed home on furlough soon.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Mar. 5 [to] Edward Livingston, Secretary of State / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 5, 1832, from President Andrew Jackson to Edward Livingston, Secretary of State. Jackson writes to recommend Robert Beal to fill an open position in the Patent office.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1814 Jul. 8, Camp Ross [to] Major General Jno [i.e., John] Cocke, Rutledge, Granger Co[unty, TN] / Geo[rge] Doherty

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written during the War of 1812, dated July 8, 1814, from General George Doherty to Major General John Cocke. Doherty explains that there is a lack of arms and supplies for the troops, despite regulations against having unarmed men in service, and he requests arms from Cocke. Doherty also includes an excerpt of a military order from Andrew Jackson.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1824 May 24, Washington, to Colo[nel] Thomas L. McKenney / Jno. [i.e., John] Ross ... [et al.]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from a delegation of Cherokee leaders including John Ross, George Lowrey, Major Ridge, and Elijah Hicks, to Colonel Thomas L. McKenney, in the Department of War, dated May 24, 1824. The delegation complains to McKenney about the payment of claims of the Cherokees against white intruders who have stolen and/or damaged Cherokee property. They indicate their dissatisfaction with the response of the U.S. agent, Joseph McMinn, to these claims and insist that the issue be addressed by the War Department.
This document is a Land Grant dated in 1790 for the Tennessee Company owned by Zachariah Cox and Mathia Maber. It grants lands along the Tennessee River.

titleInfo.title: [Invoice] 1809 Mar.-Oct., The United States to Return J. Meigs, Agent to the Cherokee Nation

mods.abstract: This document is an invoice dated 1809 from the United States to Return J. Meigs for services rendered as agent to the Cherokee Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1843 Jun. 28, Nashville, [TN] [to] Sarah B. Woods, Philadelphia, Penn[sylvania] / J[ane] W[oods]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Sarah Woods from her sister Jane, dated June 28, 1843. Most of the letter is updating Sarah on the activities of the townspeople. Jane also tells Sarah that there is some question as to where Joseph will be spending the fall, if he will be sent away to school, stay with Maria Price, or stay home at Westwood. The death of Henry Stephens is reported. Jane also mentions that people are trying to build a Second Presbyterian Church.

titleInfo.title: 1829 Feb. 28, Nashville [TN] [to] Andrew J. Donelson, Washington City, D[istrict of] Columbia / J. G. Martin

mods.abstract: This is a letter from J. G. Martin to Andrew J. Donelson, dated February 28, 1829. Martin writes about helping Mr Steel with a cotton shipment. He sends the love of Mrs. Martin to Donelson and family. He also writes that he wants news of the President's Inaugural speech.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1836 Dec. 16, McMinn County [to] State of Tennessee / John Austin

mods.abstract: This note, dated December 16, 1836 is in reference to a murder trial in McMinn County, Tennessee. The accused murderers, James Foreman and Anderson Springstin were both Cherokee Indians. The victim, John Walker Jr. was also a native. Springstin and Foreman employeed E.M. Churchill and Spencer Jarnigan to defend them and the case was sent to the United States Supreme Court.
This document is a receipt dated May 3, 1820. William Blythe of the Cherokee Nation, for the sum of five hundred dollars sells to Henry Welker a thirty year old man named George Kemp.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1843 Feb. 17, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Miss Martha B. Chester, Jackson, Tenn[essee] / Mary J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter addressed to Martha B. Chester from her sister Mary Jane Chester, dated February 17, 1843. Mary Jane updates her sister on her past examination and her current endeavors at the Female Institute in Columbia, TN. Mary Jane also encloses a letter to her brother John, in which she scolds him for not writing to her more frequently.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1826 Nov. 1

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Wednesday November 1, 1826 session of court, during which a case over the rights to a slave woman was heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1837 Feb. 23, to Joseph Burke / Henry Welcker

mods.abstract: This document is a purchase agreement signed by Henry Welcker of Roane County, TN and dated February 23, 1837. Welcker has sold to Joseph Burke 400 bushels of corn, and the document outlines how the transfer of the corn is to take place.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1802 Jul. 9, War Department [to] Archibald Roane / Henry Dearborn

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 9, 1802 from Henry Dearborn to governor Archibald Roane of Tennessee. The subject of the letter is the cutting and clearing of a road through Davidson and Williamson counties. Also in the letter, he discusses the contemplation by the president of the United States to the opening of a road from Tennessee to the navigable waters of Georgia.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Oct. 20

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota [also called New Town] beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is the excerpt of the Wednesday October 20, 1824 session of court, which was adjourned until the following Monday due to the absence of some judges. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 May 23, Jackson, Tenn[essee] [to] Miss Mary Jane Chester, Female Institute, Columbia, Ten[nessee] / Elizabeth Chester

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated May 23, 1841, from Elizabeth Chester to her daughter Mary Jane at the Female Institute in Columbia, TN. Chester scolds her daughter for speaking of politics and fears that such talk with threaten her father's political career. Also included in this document is a letter written to Mary Jane from her father, Colonel Robert J. Chester.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1824 Oct. 27, Cherokee Agency [to] John C. Calhoun, Secretary of War / Joseph McMinn

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Joseph McMinn, U.S. agent to the Cherokee Indians at the Cherokee Agency in Tennessee, to John C. Calhoun, Secretary of War, dated October 27, 1824. McMinn reports to Calhoun on the claim of Mr. Elsworth, superintendent of the Brainerd Mission, and the Cherokee Nation that they are due funds for the construction of a building to house female students at the mission school. McMinn refers to previous correspondence between Return J. Meigs, his predecessor at the Cherokee Agency, and Calhoun on this matter.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Sep. 26, Bolivar [TN] [to] Cordy [i.e., Cordelia Brown] / S. L. McNeal

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated Sep. 26, 1833, to a woman named Cordelia Brown from her uncle S. L. McNeal, who is probably an in-law of David Franklin Brown. McNeal is anxious for "Cordy" to come home.

titleInfo.title: [Claim under the Treaties of 1817 & 1819] 1837 August 14, Cherokee County Georgia

mods.abstract: This document is a claim, dated August 14, 1837 made by Eleanor Ragsdale, a Cherokee woman who possessed property in the state of Georgia. Ragsdale is requesting a valuation of her property and to be compensated under the Treaties of 1817 and 1819.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1813 Dec. 19 [to] William B. Lewis Esq[uire] Nashville, Tennessee / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 19th 1813 to William B. Lewis from Andrew Jackson. Jackson complains about losing the Tennessee Volunteers to sickness and desertion. He requests that the Lewis convince the Governor of Tennessee to issue an order to keep the Tennessee Militia involved in the Creek War. See also document sl005 for an early printed transcription of this letter.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 May 13, Cropland [to] Issac Butler, Murfreesborough, Tennessee / John Butler

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated may 13, 1829 from John Butler to his father Issac Butler. He expresses wishes of well-being for his father, and a desire to hear from him soon.

titleInfo.title: [Deposition] 1789 Mar. 4, Joseph McDowell, Burke County, North Carolina

mods.abstract: This document is a deposition dated March 4, 1789. It is given to Colonel Joseph McDowell in a case between James Cook and David Nelson. The case involves a dispute over the theft of a gun and the payment of money.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of a reconstructed Cherokee cabin at the Red Clay site at Red Clay State Park in Bradley County, Tennessee] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This photograph is of a reconstructed Cherokee cabin at the Red Clay site at Red Clay State Park in Bradley County, Tennessee. The cabin is a chinked log cabin with two stories. There are also reconstructed outbuildings that would have associated with the Cherokee farmers' homesteads of the time. By 1832, the state of Georgia had refused the Cherokee the right to hold council meetings unless the meeting dealt with treaties that gave away their lands. The Cherokee decided to move their capital from New Echota, Georgia across the state line to Red Clay, Tennessee because the state of Tennessee did not prohibit the Cherokees from meeting together. Thus, Red Clay became the seat of the Cherokee government in 1832 and lasted until the removal of the Cherokees to the west in 1838. Red Clay was composed of 11 general councils and the meetings were attended by up to 5000 people. It was at Red Clay that the Cherokee learned that they had lost all of their land and would be removed to the west. Red Clay consists of the sacred Blue Hole Spring, a reconstructed council house, and several reconstructed homestead homestead buildings. Red Clay is also the home to the Eternal Flame, lit on April 6, 1984. The Cherokees took hot coals from their council fire at Red Clay on the Trail of Tears. The flame was later taken to Cherokee, North Carolina in the 1950s but was returned to Red Clay in 1984. This was the first symbolic step unifying the Eastern Cherokees with the Cherokee nation in Oklahoma since their removal in 1838. Today Red Clay State Historical Park is not only a historical site, but is also an interpretive site on the Trail of Tears.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1823 Apr. 10, Nashville, Tennessee [to] William Fitzgerald / Thomas Crutcher

mods.abstract: This is a one page receipt for the payment of Tennessee state tax collected by William Fitzgerald dated April 10, 1823 to Thomas Crutcher.

titleInfo.title: [Legal agreement] 1819 Feb. 10 [between] Lafayette Sanders [and] Richard Alexander

mods.abstract: This document is a land indenture between Richard Alexander and Lafayette Sanders dated February 10, 1819. Sanders sold approximately 180 acres in Smith County, Tennessee to Alexander for two thousand two hundred dollars.
This is a letter from Jno. Navarre to James Winchester dated November 18, 1817, explaining the death of Mrs. Navarre and the return of some of Winchester's personal belongings.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Dec. 5, Harpeth, Tennessee [to] W[illia]m Carroll, Tennessee / Newton Cannon

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Colonel Newton Cannon to Governor William Carroll, dated December 5, 1825. This is Cannon's survey report from where he worked with other engineers on the route for the proposed national road from Washington D.C. to New Orleans. Cannon lists the cities and rivers they cross, including the Cherokee Nation. He also gives details about the quality of the land. Cannon mentions the route the other engineers took before he met up with them in Knoxville.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt], 1798 Jan. 30, [to] Anthony Foster / [signed by] Edm[un]d Crutcher, Francis B. Sappington

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for goods dated January 30, 1798. The receipt was given to Anthony Foster and pertained to goods given to two Cherokee Indians in reward for returning 10 stolen horses from the Creek Nation. Their payment of goods, not cash, included a rifle and powder, cloth, thread, buttons, and other domestic goods. The receipt was signed by Edmond Crutcher and Francis B. Sappington.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Jun. 16, Rural Rest [to] Henry King, Koss Landing, Tennessee / Ja[mes] M. King

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 16, 1838 from James King to his son, Henry King. He praises his son for his achievements as a volunteer in the army and is grateful for the letters Henry has written to him. He urges him to write with more information on army movements and other inside information.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 June 9, Greene County, Ten[nessee] [to] Tho[ma]s E. Abernathy / M. S. Temple

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by M. S. Temple to Thomas E. Abernathy on June 9, 1841. Temple says in the letter that although the area of Tennessee that he lives in has a good crop of corn and grain, times are hard financially on everyone and that he will have to sell some of his land. Temple inquires as to whether Abernathy would be interested in purchasing some of his land. Temple also mentions the speeches given by Martin Van Buren and that the public in Greene County are good people.

titleInfo.title: 1850 Feb. 11, Rome [to] Adam Fergusson / G. G. Dillard

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Adam Fergusson dated February 11, 1850. There is a letter from a representative of the firm C. W. Ferguson & Co. claiming that Adam Fergusson is trying to steal their tobacco suppliers. Written on the bottom of this letter is one from G. G. Dillard.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Nov. 25 Bastrop [TX] [to] Col. Joseph Brown, Maury County, Tennessee / David Franklin Brown

mods.abstract: This is a letter written by David Franklin Brown to his father Colonel Joseph Brown on November 25 1839. David Brown writes that his crops have failed due to lack of rain and that they still have problems with Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1827 Oct. 29

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1824 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Monday October 29, 1827 session of court, during which a series of civil cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1843 Nov. 24, Minutes of the trial of Mary Hooker

mods.abstract: This document dated November 24, 1843 contains the official minutes of the trial of Mary Hooker, accused of stealing a silk dress from a store. She was found found guilty and appealed to the quarterly meeting held the following month.

titleInfo.title: 1837 Oct. 15 [to] A[ndrew] J[ackson] Donelson, Nashville, Ten[nessee] / Dan[iel] S. Donelson

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated October 15, 1837. It is to Andrew Jackson Donelson from his brother Daniel S. Donelson. Daniel informs Andrew that the cotton crop is looking good. He updates Andrew on the health of various family members. Daniel assures him that Andrew's children are being well cared for. Daniel also mentions a local election.

titleInfo.title: Letter, 1818 July 15, Department of War to Jer[emia]h Evarts [and] Rev. Elias Cornelius / John C. Calhoun, Secretary of War

mods.abstract: Copy of a letter wherein John C. Calhoun writes to Jeremiah Evarts and Reverend Elias Cornelius to inform them that Congress is in control of the public land that was once Indian territory and will dictate where the missionary schools may be established after the extinguishment of the Indian title. He informs them that the four youths, which accompany them on their way to a school in Connecticut, will be allowed a sum of one hundred dollars per year for four years, July 15, 1818.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Nov. 5, Batchelors [Bachelors] Hall, Tennessee [to] D[octo]r James L. Alexander / N. B. Hamilton

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by N. B. Hamilton to Doctor James L. Alexander on November 5, 1838. In the letter, Hamilton discusses several social events that have occurred in Murfreesboro, Tennessee, including a Ladies' Fair and participating in the activities at a local singing school. Hamilton also mentions that a volunteer company has gone to the Cherokee Nation, but he does not know why they have gone there. He concludes the letter by stating that the corn crop will be good in his area that year, but little fruit will be available for sale.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Oct. 29

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from October 29, 1824, in which jury foreman George Saunders accounts the many cases heard that day. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Dec. 27, Jackson, Tennessee [to] Miss Mary Jane Chester, Columbia, Tennessee / Elizabeth Chester

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated December 27, 1840, from Elizabeth Chester to her daughter Mary Jane Chester. Elizabeth writes to her daughter who is being schooled at the Female Institute in Columbia, TN, and updates her on the happenings back home in Jackson. She talks of all the people who will be recently married and mentions her husband, Colonel Robert Chester's recent trip to visit Mary Jane. Also included is a short letter written to Mary Jane from her younger sister Martha.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Jan. 29, Washington City [to] James Park, Knoxville, Tennessee / Luke Lea

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated January 29, 1838 from Luke Lea to James Park in Knoxville Tennessee. The letter concerns a matter involving testimony in an unnamed committee of investigation. Lea compares the proceedings of the investigation to the Spanish Inquisition.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of the posthole pattern of a Cherokee townhouse at the former site of the mid-18th century Cherokee town of Toqua, taken in 1977] / [by Robert D. Newman]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of the posthole pattern of a Cherokee winter townhouse at the former site of mid-18th century Toqua. Winter townhouses were cone-shaped and appeared to look like small mountains from a distance. Townhouses were used for all public, social, and political events. Some were large enough to hold 500 people. The seats were arranged like an amphitheater with the seats rising one above another, leaving an area in the center for a fire. Excavations were conducted by the University of Tennessee in 1977 in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Jefferson Chapman. Field Director, Robert D. Newman

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 August 1st, Clover Dale, [TN] [to] Ann Jane Bell, Cornplanter, Penn[sylvania] / C[aroline] D. Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Caroline Bell in Cloverdale, TN, to her sister Ann Jane Bell, in Cornplanter, PA, dated August 1, 1838. Caroline writes about the latest happenings in their Presbyterian church in Charlotte. She says that she took her first communion, and she comments on the preaching styles of the ministers. She writes that the weather has been too dry for the farms and that there are no peaches. She also writes that their mother will be expecting Jane to visit in about two weeks.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1820 July 27, State of Tennessee, to the Sheriff of Rhea County

mods.abstract: This document, dated July 27, 1820, is a legal claim concerning a legal suit brought against Joseph Tompson by William Cochrine. Tompson was sued by Cochrine over money he owed to Cochrine in the amount of 250.00.

titleInfo.title: Map of Places refered [i.e., referred] to in "JOHN SEVIER, the commonwealth builder" / Ramsey's Annals of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a map, circa 1800, of places referred to by John Sevier in East Tennessee, North Carolina, Kentucky, and Georgia.

titleInfo.title: [Lottery proposal] 1810 Jan. 03, Knoxville / East Tennessee College

mods.abstract: This document is a lottery proposal written on January 3, 1810 to benefit East Tennessee College. The proposal specifies how much and in what manner the money will be given out to the winners and what percentage would be retained by the college. The funds gained through the lottery for the College will benefit the Seminary of Education. The document concludes by giving incentives to the public as to why they should participate in the lottery, such as the fact that it will benefit and education the students of the present, as well as the future.

titleInfo.title: Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors [James Knox Polk 1839-1841] / J. S. Jones

mods.abstract: The Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors, dated 1904, contains 31 plates, each featuring a Tennessee Governor's photo on the front and biographical information on the back. This plate features James Knox Polk, who later became President of the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1812 Mar. 23, 3 Springs [to] James Winchester / Thomas Johnson

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated March 23, 1812 from Thomas Johnson to General James Winchester. In the letter, Johnson writes of the impending war with the British, and Volunteer militia service in what would be known as the War of 1812.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Sept. 29, Jackson, Tennessee [to] Mary Jane Chester, Columbia, Ten[nessee] / Martha B. Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter containing two parts, both written to Mary Jane Chester, on September 29, 1840. The first part of the letter is written by Mary Jane's younger sister Martha, who discusses events going on at home. The second part is written by her father, Robert, and discusses family events and her health. Robert writes that if she is still ill by their next correspondence, he is going to send for her to come home from school.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Oct. 28

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Thursday October 28, 1824 session of court, during which two cases were brought forth. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Aug. 1, Salem, Miss[issippi] [to] Mr [Howell] Taylor, near Summerville, Tenn[essee] / John D. Alexander

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by John D. Alexander to Howell Taylor on August 1, 1846. In the letter, Alexander informs Taylor that the Female Academy has a new principal by the name of Mr. C. A. Sprague, who plans to invite a Miss Goode to fill the position of director of the Department of Music.

titleInfo.title: Taylor Family of Fayette Co. TN Letters MS 384 (corr. 1836-1847)
[Letter] 1832 Dec. 22 [to] J.M. King / Thomas O. Moore

mods.abstract: Letter dated December 22, 1832 from Thomas O. Moore to his cousin J.M. King. Moore acknowledges the letter is long overdue, but writes that he and his family are well, except fear of being inflicted with cholera that has plagued many in New Orleans. He says the victims of the disease are greater than the number of available coffins, and that many bodies were thrown into the Mississippi river.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1834 Jan. 31, Port Tobacco, Charles County, Maryland [to] William Fitzgerald, Weakley County, Dresden, West Tennessee / Sarah Fitzgerald

Sarah openly expresses grief with a blend of good humor concerning the long absence since having seen or had communication with her son. She asks him to write her soon.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1826 Jan. 2, Mecklenburg, [to] F. S. Heiskell, Knoxville, Tennessee / J. G. M. Ramsey

titleInfo.title: [Bond] 1787 Sep. 12, North Carolina [owed to] Richard Caswell / Titus Ogden, William Blount, John Witgreaves

mods.abstract: This is a bond dated September 12, 1787. It states that William Blount, Titus Ogden, and John Witgreaves owe Richard Caswell five thousand pounds. Caswell is governor of North Carolina.

titleInfo.title: Letter, 1821 Dec. 12 to Mr. Hoyt / J[ohn] C. Calhoun, Secretary of War

mods.abstract: Copy of a letter in which John C. Calhoun, Secretary of War, writes to Mr. Hoyt and informs him that his report of the state of the Brainerd Mission and of those which have grown out of it in the Cherokee Nation was received, Dec 12, 1821.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1820 Jun. 22 [to] Mr. J. Wharton, Nashville, Tennessee / Thomas Jefferson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated June 22, 1820 from Thomas Jefferson to a Mr. Wharton. Mr. Wharton had requested information from Jefferson about an incident that occurred 40 years prior. Jefferson responded that his memory was no longer clear but he thought that a statement given by one General Smith was accurate.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1798 May 17 [to] David Allison /Andrew Jackson [and] Pierce Butler

mods.abstract: This is a legal document dated May 17, 1798 signed by Andrew Jackson and Pierce Butler. Jackson and Butler assert that they are indentured to David Allison for eight hundred thousand dollars.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of a reconstructed barracks at Fort Southwest Point, Kingston, Tennessee] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl]

mods.abstract: This photograph is of a reconstructed barracks at Fort Southwest Point, located near the city of Kingston, in Roane County, Tennessee. The barracks are made with hewn logs and are double penned structures with a fireplace in the middle of the building. The barracks were most likely used to house the enlisted men that occupied the fort. Fort Southwest Point was established in 1792 as a blockhouse post for the territorial militia troops that were protecting white settlers from Indian acts of hostility. By 1797, the militia was replaced by Federal troops whose goals were to maintain peace with the Indians and protect their rights on the frontier. During the years between 1801-1807, the fort was established as the headquarters for the Cherokee Agency. In 1974, archaeological crews from the University of Tennessee unearthed portions of six fort building foundations, the remains of a massive stone wall, and many fort-period artifacts. A 1984 excavation of the site by the Department of Conservation and the City of Kingston located the sites of a total of thirteen buildings. These buildings include an officer's barracks, four blockhouses, and several buildings that are believed to have been barracks. A complementary excavation in 1986 revealed the location of two more buildings, bringing the total to fifteen buildings. The excavation also produced a more detailed examination of the palisade and stone wall enclosures, and uncovered several historic and prehistoric features. Additional excavations were conducted at Fort Southwest Point in the 1990s yielded new information as to the fort's original layout and functions, as well as the life ways of the people who occupied the fort. Fort Southwest Point was given to the city of Kingston by the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) and is now used as a historical and recreational area.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1828 Oct. 25

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This document is an excerpt from the court from Saturday October 25, 1828 to Tuesday October 28. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Jun. 4, Washington, D.C. [to] Aaron V. Brown / G. Talbot

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 4, 1846 from G. Talbot at the Ordinance Office in Washington, D.C. to Tennessee governor Aaron V. Brown. Talbot informs Brown of orders from the Ordinance Office for a horse, and two foot regiments of Tennessee volunteers to be called into service of the United States

titleInfo.title: 1823 Apr. 4, Nashville [Tennessee, to] James Winchester, Cairo [Tennessee] / J[ohn] W. Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Judge John Overton to General James Winchester, dated April 4, 1823. The subject is Memphis, which was founded by Overton, Winchester, and General Andrew Jackson. Overton is concerned about the future of Memphis. Apparently, some in the Legislature want to take Memphis' court house away. Overton believes that this would be harmful to its success.

titleInfo.title: 1843 Apr. 23, Shelbyville [to] Samuel Orr, Mount Pleasant, Tenn[essee] / John Orr

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John Orr to Sam Orr, dated April 23, 1843. John apologizes for not writing sooner, and that he can not blame it on being occupied with women. He writes that the night before was supposed to be the Second Coming according to Miller's doctrine. John does not believe in Miller. He also mentions that he does not support the temperance movement. He reports no success at getting a job for James, and that he has not heard from an uncle or Jane in some time.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 June 8, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] warriors cheifs [sic] of the Cherokee Nation / J[ohn] Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written on June 8, 1797, to the warriors and chiefs of the Cherokee Nation by John Sevier, governor of Tennessee from 1796-1801 and 1803-1809. In the letter, Sevier explains that there has been talk of a war between the United States and England. He says that England will try to get the Cherokee warriors to fight against the Americans, and warns the chiefs not to let their young men and warriors listen to this talk and remain loyal to the United States.

titleInfo.title: Opinion of the Supreme Court of the United States, 1831 Jan. / delivered by Chief Justice [John] Marshall on a motion of the Cherokee Nation for a writ of injunction and subpoena against the State of Georgia

mods.abstract: This is a copy of the official opinion of the Supreme Court of the U.S., delivered by Chief Justice John Marshall, on the motion filed by the Cherokee Nation for an injunction against the state of Georgia. The Cherokees sought the opinion of the court on the issue of Georgia's right to extend its jurisdiction over the Cherokee Nation, effectively depriving them of their sovereignty. Marshall's decision here indicates that the Cherokees cannot be strictly considered foreign nations, as they had argued, and are instead considered "wards of the state," or "domestic dependents." This decision was delivered in the January term of 1831 and is of extreme significance in the development of Indian Removal issues.

titleInfo.title: 1841 Dec. 2, Rutherford County, Tennessee [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / Logan Anderson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Logan Anderson to A. Fergusson, dated December 2, 1841. Fergusson had written to Anderson requesting information on Jerry Smith's service during the American Revolution. Anderson cannot help him because he was not yet born, but he gives Fergusson the name of someone who might be able to help him.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1834 Jul. 7, Bristol, Tennessee [to] Horace Thomson, Farmington, Conn. / H. L. Rich

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by H. L. Rich to Horace Thomson regarding missionary work in East Tennessee. Rich requested help from his old friends in Farmington, Connecticut to help supply his religious school with books and other donations.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1787 Aug. [to] The Sheriff of Greene County / State of Franklin

mods.abstract: This document is a legal writ to the sheriff of Greene County, in the state of Franklin (Tennessee) dated 1787. The writ commands that the tenements of Abraham Purnut pay eight pounds, four shillings, and eleven pence. This amount was awarded to Charles Hays in the court of pleas.

titleInfo.title: 1842 Nov.19, 1842, Pulaski, Tennessee [to] Mr. [George W.] House, Nashville, Tennessee / D. M. Leatherman

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated Nov. 19, 1842 from D. M. Leatherman to George W. House. Leatherman has a friend who needs some medical advice from House. He is asking about the medicinal properties of the hot springs in Arkansas in relation to specific health problems.

titleInfo.title: 1842 Dec. 21, Nashville [TN] [to] Martin Van Buren, Kinderhook, New York / A. J. Donelson

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Martin Van Buren from Andrew Jackson Donelson, dated December 21, 1842. Donelson writes about his recent activities including a trip to Arkansas and long illness. Donelson also writes about a political intrigue against Van Buren and General Andrew Jackson by a Mr. Branch and Dr. Ewien.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Feb. 3 [to] Walter Moore, Rutherford County, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / T.O. Moore, Parish Rapids, Louisiana

mods.abstract: Letter dated February 3, 1833 from T.O. Moore to his brother Walter Moore. In addition to a payment of money, he urges his brother to settle on the Bayou, and writes of the wedding of their cousin.

titleInfo.title: 1843 Nov. 13 Nashville [TN] [to] Mrs. [Sally B.] Hamilton, Russellville, K[entuck]y / Robert A. Lapsley

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Mrs. Sally Hamilton from Robert Lapsley. It is dated Nov. 13, 1843. Lapsley asks Hamilton to be the house mother for the Nashville Female Academy in the upcoming year.

This document, dated October 5, 1838, is a petition from William Smith, Sally Bank, Cut Bread, Big Ratlinggoard, The Bank, and Laugh at Mush. The petiotion concerns the proceeds and net income of a Turnpike and main gate on the road from the Head of Coosa to Alabama. The petition concerns also discusses the fact that when the laws of Alabama were extended to cover a portion of the Cherokee country, these petitioners were dispossessed of ownership of the Turnpike and main gate.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Jan. 18, Gainesboro, [Tennessee] [to] Postmaster General / Sam Smith

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Sam Smith to the Postmaster General on January 18, 1825. Smith instructs the Postmaster General to forward the mail of Armour & Lake, two merchants, to their new residence in Jackson, Madison County, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1817 Apr. 29, [for] Property Tax, 3rd Collection District of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt dated April 29, 1817 made out to John McCord for forty-five cents paid to the 3rd Collection District for property taxes for 1816.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1824 Dec. 13, Highwassee Agency [to] Col[onel] James G. William / Charles R. Hicks

mods.abstract: This is a letter, dated December 13, 1824, from Charles Hicks to Colonel James G. Williams concerning a list, taken by the Cherokee Commissioners, on Cherokee who claimed pay for improvements they made to their lands.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Nov. 6, Salem, Miss[issippi] [to] Mrs Susan Taylor / Mit :

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated November 6, 1846, to Susan Taylor from her sister-in-law. In the letter, the sister-in-law discusses piano lessons she will be giving as well as her current lodging and living conditions.

titleInfo.title: Taylor Family of Fayette Co. TN Letters MS 384 Corr. 1830-1847
[Letter] 1827 Nov. 6 [to] Major W[illia]m Crisp, Nashville, Tennessee / Jas Royall

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 6th, 1827 to Major William Crisp from Jas Royall regarding a journal manuscript that Royall is waiting to be printed.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1848 Jan.16, Abingdon, Va. [to] Moses W. White, Knoxville, Tennessee / William G. Campbell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by William G. Campbell to his friend Moses White in 1848. Campbell writes of his social life in Virginia and inquires about his lady friends back in Knoxville, Tennessee.

This is a letter dated December 20, 1843 from Thomas Moore to James M. King. In addition to asking King to repent his political sins, Moore reports on the condition of his crops, and plans for future visits.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1848 Jan. 9, New Orleans, Louisiana [to] Neill Brown, Nashville, Tennessee / Z. Taylor

In the letter, Taylor asks Brown to convey his esteem to the state legislature for the invitation to visit them during their current session.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1803 Oct. 10, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] John Sevier / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to John Sevier by Andrew Jackson on October 10, 1803. In the letter, Andrew Jackson challenges John Sevier to a duel. He requests Sevier respond to his challenge and to meet either in Knoxville or at Southwest Point, on the Indian boundary line, to fight the duel.

titleInfo.title: [Court record] 1805 Feb. Description of road closings in Washington County, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a court record from Washington County, Tennessee dated February 1805. The record is signed by members of the grand jury and lists roads that are closed due to being in need of repair.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1848 Apr. 5 [to] Mary House / George W. House

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated April 5, 1848 from George W. House to his wife Mary. George writes that he will be on a one day trip to see a patient who cannot travel due to asthma and cancer.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1821 Nov. 22 [to] John C. Calhoun, Secretary of War / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Andrew Jackson dated November 22, 1821 to John C. Calhoun, Secretary of War. Jackson tells Calhoun that since he has turned in his resignation as Governor of Florida he has referred a Mr. Peniurs to the Secretary of East Florida regarding his memoirs of the Floridas.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1803 Aug. 26, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] James Winchester, Cragfont, Sumner County, Tennessee / Archibald Roane

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated August 26, 1803 from Archibald Roane in Knoxville, Tennessee to James Winchester in Sumner County, Tennessee. In the letter, Roane mentions unnamed "villains' who are in involved in depraved conduct, and that it is the responsibility of the president to put a halt to their behavior and bring them to justice.

titleInfo.title: [Order] 1797 Mar. 19, State of Tennessee, [to] the sherriff [sic] of Hawkins County / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is an order issued by John Sevier, Governor of Tennessee from 1796-1801, to the sheriff of Hawkins County. Sevier stated that he had been informed by the governor of Kentucky of the murders of two Cherokees committed by Edward Mitchell and John Levingston, both citizens of the state of Tennessee and inhabitants of Hawkins County. In compliance with the demand of Governor Garrard of Kentucky, Sevier commanded the sheriff to apprehend Mitchell and/or Levingston and have them taken to the public jail of Kentucky. He also ordered that all civil and military officers aid the sheriff in the capture and transport of Mitchell and Levingston. This document was signed and sealed on March 19th, 1797.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1808 Feb. 19, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Return J. Meigs, mouth of Hiawassee [River] / James Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter from James Overton to Return J. Meigs, dated February 19, 1808 regarding David Barclay. Overton writes about Barclay's good qualities, and his unfortunate circumstances. Overton wants Meigs to give Barclay permission to start a ferry operation on the Tennessee River.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Nov. 28 [to] Mrs. [Sally Bedinger] Hamilton / Jno [i.e., John] P Freeman

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John P. Freeman to Sally Bedinger Hamilton dated November 28, 1844. Freeman writes how upset everyone is because Henry Clay lost his campaign for the presidency to Polk, but he is at least relieved that Logan County, KY voted for Clay. He also inquires about a possible land purchase from Hamilton.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1807 Aug. 29, United States to Daniel McCoy / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for payment of $50.00 to Daniel McCoy for 20 spinning wheels made for the Cherokee Indians. Return J. Meigs, agent for the War Department in Tennessee made the payment on behalf of the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Jun. 8, Nashville, Tennessee [to] William. L. Marcy, Sec. of War / Aaron Brown

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 8, 1846 from Tennessee Governor, Aaron Venable Brown to the Secretary of War, William L. Marcy. The subject of the letter concerns infantry troop formation, provisioning and movements in Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: 1819 Oct. 4, Nashville [Tennessee, to] James Winchester, Cragfont [Tennessee] / J[ohn] W. Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Judge John Overton to General James Winchester, dated October 4, 1819. Overton is writing in regards to Memphis, which he, Winchester, and General Andrew Jackson founded. Overton has had some different city plans drawn up. He writes to let Winchester know how much money he and the others involved, owe to the designer.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1831 Jan. 17, [to] James Moore King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Shubal S. King

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Dec 6, Cornplanter, [PA], [to] Mrs. [Anne] Walter Bell, Dickson County, TN / Jane Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Jane Bell in Cornplanter, PA, to her mother Anne Bell in Cloverdale, TN, dated December 6, 1837. Jane has decided to marry Mr. Bell without her parents expressed consent, although she knows they do like him. She believes she will not make a very good wife because she is sickly. Even though her new family has been very welcoming, she misses her old family and friends and says that she will always consider Clover Dale her home. She also fears that her family will not keep in touch as much as she would like.

titleInfo.title: [Military order] 1812 Dec. 30 [to] Quarter Master of 1st Regiment of Tennessee Volunteers / James Henderson

mods.abstract: This is a legal document written on December 30, 1812 by James Henderson, the Brigade Quarter Master, to the Quarter Master of the 1st Regiment of Tennessee Volunteers. He orders the Regiment to furnish as many wagons as needed to transport the baggage of the Regiment to the site of their next encampment from their present encampment.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1794 Apr. 3, Knoxville, [Tennessee to] General Smith / William Blount, Governor of the state of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to a General Smith from William Blount, then governor of the state of Tennessee (1790-1795), in Knoxville on April 3, 1794. In his letter, Governor Blount reported that French Minister Edmund Genet had been removed from his post, thus bringing to halt the project of General Clark. Also, Governor Blount referred to his correspondence with a person he referred to by the initials D.A., who had informed Governor Blount that the Commissioner of Indian Affairs was in favor of commencing offensive military operations. Governor Blount also discussed his upcoming business plans and some news from the House of Representatives.

titleInfo.title: [Household Inventory List] 1843 Apr. 7, Westwood, [TN] [to] James Woods, Nashville, [TN] / Sarah B. Woods

mods.abstract: This is an inventory of household items made on April 1, 1843. It was made by Sarah B. Woods upon the death of Robert Woods, and sent to James Woods in Nashville who was the executor of the estate.

titleInfo.title: [Computer generated map of an excavation unit at Chattooga showing post hole pattern of the Chattooga townhouse, created in 1993] / [by Eric Howard and Brett Riggs] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is a computer generated map of an excavated unit at the Chattooga site, showing the post hole pattern of the Chattooga townhouse. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. Through the use of surface collection, test pit excavations, and remote sensing equipment, vast amounts of artifacts and the location of additional buildings and features were found with minimal disturbance to the site. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Apr. 8, Walnut Grove, Rutherford C[oun]ty, Tennessee [to] Cha[rle]s F. Welcker, Taladega [i.e., Talladega], Alabama / J M Mitchell

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated April 8, 1835, from J. M. Mitchell in Walnut Grove, Tennessee, to Charles F. Welcker in Talladega, Alabama. Mitchell writes the letter to discuss Welcker's horse breeding business. Mitchell advises Welcker that it is in the interest of his business to come to Walnut Grove, and he also informs Welcker of his plans of starting a cotton business in Mississippi.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Jul. 18, New York [to] John Dickenson, Nashville, Tennessee / Samuel Ferguson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Samuel Ferguson to John Dickenson on July 18, 1815. In the letter, Ferguson asks Dickenson to collect a debt from a George Poyzer and give the proceeds to a man named William Seger. Ferguson also includes directions as to how the debt of $1298.00 is to be collected and paid.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Dec. 12, Madisonville, Kentucky [to] James Jones, Nashville, Tennessee / A.R. Murray

mods.abstract: This document is a letter of inquiry concerning the United States presidential election of 1844, between Henry Clay for the Whig party, and James K. Polk, a member of the Democratic party. The purpose of the letter, written by A.R. Murray in Madisonville, Kentucky to the governor of Tennessee, James Jones in Nashville, is to determine the exact majority vote in the election of the previous month. Polk won the election, becoming the nations eleventh Chief Executive, and the last Jacksonian Democrat in the White House.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 Jun. 14 [to] Samuel Houston, Nashville, Ten [nessee] / R M Woods

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Governor Samuel Houston (1827-1829) from R M Woods on June 14, 1828. R M Woods asks for the pardon of a farmer named Daniel Allen. Woods states that this farmer is respected by his neighbors and is needed to support his family as reasons that he should be pardoned.

titleInfo.title: 1851 Oct. 26, Phila[delphia, PA] [to A. J. Donelson] / John D. Martin

mods.abstract: This is a letter form John D. Martin dated October 26, 1851. It is believed to be to A. J. Donelson. Martin is borrowing money for school. He also thanks Donelson for being a good role model.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1827 Oct. 23

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Tuesday October 23, 1827 session of court, during which both criminal and civil cases were heard. A breakdown of court costs are included for two of the cases. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: 1795 Dec. 10, Nashville [Territory South of the Ohio River, to] David Henley / J.W. Overton

Overton reports that persons named Allison and Evans are broke, and consequently have stopped making payments on their debts. The debts are owed to Mr. Tait. Overton blames Governor William Blount, who also owes money to Tait, as the prime cause of everyone's financial problems.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1796 Apr. 25, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] W[illia]m Blount [and] W[illia]m Cocke / John Sevier

Sevier writes that a seal has been requested but there are no suitable artists in the state. He wants Blount and Cocke to find an artist in Philadelphia to create an appropriate seal for Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1804 Apr. 4, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Colo[nel] Hugh Montgomery / J[ohn] Sevier: a machine-readable transcription of an image

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) to Colonel Hugh Montgomery on April 4, 1804. The letter states that people have illegally settled on Indian lands and that troops are going to be employed to remove them. Sevier instructs Montgomery to warn these settlers of the dangers to which they will be exposed if they trespass on Indian lands.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Feb. 6, Spring Place, GA [to] W[illia]m Schley, Gov[ernor] of Georgia / Ben[jamin] F. Currey

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 6, 1836, from Benjamin Currey, U.S. agent to the Cherokee Nation, to Governor William Schley of Georgia. Currey warns Schley that the Cherokees in Georgia may be enlisting the help of the Creek Indians in order to resist removal west of the Mississippi River.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1818 Dec. 11, Cherokee Agency, [to] Secretary [of State Daniel Graham] / Joseph McMinn

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Governor Joseph McMinn (1815-1821) to Secretary of State Daniel Graham on December 11, 1818. Governor McMinn writes about his efforts to sign up Cherokees to move westward and having to pay and provide them with supplies for the trip. McMinn also reports that, despite previous oppositions, he had not encountered hostilities and had signed up 300 families since October 20 of that year.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Jul. 5, Rural Rest [to] Henry King, Ross Landing, Tennessee / James King

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated July 5, 1838 from James King to his son Henry King. In much of the letter, King offers advice to his son concerning military matters, discipline, and the attributes of a good soldier.
