titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Jan. 12, New Albany [to] Father [Ethel Henry Porter] / Mary [Porter]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Mary C. Porter to her father, Ethel Henry Porter, on January 12, 1850. In the letter, Mary discusses social events happening in Connecticut, where she is attending school, and back at home, and she thanks her father for her Christmas gifts. Mary also briefly mentions her desire to find her daguerreotype, which was an early form of photography.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Sep. 10, H[ea]d Q[uarte]rs Western Division, Steam Boat Platte, near Boonsville, [Arkansas] To His Excellence Lilburn W. Boggs, Governor of Missouri / Edmund P. Gaines

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated September 10, 1838, from Edmund Pendleton Gaines, commander of the US Army Western Division, to Governor Lilburn W. Boggs of Missouri. Gaines writes from near Boonsville, Arkansas and informs Boggs of a council being called by the Cherokee in Arkansas to which several Native American nations of the frontier region were invited. He expresses concern as to the intention behind this council and gratefully reports that the Delawares and Shawnees have refused the invitation.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1843 Feb. 22, Bastrop [TX] [to] Col. Joseph Brown, Maury County, Tennessee / David F. Brown

mods.abstract: This is a letter from David F. Brown to his father Joseph Brown dated Febrary 22, 1843. David updates his father about his family, his brother Joseph, and the death of a woman named Julia Ann. David mentions skirmishes between Mexican and US soldiers as far into Texas as San Antonio. Twelve US soldiers were taken prisoner, but the people have hope they will be released because there is a revolution against Santa Anna going on in Mexico. He also mentions that Jane (unsure if he is referring to his aunt, wife, or sister in law by brother Joseph) wishes to visit Joseph in order to improve her health.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Feb. 18 [to] Mr. John D. Coffee, Nashville, Ten[nessee] / A[ndrew] J[ackson] Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from Andrew Jackson Coffee to his brother, John D. Coffee on February 18, 1838. In the letter, Andrew Coffee tells his brother about his school subjects and of events taking place that he is not present to witness.

titleInfo.title: An abstract of disbursement on account of expenses of the War Department, 1809 Apr. 1 - 1809 Oct. 29

mods.abstract: This document is an abstract of the funds disbursed in relation to expenses incurred (at the Cherokee Agency ?) from April 1, 1809 through October 29, 1809, compiled by Return J. Meigs, U.S. Agent to the Cherokees, for the War Department. The expenses are itemized to include date, person by whom expense incurred, brief description of expense, and total cost.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Jan. 28, Ross Landing, Tennessee [to] Newton Cannon / James A. Whiteside

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated January 28, 1839 from James A. Whiteside to the governor of Tennessee, Newton Cannon. The purpose of the letter is railroad construction and transportation improvements.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] ca.1824 Oct

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt, dated Thursday October 23, around the year 1824, is of two cases, one regarding and unpaid debt and the other about stolen hogs. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1818 Aug. 25, Plainfield, N.C. [to] James M. King, Rutherford County, Murfeesborough, Tennessee / Ann Eliza King

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated August 25, 1818 from Ann Eliza King to her cousin James Moore King. She wrote to tell him of a lady she has found for him to possibly marry. In the letter she offers a detailed description of the young lady, and laments about James' wasted bachelor life.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: 1832 Jan. 10, Washington [D.C] [to] E[lizabeth] Fitzgerald, Dresden, Tennessee / W[illiam] Fitzgerald

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Congressman William Fitzgerald to his wife Elizabeth, dated January 10, 1832. William describes having dinner with President Jackson. William mentions the U.S. Bank trying to renew its charter and that he doubts it will happen this session. He also mentions that his land bill is promised to pass through the Land Committee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Nov. 6, Nashville, Tennessee [to] N[eill] S. Brown / E. W. M. King

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Governor Neill S. Brown from E. W. M. King, dated November 6, 1847. King is writing on behalf of an inmate named McCoy, who he believes should be pardoned. King also relays the details of the case.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1815 Jan. 17, Daniel Bartly to First Collection District in the State of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This is a property tax receipt dated January 17, 1815. It was paid by Daniel Bartly of Washington County, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: Manners and Customs of the Cherokees, 1818 Oct. 13 / Charles Hicks [and] Calvin Jones

mods.abstract: Article entitled "Manners and Customs of the Cherokees" dated October 13, 1818 from the Niles' Register, supplement to Volume XVI, reprinted from the Raleigh Register. The article begins with a letter from Calvin Jones to Mr. Gales in which he discusses the publication of information about Cherokee society that was drawn up by Cherokee leader Charles Hicks. The article itself, as written by Hicks, gives brief descriptions of a few of the cultural practices of the Cherokees.

subject.topic: Cherokee Indians--Social life and customs--19th century

titleInfo.title: [Commission of John N. Westin to the Tennessee Militia] 1828 March / [signed by Sam Houston]

mods.abstract: This document is a commission appointing John N. Westin First Lieutenant of the Kingston Rifle Company in the Tennessee Militia. It is signed March 1828, by Sam Houston, Governor of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1831 Aug. 5 [to] William Carroll, Carthage, Tennessee / Nath. W. Williams

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated August 5, 1831 from Nath. W. Williams to Tennessee governor William Carroll. The purpose of the letter is to inform the governor that he has been afflicted with Rheumatism, and as a result is confined to his bed, and therefore will not be able to fulfill his duties in the circuit courts of Smith County.

This document is a communication from an unidentified source and is ostensibly directed to the Cherokees. The document indicates that the President of the United States desires a post road to be permitted to run through part of the Cherokee Nation, the Creek Nation and the Choctaw Nation from Knoxville (Tennessee) to New Orleans (Louisiana). The communication further reveals the President's request that the post riders be welcomed and entertained by the nations through which they travel. Dated October 27, 1805.

titleInfo.title: [List] 1795 Nov. 11-27, Persons in Mero District Killed by Indians

mods.abstract: This is a list of persons in Mero District Killed by Indians, from November 11-27, 1795

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Apr. 20 [to] Governor Sam Houston / James H. Peck et. al

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 20, 1829 to Sam Houston regarding Jacob Philipson a sixteen year old boy being held in jail on a larceny charge in Nashville, Tennessee. The letter pleads for the boy's release by explaining how his respectable family suffered personal and financial hardships.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 May 3, Alexander, New York [to] George W. Sevier, Forest Hill, West Tennessee / Lyman C. Draper

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated May 3, 1839 from Lyman C. Draper in Alexander, New York to George W. Sevier of West Tennessee. Draper is preparing biographical literature on "noble and daring" men of the Revolutionary War period. This is Draper's second letter to Sevier seeking information on prominent figures of the early United States historical period. This specific correspondence is in solicitation of information on General John Sevier, George W.'s father and who Draper calls the "patriarchal father of Tennessee."

titleInfo.title: [Military commission order] 1842 Apr. 11, Memphis, Tennessee [to] James Jones / J.C. McMackin

mods.abstract: This is a response to a military commission from J.C. McMackin in Memphis, Tennessee to governor James Jones in Nashville. McMackin requests the governor to commission and give the order for arms to be supplied to the 128th regiment volunteer company of troops he has raised.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 May 20, Murfreesboro, Tennessee [to] Aaron Brown, Nashville, Tennessee / William Lytle

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated May 20, 1846 from William Lytle in Murfreesboro, Tennessee to the Governor of Tennessee, Aaron V. Brown. In this short letter, Payth tells the governor that in light of the war with Mexico, members of a disbanded company of soldiers he once commanded were determined to reorganize and answer their call to duty.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Apr. 4 Washington, D.C., [to] Alex[ander] D. Coffee, Florence, Alabama / Andrew J[ackson] Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from Andrew Jackson Coffee to his brother Alex Coffee, dated April 4, 1849. Andrew writes the letter from Washington D. C., and speaks of the political atmosphere there at the time.

titleInfo.title: Andrew Jackson Coffee Family Papers 1833-1903 MS 27
[Letter] 1839 Jun. 18, Merry Oaks, Tennessee [to] Martha King, Madison County, Hazlegreen, Alabama / Sally Gannaway

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 18, 1839 from Sally Gannaway to her Aunt Martha King. This is a very personal letter, filled with the recollections and thoughts of day-to-day life concerning the family, as well as news of the impending death of her cousin Judy.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: Account [of] Return J. Meigs, 1810 May 21 - 1810 June 30

mods.abstract: This is a copy of the account of Return J. Meigs, U.S. agent to the Cherokee Nation, for his salary and expenses relative to the Cherokee Agency in Tennessee, covering the period from May 21, 1810 - June 30, 1810.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1845 Mar. 25, United States to John H. Stover

mods.abstract: This document is a claim against the United States by John H. Stover, who lost two hundred dollars he paid as security for a William M. Green. Green ran away causing Stover to be sued and the United States rejected his claim.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1809 Apr. 11, Highwassee Garrison, Kingston, Tennessee [ to] John Sevier, Knoxville, Tennessee / Return J[onathan] Meigs

mods.abstract: This is a letter to John Sevier, governor of Tennessee from Return J. Meigs, dated April 11, 1809. Meigs is the U.S.'s Agent to the Cherokee Nation. Meigs is writing to Sevier in regards to an upcoming meeting with some Cherokee Chiefs. He is describing tracts of lands that the Chiefs may be relinquishing to the state.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 May 1, Brownsville [to] Edmund Taylor? / W[illia]m M. Smith

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from William M. Smith, possibly to Edmund Taylor, on May 1, 1838. In the letter, Smith discusses social events such as marriages and a death, his cotton not being injured by frost, and gives thanks to the letter's recipient for a loan that he might give to Smith.

titleInfo.title: Taylor Family of Fayette Co. TN Letters MS 384 (corr. 1836-1847)

mods.abstract: The following document is a recipe for ripe tomato pickle. The author and date of the document is unknown.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Nov. 3, Clover Dale, [TN] [to] Mrs. A[nne] Jane Bell, Cornplanter, PA / M[argaret] V. Bell

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter written by Margaret Bell in Clover Dale, TN to her sister Anne Jane Bell in Cornplanter, PA. Margaret began the letter on November 3, 1839, and she last wrote in it on November 15. The letter primarily relates the events happening in Cloverdale and the friends and family that have been visiting.

titleInfo.title: Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors [William Trousdale--1849-1851] / J. S. Jones

mods.abstract: The Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors, dated 1904, contains 31 plates, each featuring a Tennessee Governor's photo on the front and biographical information on the back. This plate features William Trousdale, Tennessee's Governor from 1849 to 1851.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Feb. 19, Nashville [to] Adam Fergusson, Carthage, Tenn[essee] / John S Dashiell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 19, 1846, to Adam Fergusson from John S. Dashiell. Dashiell, Grand Secretary of the Masonic Grand Lodge of Tennessee, requests that Fergusson call an action to vote on the new constitution submitted by the Grand Lodge at their next local meeting.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 June 7, Pulaski [to] Mary House / George House

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated June 7, 1850 from George W. House to his wife Mary. George tells his wife the cities he will be travelling through and which ones to write him at.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Dec. 10, Oakland, Tennessee [to] Newton Cannon, Nashville, Tennessee / Jacob Peck

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Judge Jacob Peck to Governor Newton Cannon, dated December 10, 1836. Peck wants to be hired as an engineer on the Charleston-Cincinnati-Louisville Rail Road. He writes to notify Cannon of some of his qualifications.
This document is a writ dated July 1793 and signed by Andrew Ewing. The writ orders James Cole to pay Howel Tatum the sum of 69 pounds, 14 shillings, and 4 pence half penny.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Apr. 20, St Louis, Missouri [to] Sam Houston, Nashville, Tennessee / James H. Peck

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 20, 1829 from James H. Peck in St. Louis, Missouri to Governor Sam Houston of Tennessee. The purpose of the letter is a plea of assistance for Jacob Philipson, who is charged with larceny. Peck asks Houston to consider Philipson's background and circumstances in assisting the sixteen year old boy, while admitting he is unaware of the circumstances of the offence.

titleInfo.title: 1820 Apr. 8 [to] James Winchester, Cragfont, Tennessee / Jno. Charles Cassedy

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Charles Cassedy to General James Winchester, dated April 8, 1820. Cassedy is requesting that Winchester send him a horse which he will use to visit him. The visit is on the request of Captain Eastland. He also criticizes General Andrew Jackson's advisors.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Oct. 16, Blythes Ferry [to] John Ross / James Powell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from James Powell to John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, dated October 16, 1838. Powell informs Ross of continuing problems in making ferry crossings with detachments, as a result of interference by local settlers. The letter is directed to Ross at the Cherokee Agency in Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 Dec. 1, Dresden, Tennessee, [to] John Overton, Nashville, Tennessee / John Charlton

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated December 1, 1828 from John Charlton to John Overton concerning land in Dresden, Tennessee that Mr. Charlton is leasing for Mr. Overton.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Jan. 27 [to] Peter Hardeman, New Orleans, Louisiana / John Hardeman

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from John Hardeman of Tennessee to his brother Peter in New Orleans. John writes of their various business ventures that he is tending to while Peter serves in the military.

titleInfo.title: [Letter to the] Speaker and the Gentlemen of the House of the Representatives / W[illia]m Blount

mods.abstract: This is a letter from William Blount to the House of Representatives, probably of the Tennessee General Assembly. The date is unknown. Blount is sending notification that Mr. Robertson is being added to the Committee in charge of laying out the road from Southwest Point to Mero District.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] Jun. 10, ca. 1815 [to the] Secretary of War / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This is a very brief copy of a letter, dated June 10 ca. 1815, from Return J. Meigs, agent to the Cherokee Nation, to the Secretary of War informing him of the drawing of five-hundred dollars for the promotion of Indian civilization.

titleInfo.title: 1846 Feb. 1 [to] George W. House, Nashville, Tennessee / Mary House

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Mary House to her husband George. It is dated February 1, 1846. Mary is aboard the steamboat Old Hickory in the Cumberland River. She writes about the trip so far. She mentions visiting an iron works, and that Mr Yerger has been organizing some entertainment. She writes that Susan and Sally are having a good time, and that Sally is the favorite.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1848 Mar. 12 [receipt for Miss Martha Burger] / H. H. Sullivan

mods.abstract: This diocument is a receipt issued for Miss Martha Burger by H. H. Sullivan on March 12, 1848. The receipt was for a subscription for the Southern Lady's Companion, costing one dollar and fifty cents.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1848 Sep. 19, Steamer Palo Alto [to] Ed[ward] E Porter, South Hanover, Ind[ian]a / E. H. Porter

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter written by E. H. Porter, addressed to his son Edward, on September 19, 1848. The elder Porter writes this letter aboard a steamer in the midst of his travels. He talks about the places he has been and provides Edward with the good news that he may have found a cure for the son's illness.

titleInfo.title: [Bill of Sale] 1830 Aug. 31, [to] James Goodner / Jacob Fite

mods.abstract: This is a receipt dated August 31, 1830 by Jacob Fite. He is the executor of Abner Avant's will. The receipt is for a slave and her child belonging to Avant that Fite has sold to James Goodner.

titleInfo.title: [Invoice] 1813 Mar. 13 [of] merchandise forwarded to that part of the Cherokee Nation removed to the River Arkansas

mods.abstract: This document dated March 13, 1813 is an invoice for seven hundred and fifty dollars worth of merchandise from Return J. Meigs, federal agent to the Cherokees, given to interpreter Samuel Riley to be delivered to those Cherokee who had emigrated west to the Arkansas River. These goods, which are mainly clothing and fabrics, constitute a portion of the federal annuity promised to the Cherokees for the year 1811.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1827, Feb.21, Philadelphia [to] Miss Ann J[ane] Bell, Charlotte, Tennessee / Dr. John Bell

mods.abstract: This a letter from Dr. John Bell to his sister Jane Bell dated February 21, 1827. John congratulates Jane on her new profession, and he informs her that he has taken on new student . He writes about a widow whom he befriended and who has sent a book for Jane. He also writes of a woman named Mrs. Griffith in New Jersey who has named her farm "Charles Hope" in honor of Sir Walter Scott. The woman is apparently a great agriculturalist, as well as a writer. Finally, he writes of a lady friend in France whose brother recently passed away.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1813 Feb. 3, Rhea County, Tennessee / George Starns

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for a fourteen year old boy who was sold to one Henry Welker by one George Starns of Rhea County Tennessee, February 3, 1813.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 May 29, Washington [D.C.] [to] James M. Welker, Knoxville, Tenn[essee] / George L. Welker

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written on May 29, 1844, by George L. Welker to his brother James M. Welker in Knoxville, Tennessee. George L. Welker writes that James K. Polk had just been nominated by the Democrats to run for President. He also explains that he received the news immediately because of a new electromagnetic telegraph that transferred the information from Baltimore to Washington in less than a second.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Feb. 8, Smithville, Tennessee [to] Parsons & Walker / M.M. Brien,

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 8, 1844 from M.M. Brien to the law firm Parsons & Walker. In the letter, Brien asks for an update on a pending case, and offers the attorneys additional information.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1825 Oct. 17

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Monday October 17, 1825 session of court, in which several cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Jan. 22, Washington [to] Colonel George Washington Sevier, Knoxville, Tennessee / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated January 22, 1815 from John Sevier to Colonel George Washington Sevier. He communicates the news of passage of the bank bill by congress, and that he does not believe it will be useful to the government.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1831 Jan. 31, Vineyard Hill [to] Mr. Walter C. Moore / John Moore, Davidson County, Murfreesboro, Tennessee

mods.abstract: Letter from John Moore dated January 31, 1831 to his brother Walter Moore. It is a personal correspondence updating the status of the families health and travels.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Motion for Treaty to United States Senate, 1812 Jan.10 ]

mods.abstract: This document is a motion to the United States Senate, dated January 10, 1812 regarding the ratification of a treaty made with the Cherokee Nation on December 2, 1807, at Chickamauga, on the Tennessee River. The senate unanimously voted no.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Jan. 5, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Charles F. Welcker, Mouth [of] Poplar Creek, Roane County / James M. Welcker

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated January 5, 1839, from James Monroe Welcker in Knoxville, Tennessee, to his brother Charles Frederick Welcker in Roane County. James informs his brother that he could not procure any of the clover seed he had been asked to send, nor could he manage to finish other business for their brother Henry and others.

titleInfo.title: [Military Commission] 1813 Sep. 10, Nashville, Tennessee, [for] Joseph Brown

mods.abstract: This is the military commission dated Sept. 10, 1813 granting Joseph Brown the powers of Lieutenant Colonel Commandant of the 27th militia regiment of Tennessee. It is signed by Gov. Willie Blount.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 Oct. 2, Tuskaloosa, Alabama, Executive Department [to] Sam Houston, Nashville, Tennessee / John Murphy

mods.abstract: This document, dated October 2, 1828, is a letter from the fourth governor of Alabama, John Murphy to the governor of Tennessee, Sam Houston. Murphy's purpose in writing the letter is to establish communication between the two chief-executives concerning mutual interests of their respective states. Specifically, a federal fund, approved by congress for the opening of a canal to improve navigation of the river at Muscle Shoal, Alabama. This improvement, according to Murphy, will open the market of New Orleans to much of Alabama, and East Tennessee via the Tennessee River. He states in the letter, however, that he believes the construction of a rail road would be a superior alternative to the canal.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1806 Mar. 5 to Col[onel] Return J. Meigs / The Glass...[et. al.]

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated march 5, 1806 from Cherokee headmen The Glass, Dick Justice, John (Bogs?), and Charles Hicks (acting as interpreter) to the United States Agent to the Cherokees, Colonel Return J. Meigs. The letter requests that Meigs pay, with Cherokee funds, the one hundred and fifty dollar fee owed to a doctor. Dr. McNeil was sent to inoculate the Cherokee without their request.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1798 July 4, [to] James Robertson, James Stuart, Lochlen [i.e. Lachlan] McIntosh / John Sevier : a machine-readable transcription of an image

mods.abstract: This document is a letter of instructions written by the Governor of Tennessee, John Sevier (1796-1801,1803-1809) to state agents James Robertson, James Stuart, and Lachlan McIntosh. The letter is dated July 4, 1798. Sevier stated that he appointed the agents to represent the interests of the state of Tennessee on the issues of a treaty to be made between the United States and the Cherokee. Among the issues Sevier noted for the three men to pay close attention to were the Indian boundary lines and the state districts in close contact with those boundaries. Sevier also commanded the men to examine the grounds of the Cherokee, to question the constitutionality of Cherokee land claims whenever possible, and to try to get more roads, rivers, and ports in the possession of the state.

titleInfo.title: 184[?] Sep. 17, Nashville [TN] [to] Mary House, Loweville [Louisville], Alabama / George House

mods.abstract: This is a letter from George House to his wife Mary House, dated September 17, in the 1840's. He writes that her mother will be pleased with recovered health. He mentions that he has helped a friend get well with a medicine of his. George writes how glad he is of his son's progress in riding. He has enclosed a picture of Henry Clay for his son. Among the Democrats, he writes that Polk is losing support. He writes extensively and poetically about love.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1843 May 15 Hamilton Place, [to] Gen [era] l Andrew Jackson, Hermitage / Mary A. Polk

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Mary A. Polk to her uncle, General Andrew Jackson on May 15, 1843. In the letter, Mary thanks Jackson for a picture, inquires about his health, and sends other familial greetings and expressions of happiness and love.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1798 Apr. 5, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Jos[eph] Anderson / [John Sevier]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Joseph Anderson dated April 5, 1798. The author is probably Governor John Sevier. Sevier is writing responses to Anderson's last letter. He mentions Judge David Campbell (whose arrest caused some disagreement). Sevier also states that he hopes Tennessee's border is the Tennessee River, as that would be best for the state's prosperity.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Aug. 19, St. Louis [to] Joel R. Poinsett, Secretary of War, Washington D.C./ Edmund P. Gaines

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to Secretary of War, Joel R. Poinsett, dated August 19, 1838, from Major General Edmund P. Gaines regarding possible wars with Native Americans near Texas.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Oct. 2 [to] Mrs. Elizabeth Caswell / William R. Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 2, 1846 from Captain William R. Caswell to his wife, Elizabeth. Captain Caswell was one of many Tennessee volunteers who served in the Mexican-American War. He writes about the recent battle in Monterey, and gives his wife advice on business at home.

titleInfo.title: Map of U.S. states and territories to the edge of the Louisiana Territory showing Native American distribution, 1778

mods.abstract: This is a map of the States in 1778. State boundaries, rivers, and Indian tribes living in the area at the time appear.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1807 Jan. 2, United States to John Browder / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for payment of three dollars to John Browder for repairs done for the Cherokee Indians. Return J. Meigs, agent for the War Department in Tennessee made the payment on behalf of the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1827 Oct. 24

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is from the Wednesday October 24, 1827 session of court, during which a series of civil cases were heard. The costs of the cases are described below. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Apr. 15, Nashville [to] Maj[or] Gen[era]l E. P. Gaines / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter written by Andrew Jackson on April 15, 1819, to Major General E. P. Gaines. Jackson writes to offer his encouragement and approval for the advances made by Gaines and his company against hostile Indians in Florida.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1814 May 7, Franklin County, Tennessee [to] Colo[nel] Return J Meiggs [i.e., Meigs] / Hallis Estill et al.

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 7, 1814, to Colonel Return J. Meigs, agent to the Cherokee Nation, from the citizens of Franklin County, Tennessee. The citizens write to inform Meigs of a band of thieves who have been stealing goods from nearby counties and keeping them on Indian lands.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1813 Oct. 20, North Carolina, Sampson Co[unty] [to] Mr. Henry King, Davidson Co[unty] Tennessee / J[ames] M[oore] King

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from James Moore King to his brother Henry King in Davidson County, Tennessee, dated October 20, 1813. He is conveying that he cannot send money at the time, and offering his regards for a future visit.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 May 15, Washington [to] Reverend Herdy M. Gryer / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 15, 1829 from President Andrew Jackson to the Reverend Herdy M. Gryer. Jackson discusses the many applicants he has for the new administration and how much he misses his late wife Rachel.
The following document is a voucher dated September 5, 1798, for William Mizell. Mizell served as interpreter for the Chickasaw Bluffs and was to be paid 369 dollars and 02 cents for his services.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Mar. 16, Columbus [Ohio], [to] Doct[or] A. King & Co[mpany] / J Pike & Co [mpany]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from J. Pike & Company to Doctor A. King & Company dated March 16, 1836. The letter shows a listing of medicines ordered by Doctor A. King & Company from J. Pike & Company. The medicines are arriving late because of delays due to a canal being closed. Some of the medicines listed are herbs and seasonings used to create medicines. The letter is concluded by giving a recipe for wine bitter using some of the medicines named in the letter.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1831 Feb. 6, Nashville [to] Susan Gallagher, Bangor Maine / J. Baynard Snowden

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated February 6, 1831 to Susan Gallagher from her brother J. Baynard Snowden of Nashville, Tennessee. Snowden writes of a friend moving to Cincinnati, Ohio in order to protect his children from the effects of slavery. He also writes that he dined with President Andrew Jackson at the Hermitage.

titleInfo.title: R. B. Snowden Family Papers 1807-1950, MS65
Letter, 1816 May 14, War Department to Rev[erend] C[yrus] Kingsbury / W[illia]m H. Crawford, Sec[retar]y of War

mods.abstract: Copy of a letter dated May 14, 1816 from Secretary of War William H. Crawford to American Board missionary Cyrus Kingsbury in response to Kingsbury's request for aid in establishing schools in the Cherokee Nation. Crawford reports that President Madison approves of the project, and he will give aid within the limits of the law. Crawford sets forth instructions for the application and receipt of supplies and equipment for the schools and informs Kingsbury that the president expects an annual report on their progress.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Apr. 6, Kingston [to] C[harles] F. Welcker, Talladega, Alabama / Henry I. Welcker

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 6, 1838, from Henry Inman Welcker in Kingston, Tennessee, to his brother Charles Frederick Welcker in Talladega, Alabama. Henry writes about a trip he had recently taken up north to purchase goods for his mercantile business. He describes his modes of travel, the fierce weather conditions, and the people he encountered along the way.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1818 Mar. 7, Westwood, [TN] [to] Joseph Woods, New Orleans, [LA] / J. W.

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Joseph Woods from someone with the initials J. W., dated March 7, 1818. The author of the letter is updating Joseph on the news from Westwood, people's health, and their activities.

titleInfo.title: [Talk] 1823 Oct. 27, Newtown, to D[uncan] G. Campbell and Ja[me]s Meriwether / Path Killer ... [et al.]

mods.abstract: This document is a talk from the General Council of the Cherokee Nation to U.S. treaty commissioners Duncan G. Campbell and James Meriwether, dated October 27, 1823. The Council rebuts a number of unfounded accusations made by the commissioners in a recent talk they delivered. The Cherokee Council explains that they have no more land to sell and thus, negotiating a treaty for further land cessions would be useless. They refer to the Treaty of Holston and numerous other treaties in developing their argument. The talk is signed by a number of important Cherokee leaders including Pathkiller, Major Ridge, and John Ross.

titleInfo.title: [Claim], 1816 Aug. 29, Cherokee Agency / Tetoneskee his x mark; witness by John Ross

mods.abstract: This document is a spoliation claim regarding fourteen hogs belonging to Te, to, nes, kee, that were stolen by the Tennessee Militia.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1827 Aug. 7, Fayetteville, Tn. [to] John Overton, Nashville, Tn. / Samuel Carmack

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated August 7, 1827 to John Overton from Samuel Carmack regarding essays written by Overton to be published in the "Village Messenger".

titleInfo.title: 1795 Mar. 13, Nashville [Territory South of the Ohio River, to David Henley, Knoxville, Territory South of the Ohio River] / J. W. Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John Overton dated March 13, 1795. It is most likely to David Henley who is an agent for the War Department. Overton who is in charge of revenue, is writing to obtain the amount owed to the infantry and calvary.

subject.topic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

titleInfo.title: 1835 Jan. 5, Peyton's Creek, Smith County [Tennessee to unknown recipient] / [Adam Fergusson]

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated January 5, 1835 to an unknown person. It is probably from Adam Fergusson who is head of Tennessee's pension office. Fergusson asks the recipient some questions about pension law, especially pertaining to widows and heirs of deceased soldiers. He also enquires about a recently passed Congressional act.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1809 Sep. 18, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Colonel Jonathan Meigs / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated September 18, 1809 from John Sevier to Colonel Jonathan Meigs. This is a very brief note concerning the Kentucky convention with the Chickasaw Indians, and negotiations of a treaty.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of the Great Spring at the Red Clay site at Red Clay State Park in Bradley County, Tennessee] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl]

mods.abstract: This photograph is of the Great Spring at the Red Clay site at Red Clay State Park in Bradley County, Tennessee. The Great Spring, also known as the Blue Hole Spring, is a natural spring that not only supplied the Cherokees who met here with potable water, but was also a sacred and spiritual place for them. By 1832, the state of Georgia had refused the Cherokee the right to hold council meetings unless the meeting dealt with treaties that gave away their lands. The Cherokee decided to move their capital from New Echota, Georgia across the state line to Red Clay, Tennessee because the state of Tennessee did not prohibit the Cherokees from meeting together. Thus, Red Clay became the sear of the Cherokee government in 1832 and lasted until the removal of the Cherokees to the west in 1838. Red Clay was composed of 11 general councils and the meetings were attended by up to 5000 people. It was at Red Clay that the Cherokee learned that they had lost all of their land and would be removed to the west. Red Clay consists of the sacred Blue Hole Spring, a reconstructed council house, and several reconstructed homestead buildings. Red Clay is also the home to the Eternal Flame, lit on April 6, 1984. The Cherokees took hot coals from their council fire at Ted Clay on the Trail of Tears. The flame was later taken to Cherokee, North Carolina in the 1950s but was returned to Red Clay in 1984. This was the first symbolic step unifying the Eastern Cherokees with the Cherokee Nation in Oklahoma since their removal in 1838. Today Red Clay State Historical Park is not only a historical site, but is also an interpretive site on the Trail of Tears.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Jul. 24, Nashville, Tennessee [to] A.R. Longren / Aaron Brown

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated July 24, 1846 from the eleventh Governor of Tennessee, Aaron V. Brown, to A.R. Longren. The subject of the letter concerns military matters, including the expressed adulation and high regard for the performance of, and high number of troop volunteers from East Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Invoice] 1812 Nov. 30 [of] Merchandise forwarded to that part of the Arkansas river in charge of John Ross

mods.abstract: This is an invoice of merchandise forwarded to a section of the Cherokee who were removed to the river Arkansas. The merchandise, given by the United States government, covered a wide range of items from fabrics to hatchets to kitchen utensils. These goods were received by John Ross from Colonel Return J. Meigs.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of pit feature filled with refuse at mid-18th century Tomotley, taken in 1974] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a pit-feature at the Overhill Cherokee town of Tomotley. The pit was originally used to recover soil or to store food, and was later filled with refuse. Excavations of Overhill Cherokee villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project. Excavations continued until 1983, and laboratory studies and report preparation continued until 1987. The excavations were conducted in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River Valley, in eastern Tennessee, by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal Investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, Gerald F. Schrodel.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Jan. 11 [to] Mr. Alex D. Coffee, University of Nashville, Tennessee / A [ndrew] J [ackson] Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Andrew Jackson Coffee to his brother, Alex D. Coffee, dated January 11, 1840. Alex is studying at the University of Nashville, Tennessee, and Andrew writes to him telling of events that have occured to others that they know and to himself.

titleInfo.title: Andrew Jackson Coffee Family Papers 1833-1903 MS 27
[Letter] 1844 Jun. 25, Jackson, Tenn[essee] [to] Col[onel] Robert J. Chester, Jonesboro, East Tennessee / M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated June 25, 1844, from Mary Jane Chester in Jackson, TN, to her father Colonel Robert J. Chester. Colonel Chester was visiting his family in Jonesboro, and Mary Jane writes this letter to update her father on the news of Jackson and the condition of all the children. Among the items she discusses are the formation of a voluntary military company to send to Texas during the Mexican-American War and the upcoming plans of Jackson's Democratic Party.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1821 Apr. 13, Knox County, Tennessee [to] John Overton, near Nashville, Tennessee / Charles McClung

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated April 13, 1821 from Charles McClung in Knox County, Tennessee to John Overton near Nashville. The main purpose of the letter is relate his opinion on land acquisition, price appraisal, and use of the land along the Mississippi river.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1832 Dec. 1, Natcheze [sic], Mississippi, [to Sarah A. H. Allen] / John D. James

mods.abstract: This is a legal document written and signed by John D. James verifying that he has sold a 16 year-old slave named Feilding Blackwell to Sarah A. H. Allen for eight hundred and fifty dollars. It is dated December 1, 1832.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Jun. 13 [to] James King, Hazlegreen, Madison County, Alabama / Burl Gannaway

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Burl Gannaway to James King. Gannaway's letter informs King of the status of his plantation crops, and other items he is selling for him.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1818 Nov. 2, Fairfield [to] Ralph Earle / W. B. Lewis

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by W. B. Lewis regarding orders from the Secretary of War to General Gaines. Lewis received the wrong orders and wanted the correct orders sent immediately.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Jun. 19, New Tazewell [to] David Hunt, Franklin County / John Hunt

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter written by John Hunt in New Tazewell to his brother David in Franklin County and dated June 19, 1835. In the letter, John explains that he plans to retire from his 18 years as sheriff and move to the rich lands of the Missouri River.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Mar. 16, Camp Coffee [to] Mother, Davidson County / J[ames] M[oore] King

mods.abstract: A letter written by James Moore King from Camp Coffee, New Orleans on March 16, 1815 to his mother. He writes that he, as many in the camp, suffers from a cold. He anticipates arriving at home in April.

titleInfo.title: [Receipts] 1803 Jul. 1, [to] Sam[ue]l Hanson [and] Tho[ma]s Hayword / [Henry Dearborn]

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for the salaries of Samuel Hanson and Thomas Hayword paid by the Secretary of War, Henry Dearborn. Hanson and Hayword worked to settle the accounts of an Indian Factory the months of May and June 1803.

titleInfo.title: 1849 Nashville, Tenn[essee] [to] A. Ferguson, Carthage, Tenn[essee]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Adam Fergusson dated July 24, 1849. The author's name is not clear. The author is requesting that Fergusson settle a debt with him so that he will have more money for an upcoming move.

titleInfo.title: 1839 Jun. 25, University [of Nashville] [to] James P. Clark [et. al.] Nashville [Tennessee] / Phillip Lindsley

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Dr. Phillip Lindsley of the University of Nashville, dated June 25, 1839. It is to some esquires including James P. Clark and Andrew Ewing who are hosting a dinner party in honor of General Sam Houston. Lindsley declines the invitation because of his responsibilities at the university.

titleInfo.title: [Agreement] 1827 Oct. 25, Smith County, Tennessee [between] David Burford and Jourdan M. Saunders

mods.abstract: This is a legal agreement dated October 25, 1827 between David Burford & Jourdon M. Saunders of Smith County Tennessee to start a "negro speculating business."

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1823 Apr. 15, Cairo, Tennessee [to] John Overton, Nashville, Tennessee / James Winchester

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated April 15, 1823 from James Winchester in Cairo, Tennessee to John Overton in Nashville, Tennessee. It is a brief, one-sided letter, and its subject matter is not completely clear. Winchester mentions opposition to Memphis in an unknown matter, and developing strategy for court.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] ca. 1818 Bachelors Hall, Ladies Choice [to] Ann Eliza King / James Moore King

mods.abstract: An unmailed letter from James Moore King to his cousin Ann Eliza King, dated ca. 1818. He apologizes for not writing sooner, and of his various tours of duty, travels, confrontations with Indians and his desire to find a wife.

titleInfo.title: 1840 May 10, House of Rep[resentatives, Washington D. C.] [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / H. S. Turney

mods.abstract: This is a letter from H. S. Turney to Adam Fergusson, dated May 10, 1840. Turney is updating Fergusson on the progress of some bills being put through Congress.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1796 Apr. 27, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Capt[ain] Chis[h]olm / J[ohn] Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Captain John D. Chisholm from Governor John Sevier, dated April 27, 1796. Sevier writes his good wishes for the Cherokees, and hopes that they will stop fighting. Chisholm is going into Cherokee land regarding the supposed murder of a Cherokee. Sevier writes that he has not been able to find the killer or the body. Sevier asks him to pass on to the Cherokee his good wishes.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Nov. 13-14

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt features summaries of the first two court sessions of 1825, Thursday October 13 and Friday October 14. On both days, court was adjourned without any cases being heard.

titleInfo.title: 1829 Mar. 29, Phil[adelphia] P[ennsylvania] [to] Andrew Jackson Donelson, Washington, District of Columbia / C. J. Jack

mods.abstract: This is a letter from C. J. Jack to Andrew J. Donelson, dated March 29, 1829. Jack has applied for the job of Marshall. He states that he is qualified for the position and that the people want him to fill it. Jack complains that other people who helped President Jackson have already been rewarded, whereas he has not. He also writes that he has papers to forward to Donelson, that are for President Jackson.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Jan. 29, Washington [to] P[eter] B. Porter, Secr[etar]y of War / Jno. [i.e., John] Ross ... [et al.]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from a delegation of Cherokee leaders, including John Ross, William S. Coody, Edward Gunter, and Richard Taylor, to Peter B. Porter, Secretary of War (1828-1829), dated January 29, 1829. The delegation informs Porter that none of the Cherokee claims for property loss have yet been paid, under provisions of the Treaty of Tellico (1804), nor have claims for improvements under the treaties of 1817 and 1819 been paid. In addition, they also discuss lingering questions regarding the continuing education of Cherokee children and the unauthorized payment of a portion of the Cherokee annuity to Cherokees in Arkansas.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1796 Oct. 25, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Dog Warrior, Creek Nation / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from the governor of Tennessee, John Sevier in Nashville to the Dog Warrior, Mad Blue, and all the principal Chiefs of the Creek Nation. In the letter, the governor expresses his feelings over the peace and and friendship that exists between the two nations, and assures their safety and protection when crossing into Cumberland to purchase ammunition and other supplies.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Apr. 13, Washington to President Martin Van Buren / delegation of the Cherokee Nation

mods.abstract: This document is a copy of a letter from a delegation of Cherokee leaders, including John Ross, Elijah Hicks, and White Path, among others, to President Martin Van Buren (1837-1841), dated April 13, 1838. The delegation complains to the President that their communications in Washington were unfairly curtailed before they truly began, and the news of this occurrence has caused considerable distress in the Cherokee Nation. They prepared a Memorial to be delivered to Congress in response, and it was signed by over fifteen thousand people. The Memorial is no longer attached.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 June 18, Columbia Female Institute [to] Mrs. Elizabeth Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated June 18, 1841, from Mary Jane Chester to her mother Elizabeth Chester. In the letter, Mary Jane expresses anticipation about returning home soon, and she also discusses her upcoming examination.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Aug. 28 [to] Mrs. William R. Caswell / William Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated August 28, 1846 from William Caswell to his wife in Jefferson County, Tennessee. Caswell served during the Mexican-American War and was part of the Tennessee volunteers. In this letter Caswell writes news of illness in the camp near Carmango, Mexico.

titleInfo.title: [Receipts for merchandise] 1848 Apr. 12 [from] Parkes, Plunkett & Co.

mods.abstract: This is three receipts for merchandise bought from Parkes, Plunkett & Company in 1848.

titleInfo.title: [Resignation] 1818 Jun. 8, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Joseph McMinn / R. Houton

mods.abstract: This document is the resignation of R. Houton, dated June 8, 1818, and is addressed to the governor of Tennessee, Joseph McMinn. Houton's job, as appointed by the state legislature, was to clear the Tennessee, and Holston rivers in order to make them more navigable.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of historic artifacts recovered from the Chattooga site, taken 1993] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of historic artifacts recovered from the Chattooga site that features trade beads, a Kaolin pipe stem, gun flint, and a button fragment. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. Through the use of surface collection, test pit excavations, and remote sensing equipment, vast amounts of artifacts and the location of additional buildings and features were found with minimal disturbance to the site. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.

titleInfo.title: [Pardon] 1797 Dec. 12, Knoxville, Tennessee [for] William Sutherland, Nashville, Tennessee / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a pardon for William Sutherland dated December 12, 1797. The pardon is granted by Governor John Sevier.

titleInfo.title: [Drawing depicting Cherokee winter and summer domestic structures] / [by Thomas R. Whyte]

mods.abstract: This is a drawing of Overhill Cherokee winter and summer domestic structures. Excavations of Overhill Cherokee Villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1982 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project. Excavations continued until 1983, and laboratory studies and report preparation continued until 1987. The excavations were conducted in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River Valley, in eastern Tennessee, by the Tellico Dam Reservoir and were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA).

titleInfo.title: [Letter] [ca 1834] Alexandria, D.C.] [ to] A[ndrew] J[ackson] Donelson, President's House, [Washington City, D.C.] / Edgar Snowden

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Andrew Jackson Donelson from Edgar Snowden of unknown date. It is believed to be around 1834. Snowden is writing in reference to President Jackson's upcoming address to Congress. He wants a copy in advance for his father's newspaper. He assures absolute secrecy as to the contents. Snowden also mentions that this is the way it has always been done in the District.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of mid-18th century kaolin smoking pipes recovered at Chota] / [by David Stansberry]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of mid-18th century Kaolin smoking pipes recovered from Chota. The Overhill Cherokees traded actively with the lower Cherokees of Georgia and South Carolina. Chota was recognized by Europeans as well as other Indians for its powerful economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. The University of Tennessee conducted excavations of Chota from 1969-1974 in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The university worked under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Directors, J. Worth Greene, Duane H. King, and Gerald F. Schroedl.
