titleInfo.title: 1847 Feb. 16, Gallatin, Tennessee [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / Abram Bradley

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Abram Bradley to A. Fergusson, dated February 16, 1847. Bradley writes Fergusson that he needs and wants to see him very much. It has to do with some money. Bradley requests that Fergusson come to his home in Gallatin

titleInfo.title: 1842 Nov. 29, Nashville [TN] [to] S[ally] B. Hamilton, Russelville, Kentucky / Jos[eph] D. Hamilton, Jr.

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Joseph D. Hamilton to his mother Sally B. Hamilton, dated November 29, 1842. He writes that he has been busy with his studies. He writes that at school, one should study not only the books, but also how virtue is connected to them. Joseph updates his mother about the local news. He mentions that a count from Poland has been lecturing about the life of Emperor Bonaparte, whom he has fought alongside.

titleInfo.title: [Invoice] 1813 Mar. 13, merchandise forwarded to that part of the Cherokee Nation which has migrated to the River Arkansas

mods.abstract: This document dated March 13, 1813 is an invoice for seven hundred and fifty dollars worth of merchandise for the Cherokees who removed to the area of the Arkansas River. These goods, which are mainly textiles are a portion of the annuity due the Cherokees for the year 1811. The merchandise was received by U.S. Agent to the Cherokee Return J. Meigs, delivered by John Ross, signed by several Cherokees.

titleInfo.title: [Writ] 1830 Apr. 20, Cherokee Nation for Robert Brown

mods.abstract: This document is a writ from the Cherokee Nation with orders to summon a Robert Brown to appear at the Chattooga Court house to answer a complaint made by Tarkahakeh and Crying Snak.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Dec. 3, Spring Hill, Maury Co[unty], Tenn[essee] [to] Tho[ma]s Abernathy / Gen[eral] W. White

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by General W. White to Thomas Abernathy on December 3, 1847. In the letter, White informs Abernathy that he has twenty pieces of rope and bagging, as well as other factory items that he will sell him for five percent less than market value if he is interested in purchasing them.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1788 Nov. 17, Washington District, North Carolina [Warrant for man accused of stealing slaves]

mods.abstract: This document is a warrant dated November 17, 1788 for the arrest of Micager Crews and an unknown woman who are accused of stealing slaves from an unknown person.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837, Dec 1, Clover Dale, TN [to] Mrs. Ann Jane Bell, Oil Creek, Venango Co., PA / Sarah B. Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Sarah Bell to her sister Mrs. Ann Jane Bell, dated Dec. 1, 1837. Sarah describes the reactions of family and friends to the news of Anne Jane's recent and unexpected marriage. She also writes that the Cumberland Presbyterians have formed a church in Charlotte, and she comments on who has converted or professed religion. She thanks Jane for the many presents the family has just received from her. Sarah further writes a bit about the farm and the neighbors.

titleInfo.title: 1850 Feb. 3, Nashville [TN] [to] A. J. Donelson [Jr.] / A. J. Donelson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Andrew J. Donelson to his son of the same name, dated February 3, 1850. Donelson writes that he was upset by a false report that Andrew Jr. had been killed by Indians. Donelson has just returned from Germany, where he was serving as ambassador, and reports that his home and financial situation are better than he had hoped. He writes that he is worried about Andrew Jr. and that he is going to speak to a colonel about some vacation time for his son. Donelson hopes that being in danger will make Andrew Jr. a better man but regrets that he has chosen a dangerous career.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1803 Aug. 27, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] William Dickson / Archibald Roane

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor Archibald Roane to Doctor William Dickson, dated August 27, 1803. Roane is writing regarding a special session of Congress to discuss the recent acquisition of the Louisiana. Roane believes that Dickson has been elected to the congress, and should not wait for notification before going.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Nov. 14, Kingston, Ten[nessee] [to] Charles F. Welcker, Talladega, Alabama / H[enry] Welcker

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 14, 1836, written by Henry Welcker of Roane County, TN, to his son Charles F. Welcker in Talladega, AL. Henry writes that he heard of some land Charles has, and he offers to send some "hiring hands" (slaves) to help work the land. He also talks of some former Cherokee land that is being surveyed and sold. He further discusses some local news and events.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Apr. 13, Harnageville, G[eorgi]a [to] Charles F Welcker, Kingston, Tennessee / W[illia]m A. Love

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter written by William A. Love in Harnageville, GA to Charles F. Welcker in Kingston, dated April 13, 1832. Love writes the letter to his friend to update him on the situation in regards to Cherokee land. Love also writes at length on religious matters.

titleInfo.title: Account of a battle axe taken from an Indian at the Battle of Long Island Flats in 1776 / Alfred H. White

mods.abstract: This document, entitled "Account of a Battle Axe Taken from an Indian at the Battle of Long Island Flats in 1776," is the description of a Tomahawk rendered to the Historical Society of Tennessee by Alfred H. White. According to White's story, which was related to him by Mr. George W. Netherland, the Tomahawk was believed to have belonged to a Cherokee known as "Big Indian" on account of his stature and status. During this East Tennessee Revolutionary battle, an American soldier by the name of Moore came in contact with "Big Indian" during a charge. The two engaged in a one-on-one conflict, which eventually resulted in Moore defeating and killing the Cherokee. The referred to Tomahawk was found near where the action took place and was further believed to have belonged to the "Big Indian" because of its large size. The document was received by the Historical Society of Tennessee on January 6, 1860.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Aug. 29, Georgetown [to] John Ross / [J.?] Mason Jr.

mods.abstract: This document is a copy of a letter from (J. ?) Mason Jr., in Georgetown to John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, dated August 29, 1838. Mason informs Ross that he has recently received information regarding the emigration of Cherokees to the Arkansas territory and expresses his desire to furnish mercantile goods, to be delivered through New Orleans.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Jul. 18, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Newton Cannon / John McMillan

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 18, 1836 from John McMillan to governor Newton Cannon of Tennessee. It encloses a paper prepared in obediance to a resolution adopted by a convention that met in Knoxville on the 4th of July.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1802 Aug. 24, South West Point [to] Archibald Roane / William Walton, et. al.

mods.abstract: This document is a brief letter dated August 24, 1802 from William Walton to the governor of the state of Tennessee, Archibald Roane. It is to inform the governor of the completion of the Cumberland Turnpike road, and to ask for the appointment of commissioners for review of said road.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Oct. 3, Rural Rest [to] Henry King, Tuscaloosa, Alabama / James King

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated October 3, 1838 from James King to his son Henry King. He tells his son to finish his business of selling meat, the prices he should expect, and tells him to make plans to come home.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1848 Oct. 12, Rome, [Italy] [to Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Jackson Donelson] / Mary [Emily Donelson Wilcox]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Mary Emily Wilcox to her parents Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Jackson Donelson, dated October 12, 1848. Donelson was serving as minister to Germany at the time, and Mary writes her letter to him from Italy, where she, her brother, and sister have been travelling. Mary relates some of the experiences of their trip, discusses cities and sites they have visited, and comments on the atmosphere in Italy and her overall fondness of the place. This visit is during a year of nationalist insurgencies throughout the Italian peninsula, and she remarks on this as well.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Feb. 13, Knoxville, TN [to] Henry I. Welcker, Kingston, Tennessee / James M. Welcker

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 13, 1838, from James Monroe Welcker to his brother Henry Inman Welcker in Kingston, Tennessee. The Welckers were a prominent family from Roane County. James writes this letter from Knoxville, where he is studying law and their younger brother Albert is attending school. James responds to Henry's earlier enquiry regarding merchants going east, and he discusses family matters as well.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Mar. 30, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Silas Dinsmore / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Tennessee Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) to Cherokee agent Silas Dinsmore, dated March 30, 1797. In the letter, Sevier demanded that the Cherokee chiefs do their best to apprehend and punish those from amongst their nation who were responsible for the murders of several citizens of Tennessee. He also assured Dinsmore that it is his intention to punish any white men who committed violence against the Cherokee Nation. Sevier requested that Dinsmore read aloud to the Chiefs of the nation a letter enclosed with this one and to assure them that the state of Tennessee only desired to be at peace with them.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1821 May 6, [to] R.E.W. Earl, New Orleans / A.J. Donelson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from A.J. Donelson to R.E.W. Earl dated May 6, 1821. In the letter, Donelson speaks of the hospitality of the citizens of New Orleans toward himself and his troops while they have been there. Donelson awaits information from Colonel Forbes on whether or not he has reached Pensacola, carrying orders to Cuba for the surrender of Florida to the United States. He states that after the information is attained, he will march to Pensacola as well and that troops will soon take possession of St. Augustine. Donelson states that people are moving from all parts of the country to Pensacola and that it has the potential to become a great commercial city. He concludes by asking R.E.W. Earl to finish the portrait of Donelson that he started and present it to his mother when it is completed.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Jun. 13, Moringo County, McKinley, Alabama [to] Henry King, Rural Rest, Rutherford County, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / James King

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 13, 1839 from James King to his son Henry King. James King gives his son several directions for looking after the plantation, and requests that every thing be well tended to.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Election Notice] 1815 Aug. 13, Columbia, [TN] [to Governor] Willie Blount / [verified and sent by] James Brown

mods.abstract: This is a notice of the election of military officers held in Columbia, TN on Aug. 13, 1815. It is verified by James Brown and sent to Governor Willie Blount on Aug. 14, 1815

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Jun. 4, Ross Landing, Louisiana [to] James King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Henry King

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 4, 1838 from Henry King to his father James King. In the letter, Henry details a few days in his life as a soldier, and some details of his movements.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1794 Dec. 24, Nashville [to] Col[onel] David Henley, Knoxville / Sampson Williams

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Sampson Williams to Colonel David Henley in Knoxville, dated December 24, 1794. Enclosed with the letter was the certificate of a man by the name of Morris Shane (or Shannon). Williams also wrote of the murder of three men at the hands of Indians, and he discussed the necessity of deploying more troops for the protection of Tennessee citizens.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Feb. 19, Nashville, TN [to] Rob[er]t C. Foster 3rd Esq., Nashville, TN / Allen A. Hall.

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated February 19, 1840 from Allen A. Hall to Robert C. Foster, III, summarizing the last meeting of the General Whig Committee of Davidson County. Hall notifies Foster that he has been appointed for the 4th Ward in Nashville.

titleInfo.title: [Deposition of Margaret Carmichal] 1838 Dec. 31, Roane County, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a deposition given by Margaret Carmichal on December 31, 1838. Her deposition concerns The Pathkiller, a Cherokee Indian who was removed from his land on the Tennessee River. The Pathkiller made several attempts in the court system to regain his land to no avail.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Feb. 15 [to] Alexander D. Coffee / Andrew Jackson Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 15, 1849 to Alexander D. Coffee from Andrew Jackson Coffee regarding a mix-up in their newspaper subscriptions.

titleInfo.title: Andrew Jackson Coffee Family Papers 1833-1903, MS27
1826 Jun. 14, Nashville [to] Adam Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / C. Cooper

mods.abstract: This is a letter from C. Cooper to Adam Fergusson, dated June 14, 1826. Fergusson has been appointed agent for the Tennessee Bank in Smith County.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Jul. 10, Brooklia, [to] Sarah M. Claybrooke / John S. Claybrooke

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated July 10, 1833 to Sarah M. Claybrooke from her brother John S. Claybrooke. John writes that he is concerned over three letters, two including gifts, not yet received by his family. He gives the family a brief update on the contents of the previous letters and tells them of other matters occurring in Tennessee. His brother Thomas also includes a note to the family saying that he is well.

titleInfo.title: 1795 Oct 8, Knoxville [Territory South of the Ohio River, to] David Henley, Nashville [Territory South of the Ohio River] / Wm. Richard

mods.abstract: This is a letter from William Richard to David Henley, dated October 8, 1795. Henley is an agent of the War Department. Richard writes that he will be marching to a treaty meeting at the Tellico Blockhouse. He expresses concern that the treaty will not last long. The meeting discussed is most likely with the Cherokee and Creek. Richard mentions that Mr. McGhee won the contract to furnish supplies for the meeting.

subject.topic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

mods.abstract: This document is a journal entry written November 22, 1846 by Captain William Richard Caswell. Caswell kept a journal during his service in the Mexican-American War.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Nov. 26, Nashville, Tennessee [to] J. R. Poinsett / James K. Polk

mods.abstract: This is a letter to the Secretary of War, J. R. Poinsett from Governor James K. Polk. It is dated November 26, 1839. The main topic of the letter is the exchange of Bonds held in trust for the Cherokee Indians with the Girard Bank in Philadelphia. Polk writes that from that point on, all Bonds will be paid with specie.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1833 Aug., State of Tennessee [to] Sheriff of Anderson County / [witnessed by Will Swan]

mods.abstract: This is a court order to the sheriff of Anderson County, Tennessee dated August 1833. The order is witnessed by Will Swan. The sheriff is ordered to bring several men as defence witnesses before the court for the case O'Brien vs McCormack.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1806 Aug. 18, Natchez, Mississippi [to] Humane Society for Abolition of Slavery, Richmond, Virginia / Seth Lewis

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated August 18, 1806 from Seth Lewis, writing from Natchez, Mississippi to the Humane Society for the Abolition of Slavery in Richmond, Virginia. Lewis is acting on behalf of a family of slaves as their legal counsel. In the letter, he asks the members of the society for assistance as he prepares and argues the case for the freedom of fourteen individuals unjustly held in the bond slavery.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Jul. 6, Clarksville, Tennessee [to] John Nitchie / Reverend C. Parish

mods.abstract: This document is a brief letter notifying John Nitchie of the formation of the Bible Society of Montgomery County, as an auxiliary chapter of the American Bible Society. The letter is signed by Reverend C. Parish, Reverend H. F. Beaumont, and John M. Heage.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] London, Great Britain [to] James K. Polk, Tennessee / Thomas Clarkson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Thomas Clarkson to Governor James K. Polk. Clarkson is writing about the Convention of the Friends of the Negroes that took place in London on June 23, 1840. He is especially adamant that slavery goes against civilized and Christian values. Clarkson includes quotes from the bible to support his argument.

titleInfo.title: [Writ] 1794 Oct. The United States to the Sheriff of Davidson County / [witnessed by Andrew Ewing]

mods.abstract: This document is a writ made in 1794 to the Sheriff of Davidson County, Tennessee to order Starling Armstrong to court to pay a judgement made against him by Bennett Searcy for two hundred pounds.

titleInfo.title: Writ for the Sheriff of Davidson County
[Letter] 1836 Jul. 29, Knoxville, Ten[nessee, to] [Newton] Cannon, Nashville, Ten[nessee] / James Park [et. al.]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Governor Newton Cannon dated July 29, 1836. It is from James Park and other Knoxville merchants. They are writing over their concern about a newly passed law that is taxing goods twice.

titleInfo.title: 1830 Jun. 29, Carthage [Tennessee] [to] Louisa C. Hazard / A. Fergusson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Adam Fergusson to his sister-in-law Louisa C. Hazard, dated June 29, 1830. Fergusson writes of an address to the students at Locust Grove Female Academy by the Honorable Felix Grundy, Esq. Grundy hopes to involve the ladies in the Temperance movement. Fergusson feels that their voices are very respected and that their involvement will be beneficial.

titleInfo.title: 1850 Jun. 8, Athens [to] Mary House, Nashville, Tenn[essee] / George [House]

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 8, 1850, from George House to his wife Mary in Nashville. He is on a business trip selling medicines. Most of the letter is naming the places he is going, which are probably in Alabama, but may be in Tennessee. He writes that the towns he is visiting are very small and that it will be difficult to sell out because of that. He misses her so much that he is dreaming of her. He sends love to the family in Nashville.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1812 Aug. 11, State of Tennessee [to] Sheriff of Knox County / [witnessed by Francis A. Ramsey]

mods.abstract: This is a court order to the sheriff of Knox County dated August 11, 1812. The sheriff is ordered to bring James Park to the county court house to testify. It is witnessed by Francis A. Ramsey.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Sep. 4, Oke [i.e., Oak] Grove [to] James Paine / J[ohn] W. Williams

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by J. W. Williams to James Paine on September 4, 1838. In the letter, Williams tells Paine that he has won a Senate seat and that there is a small Whig majority in the Senate for the first time. He also mentions a drought that has destroyed most of the corn crop he farms, as well as the tobacco plants. He concludes the letter by asking Paine to either manage or sell some of the land he owns to make up for the money he will lose from the destruction of his crops.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1826 Apr. 11, Philadelphia, [to] Miss Ann J[ane] Bell, near Charlotte, Dickson Co[unt]y, Tennessee / John Bell

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated April 11, 1826, written from Dr. John Bell in Philadelphia to his sister Ann Jane Bell in Dickson County, TN. Dr. Bell writes in answer to several questions Ann Jane had previously asked in regards to vaccination. He also describes a treatment for skin eruptions and eases his sister's mind about their brother William's recent weakness of memory. Dr. Bell concludes the letter by criticizing his sister's writing style.

titleInfo.title: Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors [Newton Cannon--1835-1839] / J. S. Jones

mods.abstract: The Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors, dated 1904, contains 31 plates, each featuring a Tennessee Governor's photo on the front and biographical information on the back. This plate features Newton Cannon, Tennessee Governor from 1835 until 1839.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Nov. 30, Memphis [to] Edward E Porter, Bridg[e]port, Con[necticut] / E. H. Porter

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated November 30, 1847, from E. H. Porter in Memphis to his son Edward E. Porter in Bridgeport, Connecticut. In the letter, the elder Porter discusses financial matters with his son and encourages him to maintain his commitment to quit smoking.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1805 Aug. 13, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Major Lovely, Cherokee Nation / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated August 13, 1805 from governor John Sevier of Tennessee to Major Lovely of the Cherokee Nation. The subject of the letter is the Saw Gin, a relative new invention by Eli Whitney and Phineas Miller, that revolutionized the cultivation of cotton in the early nineteenth-century.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 May 29, Rural Rest [to] Henry King, Ross Landing, Hamilton County / Martha Batey King

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated May 29, 1838 from Martha Batey King to her son Henry King. She warns her son to take care of himself, and to observe safety and duty as a young soldier.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1826 Oct. 28

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is an excerpt from Saturday October 28, 1826. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1842 Apr. 18, The United States to Polly Vann

mods.abstract: This document is a spoliation claim made by Polly Vann of the Eastern Band of Cherokees against the United States for the amount of 264 dollars.

titleInfo.title: 1815 Jun. 30, Nashville, Tennessee [to] J[ames] Winchester, Cragfont, Tennessee / Jo[natha]n Anderson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Jonathan Anderson to James Winchester, dated June 30, 1815. Anderson is writing on behalf of the Bank of Nashville. He is explaining to Winchester why the bank will not take his North Carolina bank notes.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Dec. 18 [to] Alex[ander] D. Coffee, Florence, Alabama / Andrew J[ackson] Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from Andrew Jackson Coffee to his brother Alexander D. Coffee, dated December 18, 1850. In the letter, Andrew discusses monies owed him by Robert and William Warren, and about the explosion of the Steamboat Knoxville.

titleInfo.title: Andrew Jackson Coffee Family Papers 1833-1903 MS 27
[Letter to the] Speaker and the Gentlemen of the House of Representatives / W[illia]m Blount

mods.abstract: This is a letter to the House of Representatives, probably of the Tennessee General assembly from William Blount. The date is unknown. Blount proposes that the repairs to the road from Southwest Point to Sumner County should be given to a joint committee to oversee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1817 Oct. 31, [to] [Robert C. Foster, Jr.] / R[obert] C. Foster

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Robert C. Foster to his son, Robert C. Foster, Jr., on October 31, 1817. Foster writes the letter to his son on his birthday, and gives him advice on what to do with his life now that he is 21 years old. He advises him not to drink, gamble, or associate with 'loose' women, to be religious, watch his money, study hard, be fair to others in business, and to how to choose a suitable wife.

titleInfo.title: [Affidavit] 1818 Jan. 18, Knox County, Tennessee [to] Robert Lindsay / Jesse Terry

mods.abstract: This document is an affidavit dated January 18, 1818, it is the result of the deposition of Jesse Terry, of Roane County, Tennessee by a justice of Knox County, Robert Lindsay. The subject of the affidavit is a "free girl of color" named Peggy Scott who was believed to be stolen from her parents in Roane County and taken to Georgia.

titleInfo.title: [Deposition of David Taylor] 1843 Nov. 6, Washington County, District of Columbia

mods.abstract: This document is a deposition given by David Taylor regarding land belonging to The Pathkiller, a Cherokee Indian. Pathkiller lost the land sometime after the Treaty of 1819 and fought for years to regain it. Upon his death, his daughter and son-in-law, James Thomas Gardenhire fought to gain the value of that land.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1788 Dec., Washing[ton] Co[unty], No[rth] Car[o]lina [for] Edmond Wiliams / Wm. G. Hall [and] Wm. Purselley

mods.abstract: This is a legal document dated December 1788. It states that William G. Hall and William Purselley owe Sheriff Edmond Wiliams one thousand pounds.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Dec. 21, Mouth of Poplar Creek [to] Charles F. Welcker / Catharine F. Welcker

mods.abstract: The following document is a correspondence amongst the Welcker family, a prominent landholding family of Roane County. The letter, dated December 21, 1836, is from Catharine F. Welcker to her brother Charles F. Welcker. Catharine gives her brother news of the mill he owns, which was situated on the mouth of Poplar Creek. She also relays business advice and proposals from their father, Henry Welcker, and talks of their brother Monroe going to school in Knoxville, most likely to East Tennessee College.

titleInfo.title: 1795 May 20, Cedar Hall [to] David Henley, Knoxville [Territory South of the Ohio River] / Robert Hays

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Robert Hays to David Henley, dated May 20, 1795. Hays wants to know if Henley will be coming to his district to pay the soldiers. Hays writes that he will have the Muster Rolls ready in a month. He also writes that he can come to Knoxville if necessary.

subject.topic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1821 Apr. 25, Dixon Springs, Tennessee [to] James Winchester, Sumner County, Cairo, Tennessee / William Martin

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated April 25, 1821 from William Martin in Dixon Springs, Tennessee to James Winchester in Cairo, Tennessee. Martin's letter concerns many topics including the appointment of General Andrew Jackson as Governor of Florida. He also addresses the explosion of the Robertson steam boat and the loss of the majority of its crew.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Feb. 28, Hermitage [to] Major W[illia]m B Lewis / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is letter from Andrew Jackson (US president, 1829-1837) to Major William B. Lewis dated February 28, 1845. In the letter, Andrew Jackson states to Major Lewis his opinions about who he believes to be the best men for the Tennessee State Department administration. Jackson approves Mr. Clay for the Secretary of State position and Mr. Buchanan into the Department of State. He approves of Colonel Polk obtaining a position in the administration, but says that Mr. Tyler's succession to the administration would split the democracy apart and damage Polk's administration. Jackson concludes this letter by informing Major Lewis of his failing health. He consequently dies several months later.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1807 Dec. 20, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] The Agent and Superintendent of the Creek Nation [Benjamin Hawkins] / John Sevier: a machine-readable transcription of an image

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Benjamin Hawkins, the Agent and Superintendent of the Creek Nation, by Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) on December 20, 1807. Governor Sevier discusses the robbery and murder of two men from Tennessee, and that he suspects a member of the Creek Nation as the murderer. He asks the agent to investigate the situation and try to discover if a Creek Indian committed the murders. He claims that several parties of Creek Indians passed through the area of the killings around the same time and that these parties robbed and plundered several of the families in the area. Governor Sevier requests that the Creek chiefs put an end to the violence and migration of their people onto other lands.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Jul. 28, Hermitage [to] Fr. P. Blair Esq[ui]re / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Andrew Jackson to Fr. P. Blair on July 28, 1840. In the letter, Jackson defends Blair and General Jessup against allegations made by General Scott. General Scott alleged that Blair and General Jessup recalled him from military duty in Florida, when in fact it was Jackson. General Scott had been ordered to Florida to look for Indian warriors and to prevent a war with the Creeks. Instead of following orders to go directly to Florida, taking eight days worth of supplies on the soldiers' backs, Scott took three weeks waiting for wagons to take the supplies to Florida. Several of the soldiers were killed in an attack while waiting for the wagons, and Scott became ill. General Jessup was sent to fight the now explosive war with the Creeks and Scott went to where Jessup's soldiers were and attempted to take command of them. Because of this action, as well as not arming his troops for six weeks on the frontier, Jackson recalled General Scott from his command duties. Jackson also mentions political events in the letter, such as the pass of the Independent Treasury bill and the next Presidential election.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Sept. 7 [to] John C. Calhoun, Secretary of War / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated September 7, 1819 to John C. Calhoun, Secretary of War from Andrew Jackson reporting on various matters including the arrest of Colonel King, and a order made by the assistant surgeon general.
This is a song/poem entitled "To the Sumner Volunteers."

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1842 Feb. 17, The United States to Hunter Langby

mods.abstract: This document is a spoliation claim against the United States by Hunter Langby who was dispossessed of his property in 1836.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] [to] Col [onel] Andrew J. Hutchings, Florence, Ala[bama] / A[ndrew] [ackson] Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Andrew Jackson Coffee to Colonel Andrew J. Hutchings. In the letter, Coffee discusses his views on the issues of slavery and the Canadian difficulties with England.

titleInfo.title: Andrew Jackson Coffee Family Papers 1833-1903 MS 27
1823 Apr. 13, Nashville, T[ennessee, to] James Winchester, Cairo, T[ennessee] / John W. Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Judge John W. Overton to General James Winchester, dated April 13, 1823. Overton writes regarding Memphis, which he, Winchester, and General Andrew Jackson founded. Overton is writing about the proposition before the Legislature to move the court from Memphis. Overton is afraid that the move will ruin Memphis as a successful city. He also asks Winchester to help him with a lawsuit he is trying.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Apr. 30, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Colonel Robert Allen, Carthage, Tennessee / James Wilkins

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by James Wilkins to Colonel Robert Allen about a loan owed to him by one Dr. Pillow. The letter is also signed by James K. Polk on Wilkin's behalf.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1823 Feb. 19, New Orleans, Louisiana [to] James Winchester, Cairo, Tennessee / Breedlove, Bradford & Robison

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated February 19, 1823 from Breedlove, Bradford & Robison in New Orleans, Louisiana to James Winchester in Cairo, Tennessee. The writers of the letter express regret that Winchester is investing in Tobacco cultivation, they tell him his prospects for profit are dim considering that currently there is a large supply and little demand. Instead, they urge Winchester to consider Cotton as a wise investment in place of tobacco. They also give him news of the sinking of the S.R. Tennessee in the Mississippi river above Natchez.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Dec. 19, [near] Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Margaret Stuart, Wytheville, Virginia / Geo[rge] Stuart

mods.abstract: This is a letter from George Stuart to his wife, Margaret, dated December 19, 1849. He writes that all is well, and actually going better than expected. He writes that he is travelling about 33 miles a day.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1824 Dec. 31, Jackson, Madison County, Ten[nessee] [to] Postmaster of Jackson County, Ten[nessee] / William Armour, et al.

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by William Armour, et al. to the Postmaster of Jackson County, Tennessee, dated December 31, 1824. In the letter, Armour & Lake request that any letters sent to them in Jackson County be forwarded to them in Jackson, Madison County, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Oct. 20, Edinburgh, [to] G[eorge] W[ashington] Campbell, St. Petersburgh, Russia / Duncan Matheson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 20, 1819, addressed to Tennessee politician George Washington Campbell in St. Petersburg, Russia during his tenure as US minister there, from his nephew Duncan Matheson. Matheson writes about his brother James, who had travelled to the East Indies to become engaged in the mercantile business, and had ended up in Canton, China. Duncan asks his uncle to appoint James to the office of Vice Consul in Canton.

titleInfo.title: 1800 Mar. 14, Philadelphia [Pennsylvania, to] David Henley, Knoxville [Tennessee] / William C.C. Claiborne

mods.abstract: This is a letter from U.S. Representative William Charles Cole Claiborne to David Henley, dated March 14, 1800. Claiborne is giving his opinion on a proposed reduction in the Army. Though he does not worry about an invasion, he still believes that a strong defence is necessary. Claiborne also writes that the Army would not be able to withstand an attack if one did occur. He believes they should concentrate on training and equipping the militia as a permanent protection force.

titleInfo.title: [Legal report consisting of the] names of persons charged with the killing of Cherokee Indians on or about Jan. 24, 1813

mods.abstract: This legal report consists of a list of names of men who were present and involved in the shooting of two Cherokee men, Dick Benge and Jacket, in the vicinity of Battle Creek on or around January 24, 1813.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Nov. 16, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Senate / Neill Brown

mods.abstract: This brief letter by Tennessee governor Neill S. Brown announces the nomination of three men as inspectors for the state penitentiary.

titleInfo.title: 1817 Aug. 25, Cairo [Tennessee, to] Colonel H. Sherburne / J[ames] Winchester

mods.abstract: This is a letter from General James Winchester to Colonel H. Sherburne, dated August 25, 1817. Winchester is writing about a town he laid off. He denies the accusation that he laid it before the area was surveyed. Winchester writes that he waited for the Chiefs to take part in the line running, but that they were so late he had to start without them. He mentions a treaty that was broken.

titleInfo.title: [Aerial photograph showing the former site of Chota and Tanasee, 18th century Cherokee villages] / [by Wayne D. Roberts]

mods.abstract: This aerial photograph shows the former site of Chota and Tanasee, 18th century Overhill Cherokee villages in the Little Tennessee River Valley. Chota was recognized by Native Americans and European settlers as a powerful social and economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. The University of Tennessee conducted excavations of Overhill Cherokee villages between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River Valley by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA).

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Aug. 8, St. Louis [to] Governor Newton Cannon, Tennessee / Edmund P. Gaines

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Edmond P. Gaines to Newton Cannon, Governor of Tennessee. Major General Gaines requests three to five thousand volunteers from Tennessee to help fight due to a possible threat by Mexicans and Cherokee Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1848 Dec. 18, New York [to] Albert G. Welker, Knoxville, Tennessee / Dorenny Nixon

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 18, 1848 to Albert G. Welker regarding a draft note on the account of J. B. Morgan.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1798 Mar. 28 [Travel Permit for] James White [et. al.] / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a travel permit for Brigadier General James White and several others from John Sevier, dated March 28, 1798. The men are to scout out the best location for a road leading to the Mero District via the Clinch River and the Cumberland Mountains.

titleInfo.title: {Letter] 1818 Dec. [to] J[ames] Winchester / J[ohn] W. Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter to General James Winchester from Judge John Overton, dated December 1818. Overton is writing about the tract of land that would later become Memphis, Tennessee at the hands of Overton, Winchester, and General Andrew Jackson. In Overton's letter he is explaining who owns how much of the land then known as Chickasaw Bluff, including relatives of Winchester. He also gives suggestions about how to administer the property, and says that they should begin laying off the town as soon as possible.

titleInfo.title: [Articles of Agreement] 1805 Jun. 1 [between the United States and the Cherokee Nation]

mods.abstract: This document dated June 1, 1805 is an article of agreement between the United States and the Cherokee Nation for a turnpike across the mountains of Tennessee into Georgia.

titleInfo.title: 1833 Aug. 6, Alexandria [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Tenn[essee] / John H. Davis

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John H. Davis to A. Fergusson, dated August 6, 1833. Davis is requesting information on divorce procedures. He wants to know how easily a woman can be awarded a divorce, on grounds of adultery committed by the husband, if he does not protest it.

titleInfo.title: [License agreement] 1820 May 1 [between] Rhea County Court and Lewis Ross

mods.abstract: This document is a legal agreement between Rhea County in Tennessee and Lewis Ross, Thomas Kelly, and Miller Frances to operate a ferry on the Highwassee River dated May 1st 1820.

titleInfo.title: [Drawing of posthole pattern of Overhill Cherokee townhouse, summer pavilion, and large pit-features at Chota] / [by Marion Drescher]

mods.abstract: This photograph of a drawing shows the posthole patterns of a Cherokee townhouse, summer pavilion, and large pit-features at Chota. Townhouses, or council houses, were large circular dome structures that served as an arena for all political and social events. The summer pavilion, which was open and rectangular in shape was used for the same purpose during warmer weather. Pits were dug for burials and for storage of refuse. The drawing is based on historical descriptions as well as archaeological excavations conducted by The University of Tennessee from 1969-1974. The excavations were conducted in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Directors, J. Worth Greene, Duane H. King, and Gerald F. Schroedl.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Nov. 5, Ross' Landing, Ten[nessee] [to] Mr. C[harles] F. Welcker, Talladega, Ala[bama] / A[lbert] S. Lenoir

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 5, 1838, from Albert S. Lenoir at Ross' Landing, Tennessee to his brother-in-law Charles Frederick Welcker in Talladega, Alabama. Albert discusses his personal business and that of the family, and he also talks of going soon to Roane County. He also mentions the building of a Georgia railroad.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Jan. 23, Warrenton, Virginia [to] D. Burford, Dixons Spring Tennessee/ J. Saunders

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated January 23, 1835 from J. Saunders in Warrenton, Virginia to David Burford in Dixons Spring, Tennessee. The subject of the letter is business, specifically slave labor speculation involving the purchase of slaves to send to the market.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Sep. 10, Nashville, Tennessee [to] William Fitzgerald, Paris, Tennessee / P. Trustley

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated September 10, 1844 from P. Trustley to William Fitzgerald for the arrangement of speakers representing the Whig and Democratic parties in Fitzgerald's old neighborhood.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1793 Sep. 16, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Colonel Daniel Kenedy, Greene County, Tennessee / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written in 1793 by John Sevier to Colonel Daniel Kenedy. Sevier complained that only half of the men from Greene County had shown up for for military service on the frontier. Sevier demanded Colonel Kenedy to send the other half of the troops.

titleInfo.title: [Petition] Stuart County Kentucky, re: Walkers line [to] Sam Houston / Citizens of Stuart County

mods.abstract: This document is a petition to governor Sam Houston of Tennessee regarding the settling of the state boundary line separating Stuart and Trigg counties on the Tennessee/Kentucky border.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1814 Feb.11, Rosses [i.e. Ross's] Lookout Mountain, [Tennessee], [to] R[eturn] J[onathon] Meigs / G[ideon] Morgan

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Return J. Meigs, agent to the Cherokee, from Gideon Morgan, Colonel of Cherokee forces, on February 11, 1814. In the letter, Morgan asks Meigs for 200 blankets for the Cherokee because they are without warm clothing. Morgan says that the Cherokee will repay Meigs for the blankets. Morgan urges Meigs to send them before they leave for Fort Armstrong or else the blankets will be useless.

titleInfo.title: [Letter], 1835[?] Oct. 7, Executive Department to the National Committee / Jo[h]n Ross

mods.abstract: Letter dated October 7, (1835 ?) from John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, to the (Cherokee ?) National Committee in regard to mining. Ross believes that the proposed bill, allowing prospectors to mine within the country would be detrimental to the Nation.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1807 Dec. 14 [to] Maj[or] W[illia]m B Lewis / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Andrew Jackson to Major William B. Lewis on December 14, 1807. In the letter, Jackson orders Major Lewis to allow the Tennessee Volunteers to return to Nashville, not enter them into service again soon, and pay them 10 dollars apiece for their weapons.

titleInfo.title: [Computer generated topographic site map of the Chattooga site, created in 1993] / [by Eric Howard and Brett Riggs] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is a computer generated topographic site map of the Chattooga site indicating the location of archaeological structures. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. Through the use of surface collection, test pit excavations, and remote sensing equipment, vast amounts of artifacts and the location of additional buildings and features were found with minimal disturbance to the site. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Apr. 12, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Colonel John Sevier, Knoxville, Tennessee / Judge Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated April 12, 1815 from Judge Overton to Colonel John Sevier. The contents of the letter include instructions regarding a law suit.

titleInfo.title: Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors [William Blount-1790-1796] / J. S. Jones

mods.abstract: The Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors, dated 1904, contains 31 plates, each featuring a Tennessee Governor's photo on the front and biographical information on the back. This plate features William Blount, Tennessee's first Territorial Governor.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1796 Feb. 29, Philadelphia [to] Governor William Blount / J. Parkes

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to Governor William Blount from J. Parkes dated February 29, 1796. Parkes recommends a Mr. Harrison Almand, a wealthy gentleman from Virginia who is interested in settling in the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River.

subject.geographic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1802 Feb. 13, [to] Governor [Archibald] Roane of the State of Tennessee / Benjamin Hawkins

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Benjamin Hawkins, Agent for Indian Affairs South of Ohio, to Tennessee Governor Archibald Roane (1801-1803) on February 13, 1802. In the letter Hawkins recommended that all horses and cattle be branded specific to their location, and he offered guidelines for how this should be done.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Jun. 24, Nashville [to] Rev[eren]d Finis Ewing, Lexington, Missouri / Ja[me]s Smith

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated June 24, 1837 from James Smith to Reverend Finis Ewing of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church. Smith is the printer of the church's newspaper, and he informs Ewing that the publication will soon cease as a result of Smith not having been paid for his printing services. He writes that he has little hope that the Presbytery can continue to afford the paper.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Jan.17, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] each of our members in Congress / John Sevier, Governor of the state of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Tennessee Governor John Sevier (1796-1801) to the members of Congress, dated January 17, 1797. Sevier reported that it was believed that Cherokees had been plundering the wagons of frontier settlers along the Cumberland road and taking their horses, and he stated that the Cherokee agent had complained about the size of the territory awarded to frontier settlers. Also reported, was that at least one Indian had been killed, but Sevier had doubts about this because the subject had not been brought before him by the Cherokees or their agent. After he made complaints about inefficiencies within the postal system, Sevier explained that Captains Wades and Sparks had arrived in the frontier but that their companies were insufficient. Sevier requested that three companies of infantry and a troop of horses be sent to help protect the frontier.

titleInfo.title: Paper from President Monroe [directed to Reverend Samuel Worcester, 1819 ?]

mods.abstract: A copy of the views of President Monroe concerning the education of the Indians. It is Monroe's opinion that part of the 10,000 dollars annually appropriated by the United States Congress for the "civilization" of the Indians ought to be spent on education, school buildings, and teachers and administered in cooperation with benevolent associations, (1819 ?). This enclosure was originally part of document ch041 that appears in the Southeastern Native American Documents Database.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Nov. 23, Nashville, Tennessee [to] George A. Weglir, Gallatin, Tennessee / James K. Polk

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor James K. Polk to George A. Weglir, dated November 23, 1839. Polk is writing about some financial and legal details of the Nashville and Kentucky Turnpike Company.

titleInfo.title: [Letter], 1857 Nov. 18, Executive Department, Tahlequah [to] Colo[nel] George Butler, U[nited] S[tates] Agent / John Ross

mods.abstract: (Copy ?) of a letter dated November 18, 1857 from John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, to Colonel George Butler calling on Butler to remove intruders from the "Neutral Land" per an act of the National Council. A copy of the act, originally enclosed, is no longer attached. A note on the back indicates that this letter is a copy, but Ross's signature appears to be in his own hand.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of a Kaolin pipe fragment in situ on the Chattooga townhouse floor, taken in 1993] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a Kaolin pipe fragment in situ on the Chattooga townhouse floor. Kaolin pipes are named for the white clay that they are made from. Kaolin pipes were made in England as early as the 17th century. Over time, the shape, size, and patterns changed on the pipes. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. Through the use of surface collection, test pit excavations, and remote sensing equipment, vast amounts of artifacts and the location of additional buildings and features were found with minimal disturbance to the site. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Dec. 19, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Martha Butler Chester / M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Mary Jane Chester to her sister, Martha Butler Chester, on December 19, 1840. In the letter, Mary Jane describes how she will spend Christmas in Columbia, Tennessee, and wishes her sister and family a Merry Christmas at home in Jackson, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] ca. 1848 Sep. 23, Masonic University [Clarksville, Tennessee] [to] Adam Fergusson / Wm. A. Forbes

mods.abstract: This is a letter from William A. Forbes to Adam Fergusson, dated September 23. It is probably from between 1848 to 1850 because those are the only years The Masonic University of Tennessee held that name. Forbes is writing to inform Fergusson about his son, William. William is behind in his studies due to neglect and is unlikely to advance with his class. Forbes is concerned for William's academic career. He writes that because he, the teachers, and the trustees of the university respect Fergusson so much, they care about William's welfare and will do what they can to help him.

titleInfo.title: [Order] 1805 Jun. 29, Nashville, Tennessee [respite] for Samuel Forrester / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is an Executive Order dated June 29, 1805 from Governor John Sevier of Tennessee. The order is a respite and prolongation of punishment for Samuel Forester for the murder of a female slave. In the order, Sevier dictates the specific time Forrester is to be escorted to the gallows by the Sheriff of Davidson County, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: 1844 Jan. 21, Columbia, Tennessee [to Mr.] Hogan [and Mr.] Heiss, Nashville, Tennessee / James K. Polk

mods.abstract: This is a letter from James K. Polk to Mr Hogan and Mr Heiss, dated January 21, 1844. Polk is questioning why his name appears above Martin Van Buren's in the Union newspaper. Polk believes that Van Buren will be the Democratic candidate for president no himself.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1793 Aug. 31, [to] David Henley Esq[ui]r[e] / Henry Knox

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Henry Knox, Secretary of War, to David Henley on August 31, 1793. In the letter, Knox appointed Henley as an agent for the War Department in the Southwest Territory. Knox further detailed the duties of Henley's new position, which mostly included regulating payments and supplies of all sorts for the troops of the Southwest Territory and also preventing and correcting improper expenditures. David Allison was appointed as a subordinate paymaster, who would be working under Henley. Henley's position was initially established on a temporary basis in response to recent occurrences in the Southwest Territory that required the deployment of more troops and greater expenditures by the War Department.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of the postholes from a mid-18th century Cherokee winter domestic house at Chota, taken in 1969] / [by George Fielder]

mods.abstract: This photograph shows the postholes of an 18th century domestic winter house at Chota, a former Overhill Cherokee village in what is today Monroe County. Winter houses were conical in shape with four central support posts and were generally about 30 feet in diameter and 15 feet high. Adjacent to these round winter homes was usually a rectangular building used for summer habitation. Excavations of Chota and other Overhill villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, J. Worth Greene

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

titleInfo.title: 1834 Feb. 5, Nashville [Tennessee] [to] Finis Ewing, Lexington, Missouri / James Smith

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Rev. Finis Ewing from Rev. James Smith, dated February 5, 1834. Smith writes about some current disagreements that are going on between the Cumberland Presbyterians. Smith has been censured for publishing a letter written by Rev. Morgan. Smith complains that people are trying to create more newspapers than the church can support. Smith also laments his financial difficulties involving The Revivalist.

titleInfo.title: [Diagram of Tellico Blockhouse excavations, American Federal period trading and military post from 1794-1807, Lower Little Tennessee River] / [by Steven Ahler]

mods.abstract: This is a diagram of the Tellico Blockhouse excavations. The Tellico Blockhouse was constructed in 1794-95 adjacent to the earlier Fort Loudoun at the confluence of the Tellico and Little Tennessee Rivers in what is presently Monroe County as a federal outpost. In 1805 federal officials and Overhill Cherokees negotiated a treaty at the Tellico Blockhouse which moved the federal agency south to the mouth of the Hiawassee. By 1807 the federal government abandoned Tellico and moved the rest of its agency to the Hiawassee River post, the new center of the Overhill Cherokee settlement. Excavations of the Tellico Blockhouse were conducted by the University of Tennessee from 1972-1974 in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. Excavations of the Blockhouse were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, Richard R. Polhemus.
