titleInfo.title: [Letters] 1840 Oct. 17, Jackson, Tennessee [to] Mary Jane Chester, Columbia, Ten[nessee] / John Chester and Elizabeth Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Mary Jane Chester on October 17, 1840, and contains two letters. The first letter is from her brother John, and discusses family events, mainly one involving a dinner where Andrew Jackson, Governor Polk, and Judge Grundy were in attendance. The second letter is from her mother, Elizabeth, and expresses feelings of love for her daughter.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1830 Jan. 11 [to] President [Andrew Jackson] / M[artin] Van Buren

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Secretary of State Martin Van Buren to President Andrew Jackson on January 11, 1830. In the letter, Van Buren thanks Jackson for sending him a letter written by a Judge Overton, a friend of Jacksons. Van Buren also thinks highly of this man and feels his thoughts and actions show great intelligence.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Mar. 5 [to] J.M. King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Thomas O. Moore, Alexandria, Louisiana

mods.abstract: Letter dated March 5, 1833 from Thomas O. Moore to his cousin J.M. King. Moore offers condolences for the loss of his son, and the many dead caused by Cholera spread on the Mississippi river.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Sept. 9, Cornplanter, [Pennsylvania] [to] Miss. Sarah B. Bell, Near Charlotte, Tenn[essee] / Jane [Bell]

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter written from Jane Bell in Cornplanter, PA, to her sister Sarah Bell, dated September 9, 1839. Jane writes about the death of their cousin Eliza's husband and the the great tribulations Eliza now faces as a widow raising children and caring for her elderly mother. Jane explains how she wishes to raise one of Eliza's daughters as a service to her cousin.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of small ceramic bowl excavated at Chota, taken in 1969] / [by George Fielder

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a small ceramic bowl recovered by excavations at Chota. Chota or Echota was an Overhill Cherokee village located in what is today Monroe County, Tennessee. In the mid-18th century, Chota was recognized by Europeans as well as other Indians for its powerful socio-economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee Nation. Chota, as with all the Overhill Cherokee sites, is now inundated by the Tellico Reservoir. Excavations of Overhill Cherokee villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project. Excavations continued until 1983, and laboratory studies and report preparation continued until 1987. The excavations were conducted in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River Valley, in eastern Tennessee, by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal Investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, J. Worth Greene.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Legislative documents] 1842 Apr. 8, Albany, New York [to] James Jones, Nashville, Tennessee / William H. Seward

mods.abstract: These are legislative documents sent to James C. Jones, Governor of Tennessee, by New York's Governor William H. Seward. They are resolutions adopted by the New York state legislature dated April 8, 1842. The resolutions concern regulations of the United States Postal Service. See also sl620.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1823 Oct. 25

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Saturday October 25, 1823 session of court. In it, Judge John Martin describes a case that came before him, involving a man by the name of Tarrapin Head giving another man a counterfeit Spanish coin. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Sep. 20, McMinnville, Tennessee [to] James K Polk / John W Ford

mods.abstract: This document is a brief letter of request from John W. Ford to James K. Polk on behalf of James D. Priest. The request is to bring Priest to the attention of Polk as a candidate for Quarter Master.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Dec. 14, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Col[onel] Robert J. Chester, Jackson, Tenn[essee] / M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated December 14, 1842, from Mary Jane Chester to her father Robert J. Chester. Mary Jane writes urging her father to visit her, and she talks about her upcoming public examination and other issues related to her schooling and finances.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 June 16, New Orleans [to] Mrs. Ephraim H. Foster, Nashville, TN/ Robert C. Foster 3

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Robert C. Foster III, son of Tennessee Senator Ephraim Foster, to his mother, dated June 16, 1846. Foster writes from his station in New Orleans, where he is the captain of a troop of Tennessee Volunteers during the Mexican-American War under the command of Colonel William Campbell. Foster reports that the soldiers are enjoying good health, though there has been one death, that of a man named McAdams from Shelbyville. He also talks extensively about public parades in New Orleans and how the Tennessee Volunteers are thought of as the finest troops to have passed through the city.

titleInfo.title: [Invoice] 1795 Jul. 17, War Office [to] Samuel Hodgdon [Military Commissary, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania] / Timothy Pickering

mods.abstract: This is an invoice to Samuel Hodgdon of the Commissary in Philadelphia from Timothy Pickering, dated July 17, 1795. Pickering is the Secretary of War. Pickering gives instructions for a shipment of goods from Philadelphia to Chickasaw Country.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Mar. 15, Winchester, Tennessee [to] C[harles] F. & C[arolyn] V. Welcker, Talladega, Ala[bama] / C. J. F Mitchell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by C. J. F. Mitchell, the sister-in-law of Charles F. Welcker, dated March 15, 1837. Mitchell writes to her sister and brother-in-law in Talladega, Alabama and informs them of the latest news from her school in Winchester, Tennessee, and she asks about the condition of all the family.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1829 Apr. 10 [between] William R. Cockeran and Samuel Houston

mods.abstract: This document is a license dated April 10, 1829 allowing William R. Cockeran to operate an ordinary within his home in Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Mar. 29 [to] Mrs. W[illia]m R. Caswell / W[illiam] R. Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by William R. Caswell to his wife on March 29, 1847. In the letter, Caswell states that he is stationed near Vera Cruz and gives accounts of events going on in the war and with himself. He describes buildings in the area, some of which have been destroyed by bomb shells. Caswell expresses the mood of the men and his desire to come home, as well as describing the character of several other soldiers. Caswell concludes the letter by stating where his Regiment will be stationed next, and his opinion that the war is almost over.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1825 Oct. 21

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Friday October 21, 1825 session of court, in which three criminal cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1825 Oct. 28

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Friday October 28, 1825 session of court, in which a series of civil cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: Dr. [Elizur] Butler's statement respecting his interview with Col[onel] Sanford, 1831 June 20, Camp Gilmer, [Murray County, Georgia]

mods.abstract: Statement by Elizur Butler, Christian missionary living in the Cherokee Nation, extracted from a letter dated June 20, 1831. Butler describes a meeting that took place between himself and Colonel Sanford at Camp Gilmer. Colonel Sanford voices his disapproval of missionaries and threatens to imprison Butler again or forcibly remove him and his family if he does not move. Butler states that Samuel Worcester, another missionary to the Cherokee, and himself are intent on staying in the Nation until they are removed by force.

titleInfo.title: 1844 Oct. 7, Carthage, Tennessee [to unknown recipient] / A[dam] Fergusson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Adam Fergusson dated October 7, 1844. The recipient is unknown, but may be James K. Polk. Fergusson writes the recipient that Smith county supports his bid for presidency. Fergusson believes that this candidate will follow in the steps of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and Andrew Jackson.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1798 Mar. 1, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Sam[ue]l Handly / [John Sevier]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Captain S. Handly dated March 1, 1798. The author is probably Governor John Sevier. Sevier announces that the General Assembly has empowered him to appoint an agent to negotiate with the Cherokee Nation for some of their land. Handly has been chosen for the position.

titleInfo.title: 1822 Apr. 20, Memphis, Tenn[essee, to] James Winchester, Cairo, Tenn[essee] / Anderson B. Carr

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Anderson B. Carr to General James Winchester, dated April 20, 1822. Carr writes about buying some property. He discusses his debts. Carr also mentions that he is sending Winchester a panther skin.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of mid-18th century central hearth Cherokee townhouse at Tomotley, taken in 1976] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a central hearth of a Cherokee townhouse from the Overhill village of Tomotley dating back to the mid-18th century. All political and social events were held in these large winter townhouses, which were cone-shaped and appeared to look like a small mountain from a distance. Some were large enough to hold 500 people. The seats were arranged like an amphitheater with the seats rising one above another, leaving an area in the center for a fire. Excavations of Tomotley were conducted by the University of Tennessee in 1976 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, Gerald F. Schroedl

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Feb. 12, Carthage, T[ennessee] [to] Colonel Ramsey, Knoxville, Tenn. / Sam Houston

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 12, 1829 to a Colonel Ramsey in Knoxville, Tennessee from Governor Sam Houston. This letter was written shortly before Houston resigned as Governor of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Provision Return] 1813 Mar. 18 [for] Tennessee Volunteers / [signed by] Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a provision return for the War of 1812 dated March 18, 1813. The document requests rations for 61 men in the Tennessee Volunteers Company and is signed by Major General Andrew Jackson.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1818 Sept 23, Washington, [D.C.], [to] Daniel Graham, Secretary of State / Joseph McMinn, Governor of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated September 23, 1818, written by Governor Joseph McMinn of the state of Tennessee (1815-1821) to Daniel Graham, Secretary of State. In his letter, Governor McMinn wrote of his unhappiness and displeasure of being at the Cherokee Agency. He wrote to Graham that he abhorred the hatred and jealously demonstrated by citizens over every section of expansion and he was anxiously looking forward to going to Knoxville to attend business.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Nov. 2, Jackson, [Tennessee] [to] Mary Jane Chester, Columbia, Ten [nessee] / Elizabeth Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Mary Jane Chester from her mother, Elizabeth Chester, on November 2, 1840. In the letter, Elizabeth discusses the visit between Mary Jane and "Uncle" Andrew Jackson. Elizabeth advises that even though Mary Jane is homesick, that she needs to stay at school, do well in her classes, and remain devoted to her Bible and religion.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Nov. 11, [to] gentlemen of the Senate House of Representatives, [Washington, D.C.] / McMinn, Joseph, Governor of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated November 11, 1815, written by Joseph McMinn, Governor of the state of Tennessee (1815-1821) addressed to the Senate and House of Representatives in Washington DC. In his letter, Governor McMinn informed the House and Senate that he had enclosed for their consideration a copy of an agreement between the United States (by Agent William Cocke) and the Chickasaw Nation concerning the opening of a road from Reynoldsberg. Governor McMinn wrote that the United States would not bear any of the expenses of opening the road. Governor McMinn stressed that the road would not only be of importance to the citizens of Tennessee, but also to those of Kentucky and Ohio.

titleInfo.title: 1796 Apr. 10, Tellico Blockhouse [Tennessee, to] David Henley, Knoxville [Tennessee] / John McKee

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John McKee to David Henley, dated April 10, 1796. McKee quotes a letter from Governor William Blount stating that his requests for money should be directed to Henley. He is an agent for the War Department. One expected expense is buying whiskey for Cherokee Chiefs.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1843 Jan. 17, Nashville, [to] Mary House / George House

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated January 17, 1843 from George House to his wife Mary House. He writes of his progress in becoming a doctor and that he found a cure for a diseased slave that had other doctors baffled for two years. He also discusses other family and friends and tells Mary he hopes she can join him soon.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Dec. 20, Washington [D.C.] [to Elizabeth Fitzgerald] / W[illiam] Fitzgerald

mods.abstract: This is a letter from William Fitzgerald to his wife Elizabeth, dated December 20, 1832. William reports on the boarding accommodations for him and his fellow Congressmen. He writes of President Jackson's determination to keep the Union intact.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 Feb. 23 [to] Sam Houston, Nashville, Tennessee / J. Hamilton

mods.abstract: This document is a recommendation by J. C. Hamilton for G. W. Terrell to receive the job of Attorney General under Governor Sam Houston.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1798 Feb. 5, Knoxville [Tennessee, to the U.S.] Congress / [John Sevier]

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Congress from Governor John Sevier, dated February 5, 1798. Sevier writes with the hope of receiving federal aid for the citizens of his state who are apparently having a bad winter.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1812 Sept. 29, United States to Timothy Meigs / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for payment of one hundred dollars and fifty cents to Timothy Meigs for delivering various goods to the Cherokee Indians. Return J. Meigs, agent for the War department, made the payment on behalf of the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Dec. 14 [to] Sam Houston, Knoxville, Tennessee / Stephen Marcum

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Sam Houston regarding a reward for three men who escaped from jail in Knoxville Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 Feb. 13 [to] B.R. Loxley / William C. Newell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 13, 1841 from B.R. Loxley to William C. Newell. The subject of the letter is obtaining a copy of Haven's Chark on the subject of Baptism.

titleInfo.title: 1823 Apr. 20, Cragfont, Tennessee [to] J[ohn] Overton, Nashville, Tennessee / J[ames] Winchester

mods.abstract: This is a letter from General James Winchester to the Honorable John Overton, April 20, 1823. Winchester is writing to discuss the court situation in Memphis. They, along with Andrew Jackson, are the founders of Memphis. Winchester lists the ways to establish a court in Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Dec. 8, Nashville [to] Charles F. Welcker, Talladega, Alabama / R. J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 8, 1837, from R. J. Meigs in Nashville to Charles F. Welcker in Talladega, Alabama. Meigs is writing in response to an inquiry of Welcker's regarding the currency exchange rate between Tennessee, Alabama, and Kentucky money.

This is a letter from Tennessee Governor Aaron V. Brown to a Mrs. Spencer, dated August 18, 1847. The Governor tells Mrs. Spencer that he is not able to grant a petition for relief of her husband from the charges made against him at this time.

titleInfo.title: Account of the U[nited] States and the Cherokee Nation for annuities for 1813, 1814, 1815, 1816, and part of 1817

mods.abstract: This document is a summary of an account between the United States and the Cherokee Nation relative to the annuity owed to the Cherokees for 1813-1816, and part of 1817. The account itself is undated.

titleInfo.title: Proceedings of [the Cherokee] Council [including a talk from Jos[eph] McMinn, Governor of Tennessee], 1818 May, Cherokee Agency / [signed by] Jos[eph] McMinn

mods.abstract: Cherokee Council minutes which include a talk from Joseph McMinn, Governor of Tennessee dated May 1818. McMinn presents the Treaty of the Cherokee Agency, July 8, 1817, before the Cherokee and Arkansas, and he discusses the federal government's plan for the removal of Indian Nations east of the Mississippi and the "civilization" of these people. The council minutes following McMinn's address appear to be in a different hand, but seem connected contextually.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1821, Jan. 7, Canton, China [to] George Washington Campbell, State of Tennessee / James Matheson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from James Matheson in Canton, China to his uncle and Tennessee statesman George Washington Campbell, dated January 7, 1821. Matheson explains that due to the East India Company's monopoly on British trade in the far East, his stay in China is threatened. He is thus inquiring of his uncle to appoint him Vice Consul for the United States to China, despite the fact that he is a British citizen.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Oct. 19, Paris, Tennessee [to] William Fitzgerald, Brownsville, Haywood County, Tennessee / E.A. Fitzgerald

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated October 19, 1849 from E.A. Fitzgerald to her husband William Fitzgerald. It is a short letter updating him on news and happenings at home.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 May 25, Boonville [to] Rev[erend] Finis Ewing, Lexington, KY / A. Benton

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by a Mr. Benton to the Reverend Finis Ewing regarding missionaries and agents to be hired to visit several counties in Tennessee and Kentucky.

titleInfo.title: Gen[eral] Jackson's Farewell Address, Together with His Proclamation to S[outh] Carolina, printed 1850, Harrisburg [printed by] J. M. G. Lescure

mods.abstract: This document is a booklet, printed by J. M. G. Lescure in 1850, which includes President Andrew Jackson's Farewell Address and his Proclamation to South Carolina. The Farewell Address was given on March 4, 1837, as Jackson prepared to retire from the presidency and from public life in general. In the address, he discusses his presidency's contributions to the nation, as well as his opposition to the national bank and nullification. The Proclamation to South Carolina was written on December 10, 1832, in response to an earlier decision of the state legislature of South Carolina to nullify a recent tariff bill passed by the federal government. Jackson severely chastises the insistence that states are sovereign and have the right to nullify federal laws, and he accuses South Carolina of trying to disrupt the Union and transgressing the Constitution.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Dec. 13 [to] B. McDaniel, Greenville, Tennessee / J.L. Edwards

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written in 1844 by J. L. Edwards of the Pension Office to B. McDaniel regarding a claim made on the estate of Sarah Hawley.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1794 Sept. 30 [to John Sevier] / [signed by] William Blount et. al.

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt signed by Governor William Blount and others to allow John Sevier to receive payment for his attendance at a session of the General Assembly in Knoxville, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841 Mar. 26, Jackson, [Tennessee] [to] Mary Jane Chester / Elizabeth Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Elizabeth Chester to her daughter, Mary Jane Chester, on March 26, 1841. In the letter, Elizabeth discusses social events taking place in Jackson, such as marriages and parties, as well as events taking place with the people in their family. She asks her daughter not to ride on horses because she could get injured, and to always tell them the truth because they need to trust her while she is away from home.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1816 Nov. 4, Cherokee Agency [to] W[illia]m H. Crawford, Secretary of War / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 4, 1816, from Return J. Meigs, Agent to the Cherokee Nation, to US Secretary of War William H. Crawford. Meigs writes to request that mechanics be hired within the Cherokee Agency for use by the Native Americans. Meigs specifically talks about the lack of blacksmiths available.

titleInfo.title: [List] 1846 Sept. 30 [List of Scholars in Pulaski, TN School District Number 3]

mods.abstract: This document is a list of the scholars of the Pulaski, Tennessee School District, Number 3, as enrolled on September 30, 1846. There was a total of 35 scholars enrolled at that time.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of the Fort Marr Blockhouse in Benton, Tennessee] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl]

mods.abstract: This photograph is of the Fort Marr Blockhouse located at Benton in Polk County, Tennessee. Fort Marr, also known as 'The Old Fort,' was constructed around 1814 near Old Fort, Tennessee. The fort was positioned along the Old Federal Road and housed troops who were assigned to protect white travelers using the road and the Cherokees from Creek retaliation. The fort was also said to have been used to safeguard supplies and as a campsite for soldiers in transit during the Creek War of 1814-1815. The name Fort Marr was established when the fort was renovated into a stockade to use during the removal of the Cherokee people to the west. It is believed that the fort was named after George Washington Lent Marr, who served under Andrew Jackson during the War of 1812 and the campaign of 1813-1814. After being relocated times since its construction, it was moved to its present location at Benton in 1965. In 1980, Fort Marr became the property of the Conservation Department of the state of Tennessee to be maintained and used as a historic site.

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: 1850 Nov. 7, Fountain Head, Sumner County, Tennessee [to] A[dam] Fergusson, Carthage, Tennessee / Abram Bradley

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Abram Bradley to Adam Fergusson, dated November 7, 1850. Bradley writes that his father received 274 acres for his service in the Revolutionary War. It is possible that he is due another 160 acres. Bradley wants Fergusson, a pension attorney, to write him and let him know for sure.

This document is a letter whose date is unknown, written from Sampson Williams to Andrew Jackson when Jackson was a member of Congress. In the letter, Williams asked Jackson to support his proposal to establish a trading post at Fort Blount. Williams also discussed the conflicts between the Indians and Whites of the Cumberland area, and he stated that some 500 families were currently residing on Indian lands. At the end of the letter, Williams also briefly mentioned the possibility of appointing a man by the name of Overton as Federal Judge.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] [1841] Apr 23, Jackson, [to] Mary J[ane] Chester, Female Institute, Columbia / Elizabeth Chester

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated April 23, 1841, from Elizabeth Chester to her daughter Mary Jane at the Female Institute in Columbia, TN. Chester updates her daughter on happenings back home while Mary Jane is away at school.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1834 Jan. 17, Nashville [to] Rev[erend] Finis Ewing, Lexington, MO / T. C. Anderson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated January 17, 1834, to Reverend Finis Ewing from T.C. Anderson, who worked in the office of the Revivalist, a publication of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church. Anderson's letter is in reply to the reception of Ewing's most recent article for publication and also Ewing's expression of disapproval of a recently-published article by a man named Amicus. Anderson explains that Amicus had deceived him into thinking the article was approved by James Smith, Ewing's nephew and the Revivalist's editor.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1830 Oct. 23

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Saturday October 23, 1830 session of court, during which a series of civil cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of the central hearth of a Cherokee townhouse in mid-18th century Toqua, taken in 1977] / [by Robert D. Newman]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of the central hearth of a Cherokee townhouse at Toqua, a mid-18th century Overhill Cherokee Village on the Little Tennessee River (present day Monroe County, Tennessee). The village, whose name means place of a mythic great fish, is on the same site as a late Mississippian Dallas culture, 1200-1600 A.D. American Revolutionary War forces destroyed the town in 1776 and 1780. It was destroyed again in 1788 post-war hostilities. In the 1970's, extensive archaeological excavations were conducted prior to its inundation by the waters of the Tellico Dam Reservoir. These excavations uncovered Mississippian structures as well as those of 18th century Cherokee. Of the latter were recorded 2 townhouses, 10 dwellings, and a number of refuse pits and burials. Excavations of Overhill Cherokee Villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project. Excavations continued until 1983, and laboratory studies and report preparation continued until 1987. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal Investigator, Jefferson Chapman. Field Director, Robert D. Newman.

titleInfo.title: Memorandum, 1838 Nov. 9, Headq[uarte]rs Eastern Division, Athens, Ten[nessee] / Winfield Scott

mods.abstract: Copy of a memorandum dated November 9, 1838 from General Winfield Scott, commander of the Cherokee removal, concerning a possible discrepancy between the number of Cherokees on muster rolls and those actually removed. Scott was informed by the Cherokee authorities that 12,608 people in twelve detachments emigrated west by land, but only 11,721 were counted. He intends to make compensation if investigation proves this true.

titleInfo.title: Letter, 1838 Feb. 15, Washington to Colo[nel] Thomas L. McKenney / Jno. [i.e., John] Ross

mods.abstract: This is a copy of a letter from John Ross, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, to Colonel Thomas L. McKenney, commissioner of Indian Affairs, dated February 15, 1838. Ross expresses his gratitude for the kind sentiments offered by McKenney on the deteriorating state of affairs in the Cherokee Nation. Ross refers to the Cherokees as powerless and indicates that the sympathy of the U.S. government is their only hope for relief.

titleInfo.title: 1842 Aug. 20, Cold Water [to] R[obert] H. McEwen, Nashville, Ten[nessee] / W.B. Robinson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from W.B. Robinson to his business associate Robert H. McEwen, dated August 20, 1842. Robinson is very concerned about his financial situation. He is in debt with no chance of repayment without irreparably damaging his families future. Robinson needs to meet in person with McEwen but is unable to travel due to poor health.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] ca.1824 Oct. 21

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt, dated Tuesday October 21, around the year 1824, announces the adjournment of court due to the absence of a judge. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1799 Mar. 14, Knoxville [to] Moses Fisk, Hanover, New Hampshire / Willie Blount

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Moses Fisk from Willie Blount on March 14, 1799. In the letter, Blount discusses political aspects of Tennessee at the time, including impeachments, a Cherokee treaty, political appointments, and land demand being very low in Tennessee. Blount also wishes for Fisk to return to Tennessee, not to marry a northern woman, and expresses dislike for Northerners in general.

titleInfo.title: Manifest of the whole Cargo on board of the Sloop Charming Sally, 1797 Nov. 11

mods.abstract: This document is an inventory of the cargo aboard a ship entitled the Charming Sally. The ship traveled on November 11, 1797, from Murfreesboro, North Carolina to New York. The document was attested to by LA Murfree.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1825 Oct. 20

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is the excerpt from Thursday, October 20, 1865, in which two cases were discussed by the court, one involving Lewis Ross, brother of Chief John Ross. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Address of the Cherokee Chiefs to the Cherokee Nation, ca. 1806]

mods.abstract: This document is a speech give by the young Cherokee Chiefs circa 1806 in Nine Towns. The young Chiefs try to dispel rumors of the old Chiefs selling land and say they should be praised for bringing peace to the Nation. They also chose a new "Beloved Man" to replace the one who died.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 May 16, Fayettville [to] A.V. Brown, Nashville, Tennessee / F. Farquharson

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated May 16, 1846 from F. Farquharson to Governor Aaron Venable Brown of Tennessee. The purpose of Farquharson's letter is to offer the services of a company of mounted riflemen from Tennessee. He tells the governor the men are ready and eager to participate in the war with Mexico in any way that they are needed.

titleInfo.title: June 2, Washington [City, D. C.] [to] A Fergusson, Carthage, Tenn[essee] / W. B. Campbell

mods.abstract: This is a letter to A. Fergusson from W. B. Campbell, dated June 2, possibly in 1837. Campbell writes that the pension claim of Mrs. Cobb has been suspended for lack of evidence. He writes about an incident that took place in the House. Representative John Bell (TN) hit Representative Hopkins Turney (TN) for calling him a liar during a speech.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Apr. 7, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Robert Houston / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a very brief letter from governor John Sevier of Tennessee to the Sheriff of Knox County, Robert Houston. In the letter, the governor asks the sheriff to inquire about the planning of a prison break by some unnamed prisoners.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of pipe fragments from the Chattooga site, taken in 1993] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of pipe fragments collected at the Chattooga site. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. Through the use of surface collection, test pit excavations, and remote sensing equipment, vast amounts of artifacts and the location of additional buildings and features were found with minimal disturbance to the site. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1838 Sept. 29, United States to John Vann

mods.abstract: This document dated September 29th 1838 is a spoliation claim for John Vann of the Cherokee Nation East. Vann is requesting that the United States government reimburse him for horses, and other personal items he claims were stolen from him by white men.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1788 Dec. 1 [to] Daniel Kennedy / John Haywood [state of North Carolina]

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for Daniel Kennedy from the state of North Carolina, signed by John Haywood, dated December 1, 1788. Daniel Kennedy was the Clerk of Greene County Court, and this is his receipt for six pounds for tax fees from May until August 1788.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 May 30, Carthage Ten[nessee] [to] Adam Fergusson, Carthage / C[harles] W. Dixon

mods.abstract: This document is a short letter by Charles W. Dixon to Adam Fergusson, dated May 30, 1846. Dixon writes that he intends to keep Fergusson's military coat, as it fits him quite well. He also wishes to leave Fergusson a personal letter that was left in the coat pocket.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Aug. 24 [to] Honorable Peter D. Vroom / Aaron Brown

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Aaron Brown to Peter D. Vroom dated August 24, 1842. Brown discusses his family, a new Tariff Bill, and other political topics.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Aug. 19 Maryville, Tennessee [to] Colonel Gant / John S. McNutt

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated August 19, 1845 from John S. McNutt to Colonel Gant of Maryville, Tennessee. McNutt writes that he has decided to run for Attorney General, and asks for Colonel Gant's support.

titleInfo.title: [Excerpt from] Early history of the Cherokees, 1917 / Emmet Starr

mods.abstract: This document is a brief excerpt from Early history of the Cherokees by Emmet Starr, 1917, pertaining to the education of the Cherokees in one district in 1826. This excerpt contains several minor typographical variations from Starr's original.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Apr. 7, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Robert Housten / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor John Sevier to Robert Housten, dated April 7, 1797. Housten is the sheriff of Knox County. Sevier is writing to compel Housten to not allow some unnamed prisoners to escape from custody.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1836 Mar. 1, Isaac W. Rogers to Lawson D. Franklin

mods.abstract: This document is a promissory note dated March 1st 1836, for one Isaac W. Rodgers to pay Lawson D. Franklin the sum of twenty one hundred dollars by September 1836.

The following document is a list of dueling rules signed by John F. Jack, John McCampbell, and J. Coffee in Knoxville on April 13, 1808. The list describes the details of the way a particular duel is to be conducted and sets the duel on an early Tuesday morning in Virginia's Cumberland Gap.

titleInfo.title: 1841 Mar. 20, Paris [Tennessee, to William and Elizabeth] Fitzgerald, Paris [Tennessee] / I[saac] B. Williams

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Isaac B. Williams to William and Elizabeth Fitzgerald, dated March 20, 1841. They are the parents of his fiance, Adeline. Isaac is writing them to formally announce his intentions to marry, and be a good and responsible husband to Adeline. He informs them that the wedding is planned for April. Isaac hopes to receive their approval for this union.

This document is a letter dated January 17, 1832 from Stockly Donelson to Andrew Jackson Donelson. Stockly informs Andrew that the trainer he had recently hired will not be allowed to stay in the state longer than twenty days due to an act of legislature limiting the residency of free black people. Stockly also discusses the status of his investment in Craighead farm as well as the condition of Andrew's cotton crop. He also mentions an episode in which their uncle Andrew Jackson, then US president, was falsely accused of owing a debt.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1825 Nov. 1

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Tuesday November 1, 1825 session of court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1808 Jul. 26, United States to James Carey / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for payment of sixteen dollars and twenty-five cents to James Carey for building expenses. Return J. Meigs, agent for the War Department in Tennessee made the payment on behalf of the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1812 Dec. 12, Nashville, [Tennessee] [to] Richard Alexander / W. B. Lewis

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by W. B. Lewis to Richard Alexander on December 12, 1812. Lewis requests that Alexander send him a report with the number of companies in his regiment, how many men and officers are in each company, and the quantities of different equipment they have, such as tents, kettles, pans, and axes.

titleInfo.title: 1811 Dec. 7 [to] James Winchester, Sumner County [Tennessee] / John Donelson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John Donelson to General James Winchester, dated December 7, 1811. Donelson is writing in regards to General Andrew Jackson. Jackson sold Winchester some land. Donelson says that Jackson intends to visit him soon, but did not receive the last letter that Winchester sent him.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1800 Feb. 25, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] the Hon[ora]ble W[illia]m Cocke, Joseph Anderson W[illia]m C. Claiborne / [John Sevier] :a machine-readable transcription of an image

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) to Joseph Anderson, William Cocke, and William C. Claiborne, dated February 26, 1800. This letter is about William Augustus Bowles and his influence over the Creek Nation. Sevier is telling the men to be prepared for what is to come, which could possibly be a war. Sevier stated that the state of Tennessee is particularly vulnerable to hostilities and violence.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1842 Jun. 27, Gallatin, Tennessee [to] James Jones, Nashville, Tennessee / Thomas Barry

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated June 27, 1842 from Thomas Barry near Gallatin, Tennessee to his state governor James C. Jones in Nashville. In the letter, Barry resigns his seat in the state legislature as a representative of Sumner County. He tells the governor that he feels it is his duty, as well as that of his colleagues to resign in order to bring the matter of state districting to a conclusion. In the second page, labeled "private," he discusses proposing a law to compel banks to receive their own notes for their debts.

titleInfo.title: Form of [a] treaty [between the Cherokee Nation and the United States], 1835[?]

mods.abstract: Copy of a treaty form for negotiations between the Cherokee Nation and the United States. The treaty pertains to the removal of the Cherokees east of the Mississippi River. The treaty articles listed detail payment for land, improvements, and loss of crops and release of Cherokees who have been seized, as well as the logistics of emigrating. The date 1838 which appears on the treaty form is dubious in light of historical record.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Oct. 13 [to] Mrs. Sarah McCulloch / William R. Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 13, 1846 from Captain William R. Caswell to his mother Sarah McCulloch. Captain Caswell served during the Mexican-American War, and was one of the Tennessee "Volunteers".

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Dec. 1, Columbia [to] James K. Polk, Nashville, Tennessee / Gideon J. Pillow

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Gideon J. Pillow to Governor James K. Polk, dated December 1, 1840. Pillow is President of the Board of Directors for the Columbia Central Turnpike Company. He is writing to inform Polk who the rest of the Directors are. Pillow also advises that they are ahead of schedule in the construction of the turnpike.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1826 Oct. 27

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1824 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This particular excerpt is from Friday October 27, 1826, in which two cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.
This document is an estimate of the value of slaves held by the Lenoir family in 1846. There are a total of 61 slaves listed at various ages and values.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Jan. 12, Knoxville, [Tennessee to] warriors and Chiefs of the Cherokee Nation/ John Sevier, Governor of the state of Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter addressed to the warriors and chiefs of the Cherokee Nation, written by Governor John Sevier of Tennessee (1796-1801) and dated January 12, 1797. The letter was given to Cherokee agent Silas Dinsmore to be read aloud to the Cherokee. In his letter, Sevier accused some Cherokees of stealing horses and plundering wagons that had passed through the Cumberland road. Sevier laid the blame on "foolish young people" within the Cherokee Nation but hoped the chiefs and warriors were not encouraging such acts. Sevier urged the Cherokee leaders to work with Dinsmore in getting the stolen property returned. Sevier also expressed condolences for the murder of an Indian and stated that he doubted any of his people would do such a thing. The letter was initially ended on a note of warning to the Cherokee, as Sevier insinuated that if they continued their aggressive behavior, war would be option. However, the last two sections of the original letter were deleted from the final text.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Sep. 29, Trenton, [Tennessee] [to] Mr. A[dam] Fergusson, Carthage, Smith C[oun]ty, Tennessee / Th Claiborne Jr

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated September 29, 1844, to Adam Fergusson in Carthage, TN, from Th [perhaps short for Thomas] Claiborne, Jr. in Trenton, TN. In this letter, Claiborne discusses politics, particularly the democratic presidential campaign to elect James K. Polk in 1844. Claiborne reports on how the democratic ticket is faring in states throughout the country and in the counties of Tennessee in particular. He is hopeful that the democrats will win out in Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Dec. 31, Washington [to] Robert J. Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Andrew Jackson to Robert J. Chester on December 31, 1836. In the letter, Jackson appoints Chester to the position of postmaster of Jackson, Tennessee. Jackson also mentions the death of Emily Donelson, the daughter of Major Donelson. Jackson finally mentions that he has been ill and suffered from a blood hemorrhage.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1838 May 23, United States to Black Fox

mods.abstract: This document is a spoliation claim dated May 23, 1838, by the United States to Black Fox for improvements made to the land he owned before he was removed by the US authorities. The case was referred to Major General Scott for settlement.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 June 14 [to] Mrs. William R. Caswell / William R. Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is letter dated June 14, 1846 from William R. Caswell to his wife in Jefferson County, Tennessee. Caswell writes that he is marching his troops to Memphis where they will go to Mexico to fight in the Mexican-American War.

titleInfo.title: 1838 Mar. 5, Marshall County, Miss[issippi, to] Isaac B. Williams, Paris, Tennessee / Rachael Greer

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Rachael Greer to her son Isaac B. Williams, dated March 5, 1838. Rachael writes that Isaac's father is willing to help him acquire some land as an investment. She adds that all in the family are well.

titleInfo.title: 1848 Mar. 5, Berlin [to] A. J. Donelson [Jr.] / A. J. Donelson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Andrew Jackson Donelson, then serving as ambassador to Prussia, to his son of the same name, dated March 5, 1848. The father writes that he is going to obtain vacation time for his son from President Polk so that he may visit his family in Berlin. Donelson advises his son against accruing more debts and to learn to live within his financial means. He writes much on how and why to keep track of one's finances.

titleInfo.title: [Membership Certificate] 1848 Nov. 16, Maury County, Tennessee, [for] Joseph Brown

mods.abstract: This is membership certificate and traveling card for Joseph Brown dated Nov. 16, 1848 for the Sons of Temperance.

This document is a resolution dated January 8, 1819 by the United States Senate requesting that the President initiate negotiations with the Chicasaw Indians for the cession of a four mile tract of land to the state of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Mar. 3, Washington [to] R[obert] J Chester / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Andrew Jackson to Robert Chester on March 3, 1833. In the letter, Jackson informs Chester that his nomination as surveyor has been rejected by the Senate because he is not a resident of Mississippi. Jackson's attempts to get the Senate to reverse their decision was futile, and they appointed a man that had previously been turned down for the same reason as Chester.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Apr. 5, Murfreesboro, Tennessee [to] John Overton / Joseph McMinn

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 5, 1819 from governor Joseph McMinn of Tennessee to John Overton. The subject of the letters is a treaty regarding a salt spring with the Chickasaw Nation of Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Jan. 21, Portsmouth [to] Gen[era]l [Andrew] Jackson, Nashville [Tennessee] / [John F. Decatur]

mods.abstract: This is a letter of sympathy for the death of the First Lady, Rachel Jackson. It is dated January 21, 1829, and is addressed to President Andrew Jackson. It is presumably from John F. Decatur.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Oct. 28 [to] John Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / Mary Jane Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 28, 1840 to John Chester from his sister Mary Jane Chester at the Female Institute, Columbia Tennessee. Mary Jane describes her daily routine at the institute and how much she misses her family. Included with her letter is a course description for the institute along with a brief note to her brother Robert.

titleInfo.title: [Certificate to study law] 1830 Oct. [for] William R. Caswell / [signed by] Henry Ewing

mods.abstract: This document is a certificate dated August 1830, allowing William Richard Caswell to take necessary steps to obtain a license to practice law in the state of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Ordination Certificate] 1844 Oct. Pleasant L. Henderson / R.W. January

mods.abstract: This document is a certificate of ordination declaring Pleasant L. Henderson a regularly ordained Minister of the Gospel of Jesus Christ for the Baptist church of Enon located in Rutherford county, Tennessee. It is dated in the month of October 1844, and is signed by ordained Ministers of the Baptist Denomination. The ordination was witnessed by the church members located at Brawley's Fork, in Cannon county, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: 1836 Aug. 8 [to] Sarah B. Hamilton, Russellville, KY / James M. Hamilton

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated Aug. 8, 1836 to Sarah B. Hamilton from James Hamilton. He sends many greetings to friends. He writes about the local, and personal news. He also mentions that President Jackson plans a visit to Nashville soon.

titleInfo.title: 1839 Nov. 15, Washington [D.C., to James K. Polk] Nashville, Tennessee / Talbot, G.

mods.abstract: This is a letter from G. Talbot to Governor James K. Polk, dated November 15, 1839. Talbot is writing to ask Polk to send him a list of arms that Tennessee's militia will need for the upcoming year.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Dec. 4 [to] J.M. King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Thomas O. Moore, Alexandria, Louisiana

mods.abstract: A letter written on December 4, 1833 from Thomas O. Moore to his cousin James Moore King. He writes of the great panic in Louisiana caused by the Cholera, as well as fear that half of the country will die from the disease. Moore also writes of difficulties in finding workers, and hope that the disease has left their region.

titleInfo.title: [Circular] 1797 Mar. 8, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Brigadair General & Colonel / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a circular dated March 8, 1797 from governor John Sevier of Tennessee. The purpose of the circular is to inform top level military officers that he has granted several temporary commissioners to volunteer companies of cavalry for the protection of the state.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Nov. 14, Nashville [Tennessee, to] H.J. Anderson / James K. Polk

mods.abstract: This is a letter to H. J. Anderson from Governor James K. Polk, dated November 14, 1839. Polk is writing to discuss a prisoner at the penitentiary that Anderson is the keeper of. Anderson wants the prisoner's sentence commuted.

titleInfo.title: [Annuities] 1820 Oct. 4, United States to the Cherokee Indians / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a report on the third quarter of annuities for 1820 owed to the Cherokee Indians. The document is signed by Return J. Meigs, agent to the Cherokees, on behalf of the United States.

Letter dated April 25, 1823 from the Cherokee Council to (U.S. Commissioners Duncan G. Campbell and James Meriwether ?) in response to a communication from these commissioners. The Council considers the commissioners' plea to repeal a resolution which disallows further land cession so that the commissioners can meet with the Council in Taloney and proceed with further negotiations. The Council responds in the negative, stating that the resolution was made to promote the interest and happiness of the Cherokee people and that no meeting will take place in Taloney because the seat of government is in New Town. A lengthy extract from the commissioners' letter follows which sets out arguments for the Cherokees to agree to further land cessions and remove west.
This document is a receipt dated May 6, 1805. The receipt is for William Clay's eight dollar tuition to Blount College.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Nov. 13, Washington [to] Rev[erend] H. M. Cryer / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Andrew Jackson to the Reverend H. M. Cryer on November 13, 1836. In the letter, Jackson discusses the political atmosphere surrounding the 1836 Presidential election. He discusses the support of Martin Van Buren by a majority of the states. The Whigs running against Van Buren have, according to Jackson, told lies about him and are hypocrites.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 Oct. 2, Tuskaloosa, Alabama [to] Governor [Sam] Houston, State of Tennessee / John Murphy

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated October 2, 1828, from Alabama Governor John Murphy to Sam Houston, governor of Tennessee (1827-1829). Murphy states that recent act passed by the US Congress called for the opening of a canal at the Muscle Shoals in Alabama. Murphy writes to solicit the cooperation and assistance of the state of Tennessee, not only in building the proposed canal, but also to build a railroad running through the valleys of the Mississippi River.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Aug. 20 [to] J.M. King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Thomas O. Moore, Clinton, North Carolina

mods.abstract: A letter dated August 20, 1833 from Thomas O. Moore to his cousin James Moore King. He wrote to inform of the death of his brother, and plans to settle matters of the estate.

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Writ] 1778 May 12, State of No[rth] Carolina [to] Sheriff of Washington [County] / [signed by] John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a writ issued by the state of North Carolina and signed by John Sevier on May 12, 1778. The writ orders the sheriff of Washington County to locate James Robertson and bring him forth to appear in court regarding a charge brought against him by Zachariah Isbell.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Oct. 21, Memphis, [to] Mrs. James King / James King

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by James King to his wife dated October 21, 1835. King writes the letter from Memphis, Tennessee, where yellow fever has killed many of its residents and has caused others to flee the city. King writes of his good health and of hers, certain business matters involving himself, and states that the fever will soon be gone so that Mrs. King can return home. King speaks of many of their friends in the city that have become ill, or were ill due to the fever. He concludes by wishing her and their family continued health and a prompt reunion.

titleInfo.title: 1844 Jul. 17 Nashville [TN] [to] Mary House, Louisville, Alaba[ma] / Geo[rge] W. House

mods.abstract: This is a letter from George W. House to his wife Mary House, dated July 17,1844. He sends updates on friends and family events. He informs her that some people want to buy her guitar. He complains of being lonely. He writes about a recent parade and public speech that he enjoyed. He mentions the passing of resolutions in Laurence County on the Texas Question. He also mentions the Philadelphia riots involving the Nativists and Irish Catholic immigrants.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Apr. 21, Nashville [to] Mrs. Sarah B. Hamilton, Russellville, K[entuck]y / Oscar Hamilton

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated April 21, 1833, from Oscar Hamilton to his mother Sarah Hamilton. In the letter, Oscar writes about his views on education, religion, and updates his mother on the cholera and scarlet fever scare.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1807 Dec. 20, Knoxville [to] Return J. Meigs, Highwassee / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Governor John Sevier to Return J. Meigs, Agent to the Cherokee Indians. Sevier responds to Meigs letter about the murders of two men presumably by the Creek Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1827 Oct. 22

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is from the Monday October 22, 1827 session of court, during which a trover case was heard. Details of court costs are contained herein. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1804 Aug. 9, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Colo[nel] Joseph McMin [i.e. McMinn], Colo[nel] Samuel Wear, and Maj[or] John Cowan / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by John Sevier, Governor of Tennessee from 1796-1801 and 1803-1809, to Colonel Joseph McMinn, Colonel Samuel Wear, and Major John Cowan, dated August 9, 1804. In the letter, Sevier informed these men that he had received word of a meeting to be held with the commissioners of Georgia regarding a road that would be built connecting the two states, which would also run through Cherokee lands. Sevier commanded the men to attend the meeting, and he gave further instructions of the agreements to be made with the Georgian commissioners. Sevier wanted to make certain that both states would have an equal amount of work to do in constructing the road and reap an equal number of advantages from its existence.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of mid-18th century gunflints, musket balls, and lockplate recovered from Chota, taken in 1967] / [by George Fielder]

mods.abstract: This photograph is of gunflints, musket balls, and a lockplate, all of which were mid-18th century trade items of the Cherokees found in archaeological excavations of Chota in what is today Monroe County. Chota was recognized by Europeans as well as other Indians for its powerful economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. Excavations of Chota and other Overhill villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA).

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837 Jun. 13, Alexandria, Louisiana [to] James M. King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Thomas Moore

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 13, 1837 from from Thomas Moore to his cousin James King. In the letter, Moore expresses his distress over the death of his sister's husband, and worry for her future. He also expresses concern over his cotton crop, that is hindered by drought. He also writes in his letter that the Bank has suspended specie payment, and he is unsure when it will resume.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1813 Jul. 1, Beauport [to] George Prevost / James Winchester

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated July 1, 1813 from James Winchester to General George Prevost. Winchester explains in the letter that he is writing on behalf of a Major in the Quarter Master's Department of the United States army. He encloses a letter, whose writer is asking for parole to return to the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1813 Oct. 11 [to] M.H. Watts, New York, New York / Charles Watts, Nashville, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a personal letter of correspondence from Charles Watts, writing from Nashville, Tennessee, to his sister M.H. Watts in New York City. In the letter, Watts recounts his travels in the south in vivid and eloquent detail. Specifically, he offers his impression and a first-hand account of sermons delivered in Nashville by minister Lorenzo Dow.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1812 Apr. 14, Highwassee Garrison [Tennessee, to] John Strother, Nashville [Tennessee] / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Return J. Meigs to Captain John Strother, dated April 14, 1812. Meigs writes about a tract of land that is in dispute between the Cherokee and Chickasaw tribes. Meigs gives some history about the land's ownership and how it is used by the Natives. Rights to a salt petre cave are in dispute. Meigs also mentions the Hopewell Treaty of 1785, and an agreement from George Washington in 1794.

titleInfo.title: [Remittance] 1836 Feb. 22 [to] Andrew J [ackson] Coffee / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a remittance to Andrew Jackson Coffee from Andrew Jackson. The remittance, dated February 22, 1836, is for a $250 reimbursement to Coffee for his expenses at West Point and to and from Washington.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1816 July 4 [to] William H. Crawford, Washington City / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 4, 1816 from Major General Andrew Jackson to William H. Crawford. Jackson reports on several events, including the removal of suspected intruders on Chickasaw land, and a murder supposedly committed by Cherokee Indians.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of archaeologists mapping the surface of the Chattooga site before the 1993 excavations, taken in 1993] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is a photographic image of archaeologists mapping the surface of the Chattooga site before the beginning of the 1993 field season. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. Through the use of surface collection, test pit excavations, and remote sensing equipment, vast amounts of artifacts and the location of additional buildings and features were found with minimal disturbance to the site. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter written by Ben Sawtell in Memphis to his niece Mary C. Porter, dated August 12, 1847. The letter is a brief note in which Sawtell extends his love to his niece and to her brother Edward.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of late 18th century to 1838 lidded double weave cane basket from Knox County, Tennessee] / [by W. Miles Wright]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a late 18th century to 1838 lidded double weave cane basket of Cherokee origin from Knox County, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: 1818 Nov. 25, Franklin, Tennessee [to] John Overton, Nashville, Tennessee / R. McGavock

mods.abstract: This is a letter to John Overton from R. McGavock, dated November 25, 1818. McGavock has just found a place in the territory on the Missouri River in which to settle. He describes in great detail how good the alluvial land is for growing crops. McGavock describes the local wild foliage. McGavock writes that it is also perfect for livestock as there are many grassy meadows. He believes that the area will have a greater population than Tennessee because the farm land is so fertile. McGavock offers to act as agent to Overton and any others who want to invest in land in the territory.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Oct. 29, [near] Sparta, Tenn[essee, to] Margaret Stuart, Wythville, Virginia / Geo[rge] Stuart

mods.abstract: This is a letter from George Stuart to his wife, Margaret, dated October 29, 1846. Stuart writes about his location and future travel plans through Tennessee. He mentions that he is in good health.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1837, April 17th, Clover Dale, TN [to] Miss Ann Jane Bell, Philadelphia, [PA] / Sarah B. Bell and M[argaret] V. Bell

mods.abstract: These are two letters written together to Ann Jane Bell dated April 17, 1837. They are from her sisters, Sarah B. Bell and Margaret V. Bell. Sarah has had a cold this week. She writes of where some people are going to school. James Gould has bought them some gifts that he has been unable to send them. She mentions how well liked a preacher named Mr. Pope is. She also says that the weather has been good for the fruit trees. Margaret writes of the muster they recently hosted. Their mother wanted to listen to a Mr. Allen's speech. Apparently the ladies were not allowed to actually attend it. They sat on the porch and had Mr. Allen speak very loudly. She also summarizes the happenings in the neighbors.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1790 May 12, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] James Ore / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor John Sevier to Colonel James Ore, dated May 12, 1790. Sevier is ordering Ore to go to the Cherokee Nation to find out their intentions towards a treaty. Sevier also asks Ore to recommend to the Cherokee the merits of an agrarian lifestyle over that of hunting. Sevier hopes that the Cherokee can be persuaded to part with more of their land. Sevier suggests they set up a trading post at Tellico. He also mentions the Law of Nations in relation to the Cherokees having more land than they can cultivate.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of a reconstructed blockhouse at Fort Southwest Point, Kingston, Tennessee] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This photograph is of a reconstructed blockhouse at Fort Southwest Point, located near the city of Kingston, in Roane County, Tennessee. There are four reconstructed blockhouses at the fort, with two blockhouses located at the west end of the fort and the other two located at the east end. Fort Southwest Point was established in 1792 as a blockhouse post for the territorial militia troops that were protecting white settlers from Indian acts of hostility. By 1797, the militia was replaced by Federal troops whose goals were to maintain peace with the Indians and protect their rights on the frontier. During the years between 1801-1807, the fort was established as the headquarters for the Cherokee Agency. In 1974, archaeological crews from the University of Tennessee unearthed portions of six fort building foundations, the remains of a massive stone wall, and many fort-period artifacts. A 1984 excavation of the site by the Department of Conservation and the City of Kingston located the sites of a total of thirteen buildings. These buildings include an officer's barracks, four blockhouses, and several buildings that are believed to have been barracks. A complementary excavation in 1986 revealed the location of two more buildings, bringing the total to fifteen buildings. The excavation also produced a more detailed examination of the palisade and stone wall enclosures, and uncovered several historic and prehistoric features. Additional excavations were conducted at Fort Southwest Point in the 1990s yielded new information as to the fort's original layout and functions, as well as the life ways of the people who occupied the fort. Fort Southwest Point was given to the city of Kingston by the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) and is now used as a historical and recreational area.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1824 Feb. 9, Washington [to] Capt[ain] John Donelson / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Andrew Jackson to Captain John Donelson, dated February 9, 1824. In the letter, Jackson discusses international affairs, and the bad relationship between England and the United States, Russia, South America, and Europe. Jackson states to Donelson that he will run for President of the United States in the 1824 election if he feels that the public wants him to run.

titleInfo.title: Duplicate account of money paid the Cherokee Nation on account of annuity, 1817

mods.abstract: This is a copy of an account of funds disbursed to the Cherokee Nation relative to the annuity for 1817, under the authority of Return J. Meigs, U.S. Agent to the Cherokees in Tennessee. The payments recorded primarily include subsistence and transportation expenses.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Jul. 26, Fayetteville, North Carolina [to] J.M. King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Thomas O. Moore,

mods.abstract: A letter dated July 26, 1833 from Thomas O. Moore to his cousin James Moore King. Moore tells King of his recent acquisition of new slaves, and his desire to acquire additional slave hands, as well as the ravages of the Cholera in the Southern states.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Oct. 5, Jackson, Ten[nessee] [to] Mary Jane Chester, Columbia, Ten [nessee] / Robert Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Robert Chester to his daughter, Mary Jane Chester, on October 5, 1840. In the letter, Robert expresses his anxieties about Mary Jane's health, and has decided to have her aunt go to Columbia, Tennessee, to get her and bring her home. He also discusses a visit to his family by Andrew Jackson.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Oct. 27

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is the excerpt from the Wednesday October 17, 1824 session, during which three cases were heard before the Court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: 1849 Dec. 13, Indianapolis [Indiana, to William Trousdale] / J. Mitchell

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Governor William Trousdale from J. Mitchell, dated December 13, 1849. Mitchell is writing on behalf of the African Colonization Society. He advocates spending more resources on the colonization of Liberia than on the African Squadron.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of a small mid-18th century pit used to smudge Cherokee ceramic vessels at Chota, taken in 1969] / [by Richard R. Polhemus]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a small pit used to smudge Cherokee ceramic vessels. It is from the 18th century Overhill Cherokee village of Chota in what is today Monroe County. Chota was recognized by Europeans as well as other Indians for its powerful socio-economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. Excavations of Chota and other Overhill villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee between 1967 and 1983 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, J. Worth Greene.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Apr. 15, Philad[elphi]a [to] Mr. Joseph P. Brown / John Gill Junr.

mods.abstract: The following document consists of two letters, the first of which is dated April 15, 1833 and is addressed to Joseph P. Brown from John Gill, Jr. In this letter, Gill asks Brown to inform him if a man by the name of James Jones had commented negatively on the character of Gill and his nephew. In his reply, Brown explains that the destitute business situation in his area has created much discord. He further explains the accusations made by Jones and others regarding Gill's character. Brown additionally remarks on business matters, and lists the names of people who have failed or retired from business.

titleInfo.title: 1795 May 5, Nashville [Territory South of the Ohio River, to] David Henley, Knoxville [Territory South of the Ohio River] / Seth Lewis

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Seth Lewis to David Henley, dated May 5, 1795. Lewis is writing because he is interested in entering the mercantile business. He needs more information on a contract involving Major Tatum.

subject.topic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of large pit-features near the former site of the mid-18th century townhouse at Chota, taken in 1969] / [by Richard R. Polhemus]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of large pit-features discovered near the former site of the mid-18th century Chota townhouse. Pits were dug by the Cherokees for burial purposes and for the storage of refuse. This excavation was conducted by the University of Tennessee in 1969 in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The university worked under contract with the National Park Service and TVA. Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, J. Worth Greene.
