titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1814 Apr. 7 Nashville, [to] Hon[ora]ble John Armstrong / Willie Blount

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to John Armstrong, Secretary of War, from Willie Blount on April 7, 1814. In the letter, Blount commissions Captain James Cowan's company of soldiers to act as the militia cavalry on the Franklin County frontier. The cavalry have been asked to protect the settlers on the frontier from Indian attacks.

titleInfo.title: 1822 Jan. 27, Knoxville, T[ennessee] [to] John Overton, Nashville, T[ennessee] / P.M. Miller

mods.abstract: This is a letter from P.M. Miller to John Overton, dated January 27, 1822. Miller gives a list of several topics that he wants Overton to consider. He wonders if there is someone other than Andrew Jackson to run for governor of Tennessee. Miller intimates that Jackson may be groomed for President if elected governor. He mentions the penitentiary house and that another may be built if needed. Miller writes about the question of slavery's effect on the presidential election. He thinks there will be many candidates running for president.

titleInfo.title: [Financial statement for funds] received in behalf of the Cherokee Nation as full compensation for time and expenses attending and completing the survey of the boundary lines, 1808 Nov. 1, Highwassee [i.e., Hiwassee, Tennessee]

mods.abstract: This is a financial statement and receipt for money received on behalf of the Cherokee Nation for expenses related to the survey of boundary lines conformable to a convention entered into with the United States at Washington on the January 7, 1806, and approved September 11, 1807. The statement indicates that the Cherokees were to receive 2,000 dollars from U.S. agent Return J. Meigs for their service in completing the survey. This document also details property losses and compensation amounts for area inhabitants who were alleged victims of Cherokee theft. Dated at Hiwassee, Tennessee, November 1, 1808.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 May 8, Pulaski, Tennessee [to] Jane T. Wood, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania / Sarah Bet

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 8, 1840 from Sarah Bet in Pulaski, Tennessee to her cousin Jane T. Wood in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The purpose of the letter is to answer a previous communication from Wood. In the letter, Bet details many intriguing and interesting events about people and life in Pulaski.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1826, Sept. 2nd, Philadelphia [to] Miss Ann Jane Bell, Nashville, TN / [Dr.] John Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Dr. John Bell to his sister Ann Jane Bell dated Sept. 2, 1826. John gives Ann advice about exercising and taking care of her health. He tells her that he thinks it is a good idea for her to work for a Mrs. Scott as an assistant. He is sending her some money and plans to send her more.

titleInfo.title: [Proposals] 1794 Oct. 31, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] David Henley / John Chisholm

mods.abstract: This document is a proposal from John Chisolm to David Henley, agent for the Department of War, dated October 31, 1794. The document provides specific details for supplying rations for the use of troops in service at the rivers in the territory south of the Ohio.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 March 28, Clover Dale, TN [to] Mrs. Ann Jane Bell, Cornplanter, Venango Co., PA / Margaret V. Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Margaret V. Bell to her sister Ann Jane Bell dated March 28, 1838. Margaret writes that many of the weddings mentioned in her last letter did not happen. Mr. Lee has stopped preaching because people have stopped going to hear him. Apparently he did something the community did not approve of. He is still running the school, now with his new wife, Elizabeth Roberts. Margaret thanks Jane for the gifts she sent, especially some monogram thimbles and shields. The family's candidate for circuit court clerk, John C. Collier won the election. The family has been reading Young's Night Thoughts and greatly enjoying it. She writes of improvements to the farm and domestic chores. The family is well except their father who is weak and feeble. She also mentions a girl named Elennora as the belle of Nashville.

titleInfo.title: [Testimony] 1836 Sept. 21, Floyd County, Georgia [to] Head of Coosa / G.M. Lavender

mods.abstract: This document, dated September 21, 1836, is a certified statement by George M. Lavender concerning the average per day income of a ferry where he had resided for several years.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Aug. 16, Alexandria, Louisiana [to] James King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Thomas Moore

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated August 16, 1838 from Thomas Moore to his cousin James King. In the letter Moore highlights some events of daily life in Louisiana as well as hopes and prospects for his crops.

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1834 Mar. 6, Vernon [to] James A. Woods, Nashville, Tennessee / J. H. Thomas

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 6, 1834, from J.H. Thomas to James A. Woods in Nashville. Thomas discusses a girl who Woods is apparently expected to marry and other personal affairs. Thomas also mentions a recent bill passed in the Mississippi legislature reforming the state's prison system.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of water screening to recover artifacts from excavations] / [by Jefferson Chapman]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a water screen used to recover archaeological artifacts from 18th century Overhill Cherokee villages in East Tennessee. Excavations were conducted by the University of Tennessee from 1967-1982 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River Valley by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA).

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of an archaeological pit feature at the former site of the mid-18th century Cherokee town of Chota, taken in 1974] / [by David Stansberry

mods.abstract: This is a 1974 photograph of an archaeological pit feature at the former site of the mid-18th century Cherokee town of Chota. Pits were dug for burial purposes and for storage of refuse. Chota was recognized by Native Americans and European settlers as a powerful social and economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. Excavations of Chota and other Overhill Cherokee villages were conducted as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project by the University of Tennessee in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The university worked under contract with the National Park Service and TVA. Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, Gerald F. Schroedl.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Affidavit of Andrew McNabb] 1839 Jan. 1, Monroe County, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is an affidavit given by Andrew McNabb in regards to a lawsuit against The Pathkiller, a Cherokee Indian. Pathkiller lost his land during the removal and fought to regain it to no avail.

titleInfo.title: 1830 Mar. 16, Nashville [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Tenne[ssee] / William H. Barker

mods.abstract: This is a letter from William Barker to A. Fergusson, dated March 16,1830. Barker is requesting that Fergusson send him money that is due to Barker from Mr. Green.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Apr. 12, Hartsville, Ten[nessee] [to] Adam Fergusson, Carthage, Ten[nessee] / Francis Duffy

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Francis Duffy to Adam Fergusson in Carthage, TN, dated April 12, 1845. Duffy writes in response to a request by Fergusson to remove the current Post Master of Fergusson's area. Duffy concurs that such a removal is desirable.

titleInfo.title: [Contract] 1839 Mar. 2 [with Charles F. Welcker for slave hire] / A[lbert] S. Lenoir

mods.abstract: This document is a contract dated March 2, 1839, written by Albert S. Lenoir. It involves the hire of two slaves from the property of his deceased father-in-law Henry Welcker and is arranged with Charles F. Welcker, son and agent to the deceased Welcker. Lenoir agrees to pay 100 dollars for each of the slaves for a term of one year.

titleInfo.title: 1832 Nov. 12, Dover, T[ennessee] [to] E[lizabeth] Fitzgerald, Dresden, Tennessee / W[illiam] Fitzgerald

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Congressman William Fitzgerald to his wife Elizabeth, dated November 12, 1832. William is trying to get Elizabeth to move the family to their farm. He reports that Cholera is spreading through the smaller towns. William asks her to take the children out of school if people start getting sick in her area.

titleInfo.title: 1808 Oct. 11, Baltimore [Maryland, to] James Winchester, Cragfont, Tennessee / David Armour

mods.abstract: This is a letter from David Armour to General James Winchester, dated October 11, 1808. Armour despairs for for the political integrity and future of the country. He fears that America's prosperity has led to an overabundance of ambition and harshness that will undermine the country's spirit of virtue and freedom. Armour mentions English policy towards America.

titleInfo.title: 1843 Mar. 9 [to] George W. House, Nashville, Tenn[essee] / J. P. Williams

mods.abstract: This is a letter from J. P. Williams to George W. House, dated March 9, 1843. Williams is trying to convince House to give him some medicine. The medicine is some kind of pill that House has declared he would not give out for moral reasons. Williams swears that if House will allow him to take some, he will not let anyone else know. He also promises to pay whatever is asked to House if the pills cure him.

titleInfo.title: [Deposition of John Carmichal] 1844 Dec. 6, Bradley County, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a sworn oath given by John Carmichal on behalf of The Pathkiller, a Cherokee Indian who lost his land a few years after the Treaties of 1817 and 1819. Pathkiller fought for his land through the courts until his death in 1844.

titleInfo.title: [Legal Quits of Claim and Registration Certification] 1814 -1816 [for] James Hamilton of Davidson County, Tennessee and William Anderson of Lexington County Ky

mods.abstract: These are three different documents. The first one is dated Dec. 15, 1814, and is written by James Hamilton. It is a quit of claim of the Cherokee/African slaves that his brother in law, Joseph Brown took back from the Cherokee Chief Cotetoy. The slaves were descendents of a slave named Sue that was owned by Hamilton's father in law (Joseph Brown's father), James Brown, and stolen by Cotetoy. The second paper is the registration certification for said quit, written by Joseph Porter in May 1816. The third paper is dated Dec. 15, 1814. It is a quit of claim to two slaves, Jinney and Suey, and offspring, by William Anderson. He also states that Joseph Brown has payed him $150 for the portion of James Brown's estate that Anderson inherited.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Jan. 29, Washington, District of Columbia [to] E.A. Fitzgerald / William Fitzgerald

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated January 29, 1832 from William Fitzgerald in Washington, D.C. to E.A. Fitzgerald. In the letter William complains of the bitter cold weather and the daunting prospect of having to venture outdoors.

titleInfo.title: [Legal Valuation] 1814 Dec. 12, Natchez, [MS] [for] Col. Joseph Brown

mods.abstract: This is a valuation dated Dec. 12, 1814 done for Colonel Joseph Brown. It is evaluating the worth of the decedents of the slave, Sue, that was stolen from Brown's father in 1788 by the Cherokee Chief Cotetoy. These children and grandchildren, know as "Indian Negroes" were returned to Brown by Cotetoy in 1814.

titleInfo.title: 1825 Oct. 1, Nashville [Tennessee, to] James Winchester, Cairo [Tennessee] / J[ohn] W. Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Judge John Overton to General James Winchester, dated October 1, 1825. Overton writes about a recent trip he took with General and Mrs. Jackson. He writes about some law suits that he and Winchester are working on. Overton also wants to know if Winchester received a deed he sent him.

titleInfo.title: [Petition] 1842 May 23 [to] James Jones / Citizens of Morgan County

mods.abstract: This is a petition for the relief of debt collection and settlement. The signers of the petition, in fear of having their property sold for less than two-thirds its value, ask the governor of Tennessee, James Jones to request the state legislature to pass some resolution that will aid in relieving the distress of the community, including a two year moratorium.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1830 Dec. 15, Columbia Tn. [to] John Overton, Nashville, Tn. / T. H. Cahal

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated December 15, 1830 to John Overton from T. H. Cahal concerning the appointment of a William Willeford as surveyor general for Mississippi and Louisiana. Cahal asks Overton to give Mr. Willeford a recommendation.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1830 Nov. 7, Washington [to] Robert J. Chester, Jackson, [Tennessee] / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Andrew Jackson to Robert J. Chester on November 7, 1830. In the letter, Jackson agrees to sell some of his slaves, one woman named Charlotte and her three children, to Chester for $800.00. Jackson also asks for Chester to send a certificate to him regarding a Colonel S. D. Hays on the matter of his sobriety and abilities as a surveyor.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Jan. 12, Knoxville, [Tennessee to] Silas Dinsmore / Governor John Sevier, Governor of the state of Tennessee: a machine-readable transcription of an image

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated January 12, 1797, written to Silas Dinsmore, agent to the Cherokee, from Governor John Sevier of Tennessee (1796-1801). The letter was written partly in response to inquiries made earlier by Dinsmore regarding Indian land boundaries in the Cumberland area. Sevier explained that Americans could begin settling in areas as low as the Tennessee River and that the settlements boundary line the government was experimenting with was going to be extended. Sevier devoted the second half of the letter to discussing problems between the white settlers and the Cherokee, by stating that several complaints had been made about robberies and plundering believed to have been committed by some Cherokees. Sevier expressed disdain toward this conduct and feared it would hinder peace. Sevier also enclosed a letter he had written to Cherokee chiefs.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1816 July 6 [to] Andrew Jackson / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 6, 1816 to Andrew Jackson from Return J. Meigs regarding the cession of Cherokee lands to the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1843 Jan. 28, Columbia, Tennessee [to] Col[onel] Rob[er]t J. Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Mary Jane Chester to her father, Robert J. Chester, on January 28, 1843. In the letter Mary Jane states that she is in the middle of her examinations for the current session. She states that she would like to take French, guitar, and piano lessons the next session and requests that her father to send her the money to do so.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1824 Nov. 27, Gainesboro, [Tennessee] [to] Postmaster General / Sam Smith

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Sam L. Smith to the Postmaster General on November 27, 1824. In the letter, Smith informs the Postmaster General that on the mail route from Sparta, Tennessee to Tompkinsville, Kentucky, one mail carrier's horse died and another became sick and could not continue the route. He is concerned about the mail not continuing on its route to Meigsville and on to Tompkinsville. Sam Smith concludes the letter by asking the Postmaster General the appropriate age for a person to become a mail carrier.

titleInfo.title: Photograph of the Tennessee Valley Authority survey crew mapping archaeological features at the former site of the mid-18th century Cherokee town of Chota, taken in 1974] / [by David Stansberry]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a 1974 Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) survey crew mapping archaeological features at the former site of the mid-18th century Cherokee town of Chota. Chota was recognized by Native Americans and European settlers as a powerful social and economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. Excavations of Chota and other Overhill Cherokee villages were conducted as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project by the University of Tennessee in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River Valley by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The university worked under contract with the National Park Service and TVA. Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, Gerald F. Schroedl.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Feb. 25, Murfreesboro, Tennessee [to] Levi Woodbury / M. Spence

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 25, 1840 from M. Spence on behalf of the Nashville Murfreesboro & Shelbyville Turnpike Company, to Levi Woodbury. The purpose of the letter is to assure payment of interest due on the state bond; Spence cites scarcity of specie for the delay.

titleInfo.title: Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors [Willie Blount--1809-1815] / J. S. Jones

mods.abstract: The Biographical Album of Tennessee Governors, dated 1904, contains 31 plates, each featuring a Tennessee Governor's photo on the front and biographical information on the back. This plate features Willie Blount, Tennessee Governor from 1809 to 1815.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1798 Aug. 29, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Andrew Jackson / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a rough draft composition of a letter to former Tennessee state senator Andrew Jackson. The letter is written by the governor of the state, John Sevier of Koxville, Tennessee, and is dated August 29, 1798. In the letter, Sevier informs Jackson that he has heard from respectable sources that if appointed to a position of judgeship, he would accept; the letter is an official offer from the governor's office for the position. Jackson would accept, and serve the Superior Court of Tennesse from 1798-1804, he would later become the seventh president of the United States in 1829.

titleInfo.title: 1836 Mar. 13, Holley Springs, Mississippi [to unknown recipient] / [Adam Fergusson]

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated March 13, 1836. The author is most likely Adam Fergusson. Fergusson writes to discuss the regulations by which the Chickasaw Nation may sell portions of their land. Fergusson also relates a story about a possible corrupt land speculator.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1827 Oct. 26

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is from the Friday October 26, 1827 session of court, during which a case involving John Ross was heard. The Court also decided that it can rule on matters dating as far back as 1800. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Nov. 17, Murfreesboro, Tennessee [to] Newton Cannon, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / W[illia]m Carroll

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor William Carroll to Colonel Newton Cannon, dated November 17, 1825. Carroll is informing Newton that he has been chosen to join a group of engineers. These men are to survey a route for a national road being built from Washington D.C. to New Orleans. The road will pass through Tennessee. Carroll gives some suggestions for routes. The engineers are also to survey for the proposed canal connecting the Hiwassee and Coosa Rivers.

titleInfo.title: [Legal Indictment] 1788 Aug. 15 [to] The Sheriff of Washington County / State of North Carolina

mods.abstract: This document is a legal indictment from the state of North Carolina to the Sheriff of Washington County, Tennessee dated August 15, 1788. The indictment refers to a man named John Campbell that did not appear in court, was fined, and should appear at the court in Jonesborough to defend himself against an execution sentence.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Apr. 1, Clover Dale, T[ennessee] [to] Mrs A[nn] Jane Bell, Cornplanter, Venango County, P[ennsylvani]a / W[illia]m Bell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated April 1, 1840, from William Bell in Dickson County, TN to his sister Ann Jane Bell in Venango County, PA. In the letter, William briefly mentions several subjects, including farming operations, the depressed state of the farming business, and his plans to value the property of their father's plantation. William also discusses a debating society he has joined with the intention of debating in favor of the temperance movement.

titleInfo.title: Letter] 1804 Apr. 1, Knoxville, [Tennessee], to the Inhabitants and people said to be Settled on the Indian Lands / [John Sevier]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Tennessee Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) on April 1, 1804, and addressed to the white inhabitants residing on lands reserved by the US government for the Cherokee Indians. In the letter, Sevier informed the settlers that by encroaching upon the Cherokee's lands, they were violating the laws of the United States and the treaty between the US and the Cherokee Nation, and he warned them that if they continue there, they would be forcibly removed from the land. Sevier also announced that he was hopeful that the Cherokee claims to lands in northern Tennessee would soon be extinguished and that, furthermore, it would be possible to acquire from the Cherokee lands to the east of the Mississippi River in exchange for land west. Sevier also encouraged the settlers to venture out onto the great expanse of land newly acquired from France instead of maintaining ideas of remaining on Cherokee lands.

titleInfo.title: 1834 Oct. 13, Sommerville, Tennessee [to] W[illia]m Carroll / Peter Hudspeth

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Peter Hudspeth to Governor William Carroll, dated October 13, 1834. Hudspeth is writing to notify Carroll of two murders that have taken place in his county. The murderers are on the run and Hudspeth wants Carroll's cooperation in apprehending them.

titleInfo.title: 1829 Sep. 6, Le[a]venworth, Indiana [to] William Hall, Nashville, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Governor William Hall dated September 6, 1829. The author is known only as a member of Indiana's state Legislature. The author is proposing his idea of an interstate railroad from Indiana to South Carolina. The author gives many reasons for the railroad, and refers to other papers on the topic. He also suggests that the idea be put forth to their respective Legislatures.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1831 Sept. 22, Warrenton, Virginia [to] David Burford, Nashville, Tennessee / J[ourdan] M. Saunders

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Jourdan M. Saunders to David Burford regarding their slave-trading business. Saunders reports on their profits for the 1st quarter of 1831.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Oct. 30

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is from the October 30, 1824 session of court, during which two cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Mar. 17, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] His Excellency Governor Garrard / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter, dated March 17, 1797, written by Governor John Sevier of Tennessee (1796-1801, 1803-1809) to Governor Garrard of Kentucky. Sevier discussed the murders of Red Bird and another Cherokee by two Tennessee residents, Edward Mitchell and John Levingston. Sevier called the murders "wanton and unprovoked," and stated that he wished to have the perpetrators apprehended and taken to Kentucky to be punished. However, Sevier also stated that it would be difficult to apprehend the offenders.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Apr. 27, Moor[e]field, Hardy C[oun]ty, V[irgini]a [to] Leroy B. Gaston Esq[uire] / A. Anderson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Leroy B. Gaston from A. Anderson on April 27, 1835. In the letter, Anderson discusses the political climate in Virginia, financial matters, and social events, including the Winchester Presbytery that is in town.

titleInfo.title: 1837 Mar. 1837, Lagrange, Tennessee [to] Newton Cannon, Nashville, Tennessee / John J. Potts

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John J. Potts to Governor Newton Cannon, dated March 4, 1837. Potts may be the treasurer for a company. Potts is writing to thank Cannon for his interest in the company. He also writes that the Board is interested in the internal improvements proposed for Tennessee.
This is a testimonial given by Alexander McCoy concerning the rendering of services by Henry L. Sims to the Cherokee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Sept. 5 [to] Mr. Gillespie / William Richard Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated September 5, 1832, written by William Richard Caswell to one Mr. Gillespie. The letter discusses possible candidates for the Senate.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Jul. 10, Bolivar [to] Col[onel] Jos[eph] Brown, Maury [County], Ten[essee] / D[avid] F. Brown

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated July 10, 1844, from David F. Brown to his father Col. Joseph Brown in Maury County, Tennessee. David talks of his travels across Missouri and Arkansas and the business of his brother Joseph and others.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Jun. 9 [to] Alexander D. Coffee / Andrew J. Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to Alexander Coffee, dated June 9, 1849 from his brother Andrew Jackson Coffee regarding the sale of slaves in New Orleans and the death of General Gaines.

titleInfo.title: Andrew Jackson Coffee Family Papers, MS27
[Legal Indictment] 1788 Aug. 15 [to] The Sheriff of Sullivan County / State of North Carolina

mods.abstract: This document is a legal indictment written to the Sheriff of Sullivan County from the state of North Carolina on August 15, 1788. The state of North Carolina asks the Sheriff to keep a man named Robert Cowan in his possession until he appears in the Court at Jonesborough.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1848 Dec. 28, Nashville [Tennessee] [to Adam Fergusson] / Jas. H. Kendrick

mods.abstract: This is a letter from J. H. Kendrick to Adam Fergusson, dated December 28, 1848. Kendrick writes that there have not been any cases of cholera in or around Nashville.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1796 Aug. 25, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Little Turkey [Cherokee Nation] / Jo[hn] Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor John Sevier to the Cherokee Chief Little Turkey, dated August 25, 1796. Sevier is writing to pass on a grievance from the Chickasaw Nation. Supposedly the Cherokees have some slaves belonging to a George Colbert. Sevier writes that he hopes they will return the slaves via Joseph Sevier, and that they will live in peace with the Chickasaw Nation.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Apr. 23 [to] Charles F. Welcker / Richard Grantham

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 23, 1836 to Charles F. Welcker from Richard Grantham regarding a buying trip for goods such as bacon and flour.

titleInfo.title: 1848 Nov. 6, Hartsville, T[ennessee] [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, T[ennessee] / Lucinda Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Lucinda Bell to A. Fergusson, dated November 6, 1848. She is requesting that he send her the money he owes her by Christmas.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1823, Cabarrus County, North Carolina [to] James Trimble / Charles Harris

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Charles Harris to James Trimble in 1823. In the letter, Harris discusses with Trimble a lawsuit that he is involved in over land he owns in Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1799 Dec. 9, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] United States Congress / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is an open letter dated December 9, 1799 from the governor of Tennessee, John Sevier to the congress of the United States. The subject of the letter is a ferry crossing of the Clinch river, and the marking out of a road as an alternative to the people's current situation in its regard. Specifically, the documents requests that the issue of marking out a road as stipulated by the fifth article of the treaty of Holston with the Cherokee Indians be laid before the President of the United States.

titleInfo.title: [Speeches, Addresses, etc.] 1813 Feb. 27, Washington / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is an address written by John Sevier on February 27, 1813. Sevier discusses the topics and events that have taken place in Washington during the last government session. In the address, Sevier states that more money and manpower will be given to the army and navy in order to fight the British. The navy at this time is strong, while the army's land battles have not been very successful. In fighting the British, many American soldiers have been taken as prisoners in Canada. Sevier worries that with the southern soldiers joining the northern troops near the Canadian border, that the Cherokee and whites remaining in the south will be at war over land and rights. Sevier states that Congress has reported using $21 million in expenditures and proposes a further $20 million be used for merchant bonds. Congress also rejected a bill requiring a 25 cent per gallon tax on the sale of whiskey. Sevier concludes the address by mentioning events and disputes in Europe between England, Spain, France, and Russia.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1844 Oct. 18 [to] Joseph Brown, Columbia, Tenn[essee] / C.B. Frazier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 18, 1844 to Colonel Joseph Brown from C. B. Frazier. Frazier writes to inform Colonel Brown of the death of his son, Joseph Porter Brown. Joseph Porter Brown died in Galveston Texas of yellow fever.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1802 Jul. 24, Kingston, Tennessee [to] W. Thomas Clark / T.A. Smith

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 24, 1802 from Major T.A. Smith to W. Thomas Clark. The subject of the letter is the opening of a turnpike road, specifically the terms and expense related to the clearing.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1813 Sep. 30, Highwassee [i.e., Hiwassee] Garrison [to] Major General John Cocke / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Return J. Meigs, agent to the Cherokee Nation, to Major General John Cocke, dated September 3, 1813. Meigs writes that he thinks that the Cherokee who had volunteered to fight against the Creek should be put together and supervised by another Cherokee. The whole group should then come under the command of a United States citizen who is familiar with Cherokee fighting. He agrees with Governor Blount that the Cherokee expedition should be lead by Judge Cocke.

titleInfo.title: [Writings] circa 1825 [for] New Jackson Paper / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document was written circa 1825 by Andrew Jackson on his thoughts for a republican newspaper which he titled "New Jackson Paper". In his writings, Jackson outlines his idea of the qualifications a person would need to help publish this paper.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1814 Jul. 26, Lockland, [TN] [to] Major Gen[era]l John Cocke, Grainger County, TN / R[obert] Weakley

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Colonel Robert Weakly to Major General John Cocke announcing his candidacy for governor of the state of Tennessee. Weakley asks Cocke to put out a good word for him in East Tennessee. It is dated July 26, 1814.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Aug. 12, Nashville [Tennessee, to] H.L. White, Knoxville [Tennessee] / Willie Blount

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor Willie Blount to H.L. White, dated August 12, 1815. White is the president of the state bank in Knoxville. The letter refers to the suspension of specie payments by banks due to the War of 1812.

titleInfo.title: [Speech] 1814 Jan. 11, Fort Hampton, [to Chief] Cutteoty [i.e., Cotetoy] and others of the Cherokee Nation / Joseph Brown

mods.abstract: This is a transcription of a speech given by Joseph Brown to Chief Cotetoy and other Cherokee on Jan. 11, 1814. Brown has taken eight Cherokee from Cotetoy because they are descended from an African slave woman that Cotetoy stole from Brown's father. Brown says that he forgives Cotetoy for killing members of his family, and that he wants them to live in peace and friendship.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Jan. 5, Rogersville [to] Neill Brown, Nashville, Tennessee / W.C. Kyle

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated January 5, 1849 from W.C. Kyle in Rogersville, Tennessee to the governor of his state, Neill S. Brown. The subject of the letter is the governor's reelection prospects, and his standing in local newspapers.

titleInfo.title: 1808 Apr. 22, Chickasaw Nation [to] James Winchester, Sumner County, Tennessee / Thomas Wright

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Thomas Wright to General James Winchester, dated April 22, 1808. Wright is the U. S. agent to the Chickasaw Nation. Wright is writing on behalf of a Chickasaw who is inquiring about the fate of his brother. The man is rumored to have been killed in the area of Sumner County, therefore Wright hopes that Winchester has heard of it.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Apr. 4, Kingston, Tennessee [to] Thomas McAdams / Mary N. Stephenson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 4, 1838 from Mary N. Stephenson to her brother Thomas McAdams. The purpose of the letter is to update the status of marriages and family, as well as various social events in Kingston, Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] ca. 1840 June 28, Lebanon [to] A. Fergusson / W. G. Davis

mods.abstract: This is a letter to A. Fergusson from his brother W. G. Davis, dated June 28 ca. 1840. He writes that he has been ill, but that it is not cholera. He also writes briefly about business.

titleInfo.title: Notice, 1838 Jan. 20, [to] the Cherokees / Nat[haniel] Smith

mods.abstract: This is a notice from General Nathaniel Smith, Superintendent of Cherokee emigration, to the Cherokee people, dated January 20, 1838. Smith informs the Cherokees that steam boats will be available for their transportation to a territory west of the Mississippi River, but emigrants may choose the overland route as well. He reminds the Cherokees of the sentiments of the President on the removal issue and warns them to remove early or face military force.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Mar. 28, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] the warriors chiefs of the Cherokee Nation / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This document is a letter addressed to the warriors and chiefs of the Cherokee Nation, written by Tennessee Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809 ) on March 28, 1797. Sevier reported that he had been requested by the Governor of Kentucky to have the two Tennessee citizens who murdered Red Bird and another Cherokee apprehended and sent to Kentucky to be tried for their crime. Sevier stated that he had sent forth orders in compliance with this request, and he was now urging the Cherokee leaders to capture those from amongst their people who were responsible for the murders of several white citizens. Sevier warned the Cherokees of the dangers of bringing about a war, which could be the consequence of further acts of aggression between the citizens of the United States and those of the Cherokee Nation.

titleInfo.title: [Court Order] 1790 Mar. 16, [to] Benjamin Lewis / Samuel Preser

mods.abstract: This document is a order issued by the Superior court of Washington District to Benjamin Lewis. It notifies him to appear at his neighbor's house in order to cross-examine several men in a court matter.

titleInfo.title: [Military] General Orders, 1812 Jul. 8, Nashville [to] Captain John Ballinger, New Orleans / [General] J[ames] Winchester

mods.abstract: The following document is a military order of July 8, 1812, issued by James Winchester in Nashville and addressed to Captain John Ballinger in New Orleans. Winchester served as Brigadier General during the War of 1812. In this general order, Winchester commands all soldiers to resume their posts and be prepared for battle. The United States had declared war on Great Britain on June 12.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1803 Oct. 22 [to] John Sevier, Nashville, Tennessee / Thomas Claiborne

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 22, 1803 from Thomas Claiborne, Chairman of the state House of Representatives to the governor of Tennessee, John Sevier. The purpose of the letter is to propose cooperation between the house and executive office, as well as to promise diligent awareness of constituent concerns. Also in the letter, Claiborne makes a point to note the importance of a careful investigation into the American code of laws for any trace of British common law.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1815 Nov. 1 [to] Return J. Meigs / The Path Killer et al

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt dated November 1, 1815, acknowledging that Return J. Meigs, acting as agent to the Cherokee Nation, paid thirty-six thousand dollars to the Cherokee for their annuities for the years 1813 through 1816.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1814 May 4, Highwassee Garrison [to] General [John] Armstrong, Secretary of War / [Return J. Meigs]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 4, 1814, from Cherokee agent Return J. Meigs to General John Armstrong, Secretary of War. Meigs writes in regards to levies brought against the Cherokee and asks for reparations. Meigs explains that many Cherokee warriors fought alongside the US against the Creek and thus deserve appreciation.

titleInfo.title: Abstract of disbursements made by Return J. Meigs on account of the Indian Department, 1810 June 30 - 1810 Oct. 1, Tennessee

mods.abstract: This document is a summary of the disbursements made by Return J. Meigs, U.S. agent to the Cherokees, at the Cherokee agency in Tennessee from June 30, 1810 through October 1, 1810. Expenses included payment of the Cherokee annuity, payment of claims by and against the Cherokees for stolen property, salaries of various agents and interpreters, and the purchase of articles for spinning and weaving.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1815 Sep. 18, Swan Pond, Tennessee [to] James G[ettys] M[cGready] Ramsey, Washington College [near Jonesboro] Tennessee / F[rancis] A[lexander] Ramsey

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Francis A. Ramsey to his son, James, dated September 18, 1815. The letter is also for another son, possibly William Baine Alexander Ramsey. James is attending Washington College. Francis expresses concern that he has not yet heard from his son. He mentions some news of the family and neighbors at Swan Pond. Francis requests that James write to him to tell him how James is planning to travel home at the end of the term. Francis regrets that he has no money to send James at this time.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1850 Jan. 9, Carthage [to] Dr. H.B. Haynie, Smith County / Adam Fergusson

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated January 9, 1850 from Adam Fergusson to Doctor H.B. Haynie. Fergusson's letter concerns the accurate weighing of his tobacco crops.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 April 29 [to] Governor Sam Houston, Nashville, Tennessee / T. A. Howard

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written April 29, 1829 by T. A. Howard to Sam Houston. Howard expresses his deep regret that Sam Houston has resigned as Governor of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of a representative selection of Qualla rim sherds from the Chattooga site, taken in 1993] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of a representative selection of Qualla rim sherds from the Chattooga site. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. Through the use of surface collection, test pit excavations, and remote sensing equipment, vast amounts of artifacts and the location of additional buildings and features were found with minimal disturbance to the site. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1847 Mar. 11 [to] Mrs. William R. Caswell, Russelville, Tenn. / William Richard Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by William Richard Caswell, March 11th, 1847, to his wife while on board the "St. Patrick" during the Mexican-American War. Caswell was part of the many "volunteers" from Tennessee to fight in the war.

titleInfo.title: 1826 Feb. 14, Princeton, Kentucky [to] Finis Ewing, Boonville, Missouri / F[ranceway]. R. Cossitt

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Rev. Finis Ewing dated February 14, 1826. It is signed by Franceway R. Cossitt, David Lowry, John Barnett, John W. Ogden. They represent the Cumberland Presbyterian College, which this letter is about. Cossitt describes the school, its land and buildings. He writes at length about the need for funding, asking Ewing if he will solicit donations for the Institution. Cossitt mentions that there are rival sectaries who are eager for the school to fail in order to improve their own positions.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of an elevated view of excavations at the Chattooga site, taken in 1993] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This photograph is of an elevated view of excavations at the Chattooga site in 1993. Chattooga is a Cherokee archaeological site that was formerly called 'Cherokee Town.' Cherokee Town was an 18th century village associated with the Lower town Cherokee communities of northern Georgia and western South Carolina. The site is thought to have been occupied for only 160 years and was abandoned by the Cherokees in the 1740s. This site is given special attention because it retained early 18th century Cherokee material culture. This material culture is difficult to find and distinguish on other Cherokee sites of the same time period. The University of Tennessee (UT) and the Francis Marion National Forest conducted archaeological excavations at Chattooga during 1989-1994. The focus of these excavations was to develop a better understanding of the nature of the historical Cherokee occupation at the site and compare these findings with those found on other 18th century Cherokee sites. As a result of these excavations, archaeologists were able to identify and partially excavate the remains of five superimposed council houses. In addition, the excavations of two winter structures and one summer domestic structure were conducted. The excavation of Chattooga is still an active research project with additional findings in the process of being documented.
