titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1830 Jul. 21, Alexandria Louisiana [to] Walter Moore, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Thomas Moore

mods.abstract: Letter written on July 21, 1830 from Thomas Moore to his brother Walter Moore. The letter addresses issues such as the conditions of crops, sickness and his plans for marriage.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Receipt for] books [bought from] Geo[rge] Hill, 1806 Jan. 16, Knoxville, [Tennessee] / [received by] Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt, dated January 16, 1806, for four books bought by Return J. Meigs, U.S. Agent to the Cherokee Nation, from George Hill.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Dec. 3, Bolivar, Tennessee [to] James King, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Austin Miller

mods.abstract: This is a very brief letter dated December 3, 1839 from Austin Miller to James Moore King. Miller informs King of the legal steps he had taken toward settlement of a debt.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1848 Jan. 20, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Legislature / Neill Brown

mods.abstract: This document is a brief message dated January 20, 1848 from the governor of Tennessee, Neill S. Brown to members of the legislature. The message conveys a letter to the members from Major General Zachary Taylor.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Oct. 10 [to] Mrs. W[illia]m R. Caswell / W[illia]m R. Caswell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Captain William Richard Caswell to his wife on October 10, 1846. Captain Caswell was a volunteer from Tennessee who served in the Mexican-American War. In the letter, Caswell expresses his unhappiness that his wife has not written to him in a while, in addition to his concern for her and their family's health. Caswell also discusses events going on in the war and the character of the other soldiers stationed with him. He concludes the letter by expressing his, as well as another soldier's, interest in learning to speak Spanish in order to understand what is being said around him.

titleInfo.title: 1836 Sep. 9, Jasper, Tennessee [to] Newton Cannon, Nashville, Tennessee / John C. Haley

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John C. Haley to Governor Newton Cannon, dated September 9, 1836. Haley has begun to clear the Tennessee River of it's obstructions. He writes that the payment he has received so far is not enough.

titleInfo.title: [Drawing depicting a late 18th century Cherokee domestic structure] / [by Thomas Whyte]

mods.abstract: This is a drawing of a late 18th century Cherokee domestic structure, based on historic descriptions and archaeological excavations by the University of Tennessee. This rectangular building is typical of a Cherokee summer home, which was usually built next to a conical winter house. Excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The drawing is by Thomas Whyte.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1806 Feb. 17, Chickamaga [to] Return J. Meigs / Pathkiller

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written February 17th 1806 by Pathkiller, Principle Chief to the Cherokees and signed by John Lowrey. The letter is written to Return J. Meigs, Agent to the Cherokee. Pathkiller requests the help of Meigs to forcefully remove Dempsey Fields from the Cherokee Nation. Pathkiller also requests a doctors care for his people who have small pox.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 May 9 [to] Robert Armstrong, Knoxville, Tennessee / James C. Luttrell

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated May 9, 1819 from James C. Luttrell to Robert Armstrong regarding the balance due on some land Luttrell bought from him.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 Jul. 21, Rutledge, Tennessee [to] Sam Houston, Nashville, Tennessee / James Whiteside

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated July 21, 1828 from James Whiteside to the governor of Tennessee, Sam Houston. In the letter, Whiteside asks the governor his probability of commanding the legislature to an extra session, for fear that it may create chaos in his district.

titleInfo.title: Private remarks on the testimony given between the state of Georgia [and] the Cherokee Nation, 1829 Dec. 30

mods.abstract: Remarks compiled by John Coffee and dated December 30, 1829 upon the character and credibility of individuals who gave testimony in a land dispute between the Cherokee Nation and Georgia (claiming under the title of the Creek Nation.) Coffee relates his difficulty in receiving information from Colonels Wales and Montgomery about the collection of testimony related to the case and presents the names of those who made statements about the boundary line along with his own comments about their character. The original enclosures are no longer attached.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1829 Aug. 29, New Echota [to] Gov[erno]r of Tennessee, William Carroll / Jno [i.e., John] Ross ... [et al.]

mods.abstract: This is a letter from a delegation of Cherokee leaders, including John Ross, William Hicks, George Lowrey, and Major Ridge, to William Carroll, Governor of Tennessee (1821-1827,1829-1835), dated August 29, 1829. The Cherokees express their unwillingness to convene a meeting with commissioners for the purpose of hearing proposals regarding removal to a territory west of the Mississippi River. They indicate that they have already informed the President and the Governor that they do not intend to sell more land now or in the future and convening a meeting for that purpose would be pointless.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1825 Oct. 26

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Wednesday October 26, 1825 session of court, during which several cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 Apr. 26, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Benj[amin] Hawkins / J[ohn] S[evier]

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) to Benjamin Hawkins, agent and superintendent to the Creek Nation, dated April 26, 1797. Sevier wrote the letter on behalf of a woman by the name of Lillean Williams, who was taken prisoner by Creeks several years ago. While under Creek supervision, Williams had given birth to a daughter, and since the girl was born in the Creek Nation, she was not released with her mother. Sevier requested that Hawkins make enquiries regarding the whereabouts and possible release of the girl, who was then eight years old.

titleInfo.title: [Legal] 1802 September, State of Tennessee [to] Sheriff of Cocke County / [witnessed by Francis A. Ramsey]

mods.abstract: This is a court order to the sheriff of Cocke County. The sheriff is ordered to bring George H. Hynds to Knoxville. It is witnessed by Francis A. Ramsey.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Dec. 8, Grenada [to] E. H. Porter, Memphis, Tennessee / H. A. Robinson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 8, 1838 to E. H. Porter of Memphis, Tennessee from H. A. Robinson regarding business that Robinson is attending to for Porter.

titleInfo.title: [Murder indictment for Jacob Gardenhire] 1795 Aug., Washington District Superior Court of Law / W[illia]m Cocke

mods.abstract: This document is the murder indictment of Jacob Gardenhire passed in the August 1795 term by the Washington District Superior Court of Law. The trial was in regards to the murder of Joseph Hackley in Greene County on May 2, 1791. The jurors declared that Gardenhire had indeed killed Hackley with the willful intent to murder. The indictment further explained the nature of the crime and Hackley's death. It was signed by attorney William Cocke, and further instructions on the back of the indictment recommended that Gardenhire be taken into custody immediately.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1828 Jun. 9 Clinton [Tennessee], [to] Major John Phillips / William Stephen

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written from William Stephen to Major John Phillips on June 9, 1828. In the letter, Stephen discusses his ability to make Whiskey from extra corn he has and will acquire.

titleInfo.title: [Petition to abolish slavery] Tennessee, General Assembly

mods.abstract: This document is an undated petition to abolish slavery in the State of Tennessee and is signed by seventy five people.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1799 Feb. 12, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] Richard Harrison, Philadelphia, Penn. / David Henley

mods.abstract: This document is a brief letter dated February 12, 1799 from David Henley to Richard Harrison. The subject of the letter is furnishings for the Indian and Quarter Masters Departments.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1824 May 22, Cherokee Agency [to] Charles R. Hicks / Joseph McMinn

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Joseph McMinn, U.S. agent to the Cherokee Indians at the Cherokee Agency in Tennessee, to Cherokee leader Charles R. Hicks, dated May 22, 1824. McMinn reports to Hicks on the attempts to prevent intruders from trespassing on Cherokee land and refers to the efforts of Colonel Archibald R. Turk to remove the outlaws.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 Jun. 5 [to] Maj[or] A[ndrew] J[ackson] Donelson, Washington City / Stockly Donelson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated June 5, 1836, to Andrew Jackson Donelson, nephew and personal secretary to President Andrew Jackson, from his brother-in-law Stockly Donelson. Stockly writes about a recent horse race that his horse, which he named Martin Van Buren, won. He also provides an update on the condition of Andrew's home, which is in the process of being built.

titleInfo.title: 1845 Jun. 23, Hendersonville [Tennessee] [to] A[ndrew] J[ackson] Donelson, N[ew] Orleans, L[ouisian]a / Dan[ie]l S. Donelson

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 23, 1845. It is to Andrew Jackson Donelson in the care of Major Thomas B. Eastland, from his brother Daniel S. Donelson. Andrew is returning from Texas where he has been conducting annexation negotiations. Daniel is considering a trip to Washington D.C. in relation to some land that he wants near the Rio Grande. He hopes to meet William Marcy, President Polk's Secretary of War. Daniel writes to Andrew that he wishes that Andrew could have made it to General Andrew Jackson's deathbed. Daniel expresses regret that General Houston did not make it either, until right after Jackson had died.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Nov. 5

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Friday November 5, 1824 session of the court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1806 Dec. 23, Mount Ebenezer [to] Francis A. Ramsey, near Knoxville, Knox County, Tennessee / M[c]K[nitt] Ramsey

mods.abstract: This is a letter to Francis A. Ramsey from his son McKnitt Ramsey, dated December 23, 1806. McKnitt is staying with his aunt and uncle. He writes that he could not be more content if he was at the family home, Swan Pond. McKnitt requests that his father send him a dictionary soon.

name.namePart: Ramsey, John McKnitt A. (John McKnitt Alexander), -1808

titleInfo.title: 1815 Feb. 21, Alabama Bluff [to] James Winchester, Mobile, Alabama / George Fisher

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Colonel George Fisher to Brigadier General James Winchester, dated February 21, 1815. Fisher is reporting about attacks from the Native Americans that are allied with England. He asks that some men in the army from this settlement be allowed to return in order to protect their home from these attacks.

titleInfo.title: 1796 Oct. 29, Knox[ville, Tennessee, to] John Chisholm / D[avid] Henley

mods.abstract: This is a letter to John Chisholm from David Henley, dated October 29, 1796. Henley, an agent for the War Department, is giving instructions on the transportation of several native peoples to Philadelphia. The natives are members of the Cherokee, Choctaw, Creek, and Chickasaw Nations. The purpose of the trip may be to gain U. S. citizenship for them. Chisholm is instructed to take great care with them, keep them fed and healthy, and to limit their drinking.

subject.topic: Indians of North America -- Government policy

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of a reconstructed barracks at Fort Southwest Point, Kingston, Tennessee, taken ca. 1980s] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl] : a machine-readable transcription

mods.abstract: This photograph is of a reconstructed barracks at Fort Southwest Point, located near the city of Kingston, in Roane County, Tennessee. The barracks are made with hewn logs and are double penned structures with a fireplace in the middle of the building. The barracks were most likely used to house the enlisted men that occupied the fort. Fort Southwest Point was established in 1792 as a blockhouse post for the territorial militia troops that were protecting white settlers from Indian acts of hostility. By 1797, the militia was replaced by Federal troops whose goals were to maintain peace with the Indians and protect their rights on the frontier. During the years between 1801-1807, the fort was established as the headquarters for the Cherokee Agency. In 1974, archaeological crews from the University of Tennessee unearthed portions of six fort building foundations, the remains of a massive stone wall, and many fort-period artifacts. A 1984 excavation of the site by the Department of Conservation and the City of Kingston located the sites of a total of thirteen buildings. These buildings include an officer's barracks, four blockhouses, and several buildings that are believed to have been barracks. A complementary excavation in 1986 revealed the location of two more buildings, bringing the total to fifteen buildings. The excavation also produced a more detailed examination of the palisade and stone wall enclosures, and uncovered several historic and prehistoric features. Additional excavations were conducted at Fort Southwest Point in the 1900s yielded new information as to the fort's original layout and functions, as well as the life ways of the people who occupied the fort. Fort Southwest Point was given to the city of Kingston by the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) and is now used as a historical and recreational area.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Legal agreement] 1819 Dec. 13 [between Jesse Maxwell and John R. Dunn, et.al.]

mods.abstract: This document is a legal agreement between Jesse Maxwell and John R. Dunn, et.al., the trustees of a school. The agreement states that Maxwell has given an acre of his property to the school in order to build a brick schoolhouse. The agreement also states that the trustees paid Maxwell $1.00 for the use of a water spring and a pathway used by the teachers and students of the school to access the spring. It is stated that both Maxwell and the school are to have equal access to the spring.

titleInfo.title: 1795 Sep. 21, Tellico Blockhouse [Territory South of the Ohio River, to] [William] Blount / John McKee

mods.abstract: There are two letters. The first letter is from John McKee to Governor William Blount, dated September 21, 1795. McKee confirms sending letters to Cherokee Chiefs and Mr. Dinsmoor as requested by Governor Blount. The second letter is a statement of witness from Silas Dinsmoor and John McKee to Blount, dated October 21, 1795. They confirm that a rifle was given to Willioe in thanks for services rendered to the United States.

subject.topic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

titleInfo.title: 1792 Aug. 25 [to] Bond for Court Appearance of John Shelby & John Scott

mods.abstract: This is a legal document dated August 25, 1792; specifically, it is a bond for the Court appearance of John Shelby and John Scott.

titleInfo.title: 1825 Sep. 12, St. Louis, M[issouri] [to] Finis Ewing, Boonville, Cooper County, M[issouri] / Salmon Giddings

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Salmon Giddings to Finis Ewing, dated September 12, 1825. Giddings announces that the Presbyterian General Assembly has declared the Cumberland Presbyterians to be an independent body of Christians. He believes that Ewing will enjoy this news. William C. Carr is mentioned in regards to a local election. Giddings gives Carr some compliments, and believes that Ewing's brother knows him.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1823 Oct. 17

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from Friday October 17 and Saturday October 18, 1823. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1841 Nov. 3 [receipt for Robert Paine & Tho[ma]s Abernathy] / signed by David Shelton

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt signed by David Shelton on behalf of Robert Paine and Thomas Abernathy dated November 3, 1841. The receipt is from a turnpike company that is paying Paine and Abernathy $1219.75 in state bonds and $1719.50 in cash.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1843 Mar. 26, The United States to Tobacco Will

mods.abstract: This document is a claim against the United States by Tobacco Will, a Cherokee, who lost his horses during the removal. The United States rejected his claim.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Nov 17, Clover Dale, TN [to] Mrs. Ann Jane Bell, Cornplanter, PA / Sarah Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Sarah Bell to her sister Ann Jane Bell dated Nov. 17, 1838. Sarah writes of her recent illness, and the death of woman from consumption. She hopes that Jane is better from her illness. She regrets not being able to visit Jane and nurse her back to health every time she is sick. Sarah writes of the repairs and improvements that are being done to the house in preparation for winter. She writes of what they have been producing on the farm. She mentions the efforts to build a church in Charlotte and of a recent camp meeting. Her favorite preacher, Mr. Marshal will be the permanent preacher now, and this pleases her very much. She includes some briefs about the neighbors, and inquiries from their parents.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1823 Oct. 21. Newtown, to the council of the Cherokee Nation / Duncan G. Campbell [and] James Meriwether

mods.abstract: This document is a letter or talk delivered to the General Council of the Cherokee Nation, by U.S. treaty commissioners Duncan G. Campbell and James Meriwether, and dated October 21, 1823. The commissioners patronizingly explain the relationship between the United States government and the Cherokee people and attempt to rationalize the continued efforts to acquire Cherokee lands. They insist that it is unfair that the Cherokees possess more land than they can physically occupy and thereby attempt to justify the intrusions of overzealous frontier settlers.

titleInfo.title: [Legal patent] ca. 1830 [Patent application for a cotton gin] / author unknown

mods.abstract: This document is a patent application most probably for a cotton gin, dating around 1830. The application comes with both drawings of the cotton gin and a description of its parts and their functions.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Oct. 2, Warrenton, Virginia [to] D. Burford, Dixons Springs, Tennessee / J. Saunders

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated October 2, 1832 from J. Saunders in Warrenton, Virginia to David Burford in Dixons Spring, Tennessee. The subject of the letter is business, specifically slave labor speculation involving the purchase of slaves.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1838 Jan 1, Clover Dale, Ten[nessee] [to] Mrs. Ann Jane Bell, Oil Creek, Venango Co., PA / Margaret Bell

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Margaret Bell to her sister Ann Jane Bell dated January 1, 1838. Margaret and their mother are glad that Jane is happy in her new home, and they hope that the fresh country air will speed her recovery in a way that the city could not. She writes there are a great many weddings going on in Clover Dale. One of the grooms is the teacher at the new boy's school. There is also now a girl's school. They celebrated Christmas differently, with prayer meetings instead of parties. She writes about who has received religion and how they have changed as a result. She also reports the death of a Mrs. Gould in her post script.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1819 Jan. 20, Murfreesboro [to] Honorable Thomas Emmerson, Jonesboro, E[ast] Tenn[essee] / Joseph McMinn

mods.abstract: This document is a letter to the Honorable Thomas Emmerson from Joseph McMinn, dated January 20, 1819. In the letter, McMinn states that Governor Roane has died and that he must appoint his successor. McMinn asks Emmerson to accept this appointment and to respond before the next month's session.

This document is a legal summons dated May 29, 1794. The summons requires a man named Samuel Newel to appear in court to declare what possessions of a man named Sollomon Marks he has in his possession.

titleInfo.title: Territory of the United States South of the River Ohio
[Letter] 1848 Mar. 7, Memphis, Tennessee [to] Ed Porter, Bridgeport, Connecticut / B. N. Sawtell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Benjamin Sawtell of Memphis Tennessee to his nephew Ed Porter in Bridgeport Connecticut. Benjamin tells his nephew about the latest events at home, including several marriages, and available females.

titleInfo.title: [Legal document] 1805 Mar. 10, Washington District Court, Green County, Tennessee, Sparling Bowman vs George Alexander et. al

mods.abstract: This document is a summary of a legal complaint brought by the attorney of Sparling Bowman against three defendents in the matter of a disputed tract of land and a water obstruction near the Nolochuckey river in Green County .

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1796 Apr. 2, Knoxville [Tennessee, to] Warriors and Chiefs of the Cherokee Nation / John Sevier

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Governor John Sevier dated April 2, 1796. The letter is to the warriors and chiefs of the Cherokee Nation. Sevier writes to advise the Cherokee to maintain peaceful relations with the U.S. He writes that peace is in the Cherokee's best interest, and if there is war again, it will not be the fault of the U.S.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Nov. 28, Columbia Institute [to] Col[onel] Robert J. Chester, Jackson, Tennessee / Mary Jane Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated November 28, 1840, from Mary Jane Chester, student of the Female Institute in Columbia, Tennessee, to her parents Colonel Robert J. and Elizabeth Chester. Mary Jane requests that her mother send her clothing, food, and pleads with her family to write her more often.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Jan. 25, Nashville, Tennessee [to] General Assembly, Nashville, Tennessee / James K. Polk

mods.abstract: This is a letter to the General Assembly from Governor James K. Polk, dated January 25, 1840. Polk is writing to inform the Assembly of his nominations for Directors of the Bank of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1797 May 8 [to] Governor John Sevier / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 8, 1797 to Governor John Sevier from Andrew Jackson regarding letters written by the Governor calling Jackson "scurrilous" at a recent election for officers of the militia. Jackson demands an explanation as to why Sevier did not come to him first with his complaints.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1836 May 30, Abingdon [Virginia, to] T.S. Heiskell, Knoxville, Tennessee / W[illiam] G. Brownlow

mods.abstract: This is a letter to T.S. Heiskell from William G. Brownlow dated May 30, 1836. Brownlow writes that he is unable to fulfill a work contract on time for Heiskell. Brownlow also writes that he does not have the money he owes to Heiskell. He informs Heiskell of the actions he has taken to remedy the situation, and sends his regrets.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1840 Dec. 8, Columbia F[emale] Institute, [Tennessee] [to] Mrs. Rob[er]t J. Chester / M[ary] J[ane] Chester

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written by Mary Jane Chester to her mother, Elizabeth Chester, on December 8, 1840. In the letter, Mary Jane discusses events occurring at the Female Institute, her recent illnesses, and asks about events taking place at home.

titleInfo.title: [Certificate] 1829 Jan. 8 [Certificate of the Anniversary of the Battle of New Orleans]

mods.abstract: This document is a certificate, dated January 8, 1829, commemorating the Anniversary of the Battle of New Orleans. The Battle of New Orleans was fought between the United States and Great Britain on January 19, 1815.

subject.topic: New Orleans, Battle of, New Orleans, La., 1815

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1832 Jul. 20, Sampson Co [to] Sister / Jane Moore

mods.abstract: A letter dated July 20, 1832 written by Jane Moore to her sister; with an additional page written by Jeanet Butler and is addressed to her children. The letters express the status and condition of family members as well as a longing for the family to reunite soon.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1803 Oct. 11, Knoxville, Tennessee [to] John Sevier / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to John Sevier from Andrew Jackson on October 11, 1803. In the letter, Jackson is still challenging Sevier to a duel and is agreeable to meet him at the Cumberland Gap in Virginia. Jackson suggests that Sevier name the time for when they are to meet. This letter was refused delivery by Governor Sevier, saying that he wanted nothing to do with the letter, duel, or Jackson, and was therefore never read.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1825 Oct. 18-19

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the October 18 and 19, 1825 sessions of court, in which several cases were heard, mostly in regard to property compensation. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Legal, Letter] 1847 July 24 [to] W[illia], Bell, Deckson [i.e., Dickson] county, TN / Robert Anderson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Robert Anderson to William Bell, referring to their legal transactions. It is dated July 24, 1847. Anderson writes that he received one slave, John, in good health. He agrees to keep him because of his bad eye sight. He also agrees to allow Bell to return another slave named Jack, as long as he is still in good health.

titleInfo.title: Articles of agreement between the United States and the Cherokee Nation for opening a road from the state of Tennessee to the state of Georgia through the Cherokee Nation / [recorded by] Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is an agreement between the United States and the Cherokee Nation for opening a road from Tellico in Tennessee into Jackson County, Georgia in the direction of the University of Georgia in Athens, Georgia. The articles of the agreement enumerate the specific rights and powers reserved to the Cherokee Nation respecting tolls, ferries, and travel along the road. The agreement was set down by Return J. Meigs and bears the signature of a number of Cherokee leaders including Charles Hicks, Pathkiller, James Vann and Black Fox.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 March 27 [to] Alexander D. Coffee / Andrew Jackson Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 27, 1849 to Alexander D. Coffee from his brother Andrew Jackson Coffee. Andrew write his brother about various political appointments about to occur in Alabama, and that he was honored by the late President for his services in the Battle of Buena Vista.

titleInfo.title: Andrew Jackson Coffee Family Papers, MS27
[Financial report] 1842 Sep. 19, Memphis, Tennessee [to] James Jones, Nashville, Tennessee / Lewis C. Hezwurst

mods.abstract: This document is a financial report, dated September 19, 1842, from the Memphis state Hospital in Tennessee to the governor of the state, James Jones. The report contains information that the hospital's funds are insufficient for the term of the regular cession of the state legislature.

titleInfo.title: 1840 Dec. 16, Nashville [Tennessee] [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Tenn[essee] / Geo. Harris

mods.abstract: This is a letter from George Harris to Adam Fergusson, dated December 16, 1840. Harris thanks Fergusson for extending the circulation of the newspaper The Union. Harris plans to use the paper to promote Republican doctrine. He mentions some political opinions.

titleInfo.title: Articles of Agreement [1803 Oct. 20] between the United States and the Cherokee Nation

mods.abstract: This document is a legal agreement dated October 20, 1803, between the Cherokee Nation and the United States to build a turnpike through Tennessee to Georgia.

titleInfo.title: [Land Indenture] 1822 Jan. 25 [Between John M. Grier and Adam Simmons]

mods.abstract: This document is a land indenture between Adam Simmons and John M. Grier dated January 25, 1822. Simmons sold 71 acres of land in Wilson County, Tennessee to John Grier for $603.50. The document contains the receipt of sale for the land, as well as the county court's registration for the sale of the land to Grier in 1830.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Jun. 10, Rural Rest [to] James King, Tuskaloosa, Alabama / Henry King

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 10, 1839 from Henry King to his father James King. He tells his father that despite the cold weather, his cotton crops are tolerable, and the other crops are in fine order.

location.physicalLocation: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Middle Tennessee State University. Albert Gore Research Center

titleInfo.title: [Letter with sworn statement], 1834 Apr. 3, Aquohee Dist[rict] to the [Cherokee ?] Delegation / John Smith

mods.abstract: Letter with sworn statement dated April 3, 1834 from John Smith in the Aquohee District to the (Cherokee ?) Delegation, concerning a property dispute. A portion of the property that Smith claims as his own was awarded to a man named Hosea Morgan, a recent emigrant to the Arkansas who claims to be Catawba, and Smith believes that Morgan has no right to this property since he is not a citizen of the nation nor Cherokee. He has presented his case to Major Curry, but has received no satisfaction and is now petitioning the delegation.

titleInfo.title: [Executive action] 1844 Jan. 4, Nashville, Tennessee [to] Legislature re Capitol site / James Jones

mods.abstract: This is an executive action dated January 4, 1844 from Tennessee governor James Jones addressed to the state legislature regarding the Capitol building site. Specifically, the subject of the letter is a resolution of the General Assembly for the governor to occupy a house on the grounds. The governor chose to decline the offer to reside in the house.

titleInfo.title: 1844 Oct. 24, Nashville [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage, Ten[nessee] / C. Conner

mods.abstract: This is a letter from C. Conner to A. Fergusson, dated October 24, 1844. Conner writes about the upcoming Presidential election. He hopes for Polk's victory. He outlines some strategies that the Democrats should employ to assure Polk's win.

titleInfo.title: [Photograph of the posthole pattern of a Cherokee segmented domestic structure ca. mid-18th century at the town of Tomotley, taken in 1976] / [by Gerald F. Schroedl]

mods.abstract: This is a photograph of posthole patterns of a Cherokee segmented domestic structure at the town of Tomotley in the Lower Little Tennessee River Valley. This structure dating back to the mid-18th century, although rectangular, appears to be more substantial than the typical summer dwelling. These sturdier structures that were often partitioned were discovered in Tomotley and Mialoquo in groups at angles to one another. It is a pattern similar to site patterning among the Creeks and Lower Cherokees and may reflect the presence of refugees settling in the Overhill country. Excavations of Tomotley were conducted by the University of Tennessee in 1976 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, Gerald F. Schroedl.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter, dated July 23, 1847, from Benjamin Sawtell in Memphis to his niece Mary Porter in Connecticut. Sawtell describes a recent temperance celebration and discusses the latest news of Memphis temperance societies.
This is a brief letter from Tennessee governor William Carroll to Samuel Smith. In the letter he discusses matters as a search for a county surveyor, and the condition of convicts.

titleInfo.title: [Military order for the honorable discharge of William English Pillar] 1814 May 10, Fayettesville, [Tennessee] / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This document is a military order from Andrew Jackson stating that William English Pillar was honorably discharged on May 10, 1814. The order states that Pillar deserves the honorable discharge because he fought with Jackson against the Creek Indians and also because he completed service for the entire length of time for which he had originally enlisted.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1812 Feb. 24, Huntsville, Mississippi [to] James Winchester, Cragfont, Sumner County Tennessee/ John Read

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John Read in Huntsville, Mississippi to General James Winchester in Sumner County, Tennessee. In the letter, Read requests to be commissioned into the army for the coming war with Great Britain.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1823 Jun. 14, Nashville, [to] J. G. M. Ramsey, Knoxville / Andrew Jackson

mods.abstract: This is a letter written in 1823 by General Andrew Jackson to J. G. M. Ramsey. Jackson responds to Ramsey's letter regarding a political convention held in 1775 in Mecklenburg County, North Carolina.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1824 Nov. 3

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1824 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This is the excerpt from the November 3, 1824 session of court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1823 Mar. 10, Cairo, Tennessee [to] Almira Winchester, New Orleans, Louisiana / NBW

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated March 10, 1823 to Almina Winchester in New Orleans, Louisiana. The author of the letter is most likely a sister or brother who signs it with the abbreviations NBW. The content of the letter serves to update Winchester on the status and conditions of her family in Cairo, Tennessee while she has been away.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1848 Jan. 15 New Orleans, [to] Alex[ander D Coffee] / Andrew J[ackson] Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter written to Alexander D. Coffee from his brother, Andrew Jackson Coffee on January 15, 1848. In the letter, Andrew expresses his views on events occuring in the Mexican-American War, judges' appointments in Tennessee, the Tennessee River's overflowing and causing destruction, the lack of a good cotton market, and the birth of his new son, Andrew Jackson Coffee.

titleInfo.title: Andrew Jackson Coffee Family Papers 1833-1903 MS 27
[Letter] 1824 Apr. 19, Washington [to] Mr. John Ross / Sam Houston

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 19, 1824 written by Sam Houston, future governor of Tennessee, to John Ross, future chief of the Cherokee Nation. Houston writes in response to some questions posed by Ross in regards to John Spears, an interpreter for the Cherokee who served as a delegate on behalf of the Arkansas tribe of the Cherokee. There is apparently a controversy involving Lewis Ross over whether or not Spears was entitled to receive a plot of land.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1846 Apr. 14, Dresden, Tennessee [to] Adam Fergusson, Carthage, Ten[nessee] / M. D. Cardwell

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated April 14, 1846, to Adam Fergusson in Carthage, TN from M. D. Cardwell in Dresden, TN. Cardwell discusses his fondness for President Polk, and he mentions a cavalcade of Mormons on their way to settle in California. Cardwell states that he hopes to start a regular correspondence with Fergusson.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1817 Mar. 25, Augusta, Georgia [to] Colonel R.J. Meigs, Highwassee, Tennessee / William Wells

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated March 25. 1817 to Return J. Meigs from a William Wells regarding a business deal made with Meigs two years prior.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] 1807 Oct. 27, United States to Samuel Hall / Return J. Meigs

mods.abstract: This document is a receipt for payment of $50.00 to Samuel Hall for 50 bushels of corn furnished to the Cherokee Indians in 1806. Return J. Meigs, agent for the War Department in Tennessee made the payment on behalf of the United States.

This is a letter dated June 20, 1850 from E.A. Fitzgerald to her husband William Fitzgerald. She tells her husband that the fields and gardens are growing very well, and that some people have already begun to harvest.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1849 Mar. 19, Nashville, Tennessee [to] D. C[lint] Douglass Lebanon, Tennessee / Alfred William Douglass

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated March 19, 1849 from Alfred William Douglass to his cousin Clint. Douglass died on August 23, 1849 as the result of a bout with cholera, it was only five months after writing this letter. Douglass is writing from Nashville, Tennessee and tells his cousin of many lively and interesting happenings in that area.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 Aug. 23, Estillville, Va. [to] Joseph Meek, Nashville, Tn. C. Haynes

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from C. Haynes to Joseph Meek dated August 23, 1835. Haynes write of his plans to buy slaves from various people in surrounding counties of Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1841, Feb. 17 [to] James A Woods, Nashville, Tenn[essee] / John R. Branch

mods.abstract: This is a letter form John R. Branch to James A. Woods dated February 17, 1841. Branch apologizes for not having written back in a while. He writes how much he and his wife Josephine miss James. He also mentions his interest in a local trial.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1818 Nov. 19, Cherokee Agency, [to] Daniel Graham / Jos[eph] McMinn: a machine-readable transcription of an image

mods.abstract: This document was written by Governor Joseph McMinn (1815-1821) to Secretary of State Daniel Graham on November 19, 1818. Governor McMinn writes that he will soon have taken the land east of the Mississippi River from the Cherokee and that if they want compensation, they must relinquish their possessions and claims to the United States within a certain number of years. He adds that the Cherokee look up to him for guidance, and he has been witness to vast amounts of monies and supplies trading hands for the trip west.

titleInfo.title: [Receipt] ca. 1850 [to] W[illia]m Faris / L. D. Franklin

mods.abstract: This is a receipt for payment from Major L.D. Franklin to William Farris for professional medical services provided in 1850. Farris signs that the payment was received.

titleInfo.title: 1801 Dec. 14, Tennessee Ridge [to] James Winchester, Cragfont, Tennessee / Captain Butler

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Captain Butler to General James Winchester, dated December 14, 1801. Butler wants to order some flour for his troop. He also requests a rifle. Butler asks that his regards be sent to Colonel William Martin.

titleInfo.title: 1836 Nov. 5, Nashville [Tennessee] [to] Finis Ewing, Lexington, M[issouri] / Ja[me]s Smith

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated March 5, 1836. It is to Rev. Finis Ewing from Rev. James Smith. Smith writes that the Presbyterian camp meetings in Tennessee are going well. He mentions some conversions. Smith explains that he has not written to Ewing in a while because he has been very busy with work. Smith asks Ewing to contact Rev. Lowry for him. He has not heard from him in a while and is worried. Smith writes that Ewing's letters are highly prized by Smith and his congregation. He publishes them in the Revivalist, a periodical of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1835 May 18, Kingston, Roane C[oun]ty, E[ast] Tenn[essee] [to] Charles F Welcker / Henry J Welcker

mods.abstract: The following document is a letter dated May 18, 1835, written to Charles F. Welcker from his brother Henry J. Welcker in Kingston, TN. Henry updates his brother on the affairs of the family, including the current status of their father's property and their brothers' whereabouts and circumstances.

titleInfo.title: 1804 Aug 20, Travellers West [to] Col. John Overton, Knoxville [TN] / Sam[ue]l Overton

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated Aug. 20, 1804, from Samuel Overton to his brother Col. John Overton. Samuel has been sick with Rheumatism like symptoms. He also writes about planting

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Oct. 6 [Tennessee, to William] Carroll / David Graham

mods.abstract: This is a letter from David Graham to Governor William Carroll, dated October 6, 1825. Graham is sending information to Carroll about the surveying of land for schools.

titleInfo.title: [Appointment] 1812 Nov. 21, Nashville, Tennessee [to] William Lauderdale appointment as 1st Lt., Infantry / Willie Blount

mods.abstract: This document is notice of formal appointment of William Lauderdale as First Lieutenant in a volunteer company of infantry, commanded by Captain William L. Alexander.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Jun. 15, Dresden, Tennessee [to] E.A. Fitgerald, Paris, Tennessee / William Fitzgerald

mods.abstract: This is a letter dated June 15, 1839 from William Fitzgerald in Washington, D.C. to his wife E.A. Fitzgerald in Dresden, Tennessee. In the letter, Fitzgerald tells his wife of the possibility of representing a bank as its attorney, and the benefits of conducting the banks business. He also writes on his feelings on a runaway slave.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1833 Feb. 12, Warrenton, Virginia [to] D. Burford / J. Saunders

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 12, 1833 from J. Saunders in Warrenton, Virginia to David Burford. The subject of the letter is slave trade and demand.

titleInfo.title: 1795 Nov. 17, Nashville [Territory South of the Ohio River, to] David Henley, Knoxville [Territory South of the Ohio River] / Sampson Williams

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Sampson Williams to David Henley, dated November 17, 1795. Williams is writing to send Henley documents of confirmation from General Winchester. Williams is requesting money from Henley, possibly to pay the salaries of militiamen, Henley is an agent for the War Department.

subject.topic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

titleInfo.title: [Certificate of Stock] 1850 July 1 [in the] Adelphi Theatre Company

mods.abstract: This document is a certificate for four shares of stock, dated July 1, 1850, in the Adelphi Theatre Company in Nashville, Tennessee, and was purchased by Frederic Sloan. The certificate was donated to the Tennessee Historical Society in 1969 by Mr. Sloan's great niece, Jeannette Sloan.

titleInfo.title: [Depositions of John Rogers and James Cary] 1844 Jul. 3, District of Columbia

mods.abstract: This document is a deposition given by John Rogers and James Cary, of the Cherokee Nation West. The deposition concerns land taken by the United States under the Treaty of 1817 belonging to The Pathkiller, also a member of the Cherokee Nation.

titleInfo.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1826 Oct. 31

mods.abstract: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Tuesday October 31, 1826 session of court. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

titleInfo.title: [Drawing of Tellico Blockhouse, American Federal period trading and military post from 1794-1807, Lower Little Tennessee River]

mods.abstract: This is a drawing of the Tellico Blockhouse. The Tellico Blockhouse was constructed in 1794-95 adjacent to the earlier Fort Loudoun at the confluence of the Tellico and Little Tennessee Rivers in what is presently Monroe County as a federal outpost. In 1805 federal officials and Overhill Cherokees negotiated a treaty at the Tellico Blockhouse which moved the federal agency south to the mouth of the Hiawassee. By 1807 the federal government abandoned Tellico and moved the rest of its agency to the Hiawassee River post, the new center of the Overhill Cherokee settlement. Excavations of the Tellico Blockhouse were conducted by the University of Tennessee from 1972-1974 in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. Excavations of the Blockhouse were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, Richard R. Polhemus.

titleInfo.title: Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture

titleInfo.title: [Testimony] 1843 Nov. 3 [of] David Taylor and Gideon Morgan

mods.abstract: This document is a sworn statement dated November 3, 1843 given by David Taylor and Gideon Morgan regarding the marriage of Rebecca Henson, of Cherokee descent and Preston Starritt. See also pa0252, pa0254, and pa0255.

titleInfo.title: 1812 Sep. 1, Cantonment [Tennessee, to] James Winchester, Lexington, Kentucky / W[illia]m Anderson

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Colonel William Anderson to Brigadier General James Winchester, dated September 1, 1812. Anderson reports on the amount of soldiers they have. He writes about an incompetent doctor in his regiment. Anderson mentions many fellow officers. He mentions how poor his recent recruits are.

titleInfo.title: [Claim] 1816 Jul. 17, The United States to Nar,che,ah

mods.abstract: This document is a spoliation claim from one Nar,che,ah, a Cherokee Indian who lost a hog and a cow to the United States Army in 1814.

titleInfo.title: 1847 Aug. 2, Russellville [to] Joseph D. Hamilton, Nashville, Tennessee / John W. Mills

mods.abstract: This is a letter from John W. Mills to Joseph D. Hamilton, dated August 2, 1847. Mills apologizes for misplacing a letter to Hamilton that contained some money. He also mentions the upcoming election and that he hopes the Whigs will beat the Democrats.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1817 May 19, Highwassee [to] Col[onel] R[eturn] J. Meigs, Highwassee / Russell Goodrich

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated May 19, 1817 and addressed to Return J. Meigs, agent to the Cherokee Nation, from Russell Goodrich. Goodrich writes to inform Meigs about work being done on a turnpike road between Georgia and Tennessee that will significantly decrease travel time between the two states. Goodrich also inquires if some land could be taken from the Cherokee Nation and given as a favor to a woman.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1817 Aug. 7, Chickasaw Agency [to] James Winchester, Cairo, Tennessee / G.L. (?) Sherburne

mods.abstract: This is a letter from G.L. Sherburne, agent for the Chickasaw Nation of Indians, dated August 7, 1817. The purpose of the letter concerns the surveying and laying off a town at the Chickasaw Bluffs.

titleInfo.title: [Letter to] the Chiefs of the Creek Nation / the inhabitants residing on the Shawnee River

mods.abstract: The following document is an undated letter addressed to the chiefs of the Creek Nation, which appears to have been written on behalf of the white settlers living along the Shawnee River. In this letter, the settlers appear to have been making an offer of peace with the Creeks. The letter states that the Chickasaws, who were in good relations with the whites, had informed the settlers that the majority of the Creek people wished to be at peace with them. However, the letter refers to several instances that were looked at as being acts of aggression by the Creeks, including the theft of some horses and the loss of white lives. The letter also mentions an instance in which the settlers stumbled upon a deserted Indian camp and retained the horses and other articles from that camp, securing them until it was known to what tribe they belonged. The settlers contend they moved to the West with the intention of being at peace with all the tribes there, nor, they state, do they wish to encroach upon Indian lands or molest Indian peoples.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1839 Dec. 25 [to] Mr. Alexander D. Coffee, Nashville, Tennessee / Andrew Jackson Coffee

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 25, 1839 to Alexander Coffee from his brother Andrew Jackson Coffee who writes of Christmas, their family, and a recent surveying trip.

titleInfo.title: Andrew Jackson Coffee Family Papers 1833-1903, MS27
[Letter] 1827 Nov. 22 [to] Sam Houston, Nashville, Tennessee / Sam Brown

mods.abstract: This document is a letter from Sam Brown dated November 22, 1827 to Governor Sam Houston of Tennessee. Brown requests that Governor Houston examine a proposal for establishing a public library in Tennessee.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1825 Feb. 11, Washington City [to] James L. Totton, Trenton TN / David Crockett

mods.abstract: This document is a letter dated February 11, 1825, from David Crockett in Washington D.C. to James L. Totton in Trenton, Tennessee. In the letter, Crockett discussed the rising political status of General Andrew Jackson, who he predicted would soon "receive the rewards of his merit." Crockett also spoke of his proposal for the construction of a new mail route, which would be addressed in a bill at the end of that session of Congress.

titleInfo.title: [Letter] 1845 Dec. 18, Nashville [Tennessee] [to] A. Fergusson, Carthage [Tennessee] / Sam Golluday

mods.abstract: This is a letter from Sam Golluday to Adam Fergusson, dated December 18, 1845. Golluday has some coffee that Fergusson purchased. He also writes that he will soon be back in business, and looks forward to having Fergusson as a client.

This document is a writ addressed to the Sheriff of Washington County, signed by John Sevier, and dated November 4, 1793. The sheriff is instructed to turn over all goods and land belonging to Richard Minton who has been ordered to pay John Cotteral the sum of 21 pounds , 18 shillings, and 11 pence.

subject.topic: Territory of the United States, South of the River Ohio

mods.abstract: This document is a telegraph dated August 3, 1849 from E. Dillahunty to the governor of Tennessee, Neill S. Brown. The purpose of the telegraph is to advise of illness, and to provide instructions for the appointment of a special judge to attend to Giles Circuit Court.
